00795|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0274.wav|||that there is no place in the metropolis where more crimes are projected or where stolen property is more secreted than in Newgate.|
00796|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0275.wav|||These malpractices were fostered by the absence of all supervision and the generally unbroken idleness.|
00797|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0276.wav|||Although attempted partially at Bridewell, and more systematically at the new Millbank penitentiary,|
00798|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0277.wav|||but just open (eighteen sixteen), the regular employment of prisoners had never yet been accepted as a principle in the metropolitan prisons.|
00799|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0278.wav|||Insuperable difficulties were still supposed to stand in the way of any general employment of prisoners at their trades.|
00800|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0279.wav|||There was fear as to the unrestricted use of tools,|
00801|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0280.wav|||limits of space, the interference of the ill-disposed, who would neither work nor let others do so,|
00802|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0281.wav|||and the danger of losing material, raw or manufactured.|
00803|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0282.wav|||Many years were to elapse before these objections should be fairly met and universally overcome.|
00804|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0283.wav|||It was not strange, therefore, that the inmates of Newgate should turn their unoccupied brains and idle hands to all manner of mischief;|
00805|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0284.wav|||that when they were not carousing, plotting, or scheming,|
00806|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0285.wav|||they should gamble with dice or cards, and play at bumble puppy or some other disreputable game of chance.|
00807|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0286.wav|||The report of the Committee of the House of Commons painted so black a picture of Newgate as then conducted, that the Corporation were roused in very shame|
00808|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0287.wav|||to undertake some kind of reform.|
00809|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0288.wav|||The above-mentioned report was ordered to be printed upon the ninth May.|
00810|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0289.wav|||Upon the twenty-ninth July the same year,|
00811|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0290.wav|||the court of aldermen appointed a committee of its own body, assisted by the town clerk, Mr. Dance, city surveyor, son to the architect of Newgate,|
00812|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0291.wav|||and Mr. Addison, keeper of Newgate, to make a visitation of the jails supposed to be the best managed, including those of Petworth and Gloucester.|
00813|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0292.wav|||This committee was to compare allowances, examine rules, and certify as to the condition of prisoners;|
00814|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0293.wav|||also to make such proposals as might appear salutary, and calculated to improve Newgate and the rest of the city jails.|
00815|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0294.wav|||This committee made its report in September the following year, and an excellent report it is, so far as its recommendations are concerned.|
00816|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0295.wav|||The committee seems to have fully realized, even at this early date (eighteen fifteen),|
00817|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0296.wav|||many of the indispensable conditions of a model prison according to modern ideas.|
00818|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0297.wav|||It admitted the paramount necessity|
00819|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0298.wav|||for giving every prisoner a sleeping cell to himself, an amount of enlightenment which is hardly general among European nations at this|
00820|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0299.wav|||the latter end of the nineteenth century, several of which still fall far short of our English ideal,|
00821|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0300.wav|||that all prisoners should always be in separate cells by night, and those of short sentences by day.|
00822|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0301.wav|||It recommended day cells or rooms for regular labor, which should be compulsory upon all transports and prisoners sentenced to hard labor,|
00823|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0302.wav|||the work being constant and suitable, with certain hours of relaxation and for food and exercise.|
00824|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0303.wav|||The personal cleanliness of all prisoners was to be insisted upon; they should be made to wash at least once a day,|
00825|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0304.wav|||with the penalty of forfeiting the day's allowance of food, an increase of which the committee had recommended.|
00826|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0305.wav|||The provision of more baths was also suggested, and the daily sweeping out of the prison.|
00827|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0306.wav|||The clothes of prisoners arriving dirty, or in rags, should be fumigated before worn in the jail,|
00828|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0307.wav|||but as yet no suggestion was made to provide prison uniform.|
00829|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0308.wav|||A laundry should be established, and a matron appointed on the female side, where all the prisoners' washing could be performed.|
00830|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0309.wav|||Proper hours for locking and unlocking prisoners should be insisted upon;|
00831|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0310.wav|||a bell should give notice thereof, and of meal-hours, working-hours, or of escapes.|
00832|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0311.wav|||The committee took upon itself to lay down stringent rules for the discipline of the prison.|
00833|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0312.wav|||The jailer should be required to visit every part and see every prisoner daily; the chaplain should perform service, visit the sick,|
00834|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0313.wav|||instruct the prisoners, quote, give spiritual advice and administer religious consolation, end quote. to all who might need them;|
00835|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0314.wav|||the surgeon should see all prisoners, whether ill or well, once a week, and take general charge of the infirmaries.|
00836|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0315.wav|||All three, governor, chaplain, and surgeon, should keep journals, which should be inspected periodically by the visiting magistrates.|
00837|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0316.wav|||It should be peremptorily forbidden to the keeper or any officer to make a pecuniary profit out of the supplies of food, fuel, or other necessaries.|
00838|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0317.wav|||No prisoner should be allowed to obtain superior accommodation on the payment of any fees. Fees indeed should be generally abolished, garnish also.|
00839|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0318.wav|||No prisoners should in future be ironed, except in cases of misconduct,|
00840|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0319.wav|||provided only that their security was not jeopardized, and dependent upon the enforcement of another new rule,|
00841|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0320.wav|||which recommended restrictions upon the number of visitors admitted.|
00842|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0321.wav|||No wine or beer should be in future admitted into or sold in the jail,|
00843|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0322.wav|||except for the use of the debtors, or as medical comforts for the infirmary.|
00844|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0323.wav|||Drunkenness, if it ever occurred, should be visited with severe punishment;|
00845|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0324.wav|||gaming of all sorts should be peremptorily forbidden under heavy pains and penalties.|
00846|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0325.wav|||The feelings of the condemned prisoners should no longer be outraged by their exposure in the chapel, and the chapel should be rearranged,|
00847|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0326.wav|||so that the various classes might be seated separately, and so as not to see each other.|
00848|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0327.wav|||It will hardly be denied that these proposals went to the root of the matter.|
00849|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0328.wav|||Had they been accepted in their entirety, little fault could in future have been found with the managers of Newgate.|
00850|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0329.wav|||In common justice to them, it must be admitted that immediate effect was given to all that could be easily carried out.|
00851|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0330.wav|||The state side ceased to exist, and the female prisoners thus regained the space of which their quadrangle had been robbed.|
00852|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0331.wav|||The privileges of the master's side also disappeared; fees were nominally abolished, and garnish was scotched, although not yet killed outright.|
00853|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0332.wav|||A certain number of bedsteads were provided, and there was a slight increase in the ration of bread.|
00854|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0333.wav|||But here the recommendations touched at once upon the delicate subject of expense, and it is clear that the committee hesitated on this score.|
00855|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0334.wav|||It made this too the excuse for begging the most important issue of the whole question.|
00856|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0335.wav|||The committee did not deny the superior advantages offered by such prisons as Gloucester and Petworth,|
00857|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0336.wav|||but it at once deprecated the idea that the city could follow the laudable example thus set in the provinces. Quote,|
00858|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0337.wav|||Were a metropolitan prison erected on the same lines, with all the space not only for air and exercise, but for day rooms and sleeping cells|
00859|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0338.wav|||End quote. it would cover some thirty acres, and cost a great deal more than the city, with the example of Whitecross Street prison before it,|
00860|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0339.wav|||could possibly afford.|
00861|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0340.wav|||The committee does not seem to have yet understood that Newgate could be only and properly replaced|
00862|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0341.wav|||by a new jail built on the outskirts, as Holloway eventually was, and permitted itself to be altogether countered|
00863|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0342.wav|||and checked in its efforts towards reform by the prohibitory costliness of the land about Newgate.|
00864|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0343.wav|||With the seeming impossibility of extending the limits of the prison as it then stood,|
00865|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0344.wav|||all chances of classification and separation vanished, and the greatest evils remained untouched.|
00866|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0345.wav|||All the committee could do in this respect was to throw the responsibility on others.|
00867|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0346.wav|||It pointed out that the Government was to blame for the overcrowding, and might diminish it if it chose.|
00868|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0347.wav|||It was very desirable that there should be a more speedy removal of transports from Newgate to the ships.|
00869|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0348.wav|||Again, there was the new Millbank penitentiary now ready for occupation.|
00870|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ003-0349.wav|||Why not relieve Newgate by drawing more largely upon the superior accommodation which Millbank offered?|
00871|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0001.wav|||The Chronicles of Newgate, Volume two. By Arthur Griffiths. Section seven: The beginnings of prison reform.|
00872|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0002.wav|||While Mrs. Fry was diligently engaged upon her self-imposed task in Newgate,|
00873|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0003.wav|||other earnest people, inspired doubtless by her noble example, were stirred up to activity in the same great work.|
00874|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0004.wav|||It began to be understood that prison reform could only be compassed by continuous and combined effort.|
00875|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0005.wav|||The pleadings, however eloquent, of a single individual were unable to more than partially remedy the widespread and colossal evils of British prisons.|
00876|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0006.wav|||Howard's energy and devotion were rewarded by lively sympathy, but the desire to improve which followed his exposures was but short-lived.|
00877|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0007.wav|||It was so powerless against the persistent neglect of those intrusted with prison management, that, five-and-twenty years later,|
00878|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0008.wav|||Mr. Neild, a second Howard,|
00879|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0009.wav|||as indefatigable and self-sacrificing, found by personal visitation that the condition of jails throughout the kingdom was,|
00880|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0010.wav|||with a few bright exceptions, still deplorable and disgraceful.|
00881|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0011.wav|||Mr. Neild was compelled to admit in eighteen twelve that "the great reformation produced by Howard|
00882|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0012.wav|||was in several places merely temporary:|
00883|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0013.wav|||some prisons that had been ameliorated under the persuasive influence of his kind advice were relapsing into their former horrid state of privation,|
00884|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0014.wav|||filthiness, severity, or neglect; many new dungeons had aggravated the evils against which his sagacity could not but remonstrate;|
00885|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0015.wav|||the motives for a transient amendment were becoming paralyzed, and the effect had ceased with the cause."|
00886|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0016.wav|||I have shown in a previous chapter what Newgate was at this period, despite a vast expenditure and boasted efforts to introduce reforms.|
00887|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0017.wav|||Some of the county jails, and one or two borough jails, had been rebuilt,|
00888|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0018.wav|||generally through the personal activity of influential and benevolent local magnates, but the true principles of prison construction|
00889|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0019.wav|||were as yet but imperfectly understood, and such portions of the "improved" jails of that period as were still extant a few years back,|
00890|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0020.wav|||contrast ludicrously with the prison architecture based upon a century's experience of our own age.|
00891|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0021.wav|||The neglect of prison reform in those days was not to be visited upon the legislature.|
00892|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0022.wav|||The executive, although harassed by internal commotion and foreign war, was not entirely callous to the crying need for amelioration in jails.|
00893|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0023.wav|||Measures remedial, although at best partial and incomplete, were introduced from time to time.|
00894|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0024.wav|||Thus in eighteen thirteen the exaction of jail fees had been forbidden by law,|
00895|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0025.wav|||and two other acts more peremptory and precise followed on the same subject in succeeding years.|
00896|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0026.wav|||In eighteen fourteen a bill was brought in to insist upon the appointment of chaplains in jails, and when this had passed into law,|
00897|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0027.wav|||it was subsequently amplified, and the rates of salaries fixed.|
00898|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0028.wav|||Various acts were also passed to consolidate and amend previous jail acts.|
00899|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0029.wav|||The erection of new prison buildings was made imperative under certain conditions and following certain rules|
00900|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0030.wav|||the principle of classification was freshly enunciated; prison regulations were framed for general observance.|
00901|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0031.wav|||But the effect of this legislation was rather weakened by the remoteness of the pressure exercised.|
00902|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0032.wav|||The onus of improvement lay upon the magistracy, the local authorities administering local funds,|
00903|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0033.wav|||and they were not threatened with any particular penalties if they evaded or ignored the new acts.|
00904|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0034.wav|||Moreover, the laws applied more particularly to county jurisdictions.|
00905|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0035.wav|||The borough jails, those in fact under corporate management, were not included in the new measures;|
00906|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0036.wav|||it was hoped that their rulers would hire accommodation in the county prisons, and that the inferior establishments would in course of time disappear.|
00907|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0037.wav|||Yet the borough jails were destined to survive many years, and to exhibit for a long time to come all the worst features of jail mismanagement.|
00908|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0038.wav|||It was in eighteen seventeen that a small band of philanthropists resolved to form themselves into an association for the improvement of prison discipline.|
00909|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0039.wav|||They were hopeless of any general reform by the action of the executive alone.|
00910|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0040.wav|||They felt that private enterprise might|
00911|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0041.wav|||with advantage step in, and by the collection and diffusion of information, and the reiteration of sound advice, greatly assist the good work.|
00912|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0042.wav|||The association was organized under the most promising auspices.|
00913|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0043.wav|||A king's son, the Duke of Gloucester, was the patron; among the vice-presidents were many great peers of the realm|
00914|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0044.wav|||several bishops, and a number of members of the House of Commons, including Mr. Manners Sutton,|
00915|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0045.wav|||Mr. Sturges Bourne, Sir James Mackintosh, Sir James Scarlett, and William Wilberforce.|
00916|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0046.wav|||An active committee was appointed, comprising many names already well known, some of them destined to become famous in the annals of philanthropy.|
00917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0047.wav|||One of the moving spirits was the Honorable H. G. Bennet, M.P., whose vigorous protests against the lamentable condition of Newgate have already been recorded.|
00918|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0048.wav|||Mrs. Fry's brother, Mr. Samuel Hoare, Junior, was chairman of the committee, on which also served many noted members of the Society of Friends|
00919|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0049.wav|||Mr. Gurney, Mr. Fry, Messrs. Forster, and Mr. T. F. Buxton, the coadjutor of Wilberforce in the great anti-slavery struggle.|
00920|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0050.wav|||Mr. Buxton had already been associated with Mrs. Fry in the Newgate visitation, and his attention had thus been drawn to the neglected state of English prisons.|
00921|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0051.wav|||When in Belgium he had examined with great satisfaction the admirable management of the great "Maison de Force" at Ghent,|
00922|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0052.wav|||which Howard had eulogized some forty years before.|
00923|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0054.wav|||In order to give greater value to the pamphlet,|
00924|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0055.wav|||he personally visited several English jails, and pointed his observations by drawing forcible contrasts between the good and bad.|
00925|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0056.wav|||Mr. Buxton's small work on prison discipline gave a new aspect to the question he had so much at heart.|
00926|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0057.wav|||For the first time the doctrine was enunciated that prisoners had rights of their own.|
00927|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0058.wav|||The untried, and in the eyes of the law still innocent, could claim pure air, wholesome and sufficient food, and opportunities for exercise.|
00928|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0059.wav|||They had a right, Mr. Buxton affirmed, to be employed in their own crafts, provided it could be safely followed in prison.|
00929|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0060.wav|||You have no right, he says, addressing the authorities, "to subject a prisoner to suffering from cold,|
00930|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0061.wav|||by want of bed-clothing by night or firing by day|
00931|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0062.wav|||and the reason is plain: you have taken him from his home, and have deprived him of the means of providing himself with the necessaries or comforts of life,|
00932|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0063.wav|||and therefore you are bound to furnish him with moderate indeed but suitable accommodation."|
00933|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0064.wav|||You have for the same reason, he goes on, "no right to ruin his habits by compelling him to be idle,|
00934|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0065.wav|||his morals by compelling him to mix with a promiscuous assemblage of hardened and convicted criminals,|
00935|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0066.wav|||or his health by forcing him at night into a damp, unventilated cell, with such crowds of companions as very speedily render the air foul and putrid;|
00936|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0067.wav|||or to make him sleep in close contact with the victims of contagious and loathsome disease,|
00937|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0068.wav|||or amidst the noxious effluvia of dirt and corruption.|
00938|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0069.wav|||In short, attention to his feelings, mental and bodily, a supply of every necessary, abstraction from evil society,|
00939|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0070.wav|||the conservation of his health and industrious habits, are the clear, evident, undeniable rights of an unconvicted prisoner."|
00940|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0071.wav|||Nor even when found guilty and his liberty forfeited did his privileges cease. The law appointed a suitable punishment for the offense;|
00941|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0072.wav|||it was for those charged with the administration of the law to guard carefully against any aggravation of that punishment,|
00942|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0073.wav|||to see that "no circumstances of severity are found in his treatment which are not found in his sentence."|
00943|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0074.wav|||No judge ever condemned a man to be half-perished with cold by day, or half-suffocated with heat by night.|
00944|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0075.wav|||Who ever heard of a criminal being sentenced to catch the rheumatism or the typhus fever?|
00945|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0076.wav|||nan|
00946|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0077.wav|||nor has he a right to poison or starve his fellow-creatures."|
00947|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0078.wav|||The convicted delinquent has his rights, said Mr. Buxton authoritatively.|
00948|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0079.wav|||nan|
00949|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0080.wav|||because they are not specified in his sentence; he is therefore entitled to a wholesome atmosphere,|
00950|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0081.wav|||decent clothing and bedding, and a diet sufficient to support him."|
00951|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0082.wav|||These somewhat novel but undoubtedly indisputable propositions were backed up, not by sound arguments only, but by the letter of the law.|
00952|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0083.wav|||As Mr. Buxton pointed out, many old acts of parliament designed to protect the prisoner were still in full force.|
00953|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0084.wav|||Some might be in abeyance, but they had never been repealed, and some were quite freshly imported upon the Statute Book.|
00954|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0085.wav|||As far back as the reign of Charles the second, a law was passed declaring that sufficient provision should be made for the relief and setting on work|
00955|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0086.wav|||of "poor and needy prisoners committed to the common jail for felony and other misdemeanors, who many times perish before their trial;|
00956|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0087.wav|||and the poor there living idle and unemployed become debauched, and come forth instructed in the practice of thievery and lewdness."|
00957|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0088.wav|||As a remedy, justices of the peace were empowered to provide materials for the setting of poor prisoners to work,|
00958|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0089.wav|||and to pay overseers or instructors out of the county rates.|
00959|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0090.wav|||Again, the twenty-two Charles the second c twenty ordered the jailer to keep felons and debtors "separate and apart from one another,|
00960|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0091.wav|||in distinct rooms, on pain of forfeiting his office and treble damages to the party aggrieved."|
00961|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0092.wav|||A much later act, the fourteen George the third c. fifty-nine (seventeen seventy-four),|
00962|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0093.wav|||which was contemporaneous with Howard's first journeys, laid down precise rules as regards cleanliness, and the proper supply of space and air.|
00963|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0094.wav|||This act set forth that "whereas the malignant fever commonly called the jail distemper|
00964|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0095.wav|||is found to be owing to want of cleanliness and fresh air in the several jails,|
00965|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0096.wav|||the fatal consequences whereof might be prevented if the justices of the peace were duly authorized|
00966|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0097.wav|||to provide such accommodations in jails as may be necessary to answer this salutary purpose,|
00967|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0098.wav|||it is enacted that the justices shall order the walls of every room to be scraped and white-washed once every year."|
00968|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0099.wav|||Ventilators, hand and others, were to be supplied.|
00969|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0100.wav|||An infirmary, consisting of two distinct rooms, one for males and one for females, should be provided for the separate accommodation of the sick.|
00970|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0101.wav|||Warm and cold baths, or "commodious bathing tubs,"|
00971|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0102.wav|||were to be kept in every jail, and the prisoners directed to wash in them before release. These provisions were almost a dead letter.|
00972|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0103.wav|||Yet another act passed in seventeen ninety-one, if properly observed, should have insured proper attention to them.|
00973|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0104.wav|||By the thirty-one George the third c. forty-six, s. five,|
00974|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0105.wav|||two or more justices were appointed visitors of prisons, and directed to visit and inspect three times every quarter.|
00975|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0106.wav|||They were to report in writing to quarter sessions as to the state of the jail, and as to all abuses which they might observe therein.|
00976|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0107.wav|||The most important jail act of that early period, however, was the twenty-four George the third c. fifty-four, s. four (seventeen eighty-four)|
00977|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0108.wav|||which was the first legislative attempt to compel the classification of prisoners, or their separation into classes|
00978|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0109.wav|||according to their categories or crimes.|
00979|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0110.wav|||It was made incumbent upon the justices to provide distinct places of confinement for five classes of prisoners, viz.|
00980|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0111.wav|||one. Prisoners convicted of felony. two. Prisoners committed on a charge or suspicion of felony.|
00981|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0112.wav|||three. Prisoners guilty of misdemeanors. four. Prisoners charged with misdemeanors. five. Debtors.|

00984|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0115.wav|||Infirmaries separating the sexes were also to be provided, a chapel too, and warm and cold baths.|
00985|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0116.wav|||Care also was to be taken that the prisoners shall not be kept in any apartment underground.|
00986|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0117.wav|||In an early report of the Prison Discipline Improvement Society,|

00989|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0120.wav|||In eighteen eighteen, out of five hundred and eighteen prisons in the United Kingdom,|
00990|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0121.wav|||to which a total of upwards of one hundred thousand prisoners had been committed in the year, only twenty-three prisons were divided according to law;|
00991|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0122.wav|||fifty-nine had no division whatever to separate males and females; one hundred and thirty-six had only one division for the purpose;|
00992|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0123.wav|||sixty-eight had only two divisions, and so on.|
00993|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0124.wav|||In four hundred and forty-five prisons no work of any description had been introduced for the employment of prisoners;|

00995|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0126.wav|||The want of room was still a crying evil.|

00998|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0129.wav|||Many of the jails were in the most deplorable condition:|

01000|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0131.wav|||To specify more particularly one or two of the worst, it may be mentioned that in the Borough Compter|

01003|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0134.wav|||The debtors were crowded almost inconceivably. In a space twenty feet long by six wide,|
01004|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0135.wav|||twenty men slept on eight straw beds, with sixteen rugs amongst them, and a piece of timber for a bolster.|
01005|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0136.wav|||Mr. Buxton, who found this, declared that it seemed physically impossible, but he was assured that it was true,|
01006|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0137.wav|||and that it was accomplished by "sleeping edgewise."|
01007|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0138.wav|||One poor wretch, who had slept next the wall, said he had been literally unable to move for the pressure.|
01008|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0139.wav|||In the morning the stench and heat were so oppressive that he and every one else on waking rushed unclothed into the yard;|

01010|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0141.wav|||The hospital was filled with infectious cases, and in one room, seven feet by nine, with closed windows,|
01011|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0142.wav|||where a lad lay ill with fever, three other prisoners, at first perfectly healthy, were lodged. Of course they were seized with the fever;|
01012|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0143.wav|||so that the culprit, in addition to his sentence,|
01013|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0144.wav|||had to endure by "the regulations of the city a disease very dangerous in its nature," and ran the risk of a lingering and painful death.|
01014|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0145.wav|||At Guildford prison, which Mr. Buxton also visited in eighteen eighteen,|
01015|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0146.wav|||there was no infirmary, no chapel, no work, no classification.|
01016|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0147.wav|||The irons, which nearly every one wore, were remarkably heavy; those double ironed could not take off their small clothes.|

01023|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0154.wav|||One hundred and fifty were lodged in a prison just capable of holding fifty-two.|
01024|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0155.wav|||In the crowd, all of them persons who had "no other avocation or mode of livelihood but thieving," Mr. Buxton counted eleven children|

01032|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0163.wav|||and of which fewer still would believe that the original is to be found in this enlightened and happy country."|

01085|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0216.wav|||The most noticeable of the improvements introduced was a better regulation of dietaries within the prison.|
01086|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0217.wav|||The old haphazard system, by which meat was issued in bulk,|
01087|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0218.wav|||a week's allowance at a time, was abolished, and there was a regular scale of daily rations adopted.|
01088|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0219.wav|||The diet was now ample. It consisted of a pound and a half of bread per diem;|
01089|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0220.wav|||for breakfast a pint of gruel; for dinner half a pound of boiled meat, or a quart of soup with vegetables, on alternate days.|
01090|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0221.wav|||The food was properly prepared in the prison kitchen.|
01091|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0222.wav|||Meat was no longer issued raw, to be imperfectly cooked before a ward fire and bolted gluttonously, the whole two pounds at one sitting.|
01092|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0223.wav|||Mr. Brown confidently asserted that no jail in England now fed its inmates so well as did Newgate.|
01093|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0224.wav|||So plentiful was this dietary, that although the old permission remained in force of allowing the friends of prisoners to bring them supplies from outside,|
01094|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0225.wav|||the practice was falling into abeyance, and the prisoners seldom required private assistance to eke out their meals.|
01095|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0226.wav|||It was also claimed for the more ample and more orderly distribution of victuals, that the general health of the prisoners had greatly improved.|
01096|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0227.wav|||Mr. Brown also, much to his own credit, brought about the abandonment of the practice of ironing all prisoners as a matter of course.|
01097|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0228.wav|||In eighteen eighteen prisoners awaiting trial in Newgate, were at length relieved from this illegal infliction.|
01098|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0229.wav|||Convicts were not even compelled to wear irons, providing they behaved well.|
01099|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0230.wav|||It was found that shackles might be safely dispensed with, even in the case of the most desperate characters.|
01100|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0231.wav|||This was effected by stopping the nearly indiscriminate admission of visitors, which had hitherto prevailed all over the jail.|
01101|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0232.wav|||Ironing it will be remembered, was a distinguishing badge, so that when the jail was cleared the free might be readily known from the captive, and escapes prevented.|

01103|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ004-0234.wav|||This change led to some discontent, until it was found that the much greater boon of relief from irons accompanied it, and the reform was quietly accepted.|

01122|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0003.wav|||Persons committed to a metropolitan jail at that time were taken in gangs, men and women handcuffed together, or linked on to a long chain,|
01123|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0004.wav|||unless they could afford to pay for a vehicle out of their own funds.|
01124|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0005.wav|||Even then they were not certain of the favor, for I find a reference to a decent and respectable woman sent to Newgate|
01125|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0006.wav|||who handed a shilling to the escort warder to provide her with a hackney coach; but this functionary pocketed the cash, and obliged the woman to walk|
01126|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0007.wav|||chained to the rest. As the miserable crew filed through the public streets, exposed to the scornful gaze of every passenger,|
01127|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0008.wav|||they were followed by a crowd of reckless boys, who jeered at and insulted them.|
01128|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0009.wav|||Many thus led in procession were in a shocking condition of dirt and misery, frequently nearly naked, and often bearing upon them|
01129|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0010.wav|||the germs, more or less developed, of contagious disease. "Caravans," the forerunners of the prison vans,|
01130|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0011.wav|||were first made use of about eighteen twenty-seven. That the need for prison reform was imperative may be gathered from the few out of many instances I have adduced,|
01131|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0012.wav|||yet there were those who, wedded to ancient ideas, were intolerant of change; they would not admit the existence of any evils.|
01132|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0013.wav|||One smug alderman, a member of the House of Commons, sneered at the ultra philanthropy of the champions of prison improvement.|
01133|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0014.wav|||Speaking on a debate on prison matters, he declared that|
01134|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0015.wav|||our prisoners have all that prisoners ought to have, without gentlemen think they ought to be indulged with Turkey carpets.|
01135|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0016.wav|||The Society for the Improvement of Prison Discipline was taxed with a desire to introduce a system|
01136|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0017.wav|||tending to divest punishment of its just and salutary terrors;|
01137|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0018.wav|||an imputation which the Society indignantly and very justly repudiated, the statement being, as they said,|
01138|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0019.wav|||refuted by abundant evidence, and having no foundation whatever in truth.|
01139|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0020.wav|||Among those whom the Society found arrayed against it was Sydney Smith,|
01140|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0021.wav|||who, in a caustic article contributed to the 'Edinburgh Review,' protested against the pampering of criminals|
01141|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0022.wav|||While fully admitting the good intentions of the Society, he condemned their ultra humanitarianism as misplaced.|
01142|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0023.wav|||He took exception to various of the proposals of the Society. He thought they leant too much to a system of indulgence and education in jails.|
01143|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0024.wav|||He objected to the instruction of prisoners in reading and writing.|
01144|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0025.wav|||A poor man who is lucky enough, he said, "to have his son committed for a felony|
01145|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0026.wav|||educates him under such a system for nothing, while the virtuous simpleton who is on the other side of the wall is paying by the quarter for these attainments."|
01146|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0027.wav|||He was altogether against too liberal a diet; he disapproved of industrial occupations in jails, as not calculated to render prisons terrible.|
01147|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0028.wav|||nan|
01148|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0029.wav|||nothing but beating hemp and pulling oakum and pounding bricks -- no work but what was tedious, unusual."|
01149|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0030.wav|||nan|
01150|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0031.wav|||no visiting of friends, no education but religious education, no freedom of diet,|
01151|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0032.wav|||no weavers' looms or carpenters' benches. There must be a great deal of solitude, coarse food, a dress of shame,|
01152|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0033.wav|||hard, incessant, irksome, eternal labor, a planned and regulated and unrelenting exclusion of happiness and comfort.|
01153|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0034.wav|||Undeterred by these sarcasms and misrepresentations,|
01154|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0035.wav|||the Society pursued its laudable undertaking with remarkable energy and great singleness of purpose.|
01155|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0036.wav|||The objects it had in view were set forth in one of its earliest meetings.|
01156|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0037.wav|||It sought to obtain and diffuse useful information|
01157|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0038.wav|||to suggest beneficial regulations, and circulate tracts demonstrating the advantages of classification,|
01158|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0039.wav|||constant inspection, regular employment, and humane treatment generally, with religious and moral instruction.|
01159|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0040.wav|||It earnestly advocated the appointment of female officers to take exclusive charge of female prisoners,|
01160|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0041.wav|||a much-needed and, according to our ideas, indispensable reform, already initiated by the Ladies' Committee at Newgate.|
01161|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0042.wav|||It made the subject of the newly-invented tread-wheels, or stepping-wheels, as they were at first called, its peculiar affair,|
01162|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0043.wav|||and obtained full details, from places where they had been adopted, of the nature of these new machines|
01163|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0044.wav|||the method by which they were worked, and the dietaries of the prisoners employed upon them.|
01164|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0045.wav|||Nor did it confine itself to mere verbal recommendations.|
01165|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0046.wav|||The good it tried to do took active shape in the establishment of temporary refuges -- at Hoxton for males, and in the Hackney Road for females|
01166|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0047.wav|||for the reception of deserving cases discharged from prison. The governor of Newgate and other metropolitan prisons had orders of admission to this refuge|
01167|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0048.wav|||which he could bestow on prisoners on release, and so save the better-disposed or the completely destitute from lapsing at once into crime.|
01168|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0049.wav|||The refuge, which had for its object the training of its inmates in habits of industry,|
01169|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0050.wav|||and in moral and religious duty, and which after a time sought to provide them with suitable situations, was supported entirely out of the funds of the Society.|
01170|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0051.wav|||At the time of its greatest prosperity, its annual income from donations and subscriptions was about one thousand six hundred pounds.|
01171|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0052.wav|||Another point to which the Society devoted infinite pains was the preparation of plans for the guidance of architects in the construction of prisons.|
01172|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0053.wav|||A very valuable volume published by the Society|
01173|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0054.wav|||traced the progress of prison architecture from the days when the jail was the mere annexe of the baronial or episcopal castle|
01174|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0055.wav|||or a dungeon above or below the gate of a town, to the first attempts at systematic reconstruction carried out under the advice and supervision of Howard.|
01175|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0056.wav|||It is interesting to observe that the plan of "radiation," by which the prison blocks radiated from a central hall, like spokes in a wheel|
01176|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0057.wav|||was introduced as early as seventeen ninety by Mr. Blackburn|
01177|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0058.wav|||an architect of eminence who was very largely employed in the erection of prison buildings at the close of the last century.|
01178|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0059.wav|||With some important modifications this principle of radiation is still the rule.|
01179|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0060.wav|||The Society did not limit its remarks to the description of what had already been done|
01180|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0061.wav|||but it offered suggestions for future buildings, with numerous carefully-executed drawings and designs of the model it recommended for imitation.|
01181|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0062.wav|||Experience has since shown that in some respects these plans are defective, especially in the placing of the governor's residence in the center of the prison.|
01182|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0063.wav|||It was thought that this would guarantee constant supervision and inspection, but it did nothing of the kind, and only the presence of warders on duty|
01183|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0064.wav|||is found now-a-days to be really efficacious. The main recommendations, however, are based upon common sense|
01184|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0065.wav|||and none are more commendable than that which deprecates the excessive ornamentation of the external parts of the edifice.|
01185|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0066.wav|||The new jails, as Howard says, "having pompous fronts, appear like palaces to the lower class of people, and many persons are against them on this account."|
01186|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0067.wav|||The Prison Society reproves the misdirected efforts of ambitious architects, who by a lavish and improvident expenditure of public money|
01187|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0068.wav|||sought to "rank the prisons they built among the most splendid buildings of the city or town."|
01188|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0069.wav|||Absence of embellishment is in perfect unison with the character of the establishment.|
01189|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0070.wav|||These are principles fully recognized now-a-days, and it may fairly be conceded that the Prison Discipline Society's ideal|
01190|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0071.wav|||differed little from that kept in view in the construction of the latest and best modern jails.|
01191|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0072.wav|||After a few years of active exertion the Society was rewarded by fresh legislation.|
01192|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0073.wav|||To its efforts, and their effect upon Parliament and the public mind, we must attribute the new Jail Acts of four George the fourth|
01193|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0074.wav|||cap. sixty-four, and five George the fourth cap. eighty-five|
01194|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0075.wav|||which having gone through several sessions, at last became law in eighteen twenty-three to four|
01195|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0076.wav|||By the preamble of the first-named act it was declared|
01196|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0077.wav|||nan|
01197|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0078.wav|||but shall also tend more effectually to preserve the health|
01198|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0079.wav|||and improve the morals of the prisoners, and shall insure the proper measure of punishment to convicted offenders.|
01199|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0080.wav|||Accordingly due provision was made for the enforcement of hard labor on all prisoners sentenced to it, and for the employment of all others.|
01200|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0082.wav|||unless such ability (to work) should cease by reason of sickness, infirmity, the want of sufficient work, or from any other cause.|
01201|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0083.wav|||It was distinctly laid down that male and female prisoners should be confined in separate buildings or parts of the prison,|
01202|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0084.wav|||so as to prevent them from seeing, conversing, or holding any intercourse with each other.|
01203|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0085.wav|||Classification was insisted upon, in the manner laid down by the twenty-four George the third cap. fifty-four,|
01204|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0086.wav|||with such further separation as the justices should deem conducive to good order and discipline.|
01205|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0087.wav|||Female prisoners were in all cases to be under the charge of female officers.|
01206|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0088.wav|||Every prison containing female prisoners was to have a matron who was to reside constantly in the prison.|
01207|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0089.wav|||The religious and moral welfare of the prisoners were to be attended to,|
01208|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0090.wav|||the first by daily services, the latter by the appointment of schoolmasters and instruction in reading and writing.|
01209|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0091.wav|||Last, but not least, the use of irons was strictly forbidden, "except in cases of urgent and absolute necessity,"|
01210|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0092.wav|||and every prisoner was to be provided with a hammock or cot to himself, suitable bedding, and, if possible, a separate cell.|
01211|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0093.wav|||The second act, passed in the following year, enlarged and amended the first, and at the same time gave powers to the House|
01212|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0094.wav|||to call for information as to the observance of its provisions.|
01213|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0095.wav|||The promulgation of these two Jail Acts strengthened the hands of the Prison Discipline Society enormously.|
01214|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0096.wav|||It had now a legal and authoritative standard of efficiency to apply,|
01215|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0097.wav|||and could expose all the local authorities that still lagged behind, or neglected to comply with the provisions of the new laws.|
01216|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0098.wav|||The Society did not shrink from its self-imposed duty, but continued year after year, with unflagging energy and unflinching spirit, to watch closely|
01217|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0099.wav|||and report at length upon the condition of the prisons of the country.|
01218|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0100.wav|||For this purpose it kept up an extensive correspondence with all parts of the kingdom, and circulated queries to be answered in detail,|
01219|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0101.wav|||whence it deduced the practice and condition of every prison that replied.|
01220|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0102.wav|||Upon these and the private visitations made by various members the Society obtained the facts,|
01221|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0103.wav|||often highly damnatory, which were embodied in its annual reports.|
01222|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0104.wav|||The progress of improvement was certainly extremely slow.|
01223|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0105.wav|||It was long before the many jurisdictions imitated the few.|
01224|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0106.wav|||Jails, of which the old prison at Reading was a specimen, were still left intact.|
01225|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0107.wav|||In that prison, with its cells and yards arranged within the shell of an ancient abbey chapel,|
01226|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0108.wav|||the prisoners, without firing, bedding, or sufficient food, spent their days "in surveying their grotesque prison,|
01227|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0109.wav|||or contriving some means of escape by climbing the fluted columns which supported the Gothic arches of the aisles,|
01228|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0110.wav|||and so passing by the roof down into the garden and on to freedom.|
01229|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0111.wav|||In a county prison adjoining the metropolis, the separation between the male and female quarters was supposed to be accomplished by the erection of an iron railing;|
01230|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0112.wav|||in this same prison capital convicts were chained to the floor until execution.|
01231|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0113.wav|||In another jail not far off male and female felons still occupied the same room -- underground, and reached by a ladder of ten steps.|
01232|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0114.wav|||In others the separation between the sexes consisted in a hanging curtain|
01233|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0115.wav|||or an imaginary boundary line, and nothing prevented parties from passing to either side|
01234|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0116.wav|||but an empty regulation which all so disposed could defy.|
01235|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0117.wav|||Numbers of the jails were still unprovided with chaplains, and the prisoners never heard Divine service.|
01236|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0118.wav|||In many others there were no infirmaries, no places set apart for the confinement of prisoners afflicted with dangerous and infectious disorders.|
01237|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0119.wav|||No attempt was made to maintain discipline.|
01238|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0120.wav|||Half the jails had no code of rules properly prepared and sanctioned by the judges, according to law.|
01239|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0121.wav|||By degrees, however,|
01240|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0122.wav|||the changes necessary to bring the prisons into conformity with the recent acts were attempted, if not actually introduced into the county prisons, to which,|
01241|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0123.wav|||with a few of the more important city or borough prisons, these acts more especially applied.|
01242|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0124.wav|||Most of the local authorities embarked into considerable expenditure, determined to rebuild their jails de novo on the most approved pattern,|
01243|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0125.wav|||or to reappropriate, reconstruct, and patch up the existing prisons till they were more in accordance with the growing requirements of the times.|
01244|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0126.wav|||Religious worship became more generally the rule; chaplains were appointed, and chapels provided for them; surgeons and hospitals also.|
01245|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0127.wav|||Workshops were built at many prisons, various kinds of manufactures and trades were set on foot, including weaving, matting, shoe-making, and tailoring.|
01246|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0128.wav|||The interior of one prison was illuminated throughout with gas, -- still a novelty, which had been generally adopted in London only four years previously,|
01247|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0129.wav|||a measure which must greatly tend to discourage attempts to escape.|
01248|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0130.wav|||There were tread-wheels at most of the prisons, and regular employment thereon or at some other kind of hard labor.|
01249|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0131.wav|||In many places too where the prisoners earned money by their work, they were granted a portion of it for their own use after proper deduction for maintenance.|
01250|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0132.wav|||Only a few glaring evils still demanded a remedy.|
01251|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0133.wav|||The provision of separate sleeping cells was still quite inadequate. For instance,|
01252|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0134.wav|||in twenty-two county jails there were one thousand sixty-three sleeping cells in all (in eighteen twenty-three)|
01253|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0135.wav|||and the average daily number committed that year amounted to three thousand, nine hundred eighty-five.|
01254|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0136.wav|||The want of sleeping cells long continued a crying need.|
01255|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0137.wav|||Four years later the Prison Society reported|
01256|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0138.wav|||that in four prisons, which at one time of the year contained one thousand three hundred eight prisoners, there were only sixty-eight sleeping rooms or cells,|
01257|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0139.wav|||making an average of nineteen persons occupying each room.|
01258|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0140.wav|||At the New Prison, Clerkenwell, which had become the principal reception jail of Middlesex, and so took all the untried,|
01259|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0141.wav|||the sleeping space per head was only sixteen inches, and often as many as two hundred ninety-three men had to be accommodated on barrack beds|
01260|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0142.wav|||occupying barely three hundred ninety feet lineal|
01261|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0143.wav|||The "scenes of tumult and obscenity" in these night rooms are said to have been beyond description; a prisoner in one nocturnal riot lost an eye.|
01262|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0144.wav|||Yet to Clerkenwell were now committed the juveniles, and all who were inexperienced in crime.|
01263|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0145.wav|||Great want of uniformity in treatment in the various prisons was still noticeable|
01264|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0146.wav|||and was indeed destined to continue for another half century, in other words, until the introduction of the Prison Act of eighteen seventy-seven.|
01265|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0147.wav|||At the time of which I am writing there was great diversity of practice as regards the hours of labor.|
01266|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0148.wav|||In some prisons the prisoners worked seven hours a day, in others ten and ten and a half.|
01267|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0149.wav|||The nature of the employment varied greatly in severity, especially the tread-wheel labor.|
01268|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0150.wav|||In some county jails, as I have already said, female prisoners were placed upon the tread-wheel;|
01269|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0151.wav|||in others women were very properly exempted from it, and also from all severe labor.|
01270|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0152.wav|||Earnings were very differently appropriated. Here the prisoners were given the whole amount, there a half or a third.|
01271|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0153.wav|||Sometimes this money might be expended in the purchase of extra articles of food.|
01272|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0154.wav|||The rations varied considerably everywhere.|
01273|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0155.wav|||It was still limited to bread in some places, the allowance of which varied from one to three pounds;|
01274|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0156.wav|||in others meat, soup, gruel, beer were given.|
01275|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0157.wav|||Here and there food was not issued in kind, but a money allowance which the prisoner might expend himself.|
01276|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0158.wav|||Bedding and clothing was still denied, but only in a few jails;|
01277|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0159.wav|||in others both were supplied in ample quantities, the cost varying per prisoner from twenty shillings to five pounds.|
01278|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0160.wav|||It was plain that although the law had defined general principles of prison government,|
01279|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0161.wav|||too much discretion was still left to the magistracy to fill in the details. The legislature only recommended,|
01280|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0162.wav|||it did not peremptorily insist. Too often the letter of the law was observed, but not its spirit.|
01281|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0163.wav|||One great impediment to wide amelioration was that a vast number of small jails lay out of reach of the law.|
01282|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0164.wav|||When the new acts were introduced, numerous prisons under local jurisdiction were exempted from the operation of the law.|
01283|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0165.wav|||They were so radically bad that reform seemed hopeless, and it was thought wiser not to bring them under provisions which clearly could not be enforced.|
01284|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0166.wav|||Mr. Peel, who as Home Secretary had charge of the bill,|
01285|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0167.wav|||which became the four George the fourth cap. sixty-four, said that he had abstained from legislating for these small jurisdictions "on mature deliberation."|
01286|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0168.wav|||It is not, he said, "that I am insensible of the lamentable and disgraceful situation in which many of them are,|
01287|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0169.wav|||but I indulge a hope that many of them will contract with the counties,|
01288|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0170.wav|||that many of them will build new jails, and that when in a year or two we come to examine their situation,|
01289|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0171.wav|||we shall find but few which have not in one or other of these ways removed the grievance of which such just complaint is made.|
01290|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0172.wav|||When that time arrives|
01291|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0173.wav|||I shall not hesitate to ask Parliament for powers to compel them to make the necessary alterations, for it is not to be endured that these local jurisdictions should remain|
01292|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0174.wav|||in the deplorable situation in which many of them now are."|
01293|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0175.wav|||At this time there were in England one hundred and seventy boroughs, cities, towns, and liberties|
01294|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0176.wav|||which possessed the right of trying criminals for various offenses.|
01295|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0177.wav|||Nearly every one of these jurisdictions had its own prison, and there were one hundred and sixty such jails in all.|
01296|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0178.wav|||Many of them consisted of one or two rooms at most.|
01297|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0179.wav|||he total number of prisoners they received during the year varied from two persons to many hundreds.|
01298|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0180.wav|||It was in these jails, withdrawn from the pressure of authority, that the new rules were invariably ignored.|
01299|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0181.wav|||The right and privilege of the borough to maintain its own place of confinement was so "ancient and indisputable,"|
01300|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0182.wav|||that for long no idea of interfering with them was entertained.|
01301|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0183.wav|||All that was urged was that the borough magistracy had no right to govern their jails|
01302|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0184.wav|||so as to corrupt those committed, "to the injury of the peace and morals of the public."|
01303|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0185.wav|||As time passed, however, these magistrates made no effort at reform.|
01304|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0186.wav|||They neither built new jails nor contracted with the counties, as had been expected, for the transfer of their prisoners.|
01305|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0187.wav|||As the Society put it in eighteen twenty-seven, "the friends to the improvement of prison discipline will regret to learn|
01306|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0188.wav|||that the jails attached to corporate jurisdictions continue to be the fruitful sources|
01307|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0189.wav|||of vice and misery, debasing all who are confined within their walls, and disseminating through their respective communities|
01308|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0190.wav|||the knowledge and practice of every species of criminality.|
01309|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0191.wav|||The Society proceeded to support this indictment by facts. It is much the old story.|
01310|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0192.wav|||The prisoners were lodged in rooms whence they could converse with passengers in the streets, and freely obtain spirits and other prohibited articles.|
01311|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0193.wav|||All descriptions of offenders congregated together in the felons' wards.|
01312|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0194.wav|||The keeper and his officers resided at a distance from the jail, and left its inmates to their own devices.|
01313|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0195.wav|||There was no decency whatever in the internal arrangements;|
01314|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0196.wav|||still no separation of the sexes, no means of ablution or other necessary services.|
01315|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0197.wav|||One borough prison consisted of nothing more than a couple of cells, about ten yards square, and absolutely nothing more.|
01316|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0198.wav|||In another borough, with a population of ten thousand, the prison was of the same dimensions.|
01317|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0199.wav|||One cell was a dungeon, and the other an "improper and unhealthy abode for any human being," with a watercourse running through it.|
01318|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0200.wav|||Most of these small jails were still in existence and in much the same state eight years later,|
01319|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0201.wav|||as is shown by the report of the Commissioners to inquire into the state of the municipal corporations in eighteen thirty-five.|
01320|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0202.wav|||An examination of this report shows how even the most insignificant township had its jail.|
01321|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0203.wav|||Thus Dinas Mwddy, in Merionethshire, had, "besides the pinfold and the stocks or crib, a little prison."|
01322|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0204.wav|||Clun, in Shropshire, had a lock-up under the town hall.|
01323|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0205.wav|||At Eye, in Suffolk, the jail was part of the poor-house; so it was at Richmond, in Yorkshire, where the master of the workhouse was also keeper of the jail.|
01324|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0206.wav|||At Godmanchester there was no jail, but a cage to secure prisoners till they could be taken before a magistrate.|
01325|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0207.wav|||Kidderminster had a prison, one damp chill room,|

01329|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0211.wav|||the jail consisted of six cells, frequently so damp that the moisture trickled down the walls; there was not space for air or exercise,|
01330|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0212.wav|||and the prison allowance was still limited to bread and water.|
01331|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0213.wav|||Newgate through all these years continued a bye-word with the Society.|
01332|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0214.wav|||Some reforms had certainly been introduced, such as the abolition of irons, already referred to, and the establishment of male and female infirmaries.|
01333|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0215.wav|||The regular daily visitation of the chaplain was also insisted upon.|
01334|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0216.wav|||But it was pointed out in eighteen twenty-three that defective construction must always bar the way to any radical improvement in Newgate.|
01335|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0217.wav|||Without enlargement no material change in discipline or interior economy could possibly be introduced.|
01336|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0218.wav|||The chapel still continued incommodious and insufficient|
01337|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0219.wav|||female prisoners were still exposed to the full view of the males, the netting in front of the gallery being perfectly useless as a screen.|
01338|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0220.wav|||In eighteen twenty-four Newgate had no glass in its windows, except in the infirmary and one ward of the chapel yard;|
01339|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0221.wav|||and the panes were filled in with oiled paper, an insufficient protection against the weather;|
01340|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0222.wav|||and as the window-frames would not shut tight, the prisoners complained much of the cold, especially at night.|
01341|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0223.wav|||There was a diminution in the numbers in custody, due to the adoption of the practice of not committing at once to Newgate every offender for trial at the Old Bailey|
01342|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0224.wav|||but nothing had been done to improve the prison buildings.|
01343|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0225.wav|||In eighteen twenty-seven the Society was compelled to report that "no material change had taken place in Newgate since the passing of the prison laws,|
01344|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0226.wav|||and that consequently the observance of their most important provisions was habitually neglected.|
01345|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0227.wav|||It was enacted that the court of aldermen should make rules for the government of the prison, and that these should be posted publicly within the walls.|
01346|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0228.wav|||As yet no rules or regulations had been printed or prepared.|
01347|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0229.wav|||By another clause of the Jail Act, two justices were to be appointed to visit the prison at least thrice in every quarter, and "oftener if occasion required."|
01348|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0230.wav|||These justices were to inspect every part of the prison, and examine into the state and condition of prisoners.|
01349|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0231.wav|||The city justices had not fulfilled this obligation.|
01350|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0232.wav|||Idleness was still the general rule for all prisoners in Newgate, in defiance of the law.|
01351|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0233.wav|||There was no instruction of adult prisoners, in accordance with the law. The sleeping accommodation was still altogether contrary to the latest ideas.|
01352|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0234.wav|||The visits of friends was once more unreservedly allowed, and these incomers freely brought in extra provisions and beer.|
01353|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0235.wav|||Last, and worst of all, the arrangements for keeping the condemned prisoners between sentence and execution were more than unsatisfactory.|
01354|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0236.wav|||They were not confined apart from each other, but were crowded thirty or forty together in the press yard,|
01355|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0237.wav|||so that "corrupt conversation obliterated from the mind of him who is doomed to suffer every serious feeling and valuable impression."|
01356|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0238.wav|||I shall have more to say on this subject, and upon the state of Newgate generally, in the following chapter.|
01357|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0239.wav|||The Prison Society did not relax its efforts as time passed, but its leading members had other and more pressing claims upon their energies.|
01358|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0240.wav|||Mr. Buxton had succeeded to the great work which William Wilberforce had commenced, and led the repeated attacks upon slavery in British colonies|
01359|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0241.wav|||till the whole body of the slaves were manumitted in eighteen thirty-three.|
01360|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0242.wav|||In the year immediately preceding this, Parliament was too busy with the great question of its own reform to spare much time for domestic legislation.|
01361|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0243.wav|||Nevertheless a committee of the House of Commons was appointed in eighteen thirty-one to report upon the whole system of secondary punishments,|
01362|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0244.wav|||which dealt with jails of all classes, as well as transportation.|
01363|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0245.wav|||This committee animadverted strongly upon the system in force at the metropolitan jails, and more especially upon the condition of Newgate|
01364|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0246.wav|||where "prisoners before and after trial are under no efficient superintendence," and where "there was no restraint, or attempt at restraint."|
01365|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0247.wav|||Mr. Samuel Hoare was examined by this committee|
01366|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0248.wav|||and stated that in his opinion Newgate, as the common jail of Middlesex, was wholly inadequate to the proper confinement of its prisoners.|
01367|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0249.wav|||From the moment of a person's committal he was certain to be plunged deeper and deeper in guilt.|
