01369|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0251.wav|||Again in eighteen thirty-five prisons and their inmates became once more the care of the senate, and the subject was taken up this time by the House of Lords.|
01370|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0252.wav|||A committee was appointed, under the presidency of the Duke of Richmond|
01371|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0253.wav|||nan|
01372|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0254.wav|||upon the rules and discipline therein established with regard to the treatment of unconvicted as well as convicted persons."|
01373|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0255.wav|||The committee was also to report upon the manner in which sentences were carried out, and to recommend any alterations necessary in the rules|
01374|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0256.wav|||in order to insure uniformity of discipline. It met on the thirty-first March, eighteen thirty-five, and continued its sittings well into July|
01375|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0257.wav|||during which time a host of witnesses were examined, and the committee presented three separate reports,|
01376|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0258.wav|||embodying recommendations which may be said to have formed the basis of modern prison management.|
01377|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0259.wav|||It was laid down as a first and indispensable principle that uniformity of discipline should prevail everywhere,|
01378|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0260.wav|||a theory which did not become a practical fact for forty more years.|
01379|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0261.wav|||As a means of securing this uniformity,|
01380|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0262.wav|||it was suggested that the rules framed for prison government should be subjected to the Secretary of State for approval,|
01381|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0263.wav|||and not, as heretofore, to the judges of assize; that, both to check abuses and watch the progress of improvement,|
01382|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0264.wav|||inspectors of prisons should be appointed, who should visit all the prisons from time to time and report to the Secretary of State.|
01383|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0265.wav|||It was recommended that the dietaries should be submitted and approved like the rules; that convicted prisoners should not receive any food but the jail allowance;|
01384|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0266.wav|||that food and fuel should be issued in kind, and never provided by the prisoners themselves out of monies granted them.|
01385|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0267.wav|||The use of tobacco, hitherto pretty generally indulged in both by men and women,|
01386|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0268.wav|||should be strictly prohibited, "as a stimulating luxury inconsistent with any notion of strict discipline and the due pressure of just punishment."|
01387|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0269.wav|||Prison officers should not have any share in prisoners' earnings,|
01388|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0270.wav|||which should be paid into general prison funds, and no part of them handed over to the prisoners themselves.|
01389|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0271.wav|||As a means of increasing the severity of imprisonment, letters and visits from outside should not be permitted during the first six months of an imprisonment.|
01390|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0272.wav|||Various other recommendations were made as regards the appointment of chaplain and schoolmasters; the limitation of the powers of wardsmen,|
01391|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0273.wav|||or prisoners employed in positions of trust, who should not be permitted to traffic with their fellow-prisoners in any way.|
01392|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0274.wav|||The committee most of all insisted upon the entire individual separation of prisoners, except during the hours of labor,|
01393|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0275.wav|||religious worship, and instruction, as "absolutely necessary for preventing contamination,|
01394|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0276.wav|||and for securing a proper system of prison discipline.|
01395|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0277.wav|||This was the first enunciation of the system of separate confinement,|
01396|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0278.wav|||which was eventually to replace the attempted arrangement of prisoners by classes according to antecedents and crimes,|
01397|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0279.wav|||an incomplete and fallacious method of preventing contamination.|
01398|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0280.wav|||The Lords' Committee fully recognized the painful fact|
01399|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0281.wav|||that the greatest mischief followed from the intercourse which was still permitted in so many prisons; to use its words,|
01400|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0282.wav|||nan|
01401|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0283.wav|||and the tendency to crime in offenders not entirely hardened is confirmed by the language, the suggestions, and the example|
01402|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0284.wav|||of more depraved and systematic criminals.|
01403|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0285.wav|||This committee, as well as the one preceding it, also reported in terms of strong reprobation on the small prisons and jails|
01404|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0286.wav|||still under the borough corporations. The Commons' Committee gave it as their opinion that they were in a deplorable state.|
01405|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0287.wav|||The same language was used by the commissioners appointed to inquire into the municipal corporations in eighteen thirty-five,|
01406|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0288.wav|||when speaking more particularly of the borough jails.|
01407|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0289.wav|||In these the commissioners found "additional proof of the evils of continuing the present constitution of the local tribunals.|
01408|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0290.wav|||Instances rarely occur in which the borough jails admit of any proper classification of the prisoners.|
01409|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0291.wav|||In some large towns, as at Berwick on Tweed, Southampton, and Southwark, they (the prisons) are in a very discreditable condition.|
01410|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0292.wav|||In many of the smaller boroughs they are totally unfit for the confinement of human beings.|
01411|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0293.wav|||In these places the prisoners are often without a proper supply of air and light; frequently the jails are mere dungeons under the town hall.|
01412|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0294.wav|||It was frequently stated in evidence that the jail of the borough was in so unfit a state for the reception of prisoners,|
01413|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0295.wav|||that plaintiffs were unwilling to consign the defendants against whom they had obtained execution to confinement within its walls."|
01414|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0296.wav|||The Lords' Committee on Jails were of the same opinion, and considered the prisons under corporate or peculiar jurisdiction in a very unsatisfactory condition.|
01415|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0297.wav|||They therefore recommended that the prisoners should be removed|
01416|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ005-0298.wav|||to the county jails from such prisons as were past improvement, and that the borough funds should be charged for the accommodation.|

01421|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0003.wav|||Newgate has remained rather in the background while the whole of the jails as a body were under discussion.|

01423|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0005.wav|||just before the public mind was first awakened to the need for thorough reform.|
01424|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0006.wav|||I shall now return to the great jail of the city of London, and give a more detailed account of its condition and inner life|
01425|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0007.wav|||as the inspectors of prisons found them in eighteen thirty-five to six.|
01426|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0008.wav|||These gentlemen were appointed in October eighteen thirty-five, owing to the strong representations of the Lords' Committee|
01427|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0009.wav|||backed up by the evidence of several influential witnesses.|
01428|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0010.wav|||Mr. Samuel Hoare, when examined, considered it indispensably necessary, to carry out whatever system might be established,|
01429|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0011.wav|||that inspectors should watch over the observance of the law. He saw no objection on the score of their probable interference with the local jurisdiction,|
01430|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0012.wav|||but he would not arm them with any authority lest their cooperation might be offensive.|
01431|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0013.wav|||Sir Frederick Roe was of the same opinion as regards the appointment, but he would give the inspectors the power of acting as well as reporting.|
01432|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0014.wav|||They should be persons, he thought, selected from the highest class; the duty was most important,|
01433|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0015.wav|||one which required discretion, judgment, and knowledge of law, with sufficient insight and experience to discover defects in prison discipline.|
01434|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0016.wav|||These considerations no doubt had weight|
01435|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0017.wav|||with those who made the selection of the first inspectors, and the two gentlemen appointed were probably the most fitted in England to be so employed.|
01436|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0018.wav|||One was Mr. William Crawford, the other the Rev. Whitworth Russell.|
01437|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0019.wav|||The first named had long been an active philanthropist, devoting himself more particularly to the reformation of juvenile criminals.|
01438|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0020.wav|||William Crawford had been one of the promoters and managers of the Philanthropic Society's farm school.|
01439|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0021.wav|||Later on he had devoted himself to the personal investigation of the prisons of the United States.|
01440|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0022.wav|||At that time the mild and intelligent prison discipline in force in Pennsylvania, the legacy of the old Quaker immigrants,|
01441|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0023.wav|||had made such prisons as Auburn a model for imitation.|
01442|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0024.wav|||Several European states had dispatched emissaries to examine and report upon them.|
01443|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0025.wav|||France had sent Misseurs Beaumont and De Tocqueville, who subsequently published several interesting works on the subject.|
01444|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0026.wav|||England was represented by Mr. Crawford, and the result of his inquiry was given to the public as an appendix to the House of Commons' Report on Secondary Punishments.|
01445|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0027.wav|||It is an able and exhaustive state paper, testifying to the keenness of the writer's perception, and his unremitting labor in pursuing his researches.|
01446|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0028.wav|||Mr. Crawford was thoroughly versed in the still imperfectly understood science of prison management, and fully qualified for his new duties.|
01447|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0029.wav|||The second inspector, the Rev. Whitworth Russell, was the chaplain of Millbank penitentiary,|
01448|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0030.wav|||the great architectural experiment which grew out of the strong representations of Jeremy Bentham and others, and was the first national recognition of the principle|
01449|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0031.wav|||that punishment must be reformatory as well as deterrent.|
01450|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0032.wav|||Messrs. Crawford and Russell proceeded to carry out their new functions with commendable energy, and without a moment's loss of time.|
01451|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0033.wav|||The ink was barely dry upon their letters of appointment before they appeared at Newgate, and commenced a searching investigation.|
01452|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0034.wav|||They attended early and late; they mustered the prisoners, examined into their condition,|
01453|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0035.wav|||took voluminous evidence from all classes of individuals, from the governor down to the convict in the condemned cells.|
01454|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0036.wav|||They visited the wards after locking-up time, and saw with their own eyes what went on.|
01455|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0038.wav|||a subject of magnitude and importance sufficient to exclude other jails, they soon narrowed their inquiry still further,|
01456|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0039.wav|||and limited it to Newgate alone. Newgate indeed became the sole theme of their first report.|
01457|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0040.wav|||The fact was that the years as they passed, nearly twenty in all, had worked but little permanent improvement in this detestable prison.|
01458|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0041.wav|||Changes introduced under pressure had been only skin deep.|
01459|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0042.wav|||Relapse was rapid and inevitable, so that the latter state of the prison was worse than the first.|
01460|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0043.wav|||The disgraceful overcrowding had been partially ended, but the same evils of indiscriminate association were still present; there was the old neglect of decency,|
01461|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0044.wav|||the same callous indifference to the moral well-being of the prisoners, the same want of employment and of all disciplinary control.|
01462|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0045.wav|||All these evils were set forth at length in the inspectors' first report.|
01463|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0046.wav|||There was no longer the faintest possible excuse for overcrowding. The numbers now committed to Newgate had sensibly diminished.|
01464|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0047.wav|||The prison had become more or less a place of detention only, harboring mainly those awaiting trial.|
01465|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0048.wav|||To these were still added an average of about fifty expecting the last penalty of the law; a certain number of transports awaiting removal to the colonies;|
01466|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0049.wav|||an occasional prisoner or two committed by the Houses of Parliament, the Courts of King's Bench, Common Pleas,|
01467|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0050.wav|||the Exchequer, the Commissioners of bankruptcy and of taxes; smugglers, and a larger number sentenced for very short terms,|

01469|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0052.wav|||The sum total thus produced was inconsiderable compared with the hundreds that had formerly filled the jail,|
01470|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0053.wav|||and the whole by proper management might have been so accommodated as to prevent overcrowding.|
01471|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0054.wav|||But incredible as it may appear, the authorities of Newgate declined to avail themselves of the advantages offered them,|

01474|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0057.wav|||Not only were the wards thus needlessly crammed, and for no reason but the niggardliness of the corporation which refused a proper supply of bedding|
01475|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0058.wav|||but the occupants of each were huddled together indiscriminately. The inspectors found in the same wards in the chapel yard the convicted and the untried,|
01476|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0059.wav|||the felon and the misdemeanant, the sane and the insane, the old and young offender.|
01477|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0060.wav|||The classification prescribed by the Jail Act, which laid down that certain prisoners should not intermix, was openly neglected,|
01478|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0061.wav|||and "the greatest contempt shown for the law."|
01479|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0062.wav|||In another part there were men charged with and convicted of unnatural offenses shut up with lads of tender years;|
01480|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0063.wav|||minor offenders charged with small thefts or non-payment of small sums were cheek by jowl with convicts sentenced to long terms of transportation.|
01481|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0064.wav|||In the master's side yard, which had only one washing place, as many as seventy-eight prisoners, frequently more,|
01482|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0065.wav|||were associated together, "of every variety of age, habit, and delinquency, without employment, oversight, or control."|
01483|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0066.wav|||In the middle yard it was still worse.|
01484|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0067.wav|||Here, say the inspectors, "are herded together the very worst class of prisoners; certainly a more wretched combination of human beings can hardly be imagined.|
01485|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0068.wav|||We have reason to fear that poverty, ragged clothes, and an inability to pay the ward dues, elsewhere exacted for better accommodation,|
01486|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0069.wav|||consign many of the more petty and unpracticed offenders to this place,|

01506|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0089.wav|||to be pitchforked by chance anywhere, into any sort of company,|

01508|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0091.wav|||Their treatment was also a matter of chance. They still slept on rope mats on the floor, herded together in companies of four or more to keep one another warm|
01509|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0092.wav|||and under the scanty covering of a couple of dirty stable-rugs apiece.|
01510|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0093.wav|||So closely did they lie together, that the inspectors at their night visits found it difficult in stepping across the room to avoid treading on them.|

01512|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0095.wav|||The rugs used were never washed; an order existed that the bedding should be taken into the yards to be aired, but it was not very punctually obeyed.|
01513|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0096.wav|||The only convenience for personal ablutions were the pumps in the yards, and the far-off baths in the condemned or press-yard.|
01514|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0097.wav|||Water might not be taken into the ward for washing purposes.|

01519|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0102.wav|||This, too, was in the depth of the winter, and during a most inclement season.|
01520|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0103.wav|||The allowance of food was not illiberal,|
01521|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0104.wav|||but its issue was precarious, and dependent on the good will of the wardsmen, who measured out the portions to each according to his eye,|
01522|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0105.wav|||and not with weights and measures, no turnkey being present.|
01523|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0106.wav|||Too much was left to the wardsman. It was he who could issue small luxuries;|
01524|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0107.wav|||he sold tea, coffee, sugar, tobacco, although prohibited, and extra beer.|
01525|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0108.wav|||He charged a weekly sum as ward dues for the use of knives, forks, and plates|
01526|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0109.wav|||a perpetuation under another form of the old detestable custom of garnish.|
01527|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0110.wav|||He had power where his exactions were resisted of making the ward most uncomfortable for the defaulter.|
01528|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0111.wav|||He could trump up a false complaint against his fellow-prisoner, and so get him punished;|
01529|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0112.wav|||he might keep him from the fire, or give him his soup or gruel in a pail instead of a basin.|
01530|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0113.wav|||The authority of these wardsmen so improperly exalted, and so entirely unchecked, degenerated into a baneful despotism.|
01531|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0114.wav|||They bought their offices from one another, and were thus considered to have a vested interest in them.|
01532|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0115.wav|||Their original capital had been a few shillings, and for this they purchased the right to tax their fellows to the extent of pounds per week.|
01533|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0116.wav|||The wardsman had a monopoly in supplying provisions, gave dinner and breakfast at his own price, and was such complete master of the ward|
01534|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0117.wav|||that none of its inmates were suffered to make tea or coffee for themselves lest it should interfere with his sales.|
01535|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0118.wav|||He made collections when it suited him for ward purposes, to be spent as he chose, in candles and so forth.|
01536|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0119.wav|||When the wardsman was a man of some education, with some knowledge of legal chicanery gained by personal experience, he might add considerably to his emoluments|
01537|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0120.wav|||by drawing briefs and petitions for his fellows. There was a recognized charge of five shillings per brief,|
01538|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0121.wav|||for a petition of from one shilling, half pence to eight shillings, according to its length,|
01539|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0122.wav|||and by these payments a wardsman had been known to amass as much as forty pounds.|
01540|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0123.wav|||The man intrusted with this privilege was often the inner gatesman,|
01541|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0124.wav|||the prisoner official already mentioned, who held the fate of new arrivals as regards location in his hands.|
01542|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0125.wav|||It was not strange that he should sometimes misuse his power, and when prisoners were not to be cajoled into securing his legal services,|
01543|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0126.wav|||had been known to employ threats, declaring that he was often consulted by the governor as to a prisoner's character,|
01544|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0127.wav|||in view of speaking to it at the trial, and he could easily do them a good turn -- or a very bad one.|
01545|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0128.wav|||The brief-drawing gatesman and wardsman at the time of the inspectors' first visit must have been a particularly powerful personage.|
01546|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0129.wav|||He was on the most intimate and improperly familiar terms with the turnkeys,|
01547|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0130.wav|||had a key of both the master's side and middle side yards, was the only person present at the distribution of beer, and was trusted to examine,|
01548|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0131.wav|||and, if he chose, pass in, all provisions, money, clothes, and letters brought for prisoners by their friends.|
01549|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0132.wav|||All the wardsmen alike were more or less irresponsible.|
01550|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0133.wav|||The turnkeys complained bitterly that these old prisoners had more power than they themselves.|
01551|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0134.wav|||The governor himself admitted that a prisoner of weak intellect who had been severely beaten and much injured by a wardsman did not dare complain|
01552|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0135.wav|||the victim of this cruel ill-usage having "more fear of the power of the wardsman to injure him, than confidence in the governor's power to protect him."|
01553|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0136.wav|||These wardsmen, besides thus ruling the roast, had numerous special privileges, if such they can be called.|
01554|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0137.wav|||They were not obliged to attend chapel, and seldom if ever went; "prisoners," said one of them under examination, "did not like the trouble of going to chapel."|
01555|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0138.wav|||They had a standing bedstead to sleep on, and a good flock mattress; double allowance of provisions, filched from the common stock.|
01556|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0139.wav|||Nobody interfered with them or regulated their conduct. They might get drunk when so disposed, and did so frequently, alone or in company.|
01557|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0140.wav|||Evidence was given before the inspectors of eight or ten prisoners seen "giddy drunk, not able to sit upon forms."|
01558|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0141.wav|||The female wards-women were also given to intemperance.|
01559|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0142.wav|||The matron deposed to having seen the gates-woman "exceedingly drunk," and having been insulted by her.|
01560|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0143.wav|||There was no penalty attached to drunkenness.|
01561|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0144.wav|||A wardsman did not necessarily lose his situation for it. Nor was drink the only creature comfort he might enjoy.|
01562|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0145.wav|||He could indulge in snuff if a snuff-taker,|
01563|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0146.wav|||and might always smoke his pipe undisturbed; for although the use of tobacco had been prohibited since the report of the Lords Committee,|
01564|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0147.wav|||it was still freely introduced into the prison.|
01565|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0148.wav|||Probably authority would not have been so recklessly usurped by the wardsmen had not the proper officials too readily surrendered it.|
01566|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0149.wav|||The turnkeys left the prisoners very much to themselves, never entering the wards after locking-up time, at dusk, till unlocking next morning,|
01567|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0150.wav|||and then only went round to count the number.|
01568|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0151.wav|||Many of them were otherwise and improperly occupied for hours every day in menial services for the governor, cleaning his windows or grooming his horse.|
01569|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0152.wav|||One turnkey had been so employed several hours daily for nearly eleven years.|
01570|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0153.wav|||It was not strange that subordinates should neglect their duty when superiors set the example.|
01571|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0154.wav|||Nothing was more prominently brought out by the inspectors than the inefficiency of the governor at that time, Mr. Cope.|
01572|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0155.wav|||He may have erred in some points through ignorance, but in others he was clearly guilty of culpable neglect.|
01573|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0156.wav|||We have seen that he took no pains to classify and separate prisoners on reception.|
01574|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0157.wav|||This was only one of many grave omissions on his part. He did not feel it incumbent on himself to visit his prison often or see his prisoners.|
01575|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0158.wav|||The act prescribed that he should do both every twenty-four hours, but days passed without his entering the wards.|
01576|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0159.wav|||The prisoners declared that they did not see him oftener than twice a week;|
01577|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0160.wav|||one man who had been in the condemned ward for two months, said the governor only came there four times.|
01578|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0161.wav|||Again, a turnkey deposed that his chief did not enter the wards more than once a fortnight.|
01579|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0162.wav|||But it is only fair to Mr. Cope to state that he himself said he went whenever he could find time|
01580|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0163.wav|||and that he was constantly engaged attending sessions and going with drafts to the hulks.|
01581|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0164.wav|||But when he did visit, his inspections were of the most superficial character|
01582|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0165.wav|||sometimes he looked at his bolts and bars, but he never examined the cupboards, coal-boxes, or other possible hiding-places for cards|
01583|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0166.wav|||dice, dangerous implements, or other prohibited articles.|
01584|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0167.wav|||He only attended chapel once on Sunday, never on the week-day, and generally devoted the time service was in progress|
01585|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0168.wav|||to taking the descriptions of newly-arrived prisoners.|
01586|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0169.wav|||He really did not know what passed in his jail|
01587|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0170.wav|||and was surprised when the inspectors proved to him that practices of which he was ignorant, and which he admitted that he reprehended, went on without hindrance.|
01588|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0171.wav|||He was satisfied to let matters run on as in the old times, he said in his own justification; with him what was, was right,|
01589|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0172.wav|||and evils that should have been speedily rooted out remained because they had the prescription of long usage.|
01590|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0173.wav|||He kept no daily journal of occurrences, and nothing, however important, was recorded at the time.|
01591|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0174.wav|||The aldermen never called upon him to report, and left him nearly unsupervised and uncontrolled.|
01592|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0175.wav|||In his administration of discipline he was quite uncertain;|
01593|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0176.wav|||the punishments he inflicted were unequal,|
01594|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0177.wav|||and it was not the least part of the blame imputed to him that he made special favorites of particular prisoners, retaining of his own accord in Newgate,|
01595|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0178.wav|||and for years, felons who should have been sent beyond the seas.|
01596|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0179.wav|||But, indeed, his whole rule was far too mild, and under this mistaken leniency|
01597|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0180.wav|||the interior of the jail was more like a bear-garden or the noisy purlieus of a public-house than a prison.|
01598|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0181.wav|||It was the same old story -- evil constantly in the ascendant, the least criminal at the mercy of the most depraved.|
01599|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0182.wav|||Under the reckless contempt for regulations,|
01600|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0183.wav|||the apathy of the authorities, and the undue ascendancy of those who, as convicted felons, should have been most sternly repressed,|
01601|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0184.wav|||the most hardened and the oldest in vice had the best of it, while the inexperienced beginner went to the wall.|
01602|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0185.wav|||Edward Gibbon Wakefield, who spent three years in Newgate a little before the time of the inspectors' first report,|
01603|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0186.wav|||said with justice that "incredible scenes of horror occur in Newgate."|
01604|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0187.wav|||It was, moreover, in his opinion undoubtedly the greatest nursery of crime in London.|
01605|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0188.wav|||The days were passed in idleness, debauchery, riotous quarreling, immoral conversation,|
01606|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0189.wav|||gambling, indirect contravention of parliamentary rules, instruction in all nefarious processes,|
01607|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0190.wav|||lively discourse upon past criminal exploits, elaborate discussion of others to be perpetrated after release.|
01608|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0191.wav|||No provision whatever was made for the employment of prisoners, no materials were purchased, no trade instructors appointed.|
01609|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0192.wav|||There was no school for adults; only the boys were taught anything, and their instructor, with his assistant, were convicted prisoners.|
01610|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0193.wav|||Idle hands and unoccupied brains found in mischief the only means of whiling away the long hours of incarceration.|
01611|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0194.wav|||Gaming of all kinds, although forbidden by the Jail Acts, was habitually practiced.|
01612|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0195.wav|||This was admitted in evidence by the turnkeys, and was proved by the appearance of the prison tables, which bore the marks of gaming-boards deeply cut into them.|
01613|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0196.wav|||Prisoners confessed that it was a favorite occupation, the chief games being "shoving halfpence" on the table,|
01614|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0197.wav|||pitch in the hole, cribbage, dominoes, and common tossing, at which as much as four or five shillings would change hands in an hour.|
01615|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0198.wav|||But this was not the only amusement. Most of the wards took in the daily papers,|
01616|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0199.wav|||the most popular being the "Times," "Morning Herald," and "Morning Chronicle"; on Sunday the "Weekly Dispatch," "Bell's Life," and the "Weekly Messenger."|
01617|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0200.wav|||The newsman had free access to the prison; he passed in unsearched and unexamined, and, unaccompanied by an officer,|
01618|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0201.wav|||went at once to his customers, who bought their paper and paid for it themselves.|
01619|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0202.wav|||The news-vendor was also a tobacconist,|
01620|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0203.wav|||and he had thus ample means of introducing to the prisoners the prohibited but always much-coveted and generally procurable weed.|
01621|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0204.wav|||In the same way the wardsman laid in his stock to be retailed. Other light literature besides the daily journals were in circulation:|
01622|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0205.wav|||novels, flash songs, play-books, such as "Jane Shore," "Grimm's German Tales," with Cruikshank's illustrations,|
01623|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0206.wav|||and publications which in these days would have been made the subject of a criminal prosecution.|
01624|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0207.wav|||One of these, published by Stockdale, the inspectors styled "a book of the most disgusting nature."|
01625|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0208.wav|||There was also a good supply of Bibles and prayers,|
01626|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0209.wav|||the donation of a philanthropic gentleman, Captain Brown, but these, particularly the Bibles, bore little appearance of having been used.|
01627|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0210.wav|||Drink, in more or less unlimited quantities, was still to be had.|
01628|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0211.wav|||Spirits certainly were now excluded; but a potman, with full permission of the sheriffs,|
01629|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0212.wav|||brought in beer for sale from a neighboring public-house, and visited all the wards with no other escort than the prisoner gatesman.|
01630|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0213.wav|||The quantity to be issued per head was limited by the prison regulations to one pint|
01631|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0214.wav|||but no steps were taken to prevent any prisoner from obtaining more if he could pay for it.|
01632|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0215.wav|||The beer-man brought in as much as he pleased; he sold it without the controlling presence of an officer.|
01633|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0216.wav|||Not only did prisoners come again and again for a "pint," but large quantities were carried off to the wards to be drunk later in the day.|
01634|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0217.wav|||There were more varied, and at times, especially when beer had circulated freely, more uproarious diversions.|
01635|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0218.wav|||Wrestling, in which legs were occasionally broken, was freely indulged in; also such low games as "cobham,"|
01636|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0219.wav|||leap-frog, puss in the corner, and "fly the garter," for which purpose the rugs were spread out to prevent feet slipping on the floor.|
01637|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0220.wav|||Feasting alternated with fighting.|
01638|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0221.wav|||The weekly introduction of food, to which I shall presently refer, formed the basis of luxurious banquets, washed down by liquor|
01639|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0222.wav|||and enlivened by flash songs and thrilling long-winded descriptions of robberies and other "plants."|
01640|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0223.wav|||There was much swearing and bad language, the very worst that could be used, from the first thing in the morning to the last thing at night.|
01641|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0224.wav|||New arrivals, especially the innocent and still guileless debutant, were tormented with rude horse-play, and assailed by the most insulting "chaff."|
01642|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0225.wav|||If any man presumed to turn in too early|
01643|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0226.wav|||he was "toed," that is to say, a string was fastened to his big toe while he was asleep, and he was dragged from off his mat,|
01644|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0227.wav|||or his bedclothes were drawn away across the room.|
01645|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0228.wav|||The ragged part of the prisoners were very anxious to destroy the clothes of the better dressed, and often lighted small pieces of cloth,|
01646|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0229.wav|||which they dropped smoldering into their fellow-prisoners' pockets.|
01647|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0230.wav|||Often the victim, goaded to madness, attacked his tormentors; a fight was then certain to follow.|
01648|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0231.wav|||These fights sometimes took place in the daytime, when a ring was regularly formed, and two or three stood by the door to watch for the officer's approach.|
01649|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0232.wav|||More often they occurred at night, and were continued to the bitter end.|
01650|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0233.wav|||The prisoners in this way administered serious punishment on one another. Black eyes and broken noses were always to be seen.|
01651|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0234.wav|||More cruel injuries were common enough, which did not result from honest hand-to-hand fights.|
01652|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0235.wav|||The surgeon's journal produced to the inspectors contained numerous entries of terrible wounds inflicted in a cowardly way.|
01653|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0236.wav|||A serious accident: one of the prisoners had a hot poker run into his eye.|
01654|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0237.wav|||A lad named Matthew White has had a wound in his eye by a bone thrown at him, which very nearly destroyed vision.|
01655|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0238.wav|||nan|
01656|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0239.wav|||During the tumult a prisoner, who was one of the worst of the rioters, was bruised about the head and body.|
01657|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0240.wav|||Watkins' knee-joint is very severely injured.|
01658|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0241.wav|||A prisoner Baxter is in the infirmary in consequence of a severe injury to his wrist-joint.|
01659|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0242.wav|||Watkins' case, referred to above, is made the subject of another and a special report from the surgeon.|
01660|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0243.wav|||He was in the transport side, when one of his fellows, in endeavoring to strike another prisoner with a large poker, missed his aim, and struck Watkins' knee|
01661|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0244.wav|||Violent inflammation and extensive suppuration ensued, and for a considerable time amputation seemed inevitable.|
01662|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0245.wav|||After severe suffering prolonged for many months, the inflammation was subdued, but the cartilage of the knee-joint was destroyed, and he was crippled for life.|
01663|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0246.wav|||On another occasion a young man, who was being violently teased, seized a knife and stabbed his tormentor in the back.|
01664|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0247.wav|||The prisoner who used the knife was secured, but it was the wardsman, and not the officers, to whom the report was made, and no official inquiry or punishment followed.|
01665|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0248.wav|||Matters were at times still worse, and the rioting went on to such dangerous lengths as to endanger the safety of the building.|
01666|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0249.wav|||On one occasion a disturbance was raised which was not quelled until windows had been broken and forms and tables burnt.|
01667|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0250.wav|||The officers were obliged to go in among the prisoners to restore order with drawn cutlasses,|
01668|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0251.wav|||but the presence and authority of the governor himself became indispensable.|
01669|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0252.wav|||The worst fights occurred on Sunday afternoons; but nearly every night the act of locking up became, from the consequent removal of all supervision,|
01670|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0253.wav|||the signal for the commencement of obscene talk, revelry, and violence.|
01671|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0254.wav|||Other regulations laid down by the Jail Acts were still defied. One of these was that prisoners should be restricted to the jail allowance of food;|
01672|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0255.wav|||but all could still obtain as much extra, and of a luxurious kind, as their friends chose to bring them in.|
01673|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0256.wav|||Visitors were still permitted to come with supplies on given days of the week, about the only limitation being that the food should be cooked, and cold;|
01674|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0257.wav|||hot meat, poultry, and fish were also forbidden.|
01675|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0258.wav|||But the inspectors found in the ward cupboards mince-pies and other pasties, cold joints, hams, and so forth.|
01676|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0259.wav|||Many other articles were introduced by visitors, including money, tobacco, pipes, and snuff.|
01677|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0260.wav|||From the same source came the two or three strong files which the inspectors found in one ward,|
01678|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0261.wav|||together with four bradawls, several large iron spikes, screws, nails, and knives;|
01679|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0262.wav|||all of them instruments calculated to facilitate attempts at breaking out of prison,|
01680|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0263.wav|||and capable of becoming most dangerous weapons in the hands of desperate and determined men.|
01681|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0264.wav|||The nearly indiscriminate admission of visitors, although restricted to certain days, continued to be an unmixed evil.|
01682|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0265.wav|||The untried might see their friends three times a week, the convicted only once.|
01683|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0266.wav|||On these occasions precautions were supposed to be taken to exclude bad characters,|
01684|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0267.wav|||yet many persons of notoriously loose life continually obtained egress.|
01685|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0268.wav|||Women saw men if they merely pretended to be wives; even boys were visited by their sweethearts.|
01686|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0269.wav|||Decency was, however, insured by a line of demarcation, and visitors were kept upon each side of a separated double iron railing.|
01687|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0270.wav|||But no search was made to intercept prohibited articles at the gate, and there was no permanent gate-keeper,|
01688|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0271.wav|||which would have greatly helped to keep out bad characters. Some idea of the difficulty and inconvenience of these lax regulations as regards visiting,|
01689|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0272.wav|||may be gathered from the statement that as many as three hundred were often admitted on the same day|
01690|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0273.wav|||enough to altogether upset what small show of decorum and discipline was still preserved in the prison.|
01691|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0274.wav|||Perhaps the worst feature of the visiting system was the permission accorded to male prisoners "under the name of husbands, brothers, and sons"|
01692|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0275.wav|||to have access to the female side on Sundays and Wednesdays, in order to visit their supposed relations there.|
01693|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0276.wav|||On this female side, where the Ladies' Association still reigned supreme, more system and a greater semblance of decorum was maintained.|
01694|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0277.wav|||But there were evils akin to those on the male side, prominent amongst which was the undue influence accorded to prisoners.|
01695|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0278.wav|||A female prisoner kept the registers.|
01696|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0279.wav|||Wards-women were allowed much the same authority, with the same temptations to excess, and intoxication was not unknown among them and others.|
01697|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0280.wav|||The clothing was still meager and ragged: the washing places insufficient, and wanting in decency;|

01699|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0282.wav|||the pump was the only provision, and this in a place within sight of visitors, of the windows of the male turnkeys, and unprotected from the weather.|
01700|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0283.wav|||There was the same crowding in the sleeping arrangements as on the male side; the same scarcity of bedding.|
01701|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0284.wav|||It was a special evil of this part of the prison, that the devotional exercises, originally so profitable, had grown into a kind of edifying spectacle,|
01702|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0285.wav|||which numbers of well-meaning but inquisitive people were anxious to witness.|
01703|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0286.wav|||Thus, when the inspectors visited there were twenty-three strangers, and only twenty-eight prisoners.|
01704|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0287.wav|||The presence of so many strangers, many of them gentlemen, distracted the prisoners' attention, and could not be productive of much good.|
01705|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0288.wav|||The separation of the sexes was not indeed rigidly carried out in Newgate as yet.|
01706|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0289.wav|||We have seen that male prisoners visited their female relations and friends on the female side. Besides this,|
01707|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0290.wav|||the gatesman who prepared the briefs had interviews with female prisoners alone while taking their instructions; a female came alone and unaccompanied by a matron|

01710|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0293.wav|||and the men could also at any time go for tea, coffee, and sugar to Mrs. Brown's shop, which was inside the female gate.|
01711|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0294.wav|||In the bail-dock, where most improper general association was permitted, the female prisoners were often altogether in the charge of male turnkeys.|
01712|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0295.wav|||The governor was also personally responsible for gross contravention of this rule of separation,|
01713|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0296.wav|||and was in the habit of drawing frequently upon the female prison for prisoners to act as domestic servants in his own private dwelling.|
01714|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0297.wav|||Some member of the Ladies' Association observed and commented upon the fact that a "young rosy-cheeked girl" had been kept by the governor from transportation,|
01715|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0298.wav|||while older women in infirm health were sent across the seas.|
01716|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0299.wav|||His excuse was that he had given the girl his promise that she should not go, an assumption of prerogative which by no means rested with him;|
01717|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0300.wav|||but he afterwards admitted that the girl had been recommended to him by the principal turnkey, who knew something of her friends.|
01718|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ006-0301.wav|||This woman was really his servant, employed to help in cleaning, and taken on whenever there was extra work to be done.|

01740|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0015.wav|||it had the bad effect of distracting attention,|
01741|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0016.wav|||it tended to "dissipate reflection, diminish the gloom of the prison, and mitigate the punishment which the law has sentenced the prisoner to undergo."|
01742|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0017.wav|||It is to be feared too that although the surface was thus whitewashed and decorous, much that was vicious still festered and rankled beneath,|
01743|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0018.wav|||and that when the restraining influences of the ladies were absent, the female prisoners relapsed into immoral and uncleanly discourse.|
01744|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0019.wav|||Even in the daytime, when supervision was withdrawn, "the language used to be dreadful," says one of the women when under examination;|
01745|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0020.wav|||swearing and talking of what crimes they had committed, and how they had done it. Another witness declared she had heard the most shocking language in the yard; she said|
01746|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0021.wav|||she had never witnessed such scenes before, and hopes she never shall again -- it was dreadful!|
01747|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0022.wav|||After locking-up time, which varied, as on the male side, according to the daylight, the scenes were often riotous and disgraceful.|
01748|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0023.wav|||The poor, who could afford no luxuries, went to bed early, but were kept awake by the revelries of the rich,|
01749|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0024.wav|||who supped royally on the supplies provided from outside, and kept it up till ten or eleven o'clock.|
01750|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0025.wav|||There were frequent quarrels and fights; shoes and other missiles were freely bandied about;|
01751|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0026.wav|||and with all this "the most dreadful oaths, the worst language, too bad to be repeated," were made use of every night.|
01752|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0027.wav|||Bad as were the various parts of the jail already dealt with,|
01753|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0028.wav|||there still remained one where the general callous indifference and mismanagement culminated in cruel culpable neglect.|
01754|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0029.wav|||The condition of the capitally-convicted prisoners after sentence was still very disgraceful. The side they occupied, still known as the press-yard,|
01755|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0030.wav|||consisted of two dozen rooms and fifteen cells. In these various chambers, until just before the inspectors made their report,|
01756|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0031.wav|||all classes of the condemned, those certain to suffer, and the larger number who were nearly certain of a reprieve,|
01757|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0032.wav|||were jumbled up together, higgledy-piggledy, the old and the young, the murderer and the child who had broken into a dwelling.|
01758|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0033.wav|||All privacy was impossible under the circumstances.|
01759|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0034.wav|||At times the numbers congregated together were very great; as many as fifty and sixty, even more, were crowded indiscriminately into the press-yard.|
01760|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0035.wav|||The better-disposed complained bitterly of what they had to endure;|
01761|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0036.wav|||one man declared that the language of the condemned rooms was disgusting, that he was dying a death every day in being compelled to associate with such characters.|
01762|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0037.wav|||In the midst of the noisy and blasphemous talk no one could pursue his meditations; any who tried to pray became the sport and ridicule of his brutal fellows.|
01763|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0038.wav|||Owing to the repeated entreaties of the criminals who could hardly hope to escape the gallows, some show of classification was carried out,|
01764|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0039.wav|||and when the inspectors visited Newgate they found the three certain to die in a day-room by themselves;|
01765|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0040.wav|||in a second room were fourteen more who had every hope of a reprieve.|
01766|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0041.wav|||The whole of these seventeen had, however, a common airing-yard, and took their exercise there at the same time,|
01767|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0042.wav|||so that men in the most awful situation, daily expecting to be hanged,|

01769|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0044.wav|||The latter, light-hearted and reckless, conducted themselves in the most unseemly fashion, and "with as much indifference as the inmates of the other parts of the prison."|
01770|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0045.wav|||They amused themselves after their own fashion; played all day long at blind-man's-buff and leap-frog, or beat each other with a knotted handkerchief,|
01771|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0046.wav|||laughing and uproarious, utterly unmindful of the companionship of men upon whom lay the shadow of an impending shameful death.|
01772|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0047.wav|||Men whose cases were dangerous, and those most seriously inclined, complained of these annoyances,|

01788|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0063.wav|||It is only fair to Mr. Cotton to add that, according to his own journal, he was unremitting in his attentions to convicts who were actually cast for death,|

01796|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0071.wav|||in the face of impediments confessedly discouraging|
01797|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0072.wav|||as regards the private teaching of prisoners; and they went on to say that "a resolved adherence, in spite of discouragements the most disheartening,|
01798|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0073.wav|||to that line of conduct which his duty imposed on him|
01799|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0074.wav|||would, it is probable, have eventually overcome the reluctance of some of the prisoners at least, and would have possessed so much moral dignity|
01800|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0075.wav|||as effectually to rebuke and abash the profane spirit of the more insolent and daring of the criminals.|
01801|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0076.wav|||The lax discipline maintained in Newgate was still further deteriorated by the presence of two other classes of prisoners who ought never to have been inmates of such a jail.|
01802|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0077.wav|||One of these were the criminal lunatics, who were at this time and for long previous continuously imprisoned there.|
01803|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0078.wav|||As the law stood since the passing of the ninth George the fourth c. forty, any two justices might remove a prisoner found to be insane, either on commitment|
01804|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0079.wav|||or arraignment, to an asylum, and the Secretary of State had the same power as regards any who became insane while undergoing sentence.|
01805|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0080.wav|||These powers were not invariably put in force, and there were in consequence many unhappy lunatics in Newgate and other jails,|
01806|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0081.wav|||whose proper place was the asylum.|
01807|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0082.wav|||At the time the Lords' Committee sat there were eight thus retained in Newgate, and a return in the appendix of the Lords' report|
01808|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0083.wav|||gives a total of thirty-nine lunatics confined in various jails, many of them guilty of murder and other serious crimes.|
01809|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0084.wav|||The inspectors in the following year, on examining the facts, found that some of these poor creatures had been in confinement for long periods:|
01810|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0085.wav|||at Newgate and York Castle as long as five years; "at Ilchester and Morpeth for seven years; at Warwick for eight years,|
01811|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0086.wav|||at Buckingham and Hereford for eleven years|
01812|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0087.wav|||at Appleby for thirteen years, at Anglesea for fifteen years, at Exeter for sixteen years, and at Pembroke|
01813|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0088.wav|||for not less a period than twenty-four years.|
01814|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0089.wav|||It was manifestly wrong that such persons, "visited by the most awful of calamities," should be detained in a common prison.|
01815|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0090.wav|||Not only did their presence tend greatly to interfere with the discipline of the prison, but their condition was deplorable in the extreme.|
01816|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0091.wav|||The lunatic became the sport of the idle and the depraved. His cure was out of the question;|
01817|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0092.wav|||he was placed in a situation "beyond all others calculated to confirm his malady and prolong his sufferings."|
01818|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0093.wav|||The matter was still further complicated at Newgate by the presence within the walls of sham lunatics. Some of those included in the category|
01819|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0094.wav|||had actually been returned as sane from the asylum to which they had been sent, and there was always some uncertainty as to who was mad and who not.|
01820|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0095.wav|||Prisoners indeed were known to boast that they had saved their necks by feigning insanity.|
