01827|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0102.wav|||Pilgrim, Bond, and Clamp, had refused to give evidence before the House of Commons' Committee; a Speaker's warrant was issued for their arrest when they absconded.|
01828|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0103.wav|||Mr. J. E. Sparrow and Mr. Clipperton|
01829|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0104.wav|||the parliamentary agents of the members whose election was impugned, were implicated in aiding and abetting the others to abscond, and a Mr. O'Mally,|
01830|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0105.wav|||counsel for the two M.P.'s, was also concerned.|
01831|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0106.wav|||Pilgrim and Dasent were caught and given into the custody of the sergeant-at-arms, and the rest were either arrested or they surrendered.|
01832|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0107.wav|||A resolution at once passed the House without division to commit the whole to Newgate, where they remained for various terms.|
01833|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0108.wav|||Dasent and Pilgrim were released in ten days, on making due submission.|
01834|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0109.wav|||O'Mally sent in a medical certificate, declaring that the imprisonment was endangering his life, and after some question he was also released.|
01835|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0110.wav|||The rest were detained for more than a month, it being considered that they were the most guilty, as being either professional agents, who advised the others to abscond,|
01836|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0111.wav|||or witnesses who did not voluntarily come forward when the chance was given them.|
01837|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0112.wav|||Many of the old customs once prevalent in the State Side, so properly condemned and abolished,|
01838|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0113.wav|||were revived for the convenience of these gentlemen, whose incarceration was thus rendered as little like imprisonment as possible.|
01839|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0114.wav|||A certain number, who could afford the high rate of a guinea per diem, fixed by the under sheriff, were lodged in the governor's house,|
01840|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0115.wav|||slept there, and had their meals provided for them from the Sessions House or London Coffee-House.|
01841|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0116.wav|||A few others, who could not afford a payment of more than half a guinea, were permitted to monopolize a part of the prison infirmary,|
01842|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0117.wav|||where the upper ward was exclusively appropriated to their use. They also had their meals sent in, and, with the food, wine almost ad libitum.|
01843|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0118.wav|||A prisoner, one of the wardsmen, waited on those in the infirmary; the occupants of the governor's house had their own servants, or the governor's.|
01844|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0119.wav|||As a rule, visitors, many of them persons of good position, came and went all day long, and as late as nine at night;|
01845|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0120.wav|||some to the infirmary, many more to the governor's house.|
01846|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0121.wav|||There were no restraints, cards and backgammon were played, and the time passed in feasting and revelry.|
01847|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0122.wav|||Even Mr. Cope admitted that the committal of this class of prisoners to Newgate was most inconvenient,|
01848|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0123.wav|||and the inspectors expressed themselves still more strongly in reprehension of the practice.|
01849|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0124.wav|||The infirmary at this particular period epitomized the condition of the jail at large.|
01850|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0125.wav|||It was diverted from its proper uses, and, as the "place of the greatest comfort," was allotted to persons who should not have been sent to Newgate at all.|
01851|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0126.wav|||All the evils of indiscriminate association were strongly accentuated by the crowd collected within its narrow limits.|
01852|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0127.wav|||It may easily be imagined, say the inspectors, in speaking of the prison generally,|
01853|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0128.wav|||nan|
01854|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0129.wav|||the sane and the insane, the young and the old, the trivial offender and the man about to suffer the extreme penalty of the law,|
01855|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0130.wav|||are all huddled together without discrimination, oversight, or control."|
01856|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0131.wav|||Enough has probably been extracted from this most damnatory report to give a complete picture of the disgraceful state in which Newgate still remained in eighteen thirty-five.|
01857|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0132.wav|||The inspectors, however, honestly admitted that although the site of the prison was convenient, its construction was as bad as bad could be.|
01858|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0133.wav|||Valuable space was cumbered with many long and winding passages, numerous staircases, and unnecessarily thick and cumbrous inner walls.|
01859|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0134.wav|||The wards were in some cases spacious, but they were entirely unsuited for separation or the inspection of prisoners.|
01860|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0135.wav|||The yards were narrow and confined, mainly because the ground plan was radically vicious. These were evils inseparable from the place.|
01861|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0136.wav|||But there were others remediable under a better system of management.|
01862|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0137.wav|||More attention to ventilation, which was altogether neglected and inadequate, would have secured a better atmosphere for the unhappy inmates|
01863|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0138.wav|||who constantly breathed an air heavy, and, when the wards were first opened in the morning, particularly offensive.|
01864|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0139.wav|||Again, the discipline commonly deemed inseparable from every place of durance was entirely wanting.|
01865|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0140.wav|||The primary object of committing a prisoner to jail, as the inspectors pointed out, was to deter not only the criminal himself, but others from crime,|
01866|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0141.wav|||and "to dispose him, by meditation and seclusion, to return to an honest life."|
01867|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0142.wav|||But at Newgate the convicted prisoner, instead of privation and hard fare,|
01868|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0143.wav|||nan|
01869|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0144.wav|||and he can almost invariably procure the luxuries of his class of life, beer and tobacco, in abundance.|
01870|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0145.wav|||Instead of seclusion and meditation, his time is passed in the midst of a body of criminals of every class and degree, in riot, debauchery, and gaming,|
01871|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0146.wav|||vaunting his own adventures, or listening to those of others;|
01872|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0147.wav|||communicating his own skill and aptitude in crime, or acquiring the lessons of greater adepts. He has access to newspapers, and of course|
01873|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0148.wav|||prefers that description which are expressly prepared for his own class, and which abound in vulgar adventure in criminal enterprise, and in the histories of the police,|
01874|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0149.wav|||the jail, and the scaffold.|
01875|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0150.wav|||He is allowed intercourse with prostitutes who, in nine cases out of ten, have originally conduced to his ruin;|
01876|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0151.wav|||and his connection with them is confirmed by that devotion and generosity towards their paramours in adversity for which these otherwise degraded women are remarkable.|
01877|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0152.wav|||Having thus passed his time, he returns a greater adept in crime, with a wider acquaintance among criminals, and, what perhaps is even more injurious to him,|
01878|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0153.wav|||is generally known to all the worst men in the country; not only without the inclination, but almost without the ability of returning to an honest life."|
01879|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0154.wav|||These pungent and well-grounded strictures applied with still greater force to the unconvicted prisoner, the man who came to the prison innocent, and still uncontaminated,|
01880|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0155.wav|||to be subjected to the same baneful influences, and to suffer the same moral deterioration, whether ultimately convicted or set free.|
01881|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0156.wav|||The whole system, or more correctly the want of system, was baneful and pernicious to the last degree.|
01882|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0157.wav|||The evils of such association were aggravated by the unbroken idleness; one "evil inflamed the other;" reformation|
01883|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0158.wav|||or any kind of moral improvement was impossible; the prisoner's career was inevitably downward, till he struck the lowest depths.|
01884|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0159.wav|||Forced and constant intercourse with the most depraved individuals of his own class;|
01885|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0160.wav|||the employment of those means and agents by which the lowest passions and the most vulgar propensities of man are perpetually kept in the highest state of excitement|
01886|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0161.wav|||drink, gaming, obscene and blasphemous language; utter idleness, the almost unrestricted admission of money and luxuries;|
01887|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0162.wav|||uncontrolled conversation with visitors of the very worst description -- prostitutes, thieves, receivers of stolen goods|
01888|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0163.wav|||all the tumultuous and diversified passions and emotions which circumstances like these must necessarily generate|
01889|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0164.wav|||forbid the faintest shadow of a hope that in a soil so unfavorable for moral culture|
01890|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0165.wav|||any awakening truth, salutary exhortation, or imperfect resolutions of amendment can take root or grow.|
01891|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0166.wav|||Strong as were the foregoing remarks, the inspectors wound up their report in still more trenchant language|
01892|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0167.wav|||framing a terrible indictment against those responsible for the condition of Newgate. Their words deserve to be quoted in full.|
01893|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0168.wav|||We cannot close these remarks, say the inspectors, "without an expression of the painful feelings with which we submit to your Lordship|
01894|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0169.wav|||this picture of the existing state of Newgate|
01895|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0170.wav|||That in this vast metropolis, the center of wealth, civilization, and information;|
01896|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0171.wav|||distinguished as the seat of religion, worth, and philanthropy,|
01897|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0172.wav|||where is to be found in operation every expedient by which Ignorance may be superseded by Knowledge, Idleness by Industry, and Suffering by Benevolence;|
01898|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0173.wav|||that in the metropolis of this highly-favored country, to which the eyes of other lands turn for example, a system of prison discipline such as that enforced in Newgate|
01899|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0174.wav|||should be for a number of years in undisturbed operation, not only in contempt of religion and humanity,|
01900|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0175.wav|||but in opposition to the recorded denunciations of authority, and in defiance of the express enactments of the law,|
01901|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0176.wav|||is indeed a subject which cannot but impress every considerate mind with humiliation and sorrow.|
01902|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0177.wav|||We trust, however, that the day is at hand when this stain will be removed from the character of the city of London,|
01903|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0178.wav|||and when the first municipal authority of our land will be no longer subjected to the reproach of fostering an institution which outrages the rights and feelings of humanity,|
01904|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0179.wav|||defeats the ends of justice, and disgraces the profession of a Christian country.|
01905|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0180.wav|||The publication of this report raised a storm in the city, and the corporation was roused to make an immediate protest.|
01906|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0181.wav|||A committee of aldermen was forthwith appointed to report upon the inspectors' report,|
01907|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0182.wav|||and the result was another lengthy blue book, printed in the parliamentary papers, eighteen thirty-six,|
01908|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0183.wav|||traversing where it was possible the statements of the inspectors, and offering explanation and palliation of such evils as could not be denied.|
01909|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0184.wav|||The inspectors retorted without loss of time, reiterating their charges, and pointing out that the committee of aldermen by its own admission|
01910|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0185.wav|||justified the original allegations. It was impossible to deny the indiscriminate association; the gambling, drinking, smoking, quarreling in the jail;|
01911|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0186.wav|||the undue authority given to prisoners, the levying of garnish under another name|
01912|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0187.wav|||the neglect of the condemned convicts, the filthy condition of the wards, the insufficiency of bedding and clothing,|
01913|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0188.wav|||the misemployment of officers and prisoners by the governor.|
01914|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0189.wav|||The corporation evidently had the worst of it, and began to feel the necessity for undertaking the great work of reform.|
01915|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0190.wav|||Next year we find the inspectors expressing their satisfaction that "the full and faithful exposure which we felt it our duty to make of Newgate|
01916|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0191.wav|||has been productive of at least some advantage,|
01917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0192.wav|||inasmuch as it has aroused the attention of those upon whom parliamentary reports and grand jury presentments had hitherto failed to make the slightest impression.|
01918|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0193.wav|||The measures of improvement introduced were mainly as follows:|
01919|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0194.wav|||the fixing of "inspection holes" in the doors and walls, so as to insure more supervision; of windows opening into the well-holes,|
01920|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0195.wav|||to give better light and ventilation; the construction of bed-places, three tiers high alongside the walls for males, two tiers for females;|
01921|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0196.wav|||the provision of dining-rooms and dining-tables.|
01922|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0197.wav|||The infirmary was enlarged, the admission of visitors limited, and the passing of articles prevented by a wire screen.|
01923|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0198.wav|||The windows were to be glazed and painted to prevent prisoners from looking out;|
01924|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0199.wav|||baths, fumigating places for clothing, wash-house, and the removal of dust-bins, completed the new arrangements in the main prison.|
01925|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0200.wav|||In the press-yard, the press-room and ward above it were parceled out into nine separate sleeping cells;|
01926|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0201.wav|||each was provided with an iron bedstead, and a small desk at which the condemned man might read or write.|
01927|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0202.wav|||But the one great and most crying evil remained unremedied.|
01928|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0203.wav|||The mischief of jail associations, say the inspectors,|
01929|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0204.wav|||nan|
01930|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0205.wav|||is not only permitted still to exist in the prison, but is rendered more powerful than before.|
01931|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0206.wav|||In endeavoring to arrest contamination, prisoners were more closely confined, and associated in smaller numbers;|
01932|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0207.wav|||but this had the effect of throwing them into closer contact, and of making them more intimately acquainted with, more directly influential upon, one another.|
01933|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0208.wav|||In the inspectors' fourth report, dated eighteen thirty-nine,|
01934|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0209.wav|||they return to the charge, and again call the corporation to task for their mismanagement of Newgate.|
01935|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0210.wav|||Abuses and irregularities, which had been partially remedied by the reform introduced in eighteen thirty-seven, were once more in the ascendant.|
01936|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0211.wav|||In our late visits, they say, "we have seen manifest indications of a retrograde movement in this respect,|
01937|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0212.wav|||and a tendency to return to much of that laxity and remissness which formerly marked the management of this prison."|
01938|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0213.wav|||Again the following year the inspectors repeat their charge.|
01939|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0214.wav|||nan|
01940|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0215.wav|||are the association of prisoners, and the unusual contamination to which such association gives rise.|
01941|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0216.wav|||For nearly twenty-two hours out of the twenty-four the prisoners are locked up, during which time no officer is stationed in the ward with them.|
01942|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0217.wav|||They go on to say|
01943|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0218.wav|||Newgate is only less extensively injurious than formerly because it is less crowded.|
01944|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0219.wav|||The effects of the imprisonment are to vitiate its inmates, to extend their acquaintanceship with each other,|
01945|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0220.wav|||to corrupt the prisoner charged with an offense of which he may be innocent, and to confirm in guilt the young and inexperienced offender.|
01946|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0221.wav|||The reports as the years flow on reiterate the same complaints.|
01947|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0222.wav|||Much bitterness of feeling is evidently engendered, and the corporation grows more and more angry with the inspectors.|
01948|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0223.wav|||The prison officials appear to be on the side of the inspectors, to the great dissatisfaction of the corporation, who claimed the full allegiance and support of its servants.|
01949|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0224.wav|||In a resolution passed by the Court of Aldermen on eighteenth March, eighteen forty-two,|
01950|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0225.wav|||I find it ordered "that the ordinary of Newgate be restricted from making any communications to the Home Office|
01951|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0226.wav|||or the Inspectors of Prisons, and that he be required wholly to confine himself to the performance of his duty as prescribed by Act of Parliament.|
01952|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0227.wav|||The inspectors were not to be deterred, however, by any opposition from the earnest discharge of their functions, and continued to report against Newgate.|
01953|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0228.wav|||In their tenth report|
01954|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0229.wav|||they state that they are compelled by an imperative sense of duty to advert in terms of decided condemnation to the lamentable condition of the prisons of the city of London,|
01955|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0230.wav|||Newgate, Giltspur St. Compter, and the City Bridewell,|
01956|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0231.wav|||in which the master evil of jail association and consequent contamination still continues to operate directly to the encouragement of crime.|
01957|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0232.wav|||The plan adopted for ventilating the dining-room on the 'master's side' and that of the middle yard is very inefficient;|
01958|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0233.wav|||it consists of several circular perforations, about two inches in diameter,|
01959|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0234.wav|||slanting downwards from the top of the walls to the outside adjoining the slaughterhouses of Newgate market; and occasionally, in hot weather,|
01960|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0235.wav|||instead of ventilating the apartments, they only serve to convey the offensive effluvia arising from the decaying animal matter into the dining-rooms.|
01961|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0236.wav|||Sometimes the stench in hot weather is said to be very bad.|
01962|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0237.wav|||Many rats also come through these so-called ventilators, as they open close to the ground at the back of the prison.|
01963|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0238.wav|||At the same time the inspectors animadvert strongly upon the misconduct of prisoners and the frequency of prison punishments,|
01964|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0239.wav|||both offenses and punishments affording a sufficient index to the practices going forward; and they wind up by declaring|
01965|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0240.wav|||that a strict compliance with their duties gave them no choice "but to report matters as we found them,|
01966|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0241.wav|||and again and again to protest against Newgate as it at present exists.|
01967|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0242.wav|||No complete and permanent improvement was indeed possible while Newgate remained unchanged.|
01968|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ007-0243.wav|||It was not till the erection of the new prison at Holloway in eighteen fifty, and the entire internal reconstruction of Newgate according to new ideas,|
01969|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0001.wav|||The Chronicles of Newgate, Volume two. By Arthur Griffiths. Section eleven: Executions, part one.|
01970|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0002.wav|||I propose to return now to the subject of Newgate executions,|
01971|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0003.wav|||which we left at the time of the discontinuance of the long-practiced procession to Tyburn.|
01972|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0004.wav|||The reasons for this change were fully set forth in a previous chapter.|
01973|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0005.wav|||The terrible spectacle was as demoralizing to the public, for whose admonition it was intended,|
01974|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0006.wav|||as the exposure was brutal and cruel towards the principal actors.|
01975|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0007.wav|||The decision to remove the scene of action to the immediate front of the jail itself|
01976|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0008.wav|||was in the right direction, as making the performance shorter and diminishing the area of display.|
01977|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0009.wav|||But the Old Bailey was not exclusively used;|
01978|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0010.wav|||at first, and for some few years after seventeen eighty-four, executions took place occasionally at a distance from Newgate.|
01979|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0011.wav|||This was partly due to the survival of the old notion that the scene of the crime ought also to witness the retribution;|
01980|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0012.wav|||partly perhaps because residents in and about the Old Bailey raised a loud protest against the constant erection of the scaffold in their neighborhood.|
01981|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0013.wav|||As regards the first, I find that in seventeen eighty-six|
01982|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0014.wav|||John Hogan, the murderer of a Mr. Odell, an attorney who resided in Charlotte Street, Rathbone Place,|
01983|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0015.wav|||was executed on a gibbet in front of his victim's house.|
01984|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0016.wav|||Lawrence Jones, a burglar, was in seventeen ninety-three ordered for execution in Hatton Garden, near the house he had robbed;|
01985|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0017.wav|||and when he evaded the sentence by suicide, his body was exhibited in the same neighborhood,|
01986|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0018.wav|||extended upon a plank on the top of an open cart, in his clothes, and fettered.|
01987|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0019.wav|||Again, as late as eighteen oh nine and eighteen twelve, Execution Dock, on the banks of the Thames, was still retained.|
01988|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0020.wav|||Here John Sutherland, commander of the British armed transport 'The Friends,' suffered on the twenty-ninth June, eighteen oh nine,|
01989|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0021.wav|||for the murder of his cabin-boy, whom he stabbed after much ill-usage on board the ship as it lay in the Tagus.|
01990|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0022.wav|||On the eighteenth December, eighteen twelve,|
01991|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0023.wav|||two sailors, Charles Palm and Sam Tilling, were hanged at the same place for the murder of their captain, James Keith|

01993|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0025.wav|||They were taken in a cart to the place of execution, amidst a vast concourse of people.|

01996|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0028.wav|||Some indications of pity were offered for the fate of Tilling; Palm, execration alone.|
01997|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0029.wav|||But the Old Bailey gradually, and in spite of all objections urged, monopolized the dread business of execution.|

02001|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0033.wav|||Ten were executed|
02002|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0034.wav|||the scaffold hung with black; and the inhabitants of the neighborhood, having petitioned the sheriffs to remove the scene of execution to the old place,|
02003|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0035.wav|||were told that the plan had been well considered, and would be persevered in.|
02004|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0036.wav|||The following twenty-third April, it is stated that the malefactors ordered for execution on the eighteenth instead|
02005|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0037.wav|||were brought out of Newgate about eight in the morning, and suspended on a gallows of a new construction.|
02006|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0038.wav|||After hanging the usual time they were taken down, and the machine cleared away in half-an-hour.|
02007|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0039.wav|||By practice the art is much improved, and there is no part of the world in which villains are hanged in so neat a manner, and with so little ceremony.|
02008|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0040.wav|||A full description of this new gallows, which was erected in front of the debtors' door, is to be found in contemporary records.|
02009|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0041.wav|||The criminals are not exposed to view till they mount the fatal stage. The last part of the stage, or that next to the jail,|
02010|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0042.wav|||is enclosed by a temporary roof, under which are placed two seats for the reception of the sheriffs, one on each side of the stairs leading to the scaffold.|
02011|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0043.wav|||Round the north, west, and south sides are erected galleries for the reception of officers, attendants, etc.|
02012|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0044.wav|||and at the distance of five feet from the same is fixed a strong railing all round the scaffold to enclose a place for the constables.|
02013|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0045.wav|||In the middle of this machinery is placed a movable platform, in form of a trap-door, ten feet long by eight wide,|
02014|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0046.wav|||on the middle of which is placed the gibbet, extending from the jail across the Old Bailey.|
02015|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0047.wav|||This movable platform is raised six inches higher than the rest of the scaffold, and on it the convicts stand;|
02016|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0048.wav|||it is supported by two beams, which are held in their place by bolts. The movement of the lever withdraws the bolts, the platform falls in;|
02017|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0049.wav|||and this, being much more sudden and regular than that of a cart being drawn away, has the effect of immediate death.|
02018|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0050.wav|||A broadsheet dated April twenty-fourth, seventeen eighty-seven, describing an execution on the newly-invented scaffold before the debtors' door,|
02019|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0051.wav|||says, "The scaffold on which these miserable people suffered is a temporary machine which was drawn out of the yard of the sessions house by horses;|
02020|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0052.wav|||it is supported by strong posts fixed into grooves made in the street;|
02021|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0053.wav|||the whole is temporary, being all calculated to take to pieces, which are preserved within the prison."|
02022|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0054.wav|||This contrivance appears to have been copied with improvements from that which had been used in Dublin at a still earlier date,|
02023|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0055.wav|||for that city claims the priority in establishing the custom of hanging criminals at the jail itself.|
02024|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0056.wav|||The Dublin "engine of death," as the gallows are styled in the account from which the following description is taken, consisted of an iron bar|
02025|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0057.wav|||parallel to the prison wall, and about four feet from it, but strongly affixed thereto with iron scroll clamps.|
02026|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0058.wav|||From this bar hang several iron loops, in which the halters are tied.|
02027|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0059.wav|||Under this bar at a proper distance is a piece of flooring or platform,|
02028|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0060.wav|||projecting somewhat beyond the range of the iron bar, and swinging upon hinges affixed to the wall.|
02029|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0061.wav|||The entrance upon this floor or leaf is from the middle window over the gate of the prison;|
02030|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0062.wav|||and this floor is supported below,|
02031|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0063.wav|||while the criminals stand upon it, by two pieces of timber, which are made to slide in and out of the prison wall through apertures made for that purpose.|
02032|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0064.wav|||When the criminals are tied up and prepared for their fate, this floor suddenly falls down, upon withdrawing the supporters inwards.|
02033|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0065.wav|||They are both drawn at once by a windlass, and the unhappy culprits remain suspended.|
02034|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0066.wav|||This mode of execution, it is alleged, gave rise to the old vulgar "chaff," "Take care, or you'll die at the fall of the leaf."|
02035|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0067.wav|||The machinery in use in Dublin is much the same as that employed at many jails now-a-days.|
02036|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0068.wav|||But the fall apart and inwards of two leaves is considered superior.|

02044|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0076.wav|||When she came out of prison she appeared languid and terrified, and trembled greatly as she advanced to the stake,|
02045|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0077.wav|||where the apparatus for the punishment she was about to experience|
02046|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0078.wav|||seemed to strike her mind with horror and consternation, to the exclusion of all power of recollectedness in preparation for the approaching awful moment.|
02047|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0079.wav|||She walked from the debtors' door to a stake fixed in the ground about half-way between the scaffold and Newgate Street.|

02086|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0118.wav|||Thank you, sir, said the governor to the doctor, "it is of little moment."|

02108|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0140.wav|||Whenever the public attention had been specially called to a particular crime, either on account of its atrocity,|
02109|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0141.wav|||the doubtfulness of the issue, or the superior position of the perpetrator,|
02110|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0142.wav|||the attendance at the execution was certain to be tumultuous, and the conduct of the mob disorderly.|
02111|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0143.wav|||This was notably the case at the execution of Holloway and Haggerty|
02112|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0144.wav|||in eighteen oh seven, an event long remembered from the fatal and disastrous consequences which followed it.|
02113|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0145.wav|||They were accused by a confederate, who, goaded by conscience, had turned approver, of the murder of a Mr. Steele,|
02114|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0146.wav|||who kept a lavender warehouse in the city, and who had gardens at Feltham,|
02115|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0147.wav|||whither he often went to distill the lavender, returning to London the same evening.|
02116|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0148.wav|||One night he was missing|
02117|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0149.wav|||and after a long interval his dead body was discovered, shockingly disfigured, in a ditch. This was in eighteen oh two.|
02118|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0150.wav|||Four years passed without the detection of the murderers,|
02119|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0151.wav|||but in the beginning of eighteen oh seven one of them, at that time just sentenced to transportation,|
02120|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0152.wav|||made a full confession, and implicated Holloway and Haggerty.|
02121|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0153.wav|||They were accordingly apprehended and brought to trial, the informer, Hanfield by name, being accepted as king's evidence.|
02122|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0154.wav|||Conviction followed mainly on his testimony; but the two men, especially Holloway, stoutly maintained their innocence to the last.|
02123|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0155.wav|||Very great excitement prevailed in the town throughout the trial, and this greatly increased when the verdict was known.|
02124|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0156.wav|||An enormous crowd assembled to witness the execution, amounting, it was said, to the hitherto unparalleled number of forty thousand.|
02125|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0157.wav|||By eight o'clock not an inch of ground in front of the platform was unoccupied.|
02126|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0158.wav|||The pressure soon became so frightful that many would have willingly escaped from the crowd; but their attempts only increased the general confusion.|
02127|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0159.wav|||Very soon women began to scream with terror;|
02128|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0160.wav|||some, especially of low stature, found it difficult to remain standing, and several, although held up for some time by the men nearest them,|
02129|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0161.wav|||presently fell, and were at once trampled to death.|
02130|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0162.wav|||Cries of Murder! murder! were now raised, and added greatly to the horrors of the scene.|
02131|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0163.wav|||Panic became general. More women, children, and many men were borne down, to perish beneath the feet of the rest.|
02132|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0164.wav|||The most affecting and distressing scene was at Green Arbor Lane, just opposite the debtors' door of the prison.|
02133|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0165.wav|||Here a couple of piemen had been selling their wares; the basket of one of them, which was raised upon a four-legged stool, was upset.|
02134|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0166.wav|||The pieman stooped down to pick up his scattered stock, and some of the mob, not seeing what had happened, stumbled over him.|
02135|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0167.wav|||No one who fell ever rose again.|
02136|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0168.wav|||Among the rest was a woman with an infant at the breast.|
02137|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0169.wav|||She was killed, but in the act of falling she forced her child into the arms of a man near her, and implored him in God's name to save it;|
02138|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0170.wav|||the man, needing all his care for his own life, threw the child from him,|
02139|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0171.wav|||and it passed along the heads of the crowd, to be caught at last by a person who struggled with it to a cart and deposited it there in safety.|
02140|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0172.wav|||In another part seven persons met their death by suffocation.|
02141|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0173.wav|||In this convulsive struggle for bare existence people fought fiercely with one another, and the weakest, of course the women, went under.|
02142|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0174.wav|||One cart-load of spectators having broken down, some of its occupants fell off the vehicle, and were instantly trampled to death.|
02143|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0175.wav|||This went on for more than an hour, and until the malefactors were cut down and the gallows removed;|
02144|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0176.wav|||then the mob began to thin, and the streets were cleared by the city marshals and a number of constables.|
02145|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0177.wav|||The catastrophe exceeded the worst anticipations. Nearly one hundred dead and dying lay about; and after all had been removed,|
02146|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0178.wav|||the bodies for identification, the wounded to hospitals, a cart-load of shoes, hats, petticoats, and fragments of wearing apparel were picked up.|
02147|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0180.wav|||Among the dead was a sailor lad whom no one knew;|
02148|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0181.wav|||he had his pockets filled with bread and cheese, and it was generally supposed that he had come a long distance to see the fatal show.|
02149|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0182.wav|||A tremendous crowd assembled when Bellingham was executed in eighteen twelve for the murder of Spencer Percival, at that time prime minister;|
02150|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0183.wav|||but there were no serious accidents, beyond those caused by the goring of a maddened, over-driven ox which forced its way through the crowd.|
02151|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0184.wav|||Precautions had been taken by the erection of barriers, and the posting of placards at all the avenues to the Old Bailey, on which was printed,|
02152|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0185.wav|||Beware of entering the crowd! Remember thirty poor persons were pressed to death by the crowd when Haggerty and Holloway were executed!|
02153|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0186.wav|||The concourse was very great, notwithstanding these warnings.|
02154|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0187.wav|||It was still greater at Fauntleroy's execution in eighteen twenty-four, when no less than one hundred thousand persons assembled, it was said.|
02155|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0188.wav|||Every window and roof which could command a view of the horrible performance was occupied.|
02156|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0189.wav|||All the avenues and approaches, places even whence nothing whatever could be seen of the scaffold,|
02157|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0190.wav|||were blocked by persons who had overflowed from the area in front of the jail.|
02158|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0191.wav|||At Courvoisier's execution in eighteen forty it was the same, or worse.|
02159|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0192.wav|||As early as six a.m. the number assembled already exceeded that seen on ordinary occasions;|
02160|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0193.wav|||by seven a.m. the whole space was so thronged that it was impossible to move one way or the other.|
02161|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0194.wav|||Some persons were kept for more than five hours standing against the barriers, and many nearly fainted from exhaustion.|
02162|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0195.wav|||Every window had its party of occupants; the adjoining roofs were equally crowded.|
02163|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0196.wav|||High prices were asked and paid for front seats or good standing room. As much as five pounds was given for the attic story|
02164|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0197.wav|||of the Lamb's Coffee House;|
02165|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0198.wav|||two pounds was a common price for a window.|
02166|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0199.wav|||At the George public-house to the south of the drop, Sir W. Watkin Wynn, Baronet,|
02167|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0200.wav|||hired a room for the night and morning, which he and a large party of friends occupied before and during the execution;|
02168|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0201.wav|||in an adjoining house, that of an undertaker, was Lord Alfred Paget, also with several friends.|
02169|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0202.wav|||Those who had hired apartments spent the night in them, keeping up their courage with liquids and cigars.|
02170|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0203.wav|||Numbers of ladies were present, although the public feeling was much against their attendance.|
02171|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0204.wav|||One well-dressed woman fell out of a first-floor window on to the shoulders of the crowd below, but neither she nor any one else was greatly hurt.|
02172|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0205.wav|||The city authorities had endeavored to take all precautions against panic and excitement among the crowd,|
02173|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0206.wav|||and caused a number of stout additional barriers to be erected in front of the scaffold,|
02174|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0207.wav|||and although one of these gave way owing to the extraordinary pressure, no serious accident occurred.|
02175|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0208.wav|||Some years later an eye-witness published a graphic account of one of these scenes.|
02176|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0209.wav|||Soon after midnight on the Sunday night, for by this time the present practice of executing on Monday morning had been pretty generally introduced,|
02177|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0210.wav|||the crowd began to congregate in and about the Old Bailey.|
02178|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0211.wav|||Gin-shops and coffee-houses were the first to open doors, and touts began to bid for tenants for the various rooms upstairs.|
02179|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0212.wav|||Cries of "Comfortable room!" "Excellent situation!" "Beautiful prospect!" "Splendid view!" resounded on every side.|
02180|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0213.wav|||By this time the workmen might be heard busily erecting the gallows;|
02181|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0214.wav|||the sounds of hammer and saw intermingled with the broad jeers and coarse jests of the rapidly increasing mob.|
02182|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0215.wav|||One by one the huge uprights of black timber were fitted together,|
02183|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0216.wav|||until presently the huge stage loomed dark above the crowd which was now ranged round the barriers;|
02184|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0217.wav|||a throng of people whom neither rain, snow, storm, nor darkness ever hindered from attending the show.|
02185|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0218.wav|||They were mainly members of the criminal classes.|
02186|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0219.wav|||their conversation was of companions and associates of former years, long ago imprisoned, transported, hanged, while they,|
02187|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0220.wav|||hoary-headed and hardened in guilt, were still at large.|
02188|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0221.wav|||They talked of the days when the convicts were hung up a dozen or more in a row;|
02189|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0222.wav|||of those who had shown the white, and those who had died game.|
02190|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0223.wav|||The approaching ceremony had evidently no terrors for these "idolaters of the gallows."|
02191|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0224.wav|||With them were younger men and women:|
02192|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0225.wav|||the former already vowed to the same criminal career, and looking up to their elders with the respect due to successful practitioners;|
02193|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0226.wav|||the latter unsexed and brutalized by dissipation,|
02194|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0227.wav|||slipshod and slovenly, in crushed bonnet and dirty shawl, the gown fastened by a single hook,|
02195|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0228.wav|||their harsh and half-cracked voices full of maudlin, besotted sympathy for those about to die.|
02196|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0229.wav|||Above the murmur and tumult of that noisy assembly, the lowing and bleating of cattle as they were driven into the stalls and pens of Smithfield|
02197|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0230.wav|||fell with a strange unnatural sound upon the ear|
02198|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0231.wav|||Hush! the unceasing murmur of the mob now breaks into a loud deep roar,|
02199|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0232.wav|||a sound as if the ocean had suddenly broken through some ancient boundary, against which its ever restless billows had for ages battered;|
02200|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0233.wav|||the wide dark sea of heads is all at once in motion;|
02201|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0234.wav|||each wave seems trying to overleap the other as they are drawn onwards towards this outlet.|
02202|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0235.wav|||Every link in that great human chain is shaken, along the whole lengthened line has the motion jarred, and each in turn sees,|
02203|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0236.wav|||coiled up on the floor of the scaffold like a serpent, the hangman's rope!|
02204|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0237.wav|||The human hand that placed it there was only seen for a moment,|
02205|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0238.wav|||as it lay, white and ghastly, upon the black boards, and then again was as suddenly withdrawn, as if ashamed of the deed it had done.|
02206|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0239.wav|||The loud shout of the multitude once more subsided, or only fell upon the abstracted ear like the dreamy murmur of an ocean shell.|
02207|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0240.wav|||Then followed sounds more distinct and audible, in which ginger-beer, pies, fried fish, sandwiches, and fruit|
02208|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0241.wav|||were vended under the names of notorious murderers, highwaymen, and criminals,|
02209|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0242.wav|||famous in the annals of Newgate for the hardihood they had displayed in the hour of execution, when they terminated their career of crime at the gallows.|
02210|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0243.wav|||Threading his way among these itinerant vendors was seen the meek-faced deliverer of tracts, the man of good intentions, now bonneted,|
02211|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0244.wav|||now laughed at, the skirt of his seedy black coat torn across; yet,|
02212|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0245.wav|||though pulled right and left, or sent headlong into the crowd by the swing of some brutal and muscular arm,|
02213|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0246.wav|||Never once from that pale face passed away its benign and patient expression.|
02214|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0247.wav|||but ever the same form moved along in the fulfillment of his mission, in spite of all persecution.|
02215|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0248.wav|||Another fight followed the score which had already taken place; this time two women were the combatants.|
02216|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0249.wav|||Blinded with their long hair, they tore at each other like two furies; their bonnets and caps were trodden underfoot in the kennel,|
02217|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0250.wav|||and lay disregarded beside the body of the poor dog which, while searching for its master in the crowd,|
02218|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0251.wav|||was an hour before kicked to death by the savage and brutal mob.|
02219|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0252.wav|||Another deep roar, louder than any which had preceded it, broke from the multitude.|
02220|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0253.wav|||Then came the cry of 'Hats off!' and 'Down in front!' as at a theatre.|
02221|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0254.wav|||It was followed by the deep and solemn booming of the death-bell from the church of St. Sepulchre|
02222|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0255.wav|||the iron knell that rang upon the beating heart of the living man who was about to die;|
02223|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0256.wav|||and with blanched cheek, and sinking, we turned away from the scene.|
02224|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0257.wav|||In thus describing the saturnalia before the gallows I have been drawn on somewhat beyond the period with which I am at present dealing.|
02225|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0258.wav|||Let me retrace my steps, and speak more in detail of the treatment of the condemned in those bloodthirsty and brutally indifferent days,|
02226|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0259.wav|||and of their demeanor after sentence until the last penalty was paid.|
02227|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0260.wav|||One of the worst evils was the terrible and long-protracted uncertainty as to the result.|
02228|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0261.wav|||In the case of convicted murderers only was prompt punishment inflicted,|
02229|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0262.wav|||and with them indeed this dispatch amounted to undue precipitancy.|
02230|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0263.wav|||Forty-eight hours was the limit of time allowed to the unhappy man to make his peace, and during that time he was still kept on a bare allowance of bread and water.|
02231|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0264.wav|||But the murderers formed only a small proportion of the total number sentenced to death, and for the rest there was a long period of anxious suspense,|
02232|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0265.wav|||although in the long run mercy generally prevailed, and very few capitally convicted for crimes less than murder actually suffered.|
02233|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0266.wav|||Thus in the years between May first, eighteen twenty-seven, and thirtieth April, eighteen thirty-one,|
02234|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0267.wav|||no less than four hundred and fifty-one sentences of death for capital crimes were passed at the Old Bailey;|
02235|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0268.wav|||but of these three hundred and ninety-six were reversed by the king in council, and only fifty-two were really executed.|
02236|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0269.wav|||Already the severity of our criminal code, and the number of capital felonies upon the statute book, had brought a reaction;|
02237|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0270.wav|||and while the courts adhered to the letter of the law, appeals were constantly made to the royal prerogative of mercy.|
02238|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0271.wav|||This was more particularly the practice in London.|
02239|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0272.wav|||Judges on assize were satisfied with simply recording a sentence of death against offenders whom they did not think deserved the extreme penalty.|
02240|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0273.wav|||At the Old Bailey almost every one capitally convicted by a jury was sentenced to be hanged.|
02241|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0274.wav|||The result in the latter case was left in the first place to the king in council,|
02242|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0275.wav|||but there was a further appeal then, as now, to the king himself, or practically to the Home Secretary.|
02243|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0276.wav|||Neither in town or country were cases entirely taken on their own merits.|
02244|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0277.wav|||Convicted offenders might have good or bad luck; they might be arraigned when their particular crime was uncommon, and were then nearly certain to escape;|
02245|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0278.wav|||or theirs might be one of many, and it might be considered necessary to "make an example."|
02246|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0279.wav|||In this latter it might fairly be said that a man was put to death less for his own sins than for the crimes of others.|
02247|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0280.wav|||The absurdity of the system, its irregularity and cruelty, were fully touched upon by the inspectors of prisons in their first report.|
02248|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0281.wav|||They found at Newgate, under disgraceful conditions as already described,|
02249|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0282.wav|||seventeen capital convicts, upon all of whom the sentence of death had been passed. Eventually two only of the whole number suffered;|
02250|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0283.wav|||two others were sentenced to three months' imprisonment, and the balance to varying terms.|
02251|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0284.wav|||Nothing could be more strongly marked than the contrast between the ultimate destiny of different individuals all abiding the same awful doom:|
02252|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0285.wav|||on the one hand the gallows, on the other a short imprisonment.|
02253|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0286.wav|||The inspectors very properly desired to call attention to the inevitable tendency in this mode of dealing with "the most awful sanctions of the law,"|
02254|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0287.wav|||to make those sanctions an object of contemptuous mockery.|
02255|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0288.wav|||The consequences were plainly proved to the inspectors.|
02256|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0289.wav|||Capitally convicted prisoners did, as a matter of fact, "treat with habitual and inexpressible levity the sentence of death."|
02257|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0290.wav|||Of this I have treated at length in the last chapter.|
02258|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0291.wav|||The time thus spent varied considerably,|
02259|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0292.wav|||but it was seldom less than six weeks. It all depended upon the sovereign's disposition to do business.|
02260|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0293.wav|||Sometimes the Privy Council did not meet for months, and during all that time the convicts languished with hope|
02261|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0294.wav|||nearly indefinitely deferred.|
02262|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0295.wav|||When the council had decided, the news was conveyed to Newgate by the Recorder, who made his "report," as it was called.|
02263|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0296.wav|||The time of the arrival of this report was generally known at Newgate,|
02264|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0297.wav|||and its contents were anxiously awaited by both convicts in the press-yard and their friends collected in a crowd outside the gates.|
02265|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0298.wav|||Sometimes the report was delayed.|
02266|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0299.wav|||On one occasion, Mr. Wakefield tells us, the Recorder, who had attended the council at Windsor, did not deliver the report till the following day.|
02267|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0300.wav|||The prisoners and their friends, therefore, were kept in a state of the most violent suspense for many hours,|
02268|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0301.wav|||during which they counted the moments -- the prisoners in their cells as usual, and their friends in the street in front of Newgate, where they passed the night.|
02269|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0302.wav|||I have heard the protracted agony of both classes described by those who witnessed it in terms so strong, that I am unwilling to repeat them.|
02270|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0303.wav|||The crowd of men and women who passed the night in front of Newgate, began, as soon as the hour was passed when they had expected the report,|
02271|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0304.wav|||to utter imprecations against the Recorder, the Secretary of State, the Council, and the King;|
02272|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0305.wav|||they never ceased cursing until the passion of anger so excited was exchanged for joy in some and grief in others.|
02273|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0306.wav|||I myself heard more than one of those whose lives were spared by that decision of the council,|
02274|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0307.wav|||afterwards express a wish to murder the Recorder for having kept them so long in suspense.|
02275|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0308.wav|||The Recorder's report generally reached Newgate late at night.|
02276|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0309.wav|||Its receipt was immediately followed by the promulgation of its contents to the persons most closely concerned,|
02277|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0310.wav|||which was done with a sort of ceremony intended to be impressive.|
02278|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0311.wav|||The whole of the convicts were assembled together in one ward, and made to kneel down.|
02279|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0312.wav|||To them entered the chaplain or ordinary of Newgate in full canonicals,|
02280|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0313.wav|||who in solemn tones communicated to each in turn the fate in store for him.|
02281|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0314.wav|||The form of imparting the intelligence was generally the same.|
02282|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0315.wav|||So-and-so, I am sorry to tell you that it is all against you; or,|
02283|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0316.wav|||A. B., your case has been taken into consideration by the king in council, and His Majesty has been mercifully pleased to spare your life.|
02284|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0317.wav|||The fatal news was not always received in the same way.|
02285|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0318.wav|||The men who were doomed often fell down in convulsions upon the floor.|
02286|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ008-0319.wav|||Sometimes any who had had a narrow escape fainted, but the bulk of those respited looked on with unfeeling indifference.|
02287|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0001.wav|||The Chronicles of Newgate, Volume two. By Arthur Griffiths. Section twelve: Executions, part two.|
02288|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0002.wav|||It is satisfactory to be able to record that some consideration was shown the capital convict actually awaiting execution.|
02289|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0003.wav|||Even so severe a critic as Mr. Wakefield states that "a stranger to the scene|
02290|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0004.wav|||would be astonished to observe the peculiar tenderness, I was going to add respect,|
02291|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0005.wav|||which persons under sentence of death obtain from all the officers of the prison.|
02292|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0006.wav|||Before sentence a prisoner has only to observe the regulations of the jail in order to remain neglected and unnoticed.|
02293|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0007.wav|||Once ordered to the cells, friends of all classes suddenly rise up; his fellow-prisoners, the turnkeys, the chaplain,|
02294|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0008.wav|||the keepers, and the sheriffs all seem interested in his fate, and he can make no reasonable request that is not at once granted by whomsoever he may address.|
02295|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0009.wav|||This rule has some, but very few, exceptions; such as where a hardened offender behaves with great levity and brutality, as if he cared nought for his life,|
02296|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0010.wav|||and thought every one anxious to promote his death.|
02297|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0011.wav|||Mr. Wakefield goes on to remark that persons convicted of forgery "excited an extraordinary degree of interest in all who approached them."|
02298|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0012.wav|||This was noticeable with Fauntleroy, who, on account of his birth and antecedents, was allowed to occupy a turnkey's room,|
02299|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0013.wav|||and kept altogether separate from the other prisoners until the day of his death.|
02300|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0014.wav|||It cannot be denied, however, that the ordinary's treatment was somewhat unfeeling, and in proof thereof|
02301|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0015.wav|||I will quote an extract from the reverend gentleman's own journal.|
02302|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0016.wav|||He seems to have improved the occasion when preaching the condemned sermon before Fauntleroy, by pointing a moral from that unhappy man's own case.|
02303|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0017.wav|||For this the chaplain was a few days later summoned before the jail committee of aldermen,|
02304|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0018.wav|||and informed that the public would not in future be admitted to hear the condemned sermon. "I was also informed," writes Mr. Cotton,|
02305|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0019.wav|||that this resolution was in consequence of their (the aldermen's) disapproving of the last discourse delivered by me,|
02306|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0020.wav|||previous to the execution of Henry Fauntleroy for uttering a forged security|
02307|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0021.wav|||in which it was said I had enlarged upon the heinous nature of his crime, and warned the public to avoid such conduct.|
02308|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0022.wav|||I was informed that this unnecessarily harassed his feelings, and that the object of such sermons was solely to console the prisoner,|
02309|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0023.wav|||and that from the time of his conviction nothing but what is consolatory should be addressed to a criminal.|
02310|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0024.wav|||One of the aldermen, moreover, informed me that the whole court of aldermen were unanimous in their opinion on this subject.|
02311|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0025.wav|||As to the exclusion of strangers on these occasions,|
02312|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0026.wav|||the experience I have had convinces me that one, and perhaps the only, good of an execution, i. e. the solemn admonition to the public,|
02313|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0027.wav|||will thereby be lost.|
02314|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0028.wav|||Probably the reader will side with the aldermen against the ordinary.|
02315|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0029.wav|||This episode throws some doubt upon the tenderness and proper feeling exhibited by the chaplain towards the most deserving members of his criminal flock;|
02316|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0030.wav|||and the idea will be strengthened by the following account of the Sunday service in the prison chapel on the occasion when the condemned sermon was preached.|
02317|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0031.wav|||The extract is from Mr. E. Gibbon Wakefield's brochure, the date eighteen twenty-eight, just three years after Fauntleroy's death.|
02318|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0032.wav|||Strangers were now excluded, but the sheriffs attended in state, wearing their gold chains,|
02319|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0033.wav|||while behind their pew stood a couple of tall footmen in state liveries.|
02320|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0034.wav|||The sheriffs were in one gallery;|
02321|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0035.wav|||in the other opposite were the convicts capitally convicted who had been respited.|
02322|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0036.wav|||Down below between the galleries was the mass of the prison population;|
02323|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0037.wav|||the schoolmaster and the juvenile prisoners being seated round the communion-table, opposite the pulpit.|
02324|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0038.wav|||In the center of the chapel was the condemned pew, a large dock-like erection painted black.|
02325|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0039.wav|||Those who sat in it were visible to the whole congregation, and still more to the ordinary,|
02326|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0040.wav|||whose desk and pulpit were just in front of the condemned pew, and within a couple of yards of it.|
02327|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0041.wav|||The occupants of this terrible black pew were the last always to enter the chapel.|
02328|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0042.wav|||Upon the occasion which I am describing they were four in number; and here I will continue the narrative in Mr. Wakefield's own words:|
02329|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0043.wav|||First is a youth of eighteen, condemned for stealing in a dwelling-house goods valued above five pounds.|
02330|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0044.wav|||His features have no felonious cast;|
02331|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0045.wav|||he steps boldly with head upright, looks to the women's gallery, and smiles. His intention is to pass for a brave fellow,|
02332|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0046.wav|||but the attempt fails; he trembles, his knees knock together, and his head droops as he enters the condemned pew.|
02333|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0047.wav|||The next convict is clearly and unmistakably a villain.|
02334|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0048.wav|||He is a hardened offender, previously cast for life, reprieved, transported to Australia, and since returned without pardon.|
02335|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0049.wav|||For this offense the punishment is death.|
02336|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0050.wav|||He has, however, doubly earned his sentence, and is actually condemned for burglary committed since his arrival in England.|
02337|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0051.wav|||His look at the sheriffs and the ordinary is full of scorn and defiance.|
02338|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0052.wav|||The third convict is a sheep-stealer, a poor ignorant fellow in whose crime are mitigating circumstances,|
02339|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0053.wav|||but who is left to die on the supposition that this is not his first conviction, and still more because a good many sheep have of late been stolen by other people.|
02340|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0054.wav|||He is quite content to die;|
02341|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0055.wav|||indeed the chaplain and others have brought him firmly to believe that his situation is enviable, and that the gates of heaven are open to receive him.|
02342|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0056.wav|||The last of the four is said to have been a clergyman of the Church of England, condemned for forgery, "a miserable old man in a tattered suit of black.|
02343|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0057.wav|||Already he is half dead.|
02344|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0058.wav|||Great efforts have been made to save his life.|
02345|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0059.wav|||Friends, even utter strangers, have interceded for him, and to the last he has buoyed himself up by hope of reprieve.|
02346|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0060.wav|||Now his doom is sealed irrevocably, and he has given himself up to despair.|
02347|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0061.wav|||He staggers towards the pew, reels into it, stumbles forward, flings himself on the ground, and, by a curious twist of the spine,|
02348|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0062.wav|||buries his head under his body.|
02349|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0063.wav|||The sheriffs shudder, their inquisitive friends crane forward, the keeper frowns on the excited congregation,|
02350|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0064.wav|||the lately smirking footmen close their eyes and forget their liveries, the ordinary clasps his hands, the turnkeys cry 'Hush!'|
02351|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0065.wav|||and the old clerk lifts up his cracked voice, saying, 'Let us sing to the praise and glory of God.'|
02352|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0066.wav|||The morning hymn is sung first, as if to remind the condemned that next morning at eight a.m. they are to die.|
02353|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0067.wav|||The service proceeds. At last the burial service is reached.|
02354|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0068.wav|||The youth alone is able to read, but from long want of practice he is at a loss to find the place in his prayer-book.|
02355|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0069.wav|||The ordinary observes him, looks to the sheriffs, and says aloud, 'The service for the dead!'|
02356|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0070.wav|||The youth's hands tremble as they hold the book upside down.|
02357|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0071.wav|||The burglar is heard to mutter an angry oath.|
02358|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0072.wav|||The sheep-stealer smiles, and, extending his arms upwards, looks with a glad expression to the roof of the chapel.|
02359|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0073.wav|||The forger has never moved.|
02360|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0074.wav|||Let us pass on.|
02361|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0075.wav|||All have sung 'the Lamentation of a Sinner,' and have seemed to pray 'especially for those now awaiting the awful execution of the law.'|
02362|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0076.wav|||We come to the sermon.|
02363|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0077.wav|||The ordinary of Newgate is an orthodox, unaffected, Church of England divine,|
02364|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0078.wav|||who preaches plain, homely discourses, as fit as any religious discourse can be fit for the irritated audience.|
02365|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0079.wav|||The sermon of this day, whether eloquent or plain, useful or useless, must produce a striking effect at the moment of its delivery.|
02366|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0080.wav|||The text, without another word, is enough to raise the wildest passions of the audience|
02367|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0081.wav|||For a while the preacher addresses himself to the congregation at large, who listen attentively|
02368|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0082.wav|||except the clergyman and the burglar, the former of whom is still rolled up at the bottom of the condemned pew,|
02369|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0083.wav|||while the eyes of the latter are wandering round the chapel, and one of them is occasionally winked impudently at some acquaintance amongst the prisoners for trial.|
02370|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0084.wav|||At length the ordinary pauses, and then, in a deep tone, which, though hardly above a whisper, is audible to all, says,|
02371|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0085.wav|||'Now for you, my poor fellow mortals, who are about to suffer the last penalty of the law.'|
02372|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0086.wav|||But why should I repeat the whole?|
02373|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0087.wav|||It is enough to say that in the same solemn tone he talks about the minutest of crimes, punishments, bonds, shame,|
02374|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0088.wav|||ignominy, sorrow, sufferings, wretchedness, pangs,|
02375|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0089.wav|||childless parents, widows and helpless orphans, broken and contrite hearts, and death tomorrow morning for the benefit of society.|
02376|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0090.wav|||The dying men are dreadfully agitated.|
02377|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0091.wav|||The young stealer in a dwelling-house no longer has the least pretense to bravery. He grasps the back of the pew,|
02378|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0092.wav|||his legs give way, he utters a faint groan, and sinks on the floor.|
02379|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0093.wav|||Why does no one stir to help him? Where would be the use? The hardened burglar moves not, nor does he speak;|
02380|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0094.wav|||but his face is of an ashy paleness; and if you look carefully you may see the blood trickling from his lip,|
02381|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0095.wav|||which he has bitten unconsciously, or from rage, or to rouse his fainting courage.|
02382|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0096.wav|||The poor sheep-stealer is in a frenzy.|
02383|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0097.wav|||He throws his hands far from him, and shouts aloud, 'Mercy, good Lord! mercy is all I ask. The Lord in His mercy come!|
02384|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0098.wav|||There! there! I see the Lamb of God! Oh! how happy! Oh! this is happy!|
02385|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0099.wav|||Meanwhile the clergyman, still bent into the form of a sleeping dog,|
02386|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0100.wav|||struggles violently; his feet, legs, hands, and arms, even the muscles of his back,|
02387|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0101.wav|||move with a quick, jerking motion, not naturally, but, as it were, like the affected parts of a galvanized corpse.|
02388|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0102.wav|||Suddenly he utters a short sharp scream, and all is still.|
02389|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0103.wav|||The silence is short. As the ordinary proceeds 'to conclude,'|
02390|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0104.wav|||the women set up a yell, which is mixed with a rustling noise, occasioned by the removal of those whose hysterics have ended in fainting.|
02391|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0105.wav|||The sheriffs cover their faces, and one of their inquisitive friends blows his nose with his glove.|
02392|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0106.wav|||The keeper tries to appear unmoved, but his eye wanders anxiously over the combustible assembly.|
02393|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0107.wav|||The children round the communion-table stare and gape with childish wonder.|
02394|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0108.wav|||The two masses of prisoners for trial undulate and slightly murmur,|
02395|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0109.wav|||while the capital convicts who were lately in that black pew appear faint with emotion.|
02396|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0110.wav|||This exhibition lasts for some minutes, and then the congregation disperses,|
02397|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0111.wav|||the condemned returning to the cells: the forger carried by turnkeys; the youth sobbing aloud convulsively, as a passionate child;|
02398|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0112.wav|||the burglar muttering curses and savage expressions of defiance; whilst the poor sheep-stealer shakes hands with the turnkeys,|
02399|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ009-0113.wav|||whistles merrily, and points upwards with madness in his look.|
