03361|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0161.wav|||he was reported to have fallen away to a shadow.|
03362|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0162.wav|||Having brought down the records of great frauds, forgeries, and thefts from about eighteen twenty-five to eighteen forty,|
03363|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0163.wav|||I will now retrace my steps and give some account of the more remarkable murders during that period.|
03364|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0164.wav|||No murder has created greater sensation and horror throughout England than that of Mr. Weare by Thurtell, Hunt, and Probert.|
03365|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0165.wav|||As this was accomplished beyond the limits of the metropolis, and its perpetrators arraigned at Hertford,|
03366|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0166.wav|||where the principal actor suffered death, the case hardly comes within the limits of my subject.|
03367|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0167.wav|||But Probert, who turned king's evidence, and materially assisted conviction,|
03368|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0168.wav|||was tried at the Old Bailey the following year for horse-stealing, and hanged in front of Newgate.|
03369|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0169.wav|||The murder was still fresh in the memory of the populace, and Probert was all but lynched on his way to jail.|
03370|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0170.wav|||According to his statement, when sentenced to death, he had been driven to horse-stealing by the execration which had pursued him after the murder.|
03371|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0171.wav|||Every door had been closed against him, every hope of future support blasted.|
03372|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0172.wav|||Since the calamitous event," he went on, "that happened at Hertford, I have been a lost man."|
03373|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0173.wav|||The event which he styles calamitous we may well characterize as one of the most deliberately atrocious murders on record.|
03374|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0174.wav|||Thurtell was a gambler, and Weare had won a good deal of money from him.|
03375|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0175.wav|||Weare was supposed to carry a "private bank" about with him in a pocket in his under waistcoat.|
03376|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0176.wav|||To obtain possession of this, Thurtell with his two associates resolved to kill him.|
03377|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0177.wav|||The victim was invited to visit Probert's cottage in the country near Elstree.|
03378|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0178.wav|||Thurtell drove him down in a gig, "to be killed as he traveled," in Thurtell's own words.|
03379|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0179.wav|||The others followed, and on overtaking Thurtell, found he had done the job alone in a retired part of the road known as Gill's Hill Lane.|
03380|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0180.wav|||The murderer explained that he had first fired a pistol at Weare's head, but the shot glanced off his cheek.|
03381|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0181.wav|||Then he attacked the other's throat with a penknife, and last of all drove the pistol barrel into his forehead.|
03382|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0182.wav|||After the murder the villains divided the spoil, and went on to Probert's cottage, and supped off pork-chops brought down on purpose.|
03383|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0183.wav|||During the night they sought to dispose of the body by throwing it into a pond, but two days later had to throw it into another pond.|
03384|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0184.wav|||Meanwhile the discovery of pistol and knife spattered with human blood and brains|
03385|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0185.wav|||raised the alarm, and suspicion fell upon the three murderers, who were arrested.|
03386|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0186.wav|||The crime was brought home to Thurtell by the confession of Hunt,|
03387|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0187.wav|||one of his accomplices, who took the police to the pond, where the remains of the unfortunate Mr. Weare were discovered, sunk in a sack weighted by stones.|
03388|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0188.wav|||Probert was then admitted as a witness, and the case was fully proved against Thurtell, who was hanged in front of Hertford Jail.|
03389|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0189.wav|||Hunt, in consideration of the information he had given, escaped death, and was sentenced to transportation for life.|
03390|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0190.wav|||Widespread horror and indignation was evoked throughout the kingdom by the discovery of the series|
03391|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0191.wav|||of atrocious murders perpetrated in Edinburgh by the miscreants Burke and Hare,|
03392|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0192.wav|||the first of whom has added to the British language a synonym for illegal suppression.|
03393|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0193.wav|||The crimes of these inhuman purveyors to medical science do not fall within the limits of this work.|
03394|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0194.wav|||But Burke and Hare had their imitators further south,|
03395|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0195.wav|||and of these Bishop and Williams, who were guilty of many peculiar atrocities, ended their murderous careers in front of the debtors' door at Newgate.|
03396|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0196.wav|||Bishop, whose real name was Head, married a half-sister of Williams'. Williams was a professional resurrectionist, or body-snatcher,|
03397|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0197.wav|||a trade almost openly countenanced when "subjects" for the anatomy schools were only to be got by rifling graves, or worse.|
03398|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0198.wav|||Bishop was a carpenter, but having been suddenly thrown out of work, he joined his brother-in-law in his line of business.|
03399|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0199.wav|||After a little|
03400|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0200.wav|||Bishop got weary of the dangers and fatigues of exhumation, and proposed to Williams that instead of disinterring they should murder their subjects.|
03401|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0201.wav|||Bishop confessed that he was moved to this by the example of Burke and Hare.|
03402|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0202.wav|||They pursued their terrible trade for five years without scruple and without detection.|
03403|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0203.wav|||Eventually the law overtook them, but almost by accident.|
03404|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0204.wav|||They presented themselves about noon one day at the dissecting room of King's College Hospital, accompanied by a third man,|
03405|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0205.wav|||an avowed "snatcher" and habitué of the Fortune of War, a public-house in Smithfield frequented openly by men of this awful profession.|
03406|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0206.wav|||This man, May, asked the porter at King's College if "he wanted anything?" the euphemism for offering a body.|
03407|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0207.wav|||The porter asked what he had got, and the answer was, a male subject.|
03408|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0208.wav|||Reference was made to Mr. Partridge, the demonstrator in anatomy,|
03409|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0209.wav|||and after some haggling they agreed on a price, and in the afternoon the snatchers brought a hamper which contained a body in a sack.|
03410|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0210.wav|||The porter received it, but from its freshness became suspicious of foul play.|
03411|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0211.wav|||Mr. Partridge was sent for, and he with some of the students soon decided that the corpse had not died a natural death.|
03412|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0212.wav|||The snatchers were detained, the police sent for, and arrest followed as a matter of course.|
03413|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0213.wav|||An inquest was held on the body, which was identified as that of an Italian boy,|
03414|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0214.wav|||Carlo Ferrari, who made a living by exhibiting white mice about the streets,|
03415|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0215.wav|||and the jury returned a verdict of willful murder against persons unknown, expressing a strong opinion that Bishop,|
03416|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0216.wav|||Williams, and May had been concerned in the transaction.|
03417|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0217.wav|||Meanwhile, a search had been made at Nova Scotia Gardens, Bethnal Green, where Bishop and Williams lived.|
03418|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0218.wav|||At first nothing peculiar was found; but at a second search the back-garden ground was dug up,|
03419|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0219.wav|||and in one corner, at some depth, a bundle of clothes were unearthed, which, with a hairy cap,|
03420|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0220.wav|||were known to be what Ferrari had worn when last seen.|
03421|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0221.wav|||In another portion of the garden more clothing, partly male and partly female, was discovered,|
03422|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0222.wav|||plainly pointing to the perpetration of other crimes.|
03423|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0223.wav|||These facts were represented before the police magistrate|
03424|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0224.wav|||who examined Bishop and his fellows, and further incriminating evidence adduced, to the effect that the prisoners had bartered for a coach to carry "a stiff 'un";|
03425|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0225.wav|||they had also been seen to leave their cottage, carrying out a sack with something heavy inside. On this they were fully committed to Newgate for trial.|
03426|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0226.wav|||This trial came off in due course at the Central Criminal Court, where the prisoners were charged on two counts,|
03427|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0227.wav|||one that of the murder of the Italian boy, the other that of a boy unknown.|
03428|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0228.wav|||The evidence from first to last was circumstantial,|
03429|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0229.wav|||but the jury, after a short deliberation, did not hesitate to bring in a verdict of guilty, and all three were condemned to death.|
03430|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0230.wav|||Shortly before the day fixed for execution, Bishop made a full confession, the bulk of which bore the impress of truth,|
03431|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0231.wav|||although it included statements that were improbable and unsubstantiated.|
03432|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0232.wav|||He asserted that the victim was a Lincolnshire lad, and not an Italian boy, although the latter was fully proved.|
03433|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0233.wav|||According to the confession, death had been inflicted by drowning in a well, whereas the medical evidence all pointed to violence.|
03434|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0234.wav|||It was, however, pretty clear that this victim, like preceding ones, had been lured to Nova Scotia Gardens, and there drugged with a large dose of laudanum.|
03435|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0235.wav|||While they were in a state of insensibility the murder was committed.|

03437|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0237.wav|||A very painful scene occurred in Newgate when the news of his escape from death was imparted to May.|
03438|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0238.wav|||He fainted, and the warrant of mercy nearly proved his death-blow. The other two looked on at his agitation with an indifference amounting to apathy.|
03439|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0239.wav|||The execution took place a week or two later, in the presence of such a crowd as had not been seen near Newgate for years.|
03440|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0240.wav|||I will close this chapter with a brief account of another murder,|
03441|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0241.wav|||the memory of which is still fresh in the minds of Londoners, although half a century has passed since it was committed.|
03442|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0242.wav|||The horror with which Greenacre's crime struck the town was unparalleled since the time when Catherine Hayes slew her husband.|
03443|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0243.wav|||There were many features of resemblance in these crimes.|
03444|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0244.wav|||The decapitation and dismemberment, the bestowal of the remains in various parts of the town, the preservation of the head in spirits of wine,|
03445|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0245.wav|||in the hope that the features might some day be recognized, were alike in both.|
03446|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0246.wav|||The murder in both cases was long a profound mystery. In this which I am now describing,|
03447|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0247.wav|||a bricklayer found a human trunk near some new buildings in the Edgeware Road, one morning in the last week of eighteen thirty-six.|
03448|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0248.wav|||The inquest on these remains, which medical examination showed to be those of a female,|
03449|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0249.wav|||returned a verdict of willful murder against some person unknown.|
03450|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0250.wav|||On the seventh July, eighteen thirty-seven,|
03451|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0251.wav|||the lockman of "Ben Jonson lock," in Stepney Fields, found a human head jammed into the lock gates.|
03452|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0252.wav|||Closer investigation proved that it belonged to the trunk already discovered on the second February.|
03453|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0253.wav|||A further discovery was made in an osier bed near Cold Harbor Lane, Camberwell,|
03454|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0254.wav|||where a workman found a bundle containing two human legs, in a drain.|
03455|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0255.wav|||These were the missing members of the same mutilated trunk,|
03456|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0256.wav|||and there was now evidence sufficient to establish conclusively that the woman thus collected piecemeal had been barbarously done to death.|
03457|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0257.wav|||But the affair still remained a profound mystery. No light was thrown upon it till, towards the end of March,|
03458|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0258.wav|||a Mr. Gay of Goodge Street came to view the head, and immediately recognized it as that of a widowed sister, Hannah Brown,|
03459|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0259.wav|||who had been missing since the previous Christmas Day.|
03460|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0260.wav|||The murdered individual was thus identified. The next step was to ascertain where and with whom she had last been seen.|
03461|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0261.wav|||This brought suspicion on to a certain James Greenacre,|
03462|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0262.wav|||whom she was to have married, and in whose company she had left her own lodgings to visit his in Camberwell.|
03463|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0263.wav|||The police wished to refer to Greenacre, but as he was not forthcoming,|

03465|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0265.wav|||A woman named Gale, who lived with him, was arrested at the same time. The prisoners were examined at the Marylebone police court.|
03466|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0266.wav|||Greenacre, a stout, middle-aged man, wrapped in a brown greatcoat, assumed an air of insolent bravado;|
03467|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0267.wav|||but his despair must have been great, as was evident from his attempt to strangle himself in the station-house.|
03468|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0268.wav|||Suspicion grew almost to certainty as the evidence was unfolded.|
03469|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0269.wav|||Mrs. Brown was a washer-woman, supposed to be worth some money; hence Greenacre's offer of marriage.|
03470|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0270.wav|||She had realized all her effects, and brought them with her furniture to Greenacre's lodgings. The two when married were to emigrate to Hudson's Bay.|
03471|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0271.wav|||Whether it was greed or a quarrel that drove Greenacre to the desperate deed remains obscure.|
03472|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0272.wav|||They were apparently good friends when last seen together at a neighbor's, where they seemed "perfectly happy and sociable, and eager for the wedding day."|
03473|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0273.wav|||But Greenacre in his confession pretended that he and his intended had quarreled over her property or the want of it,|
03474|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0274.wav|||and that in a moment of anger he knocked her down.|
03475|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0275.wav|||He thought he had killed her, and in his terror began at once to consider how he might dispose of the body and escape arrest.|
03476|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0276.wav|||While she was senseless, but really still alive, he cut off her head, and dismembered the body in the manner already described.|
03477|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0277.wav|||It is scarcely probable that he would have gone to this extremity if he had had no previous evil intention,|
03478|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0278.wav|||and the most probable inference is that he inveigled Mrs. Brown to his lodgings with the set purpose of taking her life.|
03479|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0279.wav|||His measures for the disposal of the corpus delicti remind us of those taken by Mrs. Hayes and her associates,|
03480|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0280.wav|||or of Gardelle's frantic efforts to conceal his crime.|
03481|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0281.wav|||The most ghastly part of the story is that which deals with his getting rid of the head.|

03483|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0283.wav|||he carried under his coat-flaps through the streets, and afterwards on his cap in a crowded city omnibus.|

03485|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0285.wav|||Another day elapsed before he got rid of the rest of the body,|

03487|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0287.wav|||On the other hand, it was adduced in evidence that Mrs. Gale had been at his lodgings the very day after the murder,|
03488|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0288.wav|||and was seen to be busily engaged in washing down the house with bucket and mop.|

03493|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ012-0293.wav|||But the medical evidence was clear that the decapitation had been effected during life, and the jury, after a short deliberation,|

03498|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0002.wav|||As the century advanced crimes of fraud increased.|
03499|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0003.wav|||They not only became more numerous, but they were on a wider scale.|
03500|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0004.wav|||The most extensive and systematic robberies were planned and carried out so as long to escape detection.|
03501|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0005.wav|||One of the earliest of the big operators in fraudulent finance was Edward Beaumont Smith,|
03502|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0006.wav|||who was convicted in eighteen forty-one of uttering false exchequer bills to an almost fabulous amount.|
03503|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0007.wav|||A not entirely novel kind of fraud, but one carried out on a larger scale than heretofore,|
03504|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0008.wav|||came to light in this same year, eighteen forty-one.|
03505|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0009.wav|||This was the willful shipwreck and casting away of a vessel which, with her supposed cargo, had been heavily insured.|
03506|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0010.wav|||The 'Dryad' was a brig owned principally by two persons named Wallace, one a seaman, the other merchant.|
03507|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0011.wav|||She was freighted by the firm of Zulueta and Co. for a voyage to Santa Cruz.|
03508|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0012.wav|||Her owners insured her for a full sum of two thousand pounds, after which the Wallaces insured her privily|
03509|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0013.wav|||with other underwriters for a second sum of two thousand pounds.|
03510|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0014.wav|||After this, on the faith of forced bills of lading, the captain, Loose by name,|
03511|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0015.wav|||being a party to the intended fraud, they obtained further insurances on goods never shipped.|
03512|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0016.wav|||It was fully proved in evidence that when the Dryad sailed she carried nothing but the cargo belonging to Zulueta and Co.|
03513|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0017.wav|||Yet the Wallaces pretended to have put on board quantities of flannels, cloths, cotton prints,|
03514|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0018.wav|||beef, pork, butter, and earthenwares, on all of which they effected insurances.|
03515|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0019.wav|||Loose had his instructions to cast away the ship on the first possible opportunity, and from the time of his leaving Liverpool|
03516|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0020.wav|||he acted in a manner which excited the suspicions of the crew.|
03517|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0021.wav|||The larboard pump was suffered to remain choked up, and the long-boat was fitted with tackles and held ready for use at a moment's notice.|
03518|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0022.wav|||The ship, however, met with exasperatingly fine weather, and it was not until the captain reached the West India Islands|
03519|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0023.wav|||that he got a chance of accomplishing his crime.|
03520|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0024.wav|||At a place called the Silver Keys he ran the ship on the reef.|
03521|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0025.wav|||But another ship, concluding that he was acting in ignorance, rendered him assistance.|
03522|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0026.wav|||The 'Dryad' was got off, repaired, and her voyage renewed to Santa Cruz.|
03523|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0027.wav|||He crept along the coast close in shore, looking for a quiet spot to cast away the ship,|
03524|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0028.wav|||and at last, when within fifteen miles of port, with wind and weather perfectly fair, he ran her on to the rocks.|
03525|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0029.wav|||Even then she might have been saved, but the captain would not suffer the crew to act. Nearly the whole of the cargo was lost as well as the ship.|
03526|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0030.wav|||The captain and crew, however, got safely to Jamaica, and so to England; the captain dying on the voyage home.|
03527|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0031.wav|||The crime soon became public.|
03528|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0032.wav|||Mate, carpenter, and crew were eager to disavow complicity, and voluntarily gave information.|
03529|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0033.wav|||The Wallaces were arrested, committed to Newgate, and tried at the Old Bailey.|
03530|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0034.wav|||The case was clearly proved against them, and both were sentenced to transportation for life.|
03531|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0035.wav|||While lying in Newgate, awaiting removal to the convict ship, both prisoners made full confessions.|
03532|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0036.wav|||According to their own statements the loss of the 'Dryad' was only one of six intentional shipwrecks with which they had been concerned.|
03533|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0037.wav|||The crime of fraudulent insurance they declared was very common, and the underwriters must have lost great sums in this way.|
03534|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0038.wav|||The merchant Wallace said he had been led into the crime by the advice and example of a city friend who had gone largely into this nefarious business;|
03535|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0039.wav|||this Wallace added that his friend had made several voyages with the distinct intention of superintending the predetermined shipwrecks.|
03536|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0040.wav|||The other Wallace, the sailor, also traced his lapse into crime to evil counsel.|
03537|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0041.wav|||He was an honest sea-captain, he said, trading from Liverpool, where once he had the misfortune to be introduced to a man of wealth,|
03538|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0042.wav|||the foundations of which had been laid by buying old ships on purpose to cast them away.|
03539|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0043.wav|||This person made much of Wallace, encouraged his attentions to his daughter,|
03540|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0044.wav|||and tempted him to take to fraudulent insurance as a certain method of achieving fortune.|
03541|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0045.wav|||Wallace's relations warned him against his Liverpool friend,|
03542|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0046.wav|||but he would not take their advice, and developing his transactions, ended as we have seen.|
03543|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0047.wav|||A clergyman nearly a century later followed in the steps of Dr. Dodd, but did not under more humane laws lose his life.|
03544|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0048.wav|||The Rev. W. Bailey, LL.D., was convicted at the Central Criminal Court, in February eighteen forty-three, of forgery.|
03545|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0049.wav|||A notorious miser, Robert Smith, had recently died in Seven Dials, where he had amassed a considerable fortune.|
03546|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0050.wav|||But among the charges on the estate he left|
03547|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0051.wav|||was a promissory note for two thousand eight hundred seventy-five pounds, produced by Dr. Bailey, and purporting to be signed by Smith.|
03548|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0052.wav|||The executors to the estate disputed the validity of this document.|
03549|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0053.wav|||Miss Bailey, the doctor's sister, in whose favor the note was said to have been given,|
03550|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0054.wav|||then brought an action against the administrators, and at the trial Dr. Bailey swore that the note had been given him by Smith.|
03551|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0055.wav|||The jury did not believe him, and the verdict was for the defendants.|
03552|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0056.wav|||Subsequently Bailey was arrested on a charge of forgery, and after a long trial found guilty. His sentence was transportation for life.|
03553|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0057.wav|||A gigantic conspiracy to defraud was discovered in the following year, when a solicitor named William Henry Barber,|
03554|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0058.wav|||Joshua Fletcher a surgeon, and three others were charged with forging wills for the purpose of obtaining unclaimed stock in the funds.|
03555|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0059.wav|||There were two separate affairs.|
03556|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0060.wav|||In the first a maiden lady, Miss Slack,|
03557|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0061.wav|||who was the possessor of two separate sums in consols, neglected through strange carelessness on her own part and that of her friends|
03558|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0062.wav|||to draw the dividends on more than one sum.|
03559|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0063.wav|||The other, remaining unclaimed for ten years, was transferred at the end of that time to the commissioners for the reduction of the National Debt.|
03560|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0064.wav|||Barber, it was said, became aware of this,|
03561|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0065.wav|||and that he gained access to Miss Slack on pretense of conveying to her some funded property left her by an aunt.|
03562|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0066.wav|||By this means her signature was obtained; a forged will was prepared bequeathing the unclaimed stock to Miss Slack;|
03563|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0067.wav|||a note purporting to be from Miss Slack was addressed to the governor of the Bank of England, begging that the said stock might be handed over to her,|
03564|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0068.wav|||and a person calling herself Miss Slack duly attended at the bank, where the money was handed over to her in proper form.|
03565|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0069.wav|||A second will, also forged, was propounded at Doctors Commons as that of a Mrs. Hunt of Bristol.|
03566|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0070.wav|||Mrs. Hunt had left money in the funds which remained unclaimed, and had been transferred, as in Miss Slack's case.|
03567|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0071.wav|||Here again the money, with ten years' interest, was handed over to Barber and another calling himself Thomas Hunt, an executor of the will.|
03568|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0072.wav|||It was shown that the will must be a forgery,|
03569|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0073.wav|||as its signature was dated eighteen twenty-nine, whereas Mrs. Hunt actually died in eighteen oh six.|
03570|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0074.wav|||A third similar fraud to the amount of two thousand pounds was also brought to light.|
03571|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0075.wav|||Fletcher was the moving spirit of the whole business. It was he who had introduced Barber to Miss Slack,|
03572|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0076.wav|||and held all the threads of these intricate and nefarious transactions.|
03573|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0077.wav|||Barber and Fletcher were both transported for life, although Fletcher declared that Barber was innocent, and had no guilty knowledge of what was being done.|
03574|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0078.wav|||Barber was subsequently pardoned, but was not replaced on the rolls as an attorney till eighteen fifty-five,|
03575|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0079.wav|||when Lord Campbell delivered judgment on Barber's petition, to the effect that|
03576|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0080.wav|||the evidence to establish his (Barber's) connivance in the frauds was too doubtful for us to continue his exclusion any longer.|
03577|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0081.wav|||Banks and bankers continued to be victimized.|
03578|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0082.wav|||In eighteen forty-four|
03579|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0083.wav|||the Bank of England was defrauded of a sum of eight thousand pounds by one of its clerks, Burgess, in conjunction with an accomplice named Elder.|
03580|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0084.wav|||Burgess fraudulently transferred consols to the above amount, standing in the name of Mr. Oxenford, to another party.|
03581|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0085.wav|||A person, Elder of course, who personated Oxenford, attended at the bank to complete the transfer and sell the stock.|
03582|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0086.wav|||Burgess, who was purposely on leave from the bank, effected the sale, which was paid for with a cheque for nearly the whole amount on Lubbock's Bank.|
03583|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0087.wav|||Burgess and Elder proceeded in company to cash this, but as they wanted all gold,|
03584|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0088.wav|||the cashier gave them eight Bank of England notes for one thousand pounds each, saying that they could get so much specie nowhere else.|
03585|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0089.wav|||Thither Elder went alone, provided with a number of canvas and one large carpet-bag.|
03586|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0090.wav|||But when the latter was filled with gold it was too heavy to lift,|
03587|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0091.wav|||and Elder had to be assisted by two bank porters, who carried it for him to a carriage waiting near the Mansion House.|
03588|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0092.wav|||The thieves, for Elder was soon joined by Burgess, drove together to Ben Caunt's, the pugilist's, public-house in St. Martin's Lane,|
03589|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0093.wav|||where the cash was transferred from the carpet-bag to a portmanteau.|
03590|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0094.wav|||The same evening both started for Liverpool, and embarking on board the mail steamer 'Britannia,' escaped to the United States.|
03591|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0095.wav|||Burgess' continued absence was soon noticed at the bank.|
03592|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0096.wav|||Suspicions were aroused when it was found that he had been employed in selling stock for Mr. Oxenford, which developed into certainty|
03593|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0097.wav|||as soon as that gentleman was referred to.|
03594|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0098.wav|||Mr. Oxenford having denied that he had made any transfer of stock, the matter was at once put into the hands of the police.|
03595|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0099.wav|||A smart detective, Forrester, after a little inquiry,|
03596|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0100.wav|||established the fact that the man who had personated Mr. Oxenford was a horse-dealer named Joseph Elder, an intimate acquaintance of Burgess'.|
03597|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0101.wav|||Forrester next traced the fugitives to Liverpool,|
03598|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0102.wav|||and thence to Halifax, whither he followed them, accompanied by a confidential clerk from the bank.|
03599|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0103.wav|||At Halifax Forrester learnt that the men he wanted had gone on to Boston, thence to Buffalo and Canada, and back to Boston.|
03600|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0104.wav|||He found them at length residing at the latter place, one as a landed proprietor, the other as a publican.|
03601|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0105.wav|||Elder, the former, was soon apprehended at his house, but he evaded the law by hanging himself with his pocket-handkerchief.|
03602|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0106.wav|||The inn belonging to Burgess was surrounded|
03603|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0107.wav|||but he escaped through a back door on to the river, and rowed off in a boat to a hiding-place in the woods.|
03604|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0108.wav|||Next day a person betrayed him for the reward, and he was soon captured.|
03605|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0109.wav|||The proceeds of the robbery were lodged in a Boston bank,|
03606|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0110.wav|||but four hundred sovereigns were found on Elder, while two hundred more were found in Burgess' effects.|
03607|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0111.wav|||Burgess was eventually brought back to England, tried at the Central Criminal Court, and sentenced to transportation for life.|
03608|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0112.wav|||Within a month or two the bank of Messrs. Rogers and Co., Clement's Lane, was broken into.|
03609|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0113.wav|||Robberies as daring in conception as they were boldly executed were common enough.|
03610|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0114.wav|||One night a quantity of plate was stolen from Windsor Castle; another time Buckingham Palace was robbed.|
03611|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0115.wav|||Of this class was the ingenious yet peculiarly simple robbery effected at the house of Lord Fitzgerald in Belgrave Square.|
03612|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0116.wav|||The butler, on the occasion of a death in the family, when the house was in some confusion, arranged with a burglar to come in,|
03613|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0117.wav|||and with another carry off the plate-chest in broad daylight, and as a matter of business. No one interfered or asked any questions.|
03614|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0118.wav|||The thief walked into the house in Belgrave Square, and openly carried off the plate-chest, deposited it in a light cart at the door, and drove away.|
03615|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0119.wav|||Howse, the steward, accused the other servants, but they retorted, declaring that he had been visited by the thief the day previous,|
03616|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0120.wav|||whom he had shown over the plate closet.|
03617|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0121.wav|||Howse and his accomplice were arrested; the former was found guilty and sentenced to fifteen years, but the latter was acquitted.|
03618|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0122.wav|||Stealing plate was about this period the crime of a more aristocratic thief.|
03619|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0123.wav|||The club spoons and other articles of plate were long a source of profitable income to a gentleman named Ashley,|
03620|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0124.wav|||who belonged to five good London clubs --|
03621|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0125.wav|||the Junior United Service, the Union, Reform, Colonial, and Erechtheum clubs.|
03622|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0126.wav|||When one of these clubs was taken in at the Army and Navy, that establishment also suffered.|
03623|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0127.wav|||Suspicion fell at length upon Ashley, who was seen to handle the forks and spoons at table in a strange manner.|
03624|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0128.wav|||A watch was set on his house, in Allington Street, Pimlico,|
03625|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0129.wav|||and one day a police constable tracked him to a silversmith's in Holborn Hill,|
03626|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0130.wav|||where Ashley produced four silver spoons, and begged that his initials might be engraved upon them.|
03627|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0131.wav|||Ashley was arrested as he left the shop; the spoons were impounded, and it was found that the club monogram had been erased from them.|
03628|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0132.wav|||On a search of the prisoner's lodgings in Allington Street, a silver fork was found,|
03629|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0133.wav|||a number of pawnbrokers' duplicates, and three small files. It was proved at the trial that Ashley had asked his landlady for brick-dust and leather,|
03630|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0134.wav|||and it was contended that these with the files were used to alter the marks on the plate.|
03631|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0135.wav|||At most of the clubs the servants had been mulcted to make good lost plate, which had no doubt been stolen by the prisoner.|
03632|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0136.wav|||Several pawnbrokers were subpoenaed and obliged to surrender plate, to the extent in some cases of a couple of dozen of spoons or forks,|
03633|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0137.wav|||which the various club secretaries identified as the property of their respective clubs.|
03634|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0138.wav|||Ashley was the son of an army agent and banker,|
03635|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0139.wav|||and many witnesses were brought to attest to his previous good character, but he was found guilty and sentenced to seven years' transportation.|
03636|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0140.wav|||A robbery of a somewhat novel kind was executed in rather a bungling fashion by Ker, a sea-captain,|
03637|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0141.wav|||whose ship brought home a mixed cargo from Bahia and other ports.|
03638|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0142.wav|||Part of the freight were four hundred rough diamonds valued at four thousand pounds.|
03639|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0143.wav|||These packages were consigned to Messrs. Shroeder of London; and as it was known that they were to arrive in Ker's ship,|
03640|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0144.wav|||one of the owners had met her at Deal, but the captain had already absconded with the packages of precious stones in his pocket.|
03641|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0145.wav|||Ker came at once to London, and, by the help of the landlord of a public-house in Smithfield and others, disposed of the whole of the diamonds.|
03642|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0146.wav|||A Jew named Benjamin effected the sale to certain merchants named Blogg and Martin,|
03643|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0147.wav|||who declared that the rough diamond market was in such a depressed condition that they could only afford to give one thousand seven fifty pounds for stones worth|
03644|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0148.wav|||four thousand pounds|
03645|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0149.wav|||The circumstances of this purchase of brilliants from a stranger at such an inadequate price was strongly commented upon at Ker's trial.|
03646|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0150.wav|||The moment it was discovered that the diamonds had disappeared, the affair was taken up by the police.|
03647|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0151.wav|||Forrester, the detective who had pursued and captured Burgess at Boston, tracked Ker to France, and following him there, eventually captured him|
03648|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0152.wav|||at Montreuil. He was arraigned at the Old Bailey, and the case fully proved. His sentence was seven years' transportation.|
03649|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0153.wav|||The gravest crimes continued at intervals to inspire the town with horror, and concentrate public attention upon the jail of Newgate,|
03650|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0154.wav|||and the murderers immured within its walls.|
03651|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0155.wav|||Courvoisier's case made a great stir. There was unusual atrocity in this murder of an aged, infirm gentleman,|
03652|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0156.wav|||a scion of the ducal house of Bedford, by his confidential valet and personal attendant.|
03653|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0157.wav|||Lord William Russell lived alone in Norfolk Street, Park Lane. He was a widower, and seventy-three years of age.|
03654|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0158.wav|||One morning in May his lordship was found dead in his bed with his throat cut.|
03655|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0159.wav|||The fact of the murder was first discovered by the housemaid,|
03656|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0160.wav|||who, on going down early, was surprised to find the dining-room in a state of utter confusion;|
03657|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0161.wav|||the furniture turned upside down, the drawers of the escritoire open and rifled,|
03658|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0162.wav|||a bundle lying on the floor, as though thieves had been interrupted in the act.|
03659|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0163.wav|||The housemaid summoned the cook, and both went to call the valet, Courvoisier,|
03660|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0164.wav|||who came from his room ready dressed, a suspicious circumstance, as he was always late in the morning.|
03661|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0165.wav|||The housemaid suggested that they should see if his lordship was all right, and the three went to his bedroom.|
03662|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0166.wav|||While Courvoisier opened the shutters, the housemaid, approaching the bed, saw that the pillow was saturated with blood.|
03663|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0167.wav|||The discovery of the murdered man immediately followed. The neighborhood was alarmed, the police sent for, and a close inquiry forthwith commenced.|
03664|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0168.wav|||That Lord William Russell had committed suicide was at once declared impossible.|
03665|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0169.wav|||It was also clearly proved that no forcible entry had been made into the house;|
03666|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0170.wav|||the fresh marks of violence upon the door had evidently been made inside, and not from outside;|
03667|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0171.wav|||moreover, the instruments, poker and chisel, by which they had no doubt been effected,|
03668|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0172.wav|||were found in the butler's pantry, used by Courvoisier.|
03669|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0173.wav|||The researches of the police soon laid bare other suspicious facts.|
03670|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0174.wav|||The bundle found in the dining-room contained, with clothes, various small articles of plate and jewelery which a thief would probably have put into his pocket.|
03671|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0175.wav|||Upstairs in the bedroom a rouleaux box for sovereigns had been broken open,|
03672|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0176.wav|||also the jewel-box and note-case, from the latter of which was abstracted a ten-pound note known to have been in the possession of the deceased.|
03673|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0177.wav|||His lordship's watch was gone.|
03674|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0178.wav|||Further suspicion was caused by the position of a book and a wax candle by the bedside.|
03675|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0179.wav|||The latter was so placed that it could throw no light on the former, which was a 'Life of Sir Samuel Romilly.'|
03676|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0180.wav|||The intention of the real murderer to shift the crime to burglars was evident although futile,|
03677|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0181.wav|||and the police, feeling convinced that the crime had been committed by some inmate of the house,|
03678|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0182.wav|||took Courvoisier into custody, and placed the two female servants under surveillance.|
03679|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0183.wav|||The valet's strange demeanor had attracted attention from the first.|
03680|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0184.wav|||He had hung over the body in a state of dreadful agitation, answering no questions, and taking no part in the proceedings.|
03681|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0185.wav|||Three days later a close search of the butler's pantry produced fresh circumstantial evidence.|
03682|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0186.wav|||Behind the skirting board several of his lordship's rings were discovered;|
03683|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0187.wav|||near it was his Waterloo medal, and the above-mentioned ten-pound note.|
03684|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0188.wav|||Further investigation was rewarded by the discovery in the pantry of a split gold ring, used by Lord William to carry his keys on;|
03685|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0189.wav|||next, and in the same place, a chased gold key;|
03686|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0190.wav|||and at last his lordship's watch was found secreted under the leads of the sink.|
03687|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0191.wav|||All this was evidence sufficient to warrant Courvoisier's committal for trial;|
03688|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0192.wav|||but still he found friends, and a liberal subscription was raised among the foreign servants in London to provide funds for his defense.|
03689|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0193.wav|||Courvoisier, when put on his trial, pleaded not guilty;|
03690|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0194.wav|||but on the second day the discovery of fresh evidence, more particularly the recovery of some of Lord William's stolen plate,|
03691|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0195.wav|||induced the prisoner to make a full confession of his crime to the lawyers who defended him.|
03692|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0196.wav|||This placed them in a position of much embarrassment. To have thrown up their brief would have been to have secured Courvoisier's conviction.|
03693|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0197.wav|||Mr. Phillips, who led in the case, went to the other extreme,|
03694|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0198.wav|||and in an impassioned address implored the jury not to send an innocent man to the gallows.|
03695|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0199.wav|||It will be remembered that the question whether Mr. Phillips had not exceeded the limits usually allowed to counsel was much debated at the time.|
03696|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0200.wav|||The jury without hesitation found Courvoisier guilty, and he was sentenced to death.|
03697|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0201.wav|||The prisoner's demeanor had greatly changed during the trial.|
03698|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0202.wav|||Coolness amounting almost to effrontery gave way to hopeless dejection.|
03699|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0203.wav|||On his removal to Newgate after sentence,|
03700|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0204.wav|||he admitted that he had been justly convicted, and expressed great anxiety that his fellow-servants should be relieved from all suspicion.|
03701|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0205.wav|||Later in the day he tried to commit suicide by cramming a towel down his throat, but was prevented.|
03702|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0206.wav|||Next morning he made a full confession in presence of his attorney, and the governor, Mr. Cope.|
03703|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0207.wav|||In this he gave as the motives of his crime a quarrel he had with his master, who threatened to discharge him without a character.|
03704|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0208.wav|||Lord William, according to the valet, was of a peevish, difficult temper;|
03705|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0209.wav|||he was annoyed with his man for various small omissions and acts of forgetfulness, and on the night of the murder had taken Courvoisier to task rather sharply.|
03706|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0210.wav|||Finally, on coming downstairs after bed-time, Lord William had found Courvoisier in the dining-room.|
03707|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0211.wav|||What are you doing here? asked his lordship.|
03708|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0212.wav|||You can have no good intentions; you must quit my service tomorrow morning.|
03709|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0213.wav|||This seems to have decided Courvoisier,|
03710|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0214.wav|||who took a carving-knife from the sideboard in the dining-room, went upstairs to Lord William's bedroom, and drew the knife across his throat.|
03711|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0215.wav|||He appeared to die instantly, said the murderer, in conclusion.|
03712|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0216.wav|||His account of his acts and movements after the deed|
03713|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0217.wav|||varied so considerably in the several documents he left behind, that too much reliance cannot be placed upon his confession.|
03714|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0218.wav|||His last statement contains the words, "The public now think I am a liar, and they will not believe me when I say the truth."|
03715|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0219.wav|||This was no doubt the case, but this much truth his confession may be taken to contain:|

03717|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0221.wav|||that he could not resist the opportunity for robbery offered him by his situation at Lord William Russell's; that when vexed with his master|
03718|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0222.wav|||he did not shrink from murder, both for revenge and to conceal his other crimes.|
03719|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0223.wav|||Courvoisier wished to commit suicide in Newgate, but was prevented by the vigilant supervision to which he was subjected while in jail.|
03720|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0224.wav|||The attempt was to have been made by opening a vein and allowing himself to bleed to death.|
03721|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0225.wav|||The Sunday night before his execution he would not go to bed when ordered.|
03722|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0226.wav|||The governor insisted, but Courvoisier showed great reluctance to strip.|
03723|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0227.wav|||The order was, however, at length obeyed, and the whole of the prisoner's clothes were minutely searched.|
03724|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0228.wav|||In the pocket of the coat Mr. Cope, the governor, found a neatly-folded cloth, and asked what it was for.|
03725|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0229.wav|||Courvoisier admitted that he had intended to bind it tightly round his arm and bleed himself to death in the night.|
03726|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0230.wav|||The next inquiry was how he hoped to open a vein. "With a bit of sharpened stick picked out of the ordinary firewood."|
03727|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0231.wav|||Where is it? asked the governor.|
03728|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0232.wav|||The prisoner replied that he had left it in the mattress of which he had just been deprived.|
03729|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0233.wav|||The bed was searched, but no piece of sharpened wood was found. It was thought that it might have been lost in changing the mattresses.|
03730|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0234.wav|||The cloth above referred to belonged to the inner seam of his trousers, which he had managed to tear out.|
03731|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0235.wav|||There is nothing to show that Courvoisier really contemplated self-destruction.|
03732|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0236.wav|||A murder which reproduced many of the features of that committed by Greenacre soon followed, and excited the public mind even more than that of Courvoisier's.|
03733|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0237.wav|||Daniel Good's crime might have remained long undiscovered but for his own careless stupidity.|
03734|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0238.wav|||He was coachman to a gentleman at Roehampton. One day he went into a pawnbroker's at Wandsworth, and bought a pair of breeches on credit.|
03735|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0239.wav|||At the same time he was seen to steal and secrete a pair of trousers. The shop-boy gave information.|
03736|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0240.wav|||Good was followed to his stables by a policeman, but obstinately denied the theft.|
03737|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0241.wav|||The policeman insisted on searching the premises, at which Good displayed some uneasiness.|
03738|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0242.wav|||This increased when the officer, accompanied by two others, a neighbor and a bailiff, entered one of the stables.|

03750|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ013-0254.wav|||and evidence was given of close relation between Good and a third woman, a girl named Butcher, residing at Woolwich.|

03766|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0002.wav|||Hocker's murder is in its way interesting, as affording another proof of the extraordinary way in which the culprit returned to the scene of his guilt.|
03767|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0003.wav|||The cries of his victim, a Mr. Delarue,|

03769|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0005.wav|||but too late to give substantial aid.|
03770|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0006.wav|||While the body lay there still warm, battered and bleeding from the cruel blows inflicted upon him by his cowardly assailant, a man came by singing.|
03771|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0007.wav|||He entered into conversation with the policemen, and learnt, as it seemed for the first time, what had happened.|
03772|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0008.wav|||His remark was, "It is a nasty job;" he took hold of the dead hand, and confessed that he felt "queer" at the shocking sight.|
03773|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0009.wav|||This sight was his own handiwork,|
03774|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0010.wav|||yet he could not overcome the strange fascination it had for him, and remained by the side of the corpse till the stretcher came.|
03775|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0011.wav|||Even then he followed it as far as Belsize Lane.|

03777|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0013.wav|||He wanted a light for a cigar, and got it from a lantern which was lifted up and fully betrayed his features.|
03778|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0014.wav|||It was noticed that he wore a mackintosh. Next day the police, in making a careful search of the scene of the murder,|
03779|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0015.wav|||picked up a coat-button, which afterwards played an important part in the identification of the murderer.|
03780|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0016.wav|||A letter, which afforded an additional clue, was also found in the pocket of the deceased. Still it was many weeks before any arrest was made.|
03781|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0017.wav|||In the mean time the police were not idle.|
03782|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0018.wav|||It came out by degrees that the person who had been seen in Belsize Lane on the night the body was found was a friend of the deceased.|
03783|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0019.wav|||His name was Hocker; he was by trade a ladies' shoemaker; and it was also ascertained that after the day of the murder he was flush of money.|
03784|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0020.wav|||He was soon afterwards arrested on suspicion, and a search of his lodgings brought to light several garments saturated with blood;|
03785|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0021.wav|||a coat among them much torn and stained, with three buttons missing, one of which corresponded with that picked up at Hampstead.|
03786|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0022.wav|||The letter found in the pocket of the deceased was sealed with a wafer marked F,|
03787|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0023.wav|||and many of the same sort were found in the possession of the accused. This was enough to obtain a committal,|
03788|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0024.wav|||after several remands; but the case contained elements of doubt, and the evidence at the trial was entirely circumstantial.|
03789|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0025.wav|||A witness deposed to meeting Hocker, soon after the cries of murder were heard,|
03790|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0026.wav|||running at a dog-trot into London, and others swore that they plainly recognized him as the man seen soon afterwards in the lane.|
03791|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0027.wav|||A woman whom he called on the same evening declared he had worn a mackintosh, his coat was much torn, there was a stain of blood on his shirt-cuff,|
03792|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0028.wav|||and he was in possession, the first time to her knowledge, of a watch.|
03793|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0029.wav|||This was Delarue's watch, fully identified as such, which Hocker told his brother Delarue had given him the morning of the murder.|
03794|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0030.wav|||These were damnatory facts which well supported the prosecution.|
03795|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0031.wav|||The prisoner made an elaborate defense, in which he sought to vilify the character of deceased|
03796|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0032.wav|||as the seducer of an innocent girl to whom he (Hocker) had been fondly attached.|
03797|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0033.wav|||When her ruin was discovered her brother panted for revenge.|
03798|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0034.wav|||Hocker, whose skill in counterfeiting handwriting was known, was asked to fabricate a letter making an assignation with Delarue|
03799|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0035.wav|||in a lonely part of Hampstead.|
03800|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0036.wav|||Hocker and the brother went to the spot, where the latter left him to meet his sister's seducer alone.|
03801|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0037.wav|||Soon afterwards Hocker heard cries of "murder,"|
03802|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0038.wav|||and proceeding to where they came from, found Delarue dead, slain by the furious brother.|
03803|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0039.wav|||Hocker was so overcome, feeling himself the principal cause of the tragedy,|
03804|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0040.wav|||that he rushed to a slaughterhouse in Hampstead and purposely stained his clothes with blood.|
03805|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0041.wav|||Such an extravagant defense did not weigh with judge or jury;|
03806|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0042.wav|||the first summed up dead against the prisoner, and the latter, after retiring for ten minutes, found him guilty.|
03807|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0043.wav|||Hocker's conduct in Newgate while under sentence of death was most extraordinary.|
03808|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0044.wav|||He drew up several long statements, containing narratives purely fictitious, imputing crimes to his victim, and repeating his line of defense|
03809|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0045.wav|||that Delarue had suffered by the hands of imaginary outraged brothers acting as the avengers of females deeply injured by him.|
03810|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0046.wav|||Hocker made several pretended confessions and revelations, all of which were proved to be absolutely false by the police on inquiry.|
03811|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0047.wav|||His demeanor was a strange compound of wickedness, falsehood, and deceit.|
03812|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0048.wav|||But at the fatal hour his hardihood forsook him, and he was almost insensible when taken out of his cell for execution.|
03813|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0049.wav|||Restoratives were applied, but he was in a fainting condition when tied, and had to be supported by the assistant executioner|
03814|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0050.wav|||while Calcraft adjusted the noose.|
03815|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0051.wav|||There was an epidemic of murder in the United Kingdom about eighteen forty-eight to nine.|
03816|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0052.wav|||In November of the first-named year occurred the wholesale slaughter of the Jermys in their house, Stanfield Hall, by the miscreant Rush.|
03817|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0053.wav|||Soon afterwards, in Gloucestershire,|
03818|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0054.wav|||a maidservant, Sarah Thomas, murdered her mistress, an aged woman, by beating out her brains with a stone.|
03819|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0055.wav|||Next year John Gleeson Wilson, at Liverpool, murdered a woman, Ann Henrichson, also a maidservant and two children;|
03820|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0056.wav|||while in Ireland a wife dashed out her husband's brains with a hammer.|
03821|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0057.wav|||London did not escape the contagion, and prominent among the detestable crimes of the period stands that of the Mannings at Bermondsey.|
03822|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0058.wav|||These great criminals suffered at Horsemonger Lane Jail, but they were tried at the Central Criminal Court, and were for some time inmates of Newgate.|
03823|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0059.wav|||Their victim was a man named Patrick O'Connor, a Custom-House gauger, who had been a suitor of Marie de Roux before she became Mrs. Manning.|
03824|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0060.wav|||Marie de Roux up to the time of her marriage had been in service as lady's maid to Lady Blantyre, daughter of the Duchess of Sutherland,|
03825|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0061.wav|||and Manning hoped to get some small Government appointment through his wife's interest.|
03826|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0062.wav|||He had failed in this as well as in the business of a publican, which he had at one time adopted.|
03827|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0063.wav|||After the marriage a close intimacy was still maintained between O'Connor and the Mannings.|
03828|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0064.wav|||He lived at Mile End, whence he walked often to call at three, Minver Place, Bermondsey, the residence of his old love.|
03829|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0065.wav|||O'Connor was a man of substance. He had long followed the profitable trade of a money-lender,|
03830|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0066.wav|||and by dint of usurious interest on small sums advanced to needy neighbors, had amassed as much as eight thousand pounds or ten thousand pounds.|
03831|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0067.wav|||His wealth was well known to "Maria," as he called Mrs. Manning, who made several ineffectual attempts to get money out of him.|
03832|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0068.wav|||At last this fiendish woman made up her mind to murder O'Connor and appropriate all his possessions.|
03833|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0069.wav|||Her husband, to whom she coolly confided her intention,|
03834|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0070.wav|||a heavy brutish fellow, was yet aghast at his wife's resolve, and tried hard to dissuade her from bad purpose.|
03835|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0071.wav|||In his confession after sentence he declared that she plied him well with brandy at this period,|
03836|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0072.wav|||and that during the whole time he was never in his right senses.|
03837|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0073.wav|||Meanwhile this woman, unflinching in her cold, bloody determination, carefully laid all her plans for the consummation of the deed.|
03838|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0074.wav|||One fine afternoon in August, O'Connor was met walking in the direction of Bermondsey.|
03839|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0075.wav|||He was dressed with particular care, as he was to dine at the Mannings and meet friends, one a young lady.|
03840|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0076.wav|||He was seen afterwards smoking and talking with his hosts in their back parlor, and never seen again alive.|
03841|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0077.wav|||It came out in the husband's confession that Mrs. Manning induced O'Connor to go down to the kitchen to wash his hands, that she followed him to the basement,|
03842|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0078.wav|||that she stood behind him as he stood near the open grave she herself had dug for him,|
03843|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0079.wav|||and which he mistook for a drain, and that while he was speaking to her she put the muzzle of a pistol close to the back of his head and shot him down.|
03844|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0080.wav|||She ran upstairs, told her husband, made him go down to look at her handiwork, and as O'Connor was not quite dead,|
03845|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0081.wav|||Manning gave the coup de grace with a crowbar.|
03846|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0082.wav|||After this Mrs. Manning changed her dress and went off in a cab to O'Connor's lodgings,|
03847|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0083.wav|||which, having possessed herself of the murdered man's keys, she rifled from end to end.|
03848|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0084.wav|||Returning to her own home, where Manning meantime had been calmly smoking and talking to the neighbors over the basement wall,|
03849|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0085.wav|||the corpse lying just inside the kitchen all the while, the two set to work to strip the body and hide it under the stones of the floor.|
03850|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0086.wav|||This job was not completed till the following day, as the hole had to be enlarged, and the only tool they had was a dust-shovel.|
03851|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0087.wav|||A quantity of quicklime was thrown in with the body to destroy all identification.|
03852|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0088.wav|||This was on a Thursday evening.|
03853|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0089.wav|||For the remainder of that week and part of the next the murderers stayed in the house, and occupied the kitchen, close to the remains of their victim.|
03854|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0090.wav|||On the Sunday Mrs. Manning roasted a goose at this same kitchen fire, and ate it with relish in the afternoon.|
03855|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0091.wav|||This cold-blooded indifference after the event was only outdone by the premeditation of this horrible murder.|
03856|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0092.wav|||The hole must have been excavated and the quicklime purchased quite three weeks before O'Connor met his death,|
03857|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0093.wav|||and during that time he must frequently have stood or sat over his own grave.|
03858|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0094.wav|||Discovery of the murder came in this wise. O'Connor, a punctual and well-conducted official, was at once missed at the London Docks.|

03861|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0097.wav|||The Mannings had seen or heard nothing of him, of course. As O'Connor still did not turn up, the police after a couple of days returned to Minver Place.|
03862|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0098.wav|||The house was empty, bare and stripped of all its furniture, and its former occupants had decamped.|
03863|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0099.wav|||The circumstance was suspicious, and a search was at once made of the whole premises.|
03864|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0100.wav|||In the back kitchen one of the detectives remarked that the cement between certain stones looked lighter than the rest, and on trying it with a knife,|
03865|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0101.wav|||he found that it was soft and new, while elsewhere it was set and hard.|
03866|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0102.wav|||The stones were at once taken up;|
03867|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0103.wav|||beneath them was a layer of fresh mortar, beneath that a lot of loose earth, amongst which a stocking was turned up, and presently a human toe.|
03868|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0104.wav|||Six inches lower the body of O'Connor was uncovered.|
03869|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0105.wav|||He was lying on his face, his legs tied up to his hips so as to allow of the body fitting into the hole.|
03870|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0106.wav|||The lime had done its work so rapidly that the features would have been indistinguishable but for the prominent chin and a set of false teeth.|
03871|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0107.wav|||The corpse settled all doubts, and the next point was to lay hands upon the Mannings.|

03873|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0109.wav|||Part of this she had deposited to be left till called for at one station, while she had gone herself to another, that at Euston Square.|
03874|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0110.wav|||At the first the boxes were impounded, opened, and found to contain many of O'Connor's effects.|
03875|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0111.wav|||At the second exact information was obtained of Mrs. Manning's movements. She had gone to Edinburgh.|

03877|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0113.wav|||advised the Edinburgh police of the whole affair, and within an hour an answer was telegraphed, stating that Mrs. Manning was in custody.|

03879|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0115.wav|||and they had given information to the police.|

03888|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0124.wav|||Manning, who was dressed in black, appeared to be a heavy, bull-necked, repulsive-looking man, with a very fair complexion and light hair.|
03889|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0125.wav|||Mrs. Manning was not without personal charms;|
03890|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0126.wav|||her face was comely, she had dark hair and good eyes, and was above the middle height, yet inclined to be stout.|
03891|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0127.wav|||She was smartly dressed in a plaid shawl, a white lace cap;|
03892|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0128.wav|||her hair was dressed in long crepe bands. She had lace ruffles at her wrist, and wore primrose-colored kid gloves.|
03893|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0129.wav|||The case rested upon the facts which have been already set forth, and was proved to the satisfaction of the jury, who brought in a verdict of guilty.|
03894|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0130.wav|||Manning, when sentence of death was passed on him, said nothing;|
03895|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0131.wav|||but Mrs. Manning, speaking in a foreign accent, addressed the court with great fluency and vehemence.|
03896|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0132.wav|||She complained that she had no justice; there was no law for her, she had found no protection either from judges, the prosecutor, or her husband.|
03897|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0133.wav|||She had not been treated like a Christian, but like a wild beast of the forest. She declared that the money found in her possession had been sent her from abroad;|
03898|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0134.wav|||that O'Connor had been more to her than her husband, that she ought to have married him.|
03899|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0135.wav|||It was against common sense to charge her with murdering the only friend she had in the world;|
03900|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0136.wav|||the culprit was really her husband, who killed O'Connor out of jealousy and revengeful feelings.|
03901|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0137.wav|||When the judge assumed the black cap|
03902|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0138.wav|||Mrs. Manning became still more violent, shouting, "No, no, I will not stand it! You ought to be ashamed of yourselves!"|
03903|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0139.wav|||and would have left the dock had not Mr. Cope, the governor of Newgate, restrained her.|
03904|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0140.wav|||After judgment was passed she repeatedly cried out Shame!|
03905|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0141.wav|||and stretching out her hand, she gathered up a quantity of the rue which, following ancient custom dating from the days of the jail fever,|
03906|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0142.wav|||was strewn in front of the dock, and sprinkled it towards the bench with a contemptuous gesture.|
03907|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0143.wav|||On being removed to Newgate from the court Mrs. Manning became perfectly furious.|
03908|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0144.wav|||She uttered loud imprecations, cursing judge, jury, barristers, witnesses, and all who stood around.|
03909|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0146.wav|||They had to handcuff her by force against the most violent resistance, and still she raged and stormed,|
