03911|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0148.wav|||From Newgate the Mannings were taken in separate cabs to Horsemonger Lane Jail.|
03912|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0149.wav|||On this journey her manner changed completely. She became flippant, joked with the officers, asked how they liked her "resolution" in the dock,|
03913|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0150.wav|||and expressed the utmost contempt for her husband, whom she never intended to acknowledge or speak to again.|
03914|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0151.wav|||Later her mood changed to abject despair.|
03915|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0152.wav|||On reaching the condemned cell she threw herself upon the floor and shrieked in an hysterical agony of tears.|
03916|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0153.wav|||After this, until the day of execution, she recovered her spirits, and displayed reckless effrontery,|
03917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0154.wav|||mocking at the chaplain, and turning a deaf ear to the counsels of a benevolent lady who came to visit.|
03918|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0155.wav|||Now she abused the jury, now called Manning a vagabond,|
03919|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0156.wav|||and through all ate heartily at every meal, slept soundly at nights, and talked with cheerfulness on almost any subject.|
03920|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0157.wav|||Nevertheless, she attempted to commit suicide by driving her nails, purposely left long, into her throat.|
03921|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0158.wav|||She was discovered just as she was getting black in the face.|
03922|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0159.wav|||Manning's demeanor was more in harmony with his situation, and the full confession he made|
03923|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0160.wav|||elucidated all dark and uncertain points in connection with the crime.|
03924|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0161.wav|||The actual execution, which took place at another prison than Newgate, is rather beyond the scope of this work.|
03925|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0162.wav|||But it may be mentioned that the concourse was so enormous that it drew down the well-merited and trenchant disapproval of Charles Dickens,|
03926|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0163.wav|||who wrote to the 'Times,' saying that he believed "a sight so inconceivably awful|

03928|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0165.wav|||and presented by no heathen land under the sun.|
03929|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0166.wav|||faded in my mind before the atrocious bearing, looks, and language of the assembled spectators.|
03930|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0167.wav|||When I came upon the scene at midnight, the shrillness of the cries and howls that were raised from time to time,|
03931|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0168.wav|||denoting that they came from a concourse of boys and girls already assembled in the best places, made my blood run cold.|

03933|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0170.wav|||This preference brought the costly stuff into disrepute, and its unpopularity lasted for nearly thirty years.|
03934|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0171.wav|||I will briefly describe one or two of the more remarkable murders in the years immediately following, then pass on to another branch of crime.|
03935|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0172.wav|||Robert Marley at the time of his arrest called himself a surgical instrument maker.|
03936|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0173.wav|||It was understood also that he had served in the army as a private, and had, moreover, undergone a sentence of transportation.|
03937|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0174.wav|||But it was supposed that he had been once in a good position, well born, and well educated.|
03938|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0175.wav|||When lying under sentence of death in Newgate, he was visited by a lady, a gentlewoman in every sense of the word, who was said to be his sister.|
03939|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0176.wav|||His determined addiction to evil courses had led to his being cast off by his family,|
03940|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0177.wav|||and he must have been at the end of his resources when he committed the crime for which he suffered.|
03941|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0178.wav|||His offense was the murder of Richard Cope,|
03942|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0179.wav|||a working jeweler, shopman to a Mr. Berry of Parliament Street. It was Cope's duty to stay in the shop till the last, close the shutters,|
03943|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0180.wav|||secure the stock of watches and jewelry, then lock up the place and take on the keys to Mr. Berry's private house in Pimlico.|
03944|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0181.wav|||Cope, a small man, crippled, and of weakly constitution, was alone in the shop about nine:thirty.|
03945|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0182.wav|||the shutters were up, and he was preparing to close, when Marley entered and fell upon him with a life-preserver,|
03946|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0183.wav|||meaning to kill him and rifle the shop.|
03947|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0184.wav|||The noise of the struggle was heard outside in the street,|
03948|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0185.wav|||and bystanders peeped in through the shutters, but no one entered or sought to interfere in what seemed only a domestic quarrel.|
03949|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0186.wav|||A milliner's porter,|
03950|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0187.wav|||Lerigo, was also attracted by the noise of the row, but after walking a few paces he felt dissatisfied, and returned to the spot.|
03951|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0188.wav|||Pushing the shop-door open, he saw Marley finishing his murderous assault.|
03952|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0189.wav|||Lerigo turned for assistance to take the man into custody.|
03953|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0190.wav|||Marley, disturbed, picked up a cigar and parcel from the counter, then ran out, pursued by Lerigo only.|
03954|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0191.wav|||Marley ran along the street, down into Cannon Row|
03955|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0192.wav|||then into Palace Yard, where the waterman of the cab-tank, in obedience to Lerigo's shouts, collared the fugitive.|
03956|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0193.wav|||Escorted by his two captors, Marley was taken back into Parliament Street to the jeweler's shop.|
03957|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0194.wav|||The policemen were now in possession;|
03958|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0195.wav|||two of them supported Cope, who was still alive, although insensible, and Marley was apprehended. The evidence against him was completed|
03959|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0196.wav|||by his identification by Cope in Westminster Hospital, who survived long enough to make a formal deposition before Mr. Jardine,|
03960|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0197.wav|||the police magistrate, that Marley was the man who had beaten him to death.|
03961|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0198.wav|||Marley at his trial was undefended, and the sheriffs offered him counsel; but he declined. The witnesses against him all spoke the truth, he said;|
03962|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0199.wav|||there was no case to make out; why waste money on lawyers for the defense? His demeanor was cool and collected throughout;|
03963|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0200.wav|||he seemed while in Newgate to realize thoroughly that there was no hope for him, and was determined to face his fate bravely.|
03964|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0201.wav|||After sentence, the Newgate officers who had special charge of him noticed that he slept well and ate well, enjoying all his meals.|
03965|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0202.wav|||One of them went into his cell just at dinner-time;|
03966|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0203.wav|||the great clock of St. Sepulchre's close by was striking the hour, and Marley, who had his elbows on the table,|
03967|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0204.wav|||with his head resting on his hands, looked up and observed calmly, "Go along, clock; come along, gallows."|
03968|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0205.wav|||On the dread morning he came out to execution quite gaily, and tripped up the stairs to the scaffold.|
03969|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0206.wav|||His captors, it may be added (Lerigo and Allen), were warmly commended by the judge for their courage and activity.|
03970|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0207.wav|||The former was given a reward of twenty and the latter of ten pounds.|
03971|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0208.wav|||A murderous assault on a police constable, which so nearly ended fatally that the culprit was sentenced to death, although not executed,|
03972|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0209.wav|||was perpetrated in eighteen fifty-two. The case was accompanied with the most shocking brutality.|
03973|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0210.wav|||Cannon, by trade a chimney-sweep, had long been characterized by the bitterest hatred of the police force,|
03974|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0211.wav|||and had been repeatedly sentenced to imprisonment for most desperate and ferocious attacks upon various constables. His last victim was Dwyer,|
03975|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0212.wav|||a fine young officer who had been summoned to take Cannon into custody when the latter was drunk and riotous in front of a public-house.|
03976|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0213.wav|||Dwyer found Cannon bleeding profusely from a wound in the head, and persuaded him to go to a doctor's.|
03977|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0214.wav|||They walked together quietly for some little distance, then Cannon, without the slightest warning,|
03978|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0215.wav|||threw the constable on his back, and violently assaulted him by jumping on his chest and stomach,|
03979|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0216.wav|||and by getting his hand inside Dwyer's stock, with the idea of strangling him.|
03980|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0217.wav|||Dwyer managed to overpower his assailant, and got to his feet; but Cannon butted at him with his head, and again threw him to the ground,|
03981|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0218.wav|||after which he kicked his prostrate foe in the most brutal and cowardly manner, and until he was almost senseless, and bruised from head to foot.|
03982|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0219.wav|||Once more Dwyer got to his feet, and managed, by drawing his staff, to keep Cannon at bay until a second constable came to his aid.|
03983|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0220.wav|||All this time not one of a numerous body of bystanders offered to assist the policeman in his extremity.|
03984|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0221.wav|||On the contrary, many of them encouraged the brutal assailant in his savage attack.|
03985|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0222.wav|||To Cannon's infinite surprise, he was indicted for attempt to murder, and not for a simple assault, and found guilty.|
03986|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0223.wav|||The judge, in passing sentence of death, told him he richly deserved the punishment.|
03987|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0224.wav|||As Dwyer survived, Cannon escaped the death sentence, which was commuted to penal servitude for life.|
03988|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0225.wav|||A handsome sum was subscribed for the injured constable, who was disabled for life.|
03989|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0226.wav|||Only a few have vied with Cannon in fiendish cruelty and brutality.|
03990|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0227.wav|||One of these was Mobbs, who lived in the Minories,|
03991|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0228.wav|||generally known by the soubriquet of "General Haynau," a name execrated in England about this time.|
03992|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0229.wav|||Mobbs systematically ill-used his wife for a long space of time, and at last cut her throat.|
03993|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0230.wav|||For this he was executed in front of Newgate in eighteen thirty-three.|
03994|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0231.wav|||Emmanuel Barthelemy again,|
03995|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0232.wav|||the French refugee, was a murderer of the same description, who dispatched his victim with a loaded cane, after which, to secure his escape,|
03996|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0233.wav|||he shot an old soldier who had attempted to detain him. He was convicted and executed.|
03997|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0234.wav|||He died impenitent, declaring that he had no belief, and that it was idle to ask forgiveness of God.|
03998|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0235.wav|||I want forgiveness of man; I want those doors (of the prison) opened.|
03999|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0236.wav|||Barthelemy was generally supposed to have been a secret agent of the French police.|
04000|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0237.wav|||I will now pass to grave but less atrocious crimes.|
04001|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0238.wav|||In eighteen fifty occurred the first of a series of gigantic frauds,|
04002|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0239.wav|||which followed each other at no long intervals, which had a strong family likeness, and originated all of them to make money easily,|
04003|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0240.wav|||without capital, and at railroad speed.|
04004|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0241.wav|||Walter Watts was an inventor, a creator, who struck an entirely new and original line of crime.|
04005|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0242.wav|||Employed as a clerk in the Globe Assurance,|
04006|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0243.wav|||he with unusual quickness of apprehension discovered and promptly turned to account an inexcusably lax system of management,|
04007|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0244.wav|||which offered peculiar chances of profit to an ingenious and unscrupulous man.|
04008|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0245.wav|||It was the custom in this office to make the banker's passbook the basis of the entries in the company's ledgers.|
04009|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0246.wav|||Thus, when a payment was made by the company, the amount disbursed was carried to account in the general books from its entry in the passbook,|
04010|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0247.wav|||and without reference to or comparison with the documents in which the payment was claimed.|
04011|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0248.wav|||This passbook, when not at the bank, was in the exclusive custody of Watts.|
04012|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0249.wav|||The cheques drawn by the directors also passed through his hands; to him too they came back to be verified and put by,|
04013|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0250.wav|||after they had been cashed by the bank.|
04014|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0251.wav|||In this way Watts had complete control over the whole of the monetary transactions of the company.|
04015|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0252.wav|||He could do what he liked with the passbook, and by its adoption, as described as the basis of all entries,|
04016|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0253.wav|||there was no independent check upon him if he chose to tamper with it.|
04017|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0254.wav|||This he did to an enormous extent,|
04018|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0255.wav|||continually altering, erasing, and adding figures to correspond with and cover the abstractions he made of various cheques as they were drawn.|
04019|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0256.wav|||It seems incredible that this passbook, which when produced in court|
04020|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0257.wav|||was a mass of blots and erasures, should not have created suspicion of foul play either at the bank or at the company's board.|
04021|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0258.wav|||Implicit confidence appears to have been placed in Watts, who was the son of an old and trusted employee, and, moreover, a young man of plausible address.|
04022|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0259.wav|||Watts led two lives.|
04023|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0260.wav|||In the West End he was a man of fashion, with a town house, a house at Brighton, and a cellar full of good wine at both.|
04024|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0261.wav|||He rode a priceless hack in Rotten Row, or drove down to Richmond in a mail phaeton and pair.|
04025|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0262.wav|||He played high, and spent his nights at the club, or in joyous and dissolute company.|
04026|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0263.wav|||When other pleasures palled he took a theatre, and posed as a munificent patron of the dramatic art.|
04027|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0264.wav|||Under his auspices several "stars" appeared on the boards of the Marylebone theatre,|
04028|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0265.wav|||and later he became manager of the newly rebuilt Olympic at Wych Street.|
04029|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0266.wav|||No one cared too closely to inquire into the sources of wealth. Some said he was a fortunate speculator in stocks,|
04030|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0267.wav|||others that he had had extraordinary luck as a gold-digger. Had his West End and little-informed associates followed him into the city,|
04031|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0268.wav|||whither he was taken every morning in a smart brougham, they would have seen him alight from it in Cornhill,|
04032|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0269.wav|||and walk forward on foot to enter as a humble and unpretending employee the doors of the Globe Assurance office.|
04033|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0271.wav|||Nevertheless, in this position, through the culpable carelessness which left him unfettered, he managed between eighteen forty-four|
04034|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0272.wav|||and eighteen fifty to embezzle and apply to his own purposes some seventy-one thousand pounds.|
04035|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0273.wav|||The detection of these frauds came while he was still prominently before the world as the lessee of the Olympic.|
04036|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0274.wav|||Rumors were abroad that serious defalcations had been discovered in one of the insurance offices,|
04037|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0275.wav|||but it was long before the public realized that the fraudulent clerk and the great theatrical manager were one and the same person.|
04038|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0276.wav|||Watts's crime was discovered by the secretary of the Globe Company, who came suddenly upon the extensive falsification of the passbook.|
04039|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0277.wav|||An inquiry was at once set on foot, and the frauds were traced to Watts.|
04040|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0278.wav|||The latter, when first taxed with his offense, protested his innocence boldly, and positively denied all knowledge of the affair;|
04041|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0279.wav|||and he had so cleverly destroyed all traces that it was not easy to bring home the charge.|
04042|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0280.wav|||But it was proved that Watts had appropriated one cheque for fourteen hundred pounds,|
04043|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0281.wav|||which he had paid into his own bankers, and on this he was committed to Newgate for trial.|
04044|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0282.wav|||There were two counts in the indictment: one for stealing a cheque value fourteen hundred pounds, the second for stealing a bit of paper value one penny.|
04045|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0283.wav|||The jury found him guilty of the latter only, with a point of law reserved. This was fully argued before three judges,|
04046|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0285.wav|||and not for the slight offense as it appeared on the record.|
04047|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0286.wav|||The sentence of the court, one of ten years' transportation, struck the prisoner with dismay.|
04048|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0287.wav|||He had been led to suppose that twelve months' imprisonment was the utmost the law could inflict, and he broke down utterly under the unexpected blow.|
04049|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0288.wav|||That same evening he committed suicide in Newgate.|
04050|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0289.wav|||The details of the suicide were given at the inquest. Watts had been in ill-health from the time of his first arrest.|
04051|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0290.wav|||In Giltspur Street Compter, where he was first lodged|
04052|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0291.wav|||he showed symptoms of delirium tremens, and admitted that he had been addicted to the excessive use of stimulants.|
04053|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0292.wav|||His health improved, but was still indifferent when he was brought up for sentence, and he was an occupant of the Newgate infirmary.|
04054|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0293.wav|||He returned from court in a state of gloomy dejection,|
04055|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0294.wav|||and in the middle of the night one of the fellow-prisoners who slept in the same ward noticed that he was not in his bed.|
04056|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0295.wav|||This man got up to look for him, and found him hanging from the bars of a neighboring room.|
04057|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0296.wav|||He had made use of a piece of rope cut out from the sacking of his bedstead, and had tied his feet together with a silk pocket-handkerchief.|
04058|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0297.wav|||The prison officers were called, but Watts was quite cold and stiff when he was cut down.|
04059|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0298.wav|||Strange to say, a second suicide occurred in Newgate the same night,|
04060|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0299.wav|||that of a prize-fighter named Donovan, tried the same day, and convicted of manslaughter.|
04061|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0300.wav|||Sentence of death had been recorded against Donovan, who, like Watts, had seemingly been overcome with sudden despair.|
04062|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0301.wav|||In eighteen fifty-three a second case of gigantic fraud alarmed and scandalized the financial world.|
04063|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0302.wav|||It outshone the defalcations of Watts.|
04064|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0303.wav|||Nothing to equal the excitement caused by the forgeries of Robert Ferdinand Pries had been known before in the city of London.|
04065|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0304.wav|||He was a corn merchant who operated largely in grain.|
04066|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0305.wav|||So enormous were his transactions, that they often affected the markets, and caused great fluctuations in prices.|
04067|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0306.wav|||These had been attributed to political action; some thought that the large purchases in foreign grains, effected at losing prices,|
04068|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0307.wav|||were intended by the protectionists to depress the wheat market, and secure the support of the farmers at the forthcoming election;|
04069|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0308.wav|||others, that Napoleon the third, but recently proclaimed Emperor of the French, wished to gain the popularity necessary to secure the people.|
04070|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0309.wav|||Few realized that these mysterious operations were the "convulsive attempt" of a ruined and dishonest speculator to sustain his credit.|
04071|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0310.wav|||Pries, although enjoying a high reputation in the city, had long been in a bad way.|
04072|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0311.wav|||His extensive business had been carried on by fraud.|
04073|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0312.wav|||His method was to obtain advances twice over on the same bills of lading or corn warrants. The duplicates were forged.|
04074|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0313.wav|||In this way he obtained vast sums from several firms, and one to which he was indebted upwards of fifty thousand pounds subsequently stopped payment.|
04075|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0314.wav|||Pries at length was discovered|
04076|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0315.wav|||through a dishonored cheque for three thousand pounds, paid over as an installment of eighteen thousand pounds owing for an advance on warrants.|
04077|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0316.wav|||Inquiries were instituted when the cheque was protested, which led to the discovery of the forgeries.|
04078|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0317.wav|||Pries was lodged in Newgate, tried at the Old Bailey, and transported for life.|
04079|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0318.wav|||Another set of frauds, which resembled those of Pries in principle, although not in practice, were soon afterwards discovered.|
04080|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0320.wav|||proposed to gain the capital he needed for business purposes by raising money on dock warrants for imported goods which had no real existence.|
04081|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0321.wav|||When such goods arrived they were frequently left at a wharf, paying rent until it suited the importer to remove them.|
04082|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0322.wav|||The dock warrant was issued by the wharfinger as certificate that he held the goods.|
04083|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0323.wav|||The warrant thus represented money, and was often used as such, being endorsed and passed from hand to hand as other negotiable bills.|
04084|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0324.wav|||Cole's plan was to have a wharf of his own, nominally occupied by a creature trading as Maltby and Co.|
04085|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0325.wav|||Goods would be landed at this wharf;|
04086|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0326.wav|||Maltby and Co. would issue warrants on them deliverable to the importer, and the goods were then passed to be stored in neighboring warehouses.|
04087|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0327.wav|||The owners of the latter would then issue a second set of warrants on these goods, in total ignorance of the fact that they were already pledged.|
04088|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0328.wav|||Cole quickly raised money on both sets of warrants. He carried on this game for some time with great success,|
04089|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0329.wav|||and so developed his business that in one year his transactions amounted to a couple of millions of pounds.|
04090|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0330.wav|||He had several narrow escapes.|
04091|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0331.wav|||Once a warrant-holder sent down a clerk to view certain goods, and the clerk found that these goods had already a "stop" upon them, or were pledged.|
04092|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0332.wav|||Cole escaped by throwing the blame on a careless partner, and at once removed the "stop."|
04093|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0333.wav|||Again, some of the duplicate and fictitious warrants were held by a firm which suspended payment, and there was no knowing into whose hands they might fall.|
04094|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0334.wav|||Cole found out where they were, and redeemed them at a heavy outlay, thus obtaining business relations with the firm that held them,|
04095|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0335.wav|||which were soon developed, much to that firm's subsequent anger and regret.|
04096|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0336.wav|||Last of all, the well-known bankers Overend and Gurney, whose own affairs created much excitement some years later,|
04097|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0337.wav|||wishing to verify the value of warrants they held, and sending to Maltby and Co.'s wharf, found out half the truth.|
04098|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0338.wav|||These bankers, wishing for more specific information,|
04099|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0339.wav|||asked Davidson and Gordon, a firm with which Cole was closely allied, whether the warrants meant goods or nothing.|
04100|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ014-0340.wav|||They could not deny that the latter was the truth, and were forthwith stigmatized by Mr. Chapman, Overend and Gurney's representative, as rogues.|
04101|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0001.wav|||Chronicles of Newgate, Volume two. By Arthur Griffiths. Section eighteen: Newgate notorieties continued, part three.|
04102|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0002.wav|||The course of the swindlers was by no means smooth, but it was not till eighteen fifty-four that suspicion arose that anything was wrong.|
04103|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0003.wav|||A firm which held a lot of warrants suddenly demanded the delivery of the goods they covered.|
04104|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0004.wav|||The goods having no existence, Cole of course could not deliver them.|
04105|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0005.wav|||About this time Davidson and Gordon, the people above-mentioned,|
04106|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0006.wav|||who had fraudulent warrants out of their own to the extent of one hundred fifty thousand pounds, suspended payment and absconded.|
04107|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0007.wav|||This affected Cole's credit, and ugly reports were in circulation charging him with the issue of simulated warrants.|
04108|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0008.wav|||These indeed were out to the value of three hundred sixty-seven thousand, eight hundred pounds.|
04109|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0009.wav|||Cole's difficulties increased more and more; warrant-holders came down upon him demanding to realize their goods.|
04110|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0010.wav|||Cole now suspended payment.|
04111|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0011.wav|||Maltby, who had bolted, was pursued and arrested, to end his life miserably by committing suicide in a Newgate cell.|
04112|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0012.wav|||Cole too was apprehended, and in due course tried at the Central Criminal Court.|
04113|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0013.wav|||He was found guilty, and sentenced to the seemingly inadequate punishment of four years' transportation.|
04114|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0014.wav|||Davidson and Gordon were also sentenced to imprisonment.|
04115|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0015.wav|||A more distressing case stands next on the criminal records --|
04116|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0016.wav|||the failure and subsequent sentence of the bankers Messrs. Strahan, Paul, and Bates,|
04117|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0017.wav|||for the fraudulent disposal of securities lodged in their hands. This firm was one of the oldest banking establishments in the kingdom,|
04118|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0018.wav|||and dated back to the Commonwealth, when, under the title of Snow and Walton, it carried on business as pawnbrokers.|
04119|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0019.wav|||The Strahan of the firm which came to grief was a Snow who changed his name for a fortune of two hundred thousand pounds;|
04120|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0020.wav|||he was a man esteemed and respected in society and the world of finance, incapable as it was thought of a dishonest deed.|
04121|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0021.wav|||Sir John Dean Paul had inherited a baronetcy from his father, together with an honored name;|
04122|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0022.wav|||he was himself a prominent member of the Low Church, of austere piety, active in all good works.|
04123|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0023.wav|||Mr. Bates had been confidential managing clerk, and was taken into the firm not alone as a reward for long and faithful service|
04124|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0024.wav|||but that he might strengthen it by his long experience and known business capacity.|
04125|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0025.wav|||The bank enjoyed an excellent reputation, it had a good connection, and was supposed to be perfectly sound.|
04126|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0026.wav|||Moreover, the partners were sober, steady men, who paid unremitting attention to business.|
04127|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0027.wav|||Yet even so early as the death of the first Sir John Paul,|
04128|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0028.wav|||the bank was insolvent, and instead of starting on a fresh life with a new name, it should then and there have closed its doors.|
04129|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0029.wav|||In December eighteen fifty-one the balance sheet showed a deficiency of upwards of seventy thousand pounds.|
04130|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0030.wav|||The bank had been conducted on false principles;|
04131|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0031.wav|||it had assumed enormous responsibilities -- on one side by the ownership of the Mostyn collieries, a valueless property,|
04132|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0032.wav|||and on the other by backing up|
04133|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0033.wav|||an impecunious and rotten firm of contractors with vast liabilities and pledged to impossible works abroad.|
04134|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0034.wav|||The engagements of the bank on these two heads amounting to nearly half a million of money,|
04135|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0035.wav|||produced immediate embarrassment and financial distress.|
04136|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0036.wav|||The bank was already insolvent,|
04137|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0037.wav|||and the partners had to decide between suspending payment or continuing to hold its head above water by flagitious processes.|
04138|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0038.wav|||They chose, unhappily for themselves, the latter alternative.|
04139|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0039.wav|||Money they must have, and money they raised to meet their urgent necessities upon the balances and securities deposited with them by their customers.|
04140|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0040.wav|||This borrowing continued, and on such a scale that their paper was soon at a discount,|
04141|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0041.wav|||and the various discount houses would not advance sufficient sums to relieve the necessities of the bank.|
04142|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0042.wav|||Then it was that instead of merely pledging securities, the bank sold them outright, and thus passed the Rubicon of fraud.|
04143|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0043.wav|||This went on for some time, and might never have been discovered had some good stroke of luck provided any of the partners|
04144|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0044.wav|||with money enough to retrieve the position of the bank. But that passed from bad to worse;|
04145|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0045.wav|||the firm's paper went down further and further in value; an application to the Committee of Bankers for assistance was peremptorily refused,|
04146|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0046.wav|||then came a run on the bank, and it was compelled to stop payment.|
04147|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0047.wav|||Its debts amounted to three-quarters of a million, and the dividend it eventually paid was three and twopence in the pound.|
04148|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0048.wav|||But worse than the bankruptcy was the confession made by the partners in the court.|
04149|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0049.wav|||They admitted that they had made away with many of the securities entrusted to their keeping.|
04150|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0050.wav|||Following this, warrants were issued for their arrest,|
04151|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0051.wav|||the specific charge being the unlawful negotiation of Danish bonds and other shares belonging to the Rev. Dr. Griffiths of Rochester|
04152|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0052.wav|||to the value of twenty thousand pounds.|
04153|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0053.wav|||Bates was at once captured in Norfolk Street, Strand.|
04154|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0054.wav|||Police officers went down at night to Nutfield, near Reigate, and arrested Sir John Paul, but allowed the prisoner to sleep there.|
04155|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0055.wav|||Next morning they only just saved the train to town, and left Sir John behind on the platform, but he subsequently surrendered himself.|
04156|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0056.wav|||Mr. Strahan was arrested at a friend's house in Bryanston Square.|
04157|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0057.wav|||All three were tried at the Central Criminal Court, and sentenced to fourteen years' transportation, passing some time in Newgate en route.|
04158|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0058.wav|||Bates, the least guilty, was pardoned in eighteen fifty-eight.|
04159|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0059.wav|||Two cases of extensive embezzlement which were discovered almost simultaneously, those of Robson and Redpath,|
04160|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0060.wav|||will long be remembered both within and without the commercial world.|
04161|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0061.wav|||They both reproduced many of the features of the case of Watts, already described,|
04162|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0062.wav|||but in neither did the sums misappropriated reach quite the same high figure.|
04163|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0063.wav|||But neither Robson nor Redpath would have been able to pursue their fraudulent designs with success had they not, like Watts,|
04164|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0064.wav|||been afforded peculiar facilities by the slackness of system and the want of methodical administration in the concerns by which they were employed.|
04165|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0065.wav|||Robson was of humble origin, but he was well educated, and he had some literary abilities.|
04166|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0066.wav|||His proclivities were theatrical, and he was the author of several plays,|
04167|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0067.wav|||one at least of which, 'Love and Loyalty,' with Wallack in a leading part, achieved a certain success.|
04168|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0068.wav|||He began life as a law-writer, earning thereby some fifteen or eighteen shillings a week;|
04169|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0069.wav|||but the firm he served got him a situation as clerk in the office of the Great Northern Railway,|
04170|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0070.wav|||whence he passed to a better position under the Crystal Palace Company.|
04171|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0071.wav|||He now married, although his salary was only a pound a week; but he soon got on.|
04172|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0072.wav|||He had a pleasant address, showed good business aptitudes, and quickly acquired the approval of his superiors.|
04173|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0073.wav|||Within a year he was advanced to the post of chief clerk in the transfer department, at a salary of one hundred fifty pounds a year.|
04174|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0074.wav|||His immediate chief was a Mr. Fasson, upon whose confidence he gained so rapidly, through his activity, industry, and engaging manners,|
04175|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0075.wav|||that ere long the whole management of the transfer department was entrusted to him.|
04176|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0076.wav|||Some time elapsed before Robson succumbed to temptation.|
04177|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0077.wav|||He was not the first man of loose morality and expensive tastes|
04178|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0078.wav|||who preferred to risk his future reputation and liberty to the present discomfort of living upon narrow means.|
04179|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0079.wav|||The temptation was all the greater because the chances of successful fraud lay ready to hand.|
04180|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0080.wav|||Shares in the company were represented by certificates, which often enough never left the company's, or more exactly Robson's, hands.|
04181|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0081.wav|||He conceived the idea of transferring shares, bogus shares from a person who held none, to any one who would buy them in the open market.|
04182|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0082.wav|||He took it for granted that the certificates representing these bogus shares, and which practically did not exist, would never be called for.|
04183|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0083.wav|||This ingenious method of raising funds he adopted and carried on without detection,|
04184|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0084.wav|||till the defalcations from fraudulent transfers and fraudulent issues combined amounted to twenty-seven thousand pounds.|
04185|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0085.wav|||With the proceeds of these flagitious frauds Robson feasted and made merry.|
04186|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0086.wav|||He kept open house at Kilburn Priory;|
04187|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0087.wav|||entertained literary, artistic, and dramatic celebrities; had a smart "turn out," attended all the race-meetings, and dressed in the latest fashion.|
04188|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0088.wav|||To his wife, poor soul, he made no pretense of fidelity, and she enjoyed only so much of his company as was necessarily spent|
04189|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0089.wav|||in receiving guests at home, or could be spared from two rival establishments in other parts of the town.|
04190|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0090.wav|||To account for his revenues he pretended to have been very lucky on the Stock Exchange, which was at one time true to a limited extent,|
04191|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0091.wav|||and to have succeeded in other speculations.|
04192|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0092.wav|||When his friends asked why he, a wealthy man of independent means, continued to slave on as a clerk on a pittance,|
04193|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0093.wav|||he replied gaily that his regular work at the Crystal Palace office was useful as a sort of discipline, and kept him steady.|
04194|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0094.wav|||All this time his position was one of extreme insecurity. He was standing over a mine which at any moment might explode.|
04195|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0095.wav|||The blow fell suddenly, and when least expected. One morning Mr. Fasson asked casually for certain certificates,|
04196|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0096.wav|||whether representing real or fictitious shares does not appear; but they were certificates connected in some way with Robson's long practiced frauds|
04197|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0097.wav|||and he could not produce them. His chief asked sternly where they were.|
04198|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0098.wav|||Robson said they were at Kilburn Priory.|
04199|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0099.wav|||Let us go to Kilburn for them together, said Mr. Fasson, growing suspicious.|
04200|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0100.wav|||They drove there, and Robson on arrival did the honors of his house, rang for lunch to gain time,|
04201|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0101.wav|||but at Mr. Fasson's pressing demands went upstairs to fetch the certificates.|
04202|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0102.wav|||He came back to explain that he had mislaid them.|
04203|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0103.wav|||Mr. Fasson, more and more ill at ease, would not accept this subterfuge, and declared they must be found.|
04204|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0104.wav|||Robson again left him, but only to gather together hastily all the money and valuables on which he could lay his hands, with which he left the house.|
04205|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0105.wav|||Mr. Fasson waited and waited for his subordinate to re-appear, and at last discovered his flight.|
04206|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0106.wav|||A reward was forthwith offered for Robson's apprehension.|
04207|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0107.wav|||Meanwhile the absconding clerk had coolly driven to a favorite dining-place in the West End,|
04208|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0108.wav|||where a fish curry and a brace of partridges were set before him,|
04209|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0109.wav|||and he discussed the latter with appetite, but begged that they would never give him curry again, as he did not like it.|
04210|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0110.wav|||After dinner he went into hiding for a day or two,|
04211|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0111.wav|||then, accompanied by a lady, not Mrs. Robson, he took steamer and started for Copenhagen.|
04212|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0112.wav|||But the continental police had been warned to look out for him, and two Danish inspectors got upon his track,|
04213|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0113.wav|||followed him over to Sweden, and arrested him at Helsingfors.|
04214|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0114.wav|||Thence he was transferred to Copenhagen and surrendered in due course to a London police officer.|
04215|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0115.wav|||Little more remains to be said about Robson. He appears to have accepted his position, and to have at once resigned himself to his fate.|
04216|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0116.wav|||When brought to trial he took matters very coolly, and at first pleaded "Not Guilty," but subsequently withdrew the plea.|
04217|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0117.wav|||Sergeant Ballantine, who prosecuted,|
04218|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0118.wav|||paid him the compliment of describing him as "a young man of great intelligence, considerable powers of mind,|
04219|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0119.wav|||and possessed of an education very much beyond the rank of life to which he originally belonged."|
04220|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0120.wav|||Robson was found guilty, and sentenced to two terms of transportation, one for twenty and one for fourteen years.|
04221|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0121.wav|||Newgate officers who remember Robson still describe him as a fine young man, who behaved well as a prisoner,|
04222|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0122.wav|||but who had all the appearance of a careless, thoughtless, happy-go-lucky fellow.|
04223|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0123.wav|||In many respects the embezzlement of which Leopold Redpath was guilty closely resembled that of Robson,|
04224|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0124.wav|||but it was based upon more extended and audacious forgeries.|
04225|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0125.wav|||Redpath's crime arose from his peculiar and independent position as registrar of stock of the Great Northern Railway Company.|
04226|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0126.wav|||This offered him great facilities for the creation of artificial stock, its sale from a fictitious holder, and transfer to himself.|
04227|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0127.wav|||All the signatures in the transfer were forged. Not only did he thus transfer and realize "bogus" stock|
04228|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0128.wav|||but he bought bona fide amounts, and increased their value by altering the figures,|
04229|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0129.wav|||by inserting say one before five hundred, and thus making it|
04230|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0130.wav|||fifteen hundred pounds, which larger amount was duly carried to his credit on the register, and entered upon the certificates of transfer.|
04231|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0131.wav|||By these means Redpath misappropriated vast sums during a period extending over ten years.|
04232|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0132.wav|||The total amount was never exactly made out, but the false stock created and issued by him was estimated at two hundred twenty thousand pounds.|
04233|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0133.wav|||Even when the bubble burst Redpath, who had lived at the rate of twenty thousand a year,|
04234|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0134.wav|||had assets in the shape of land, house, furniture, pictures, and objets d'art to the value of fifty thousand pounds.|
04235|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0135.wav|||He began in a very small way.|
04236|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0136.wav|||First a lawyer's clerk, he then got an appointment in the Peninsular and Oriental Company's office;|
04237|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0137.wav|||afterwards he set up as an insurance broker on his own account, but presently failed.|
04238|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0138.wav|||His fault was generosity,|
04239|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0139.wav|||an open-handed, unthinking charity which gave freely to the poor and needy the money which belonged to his creditors.|
04240|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0140.wav|||After his bankruptcy he obtained a place as clerk in the Great Northern Railway office,|
04241|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0141.wav|||from which he rose to be assistant registrar, with the special duties of transferring shares.|
04242|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0142.wav|||He soon proved his ability, and by unremitting attention mastered the whole work of the office.|
04243|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0143.wav|||Later on he became registrar, and in this more independent position|
04244|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0144.wav|||developed to a colossal extent the frauds he had already practiced as a subordinate.|
04245|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0145.wav|||Now he launched out into great expenditure, took a house in Chester Terrace, and became known as a Maecenas and patron of the arts.|
04246|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0146.wav|||He had a nice taste in bric-à-brac, and was considered a good judge of pictures.|
04247|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0147.wav|||Leading social and artistic personages were to be met with at his house, and his hospitality was far famed.|
04248|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0148.wav|||The choicest wines, the finest fruits,|
04249|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0149.wav|||peas at ten shillings a quart, five-guinea pines, and early asparagus were to be found on his table.|
04250|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0150.wav|||But his chief extravagance, his favorite folly, was the exercise of an ostentatious benevolence.|
04251|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0151.wav|||The philanthropy he had displayed in a small way when less prosperous became now a passion.|
04252|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0152.wav|||His name headed every subscription list; his purse was always open.|
04253|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0153.wav|||Not content with giving where assistance was solicited, he himself sought out deserving cases and personally afforded relief.|
04254|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0154.wav|||When the crash came there were pensioners and other recipients of his bounty who could not believe|
04255|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0155.wav|||that so good a man had really been for years a swindler and a rogue.|
04256|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0156.wav|||Down at Weybridge, where he had a country place, his name was long remembered with gratitude by the poor.|
04257|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0157.wav|||During the days of his prosperity he was a governor of Christ's Hospital,|
04258|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0158.wav|||of the St. Ann's Society, and one of the supporters and managers of the Patriotic Fund.|
04259|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0159.wav|||In his person he was neat and fastidious;|
04260|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0160.wav|||he patronized the best tailors, and had a fashionable coiffeur from Hanover Square daily to curl his hair.|
04261|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0161.wav|||There was something dramatic in Redpath's detection|
04262|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0162.wav|||Just after Robson's frauds had agitated the minds of all directors of companies, the chairman of the Great Northern (Mr. Denison)|
04263|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0163.wav|||was standing at a railway station talking to a certain well-known peer of the realm.|
04264|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0164.wav|||Redpath passed and lifted his hat to his chairman; the latter acknowledged the salute.|
04265|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0165.wav|||But the peer rushed forward and shook Redpath warmly by the hand.|
04266|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0166.wav|||What do you know of our clerk? asked Mr. Denison of his lordship. "Only that he is a capital fellow, who gives the best dinners and balls in town."|
04267|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0167.wav|||Redpath had industriously circulated reports that he had prospered greatly in speculation;|
04268|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0168.wav|||but the chairman of the Great Northern could not realize that a clerk of the company could honestly be in the possession of unlimited wealth.|
04269|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0169.wav|||It was at once decided at the board to make a thorough examination of all his books.|
04270|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0170.wav|||Redpath was called in and informed of the intended investigation. He tried to stave off the evil hour by declaring that everything was perfectly right;|
04271|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0171.wav|||but finding he could not escape, he said he would resign his post, and leaving the boardroom, disappeared.|
04272|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0172.wav|||The inquiry soon revealed the colossal character of the frauds.|
04273|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0173.wav|||Warrants were issued for Redpath's arrest, but he had flown to Paris.|
04274|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0174.wav|||Thither police officers followed, only to find that he had returned to London.|
04275|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0175.wav|||A further search discovered him at breakfast at a small house in the New Road.|
04276|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0176.wav|||He was arrested, examined before a police magistrate, and committed to Newgate.|
04277|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0177.wav|||Great excitement prevailed in the city and the West End when Redpath's defalcations were made public.|
04278|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0178.wav|||The Stock Market was greatly affected, and society, more especially that which frequents Exeter Hall, was convulsed.|
04279|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0179.wav|||The Central Criminal Court, when the trial came on,|
04280|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0180.wav|||was densely crowded, and many curious eyes were turned upon the somewhat remarkable man who occupied the dock.|
04281|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0181.wav|||He is described by a contemporary account as a fresh-looking man of forty years of age, slightly bald, inclined to embonpoint,|
04282|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0182.wav|||and thoroughly embodying the idea of English respectability.|
04283|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0183.wav|||His manner was generally self-possessed, but his face was marked with "uneasy earnestness,"|
04284|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0184.wav|||and he looked about him with wayward, furtive glances.|
04285|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0185.wav|||When the jury found a verdict of guilty he remained unmoved. He listened without emotion to the judge's well-merited censures,|
04286|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0186.wav|||and received his sentence of transportation for life without much surprise.|
04287|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0187.wav|||Redpath passed away into the outer darkness of a penal colony, where he was still living a year or two back|
04288|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0188.wav|||But his name lingers still in this country as that of the first swindler of his time,|
04289|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0189.wav|||and the prototype of a class not uncommon in our later days|
04290|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0190.wav|||that of dishonest rogues who assume piety and philanthropy as a cloak for their misdeeds.|
04291|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0191.wav|||In Newgate Redpath is remembered by the prison officer as a difficult man to deal with.|
04292|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0192.wav|||From the moment of his reception he gave himself great airs, as a martyr and a man heavily wronged.|
04293|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0193.wav|||By-and-by, when escape seemed hopeless, and after sentence, he suddenly degenerated into the lowest stamp of criminal,|
04294|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0194.wav|||and behaved so as to justify a belief that he had been a jail-bird all his life.|
04295|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0195.wav|||It has been already remarked in these pages that with changed social conditions came a great change in the character of crimes.|
04296|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0196.wav|||Highway robberies, for instance, had disappeared, if we except the spasmodic and severely repressed outbreak of "garotting,"|
04297|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0197.wav|||which at one time spread terror throughout London. Thieves preferred now to use ingenuity rather than brute force.|
04298|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0198.wav|||It was no longer possible to stop a coach or carriage, or rob the postman who carried the mail.|
04299|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0199.wav|||The improved methods of locomotion had put a stop to these depredations. People traveled in company, as a rule;|
04300|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0200.wav|||only when single and unprotected were they in any danger of attack, and that but rarely.|
04301|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0201.wav|||There were still big prizes, however, to tempt the daring, and none appealed more to the thievish instinct than the custom of transmitting gold by rail.|
04302|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0202.wav|||The precious metal was sent from place to place carefully locked up and guarded, no doubt;|
04303|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0203.wav|||but were the precautions too minute, the vigilance too close to be eluded or overcome?|
04304|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0204.wav|||This was the question which presented itself to the fertile brain of one Pierce,|
04305|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0205.wav|||who had been concerned in various "jobs" of a dishonest character, and who for the moment was a clerk in a betting office.|
04306|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0206.wav|||He laid the suggestion before Agar, a professional thief, who was of opinion it contained elements of success.|
04307|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0207.wav|||But the collusion and active assistance of employees of the railway carriers were indispensable, and together|
04308|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0208.wav|||they sounded one Burgess, a guard on the South-Eastern Railway, a line by which large quantities of bullion were sent to the Continent.|
04309|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0209.wav|||Burgess detailed the whole system of transmission.|
04310|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0210.wav|||The gold, packed in an iron-bound box, was securely lodged in safes locked with patent Chubbs.|
04311|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0211.wav|||Each safe had three sets of double keys, all held by confidential servants of the company.|
04312|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0212.wav|||One pair was with the traffic superintendent in London, another with an official in Folkestone,|
04313|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0213.wav|||a third with the captain of the Folkestone and Boulogne boat.|
04314|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0214.wav|||At the other side of the Channel the French railway authorities took charge.|
04315|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0215.wav|||The safes while on the line en route between London and Folkestone were in the guard's van.|
04316|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0216.wav|||This was an important step, and they might easily be robbed some day when Burgess was the guard, provided only that they could be opened.|
04317|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0217.wav|||The next step was to get impressions and fabricate false keys.|
04318|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0218.wav|||A new accomplice was now needed within the company's establishment, and Pierce looked about long before he found the right person.|
04319|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0219.wav|||At last he decided to enlist one Tester, a clerk in the traffic department, whom he thought would prove a likely tool.|
04320|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0220.wav|||The four waited patiently for their opportunity,|
04321|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0221.wav|||which came when the safes were sent to Chubbs' to be repaired; and Chubbs sent them back, but only with one key,|
04322|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0222.wav|||in such a way that Tester had possession of this key for a time.|
04323|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0223.wav|||He lent it to Agar for a brief space, who promptly took an impression on wax. But the safes had a double lock;|
04324|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0224.wav|||the difficulty was to get a copy of the second key.|
04325|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0225.wav|||This was at length effected by Agar and Pierce.|
04326|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0226.wav|||After hanging about the Folkestone office for some time, they saw at last that the key was kept in a certain cupboard.|
04327|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0227.wav|||Still watching and waiting for the first chance, they seized it when the clerks left the office empty for a moment.|
04328|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0228.wav|||Pierce boldly stepped in, found the cupboard unlocked; he removed the key, handed it to Agar outside,|
04329|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0229.wav|||who quickly took the wax impression, handed it back to Pierce; Pierce replaced it, left the office, and the thing was done.|
04330|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0230.wav|||After this nothing remained but to wait for some occasion when the amount transmitted would be sufficient to justify the risks of robbery.|
04331|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0231.wav|||It was Tester's business, who had access to the railway company's books, to watch for this.|
04332|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0232.wav|||Meanwhile the others completed their preparations with the utmost care.|
04333|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0233.wav|||A weight of shot was bought and stowed in carpet bags ready to replace exactly the abstracted gold.|
04334|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0234.wav|||Courier bags were bought to carry the "stuff" slung over the shoulders;|
04335|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0235.wav|||and last, but not least, Agar frequently traveled up and down the line to test the false keys he had manufactured with Pierce's assistance.|
04336|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0236.wav|||Burgess admitted him into the guard's van, where he fitted and filed the keys till they worked easily and satisfactorily in the locks of the safe.|
04337|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0237.wav|||One night Tester whispered to Agar and Pierce, "All right," as they cautiously lounged about London Bridge.|
04338|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0238.wav|||The thieves took first-class tickets, handed their bags full of shot to the porters, who placed them in the guard's van.|
04339|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0239.wav|||Just as the train was starting Agar slipped into the van with Burgess, and Pierce got into a first-class carriage.|
04340|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0240.wav|||Agar at once got to work on the first safe.|
04341|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0241.wav|||opened it, took out and broke into the bullion box, removed the gold, substituted the shot from a carpet bag,|
04342|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0242.wav|||re-fastened and re-sealed the bullion box, and replaced it in the safe.|
04343|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0243.wav|||At Redhill Tester met the train and relieved the thieves of a portion of the stolen gold.|
04344|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0244.wav|||At the same station Pierce joined Agar in the guard's van, and there were now three to carry on the robbery.|
04345|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0245.wav|||The two remaining safes were attacked and nearly entirely despoiled in the same way as the first, and the contents transferred to the courier bags.|
04346|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0246.wav|||The train was now approaching Folkestone, and Agar and Pierce hid themselves in a dark part of the van.|
04347|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0247.wav|||At that station the safes were given out, heavy with shot, not gold; the thieves went on to Dover, and by-and-by,|
04348|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0248.wav|||with Ostend tickets previously procured, returned to London without mishap, and by degrees disposed of much of the stolen gold.|
04349|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0249.wav|||The theft was discovered at Boulogne, when the boxes were found not to weigh exactly what they ought. But no clue was obtained to the thieves,|
04350|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0250.wav|||and the theft might have remained a mystery but for the subsequent bad faith of Pierce to his accomplice Agar.|
04351|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0251.wav|||The latter was ere long arrested on a charge of uttering forged cheques, convicted, and sentenced to transportation for life.|
04352|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0252.wav|||When he knew that he could not escape his fate,|
04353|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0253.wav|||he handed over to Pierce a sum of three thousand pounds, his own, whether rightly or wrongly acquired never came out,|
04354|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0254.wav|||together with the unrealized part of the bullion, amounting in all to some fifteen thousand pounds,|
04355|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0255.wav|||and begged his accomplice to invest it as a settlement on a woman named Kay, by whom he had had a child.|
04356|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0256.wav|||Pierce made Kay only a few small payments, then appropriated the rest of the money.|
04357|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0257.wav|||Kay, who had been living with Agar at the time of the bullion robbery,|
04358|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0258.wav|||went to the police in great fury and distress, and disclosed all she knew of the affair.|
04359|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0259.wav|||Agar too, in Newgate, heard how Pierce had treated him, and at once readily turned approver.|
04360|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0260.wav|||As the evidence he gave incriminated Pierce, Burgess, and Tester, all three were arrested and committed to Newgate for trial.|
04361|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0261.wav|||The whole strange story, the long incubation and the elaborate accomplishment of the plot,|
04362|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0262.wav|||came out at the Old Bailey, and was acknowledged to be one of the most extraordinary on record.|
04363|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0263.wav|||Scarcely had the conviction of these daring and astute thieves been assured, than another gigantic fraud was brought to light.|
04364|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0264.wav|||The series of boldly-conceived and cleverly-executed forgeries in which James Townshend Saward, commonly called "Jem the Penman,"|
04365|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0265.wav|||was the prime mover,|
04366|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0266.wav|||has probably no parallel in the annals of crime. Saward himself is a striking and in some respects an unique figure in criminal history.|
04367|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0267.wav|||A man of birth and education, a member of the bar, and of acknowledged legal attainments, his proclivities were all downward.|
04368|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0268.wav|||Instead of following an honorable profession, he preferred to turn his great natural talents and ready wits to the most nefarious practices.|
04369|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0269.wav|||He was known to the whole criminal fraternity as a high-class receiver of stolen goods, a negotiator more especially of stolen paper,|
04370|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0270.wav|||cheques and bills, of which he made a particular use.|
04371|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0271.wav|||He dealt too in the precious metals, when they had been improperly acquired,|
04372|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0272.wav|||and it was to him that Agar, Pierce, and the rest applied when seeking to dispose of their stolen bullion.|
04373|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0273.wav|||But Saward's operations were mainly directed to the fabrication and uttering of forged cheques.|
04374|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0274.wav|||His method was comprehensive and deeply laid.|
04375|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0275.wav|||Burglars brought him the cheques they stole from houses, thieves what they got in pocketbooks.|
04376|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0276.wav|||Cheques blank and canceled were his stock-in-trade. The former he filled up by exact imitation of the latter, signature and all.|
04377|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0277.wav|||When he could get nothing but the blank cheque, he set in motion all sorts of schemes for obtaining signatures, such as|
04378|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0278.wav|||commencing sham actions, and addressing formal applications, merely for the reply.|
04379|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0279.wav|||One stroke of luck which he turned to great account|
04380|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0280.wav|||was the return from transportation of an old "pal" and confederate, who brought with him some bills of exchange.|
04381|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0281.wav|||Saward's method of negotiating the cheques was equally well planned.|
04382|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0282.wav|||Like his great predecessor Old Patch, he never went to a bank himself, nor did any of his accomplices.|
04383|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0283.wav|||The bearer of the cheque was always innocent and ignorant of the fraudulent nature of the document he presented.|
04384|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0284.wav|||In order to obtain messengers of this sort, Saward answered advertisements of persons seeking employment,|
04385|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0285.wav|||and when these presented themselves, entrusted them as a beginning with the duty of cashing cheques.|
04386|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0286.wav|||A confederate followed the emissary closely,|
04387|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0287.wav|||not only to ensure fair play and the surrender of the proceeds if the cheque was cashed, but to give timely notice if it was not,|
04388|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0288.wav|||so that Saward and the rest might make themselves scarce.|
04389|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0289.wav|||As each transaction was carried out from a different address, and a different messenger always employed,|
04390|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0290.wav|||the forgers always escaped detection. But fate overtook two of the gang,|
04391|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0291.wav|||partly through their own carelessness, when transferring their operations to Yarmouth.|
04392|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0292.wav|||One named Hardwicke assumed the name of Ralph, and, to obtain commercial credit in Yarmouth, paid in two hundred fifty pounds to a Yarmouth bank|
04393|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0293.wav|||as coming from a Mr. Whitney.|
04394|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0294.wav|||He forgot to add that it was to be placed to Ralph's credit, and when he called as Ralph,|
04395|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0295.wav|||he was told it was only at Mr. Whitney's disposal, and that it could be paid to no one else.|
04396|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0296.wav|||Hardwicke, or "Ralph," appealed to Saward in his difficulty|
04397|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0297.wav|||and that clever schemer sent an elaborate letter of instructions how to ask for the money.|
04398|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0298.wav|||But while Hardwicke was in communication with Saward, the bank was in communication with London|
04399|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0299.wav|||and the circumstances were deemed sufficiently suspicious to warrant the arrest of the gentlemen at Yarmouth on a charge of forgery and conspiracy.|
04400|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0300.wav|||Saward's letter to Hardwicke fell into the hands of the police and compromised him.|
04401|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0301.wav|||While Hardwicke and Atwell were in Newgate awaiting trial, active search was made for Saward,|
04402|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0302.wav|||who was at length taken in a coffee-shop near Oxford Street, under the name of Hopkins. He resisted at first, and denied his identity,|
04403|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0303.wav|||but on being searched, two blank cheques of the London and Westminster Bank were found in his pocket.|
04404|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0304.wav|||He then confessed that he was the redoubtable Jem Saward, or Jem the Penman, and was conveyed to a police-court, and thence to Newgate.|
04405|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0305.wav|||At his trial Atwell and Hardwicke, two of his chief allies and accomplices, turned approvers,|
04406|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0306.wav|||and the whole scheme of systematic forgery was laid bare.|
04407|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0307.wav|||The evidence was corroborated by that of many of the victims who had acted as messengers,|
04408|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0308.wav|||and others who swore to the meetings of the conspirators and their movements. Saward was found guilty,|
04409|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0309.wav|||and the judge, in passing sentence on him of transportation for life, expressed deep regret that "the ingenuity, skill, and talent,|
04410|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0310.wav|||which had received so perverted and mistaken direction,|
04411|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0311.wav|||had not been guided by a sense of virtue, and directed to more honorable and useful pursuits.|
04412|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0312.wav|||The proceeds of these forgeries amounted, it was said, to some thousands per annum.|
04413|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0313.wav|||Saward spent all his share at low gaming houses, and in all manner of debaucheries.|
04414|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ015-0314.wav|||He was in person a short, square-built man of gentlemanly address, sharp and shrewd in conversation and manner.|
04415|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0001.wav|||The Chronicles of Newgate, Volume two. By Arthur Griffiths. Section nineteen: Later Records|
04416|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0002.wav|||The old notion always prevailed that Newgate was impregnable, so to speak, from within,|
04417|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0003.wav|||and that none of its inmates could hope to escape from its secure precincts.|
04418|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0004.wav|||Yet the jail, in spite of its fortress-like aspect, was by no means really safe.|
04419|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0005.wav|||Year after year prisoners determined to get free, and occasionally succeeded in their efforts.|
04420|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0006.wav|||The inspectors' reports mention many cases of evasion accomplished.|
04421|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0007.wav|||There were others less successful.|
04422|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0008.wav|||Charles Thomas White, awaiting execution for arson, made a desperate effort to escape from Newgate in eighteen twenty-seven.|
04423|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0009.wav|||He had friends and auxiliaries inside the jail and out. The cell he occupied was near the outer wall,|
04424|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0010.wav|||and had he but been able to remove its iron bars, he might have descended into Newgate Street by means of a rope ladder.|
04425|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0011.wav|||The ladder was actually made, of black sewing-thread firmly and closely interwoven. But White could not remove the bars;|
