04426|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0012.wav|||the instruments needed for the purpose never reached him.|
04427|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0013.wav|||It was noticed that he was most anxious to receive a pair of shoes for which he had asked, and when they arrived they were closely examined.|
04428|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0014.wav|||Sewn in between the upper and lower leathers several spring saws were found, which would have easily cut through any bars.|
04429|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0015.wav|||White, when taxed with his attempt, admitted that the accusation was true, and spoke "with pride and satisfaction of the practicability of his scheme."|
04430|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0016.wav|||There is an attempt at escape mentioned in Mr. Wakefield's book, which might have been an intended suicide.|
04431|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0017.wav|||John Williams, a young fellow only twenty-three years of age, awaited execution in eighteen twenty-seven for stealing in a dwelling-house.|
04432|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0018.wav|||On the very morning on which he was to suffer he eluded the vigilance, such as it was, of his officers|
04433|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0019.wav|||and climbed up the pipe of a cistern in the corner of the press yard; some thought with the idea of drowning himself.|
04434|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0020.wav|||He never reached the cistern, but fell back into the yard, injuring his legs severely.|
04435|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0021.wav|||Although his execution was imminent, a surgeon attended to his wounds, and he was carried more dead than alive to the scaffold.|
04436|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0022.wav|||A harrowing scene followed;|
04437|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0023.wav|||the wounds broke open and bled profusely while the last dread penalty was being performed, to the manifest excitement and indignation of the crowd.|
04438|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0024.wav|||A more daring and skilful escape was effected in eighteen thirty-six by the chimney-sweep Henry Williams,|
04439|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0025.wav|||who, while detained in the press-yard as a capital convict, under sentence of death for burglary,|
04440|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0026.wav|||managed to get away in the very same spot where his namesake had nine years before so miserably failed.|
04441|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0027.wav|||Escape seemed absolutely hopeless,|
04442|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0028.wav|||and would certainly have been impossible to any one less nimble than a chimney-sweep, trained under the old system to ascend the most intricate flues.|
04443|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0029.wav|||Even after Williams had got out, persons were disposed to disbelieve that the escape had been accomplished in the manner indicated;|
04444|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0030.wav|||they preferred to credit it to carelessness or collusion from officers of the jail.|
04445|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0031.wav|||Yet from the circumstantial account given by Williams after recapture, there can be little doubt that he got away as will be described.|
04446|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0032.wav|||Williams as a capital convict was lodged in the press-yard or condemned ward.|
04447|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0033.wav|||He had access to the airing yard, and there was for hours no kind of supervision.|
04448|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0034.wav|||In one corner of the airing yard stood a cistern at some height from the ground;|
04449|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0035.wav|||the wall beneath and above it was "rusticated," in other words, the granite surface had become roughened, and offered a sort of foothold.|
04450|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0036.wav|||About fifty feet from the ground level, and above the cistern, a revolving chevaux-de-frise of iron was fixed,|
04451|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0037.wav|||with only a short interval between it and the wall, supported by a horizontal iron railing with upright points;|
04452|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0038.wav|||in the wall above the chevaux-de-frise projected a series of iron spikes sharp enough to forbid further ascent.|
04453|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0039.wav|||Williams surveyed these formidable obstacles to evasion, and calmly proceeded to surmount them.|
04454|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0040.wav|||His first task was to gain the top of the cistern; this he effected by keeping his back to one side of the angle,|
04455|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0041.wav|||and working with his hands behind him, while he used his bare feet like claws upon the other side of the wall angle.|
04456|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0042.wav|||The condition of the stone surface just mentioned assisted him in this, and he managed to get beyond the cistern to the railing below the chevaux-de-frise.|
04457|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0043.wav|||The least slip now would have been fatal to him. But he could not thrust his body in through the narrow space left by the chevaux-de-frise,|
04458|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0044.wav|||and was compelled to work along the railing round three-quarters of the square of the yard,|
04459|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0045.wav|||and at length reached a point opposite the top of the building containing the condemned wards. This had been a perilous and painful task;|
04460|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0046.wav|||the spikes of the railing penetrated his flesh and made progression slow and difficult.|
04461|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0047.wav|||But the worst part of the business was to jump from this irksome foothold of the iron grating on to the top of the building just mentioned,|
04462|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0048.wav|||a distance of eight or nine feet.|
04463|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0049.wav|||He had here completed his ascent.|
04464|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0050.wav|||His next job was to descend outside Newgate.|
04465|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0051.wav|||Clambering along the roof,|
04466|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0052.wav|||he passed to the top of the ordinary's residence, hoping to find an open sky-light by which he might enter and so work downstairs.|
04467|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0053.wav|||If the worst came to the worst, he intended to have gone down some chimney, as he had often done before in the way of business.|
04468|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0054.wav|||But he did not like the risk of entering a room by the fireplace, and the chances of detection it offered.|
04469|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0055.wav|||He traversed vainly all the roofs in Newgate Street,|
04470|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0056.wav|||running a great risk of discovery as he passed by a lot of workmen at Tyler's manufactory in Warwick Square, which had formerly been the College of Physicians.|
04471|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0057.wav|||As his coat was an encumbrance, he left it on the top of the third house in Newgate Street, and thus in shirt-sleeves, barefoot and bareheaded,|
04472|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0058.wav|||he worked along to the roofs in Warwick Lane.|
04473|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0059.wav|||Here he came upon a woman on the leads hanging out clothes to dry.|
04474|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0060.wav|||Williams concealed himself behind a chimney till she had re-entered her garret,|
04475|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0061.wav|||and then following her down a step ladder into the house, told his story, appealed to and won her compassion.|
04476|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0062.wav|||She suffered him to pass downstairs.|
04477|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0063.wav|||Below he met another woman and a girl, both of whom were terrified at his appearance, but|
04478|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0064.wav|||when he explained that he was running away from the gallows they left him the road clear.|
04479|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0065.wav|||To walk out into the street was an easy affair, and he was now free, with one and fourpence in his pocket and a shirt and trousers for all his clothing.|
04480|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0066.wav|||Denied admission everywhere as a ragged, half-naked beggar,|
04481|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0067.wav|||he tramped across London Bridge to Wandsworth, where he refreshed himself with a pint of strong ale, the first sustenance he had taken since his escape,|
04482|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0068.wav|||and continued his march to Kingston, where he slept soundly under a hedge till next morning.|
04483|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0069.wav|||Entering a town, he obtained employment at once as a chimney-sweep|
04484|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0070.wav|||from a widow woman, who gave him "bub and grub," or food and one-and-sixpence, for every nine days' work.|
04485|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0071.wav|||Dissatisfied with this remuneration, he again took to the road, and tramped into Hampshire,|
04486|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0072.wav|||where he presently committed a burglary at Lymington, was caught, and lodged in Winchester Jail.|
04487|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0073.wav|||Mr. Cope, the governor of Newgate, having been communicated with, proceeded to Winchester, where he at once identified Williams.|
04488|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0074.wav|||The success, although very short-lived, which attended him, no doubt inspired other inmates of Newgate to follow his example.|
04489|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0075.wav|||It was for some time after this a constant practice to go up the chimneys in the hopes of escaping by the flue.|
04490|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0076.wav|||Even then, however, irons across barred the ascent after a certain distance, and in no one case did a fugitive get clear away.|
04491|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0077.wav|||A man named Lears, under sentence of transportation for an attempt at murder on board ship, got up part of the way,|
04492|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0078.wav|||but had to come down again covered with soot and filth just as the officers entered the ward.|
04493|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0079.wav|||Lears was rewarded by being obliged to wear cross irons on his legs, a punishment rarely inflicted in Newgate,|
04494|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0080.wav|||and probably one of the few cases of a recurrence, but under proper safeguards and limitations, to the old system of chains.|
04495|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0081.wav|||On another occasion Mr. Cope the governor came in and missed a man.|
04496|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0082.wav|||The ward was one short of its number. What had become of the fellow?|
04497|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0084.wav|||the fugitive, uncomfortably ensconced in the flue, came down of his own accord, like Colonel Colt's raccoon.|
04498|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0085.wav|||After this great iron guards, just as are to be seen in lunatic asylums,|
04499|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0086.wav|||were fixed over the fireplaces, and the prisoners had no longer access to the chimneys.|
04500|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0087.wav|||Among the escapes still remembered was one in eighteen forty-nine, accomplished by a man who had been employed|
04501|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0088.wav|||working at the roof of the chapel on the female side.|
04502|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0089.wav|||He was engaged in whitewashing and cleaning; the officer who had him in charge left him on the stairs leading to the gallery.|
04503|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0090.wav|||Taking advantage of being unobserved, he got out through the roof on to the leads, and traveled along them towards Number one, Newgate Street.|
04504|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0091.wav|||This was a public-house.|
04505|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0092.wav|||He stepped in at a garret window, coolly walked downstairs, and entered the bar.|
04506|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0093.wav|||They asked him how he had cut his hand, which was bleeding, and he said he had done it while working up on the roof.|
04507|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0094.wav|||No further notice was taken of him; no one seemingly suspected that he was a prisoner, and he was suffered to walk off without let or hindrance.|
04508|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0095.wav|||In eighteen fifty-three three men escaped in company from one of the wards in the middle yard.|
04509|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0096.wav|||They were penal servitude men, their names Bell, Brown, and Barry, and they were awaiting transfer to Leicester,|
04510|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0097.wav|||which with Wakefield was utilized as a receptacle for convicts not going to Western Australia,|
04511|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0098.wav|||or any of the new establishments at home, at Portland, Dartmoor, or elsewhere.|
04512|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0099.wav|||These men managed to cut a hole in the ceiling of the ward near the iron cage on the landing, and so got access to the roof.|
04513|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0100.wav|||At that time rope mats were still used as beds.|
04514|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0101.wav|||One of the three, shamming ill, remained all day in his ward, where he employed himself unraveling the rope from the sleeping-mats.|
04515|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0102.wav|||By evening he manufactured a good long length,|
04516|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0103.wav|||and after all was quiet the three got on to the roof through the hole, and so on to Tyler's manufactory close by,|
04517|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0104.wav|||whence they let themselves down into the street by the rope.|
04518|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0105.wav|||These men were all in prison dress at the time of their escape, but one of their number, Bell, sent back his clothes a few days later by parcel's delivery,|
04519|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0106.wav|||with a civil note to the governor, saying he had no further use for them. All three fugitives were recaptured,|
04520|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0107.wav|||Brown almost at once; then Barry, who was taken at the East End in a public-house where he had arranged to meet a pal.|
04521|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0108.wav|||The Newgate officers obtained information of this, and went to the spot, where they effected the capture,|
04522|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0109.wav|||but not till they had had an exciting chase down the street.|
04523|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0110.wav|||The third, Bell, remained longest at large. He too was run into at a lodging in the Kingsland Road.|
04524|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0111.wav|||The officers dropped on to him while he was still in bed, but as they came upstairs he jumped up and hid in a cupboard.|
04525|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0112.wav|||All three after recapture passed on, as originally intended, to Leicester, where they did their "bit" and were released;|
04526|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0113.wav|||but only to be taken soon afterwards for a fresh offense, and again pass through Newgate with sentences of penal servitude.|
04527|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0114.wav|||A later case was still more remarkable, as it was effected after the alteration of the prison and its reconstruction on the newest lines.|
04528|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0115.wav|||A sailor, Krapps by name, occupied one of the upper cells in the new block.|
04529|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0116.wav|||The doors, through incomplete knowledge of prison needs, were not, as now, sheeted with iron.|
04530|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0117.wav|||The prisoner had nothing to deal with but wooden panels, and by dint of cutting and chopping he got both the lower panels out.|
04531|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0118.wav|||Through the aperture he crept out on to the landing at the dead of night, and so down into the central space of the building.|
04532|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0119.wav|||Under superior orders all the doors and gates of this block were left open at night, to allow the night watchman to pass freely to all parts.|
04533|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0120.wav|||This was considered safer than intrusting him with keys.|
04534|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0121.wav|||Krapps walked at once into the yard and across to the female side, where he found some of the washing still hanging out to dry.|
04535|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0122.wav|||He made a strong rope with several of the sheets; then, returning to the male yard,|
04536|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0123.wav|||got hold of the step ladder used in lighting the gas, and which under our more careful supervision would have been, as now-a-days, chained up.|
04537|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0124.wav|||Cutting the cord which fastened the two legs of the step ladder, he opened them out and made one long length;|
04538|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0125.wav|||with this, placed against the wall near the chevaux-de-frise, he made an escalade.|
04539|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0126.wav|||The top of the wall was gained without difficulty.|
04540|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0127.wav|||Along this Krapps crawled, and then dropped down on to the cook-house.|
04541|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0128.wav|||He now put in requisition the rope made of the sheets, and with its help lowered himself into the street.|
04542|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0129.wav|||Down below were market-carts waiting for daylight, and among them Krapps found a refuge and friends.|
04543|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0130.wav|||The first intimation of his escape was afforded by the police, who informed the prison authorities next day that a rope was hanging down from the cook-house roof.|
04544|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0131.wav|||Nothing more was heard of Krapps. The curious thing in his case was that his offense was a trifling one;|
04545|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0132.wav|||he was still untried, but would almost certainly have escaped with a minor penalty, say of three or four months' imprisonment.|
04546|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0133.wav|||There is, however, no explanation of the motives which prompt prisoners to attempt escapes.|
04547|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0134.wav|||Cases well authenticated have been known of men who had all but completed their sentences, and for whom the prison gates would open within a few days,|
04548|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0135.wav|||who yet faced extraordinary risks to advance their enlargement by only a few hours.|
04549|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0136.wav|||On the other hand, at the great convict establishments, such is the moral restraint of a systematic discipline,|
04550|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0137.wav|||that numbers of men, "lifers," and others with ten, fourteen, or twenty years to do, can be trusted to work out of doors without bolts and bars|
04551|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0138.wav|||at a distance from the prison.|
04552|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0139.wav|||The last escape from Newgate was only three years ago, and occurred just before the final closing of the prison.|
04553|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0140.wav|||No report of it was made public, as the man was almost immediately recaptured.|
04554|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0141.wav|||He was at work under the supervision of the artisan warder of the prison,|
04555|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0142.wav|||who permitted him to go up on to the roof of the old wards, in order to throw water for flushing purposes down a shoot.|
04556|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0143.wav|||He was out of sight while so employed, and remained so long absent that the warder, becoming uneasy, went in search of him.|
04557|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0144.wav|||He had disappeared.|
04558|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0145.wav|||Encouraged by the shouts and signals of some workmen employed on a building outside, the prisoner made one of the most marvellous jumps on record,|
04559|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0146.wav|||from the building he was on to a distant wall, with a drop of sixty feet between.|
04560|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0147.wav|||Then he ran along the coping of the wall towards its angle with Tyler's manufactory, and dropped down on to the gridiron below.|
04561|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0148.wav|||This was not strong enough to carry him, and he fell through.|
04562|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0149.wav|||Suicides and executions were, however, always the most effectual methods of making exit from durance.|
04563|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0150.wav|||Suicides at Newgate were numerous enough, but they seldom possessed any novel or unusual features;|
04564|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0151.wav|||prison suicides seldom do, except as regards ingenuity and determination.|
04565|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0152.wav|||Only great resolution indeed, persisted in to the bitter end,|
04566|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0153.wav|||would make death a certainty, so limited and imperfect are the means generally available.|
04567|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0154.wav|||When a bit of rope carefully secreted,|
04568|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0155.wav|||braces, shoe-strings, shirt torn into strips are the only instruments, and a bar or small hook|
04569|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0156.wav|||at no elevation affords the only drop, strangulation would seldom supervene but for the resolution of the miserable felo de se.|
04570|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0157.wav|||One curious instance of a suicide carried out under the most adverse and extraordinary circumstances may be quoted.|
04571|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0158.wav|||It was that of a "Long Firm" swindler, by name Johnson,|
04572|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0159.wav|||who contrived to hang himself from a hammock hook only eighteen inches from the ground.|
04573|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0160.wav|||The noose was one of his hammock straps, which he buckled round his throat.|
04574|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0161.wav|||Having carefully spread out a blanket on the floor just below the hammock as it lay suspended,|
04575|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0162.wav|||he fastened one end of the strap above mentioned to the hook, and then fell down.|
04576|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0163.wav|||He might have saved himself at any moment by merely extending an arm; but he lay there patiently till death supervened.|
04577|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0164.wav|||When discovered next morning, quite dead, it was found that the strap actually did not touch his throat;|
04578|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0165.wav|||three fingers might have been inserted between it and the flesh; the pressure was all on the arteries behind the ears,|
04579|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0166.wav|||and surgical opinion stated that the stoppage of circulation was the cause of death.|
04580|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0167.wav|||Probably dissolution came as easily and almost without pain.|
04581|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0168.wav|||A laudable desire to invest executions with more and more solemnity and decorum gained ground as they became more rare.|
04582|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0169.wav|||As more humane principles were introduced into prison management,|
04583|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0170.wav|||greater attention was paid to the capital convicts, and the horrors of their situation while awaiting sentence|
04584|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0171.wav|||were as far as possible mitigated and toned down. But there was little improvement in the ceremony itself.|
04585|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0172.wav|||There were still untoward accidents occasionally at executions, and even the chief practitioner of recent times, Calcraft,|
04586|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0173.wav|||was not always to be trusted to do his fell work efficiently.|
04587|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0174.wav|||Having mentioned Calcraft's name,|
04588|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0175.wav|||I may be permitted to digress for a moment to give a few particulars concerning the last officially appointed hangman of the city of London.|
04589|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0176.wav|||After Calcraft's resignation no successor was really appointed.|
04590|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0177.wav|||Marwood, whose name is so familiar with the present generation,|
04591|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0178.wav|||had no official status, and was merely an operator selected by the Corporation, and who, on the strength of it,|
04592|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0179.wav|||contracted with sheriffs and conveners to work by the job.|
04593|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0180.wav|||But Calcraft regularly succeeded Foxen, who followed Botting, and Dennis, the actor in the seventeen eighty riots.|
04594|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0181.wav|||Calcraft was born at Baddow, in Essex, in eighteen hundred;|
04595|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0182.wav|||he was a shoemaker by trade, and settled in London after his marriage in eighteen twenty-five.|
04596|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0183.wav|||The story goes, that about eighteen twenty-eight|
04597|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0184.wav|||his attention was drawn early one morning to a man who leant against a lamp-post in Finsbury Square, coughing violently.|
04598|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0185.wav|||Calcraft, who, in spite of the dreadful calling he subsequently followed, was always reputed a kindly man,|
04599|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0186.wav|||invited the man with the cough to enter a neighboring house and try a little peppermint for it.|
04600|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0187.wav|||The other accepted, and they got into conversation.|
04601|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0188.wav|||He told Calcraft that he was Foxen the executioner, and that he was that moment on his way to Newgate to hang a man,|
04602|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0189.wav|||but that his cough was getting so much the master of him that he feared he would not be able to carry on his duties much longer.|
04603|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0190.wav|||I have no idea who the sheriffs will get to do the work after me, said Foxen, adding that his assistant, Tom Cheshire,|
04604|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0191.wav|||was given to drink, and not to be trusted.|
04605|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0192.wav|||I think I could do that sort of job, said Calcraft, on the spur of the moment.|
04606|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0193.wav|||Foxen asked him his name and address, and went away.|
04607|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0194.wav|||Calcraft thought no more of what had occurred till the next sessions at the Old Bailey, when the sheriffs sent for him,|
04608|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0195.wav|||and offered him the post of executioner for the city of London and Middlesex.|
04609|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0196.wav|||He accepted, having at first Tom Cheshire as his assistant, then for a time, when Cheshire was dismissed for drunkenness, a man named Osborne.|
04610|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0197.wav|||After that he worked alone.|
04611|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0198.wav|||I cannot find that Calcraft was sworn in when appointed, or any exact information when the old forbidding ceremony ceased to be practiced.|
04612|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0199.wav|||It was customary to make the executioner take the Bible in his hand, and swear solemnly that he would dispatch every criminal condemned to die,|
04613|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0200.wav|||without favoring father or mother or any other relation or friend.|
04614|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0201.wav|||When he had taken the oath he was dismissed with the words, "Get thee hence, wretch!"|
04615|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0202.wav|||Calcraft's emoluments were a guinea per week, and an extra guinea for every execution.|
04616|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0203.wav|||He got besides half-a-crown for every man he flogged, and an allowance to provide cats or birch rods.|
04617|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0204.wav|||For acting as executioner of Horsemonger Lane Jail|
04618|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0205.wav|||he received a retaining fee of five pounds, five shillings, with the usual guinea for each job;|
04619|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0206.wav|||he was also at liberty to engage himself in the country, where he demanded and was paid ten pounds on each occasion.|
04620|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0207.wav|||It was not always easy to get a hangman so cheap, as I have already indicated on a previous page.|
04621|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0208.wav|||The onus and responsibility of carrying out the sentence is personal to the sheriff. A good story is told illustrating this.|
04622|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0209.wav|||Some wags in Scotland seized Calcraft and kept him in durance the night before the execution.|
04623|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0210.wav|||Meanwhile the convener or sheriff was in despair, expecting that, failing the executioner, he would have to do the job himself.|
04624|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0211.wav|||But, fortunately for him, just at the last moment Calcraft was set free.|
04625|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0212.wav|||Calcraft's salary was more than the proverbial "thirteenpence halfpenny -- hangman's wages."|
04626|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0213.wav|||The origin of this expression dates, it is said, from the time when the Scottish mark,|
04627|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0214.wav|||a silver coin bearing the same relation to the Scottish pound that an English shilling does to an English pound, was made to pass current in England.|
04628|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0215.wav|||The mark was valued at thirteenpence halfpenny, or rather more than the shilling, which from time immemorial had been the hangman's wages.|
04629|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0216.wav|||That very ancient perquisite the convict's clothes was never claimed by Calcraft, and it may be doubted whether he was entitled to it.|
04630|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0217.wav|||On one particular occasion, however, he got them. A gentleman whose sins brought him to the gallows at Maidstone|
04631|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0218.wav|||wished to do Calcraft a good turn, and sent to his London tailor for a complete new suit, in which he appeared at his execution.|
04632|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0219.wav|||He expressly bequeathed them to Calcraft, who was graciously pleased to accept them.|
04633|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0220.wav|||On another occasion an importunate person begged Calcraft eagerly to claim his right to the clothes, and give them to him.|
04634|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0221.wav|||Calcraft consented, got and bestowed the clothes, only to find that the person he had obliged exhibited them publicly.|
04635|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0222.wav|||It may be added that of late years the clothes in which a convict has suffered are invariably burnt.|
04636|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0223.wav|||Capital convicts go to the gallows in their own clothing, and not in prison dress, unless the former is quite unfit to be worn.|
04637|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0224.wav|||Calcraft shared the odium which his office, not strangely, has always inspired. But he was admitted into the jail,|
04638|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0225.wav|||which his predecessors were not, and who were paid their wages over the gate to obviate the necessity for letting them enter.|
04639|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0226.wav|||To this curious etiquette was due the appointment of an official whose office has long since disappeared, "the yeoman of the halter,"|
04640|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0227.wav|||whose business it was to provide the rope and do the pinioning, and who was paid a fee of five shillings.|
04641|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0228.wav|||They did not dislike Calcraft, however, at Newgate. He was an illiterate, simple-minded man, who scarcely remembered what executions he had performed.|
04642|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0229.wav|||He kept no record of them, and when asked questions, referred to the officers of the jail.|
04643|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0230.wav|||His nature must have been kindly.|
04644|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0231.wav|||When he came to the prison for his wages his grandchildren often accompanied him, affectionately clinging to his hands;|
04645|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0232.wav|||and he owned a pet pony which would follow him about like a dog.|
04646|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0233.wav|||In his own profession|
04647|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0234.wav|||he was not unskilful, but he proceeded entirely by rule of thumb, leaving the result very much to chance and the strength of the rope.|
04648|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0235.wav|||He was so much in favor of short drops that his immediate successor, Marwood, stigmatized him as "short-drop" man.|
04649|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0236.wav|||Marwood being, on the other hand, in favor of giving a man as much rope as possible.|
04650|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0237.wav|||With Calcraft's method there were undoubtedly many failures, and it was a common custom for him to go below the gallows|
04651|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0238.wav|||just to steady their legs a little; in other words, to add his weight to that of the hanging bodies.|
04652|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0239.wav|||Marwood till latterly seemed to have done his work more effectually, and has been known to give as much as six feet fall.|
04653|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0240.wav|||This generally produces instantaneous death, although cases where complete fracture of the spinal cord occurred are said to be rare.|
04654|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0241.wav|||Calcraft served the city of London till eighteen seventy-four, when he was pensioned at the rate of twenty-five shillings per week.|
04655|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0242.wav|||The last execution at which he acted was that of Godwin, on the twenty-fifth May, eighteen seventy-four.|
04656|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0243.wav|||Marwood, who succeeded him, and who died while these sheets were in the press, was a Lincolnshire man, a native of Horncastle,|
04657|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0244.wav|||who first took to the work from predilection, and the idea of being useful in his generation, as he himself assured the writer of these pages.|
04658|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0245.wav|||Until the time of his death he kept a small shop close to the church in Horncastle.|
04659|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0246.wav|||Over the door, in gilt letters, were the words "Crown Office"; in the window was a pile of official envelopes, ostentatiously displayed,|
04660|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0247.wav|||while round about were shoe-strings, boot-laces, and lasts. Marwood, strange to say, followed the same trade as Calcraft.|
04661|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0248.wav|||Marwood was proud of his calling, and when questioned as to whether his process was satisfactory, replied that he heard "no complaints."|

04663|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0250.wav|||It may, however, be remarked that the wisdom of appointing any regular hangman is very open to question,|
04664|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0251.wav|||and must be strongly deprecated on moral grounds, as tending to the utter degradation of one individual.|
04665|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0252.wav|||Possibly such changes may be introduced into the method of execution|
04666|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0253.wav|||that the ceremony may be made more mechanical, thus rendering the personal intervention of a skilled functionary unnecessary.|
04667|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0254.wav|||Executions long continued to be in public, in spite of remonstrance and reprobation.|
04668|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0255.wav|||The old prejudices, such as that which enlisted Dr. Johnson on the side of the Tyburn procession, still lingered and prevented any change.|
04669|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0256.wav|||It was thought that capital punishment would lose its deterrent effect if it ceased to be public,|
04670|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0257.wav|||and the raison d'être of the penalty, which in principle so many opposed, would be gone.|
04671|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0258.wav|||This line of argument prevailed over the manifest horrors of the spectacle. These increased as time passed.|
04672|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0259.wav|||The graphic and terrible account given by Charles Dickens of the awful scene before Horsemonger Lane Jail, at the execution of the Mannings,|
04673|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0260.wav|||has already been quoted. Again, the concourse of people collected in front of Newgate to witness the execution,|
04674|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0261.wav|||simultaneously, of the five pirates, part of the mutinous crew of the 'Flowery Land,' was greater than on any previous occasion.|
04675|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0262.wav|||It was a callous, careless crowd of coarse-minded, semi-brutalized folk, who came to enjoy themselves.|
04676|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0263.wav|||Few, if any, showed any feeling of terror, none were impressed with the solemnity, or realized the warning which the sight conveyed.|
04677|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0264.wav|||The upturned faces of the eager spectators resembled those of the 'gods' at Drury Lane on Boxing Night;|
04678|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0265.wav|||the crowd had come to witness a popular and gratuitous public performance -- better than a prize-fight or a play.|
04679|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0266.wav|||No notion that they were assisting at a vindication of the law filled the minds of those present with dread.|
04680|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0267.wav|||On the contrary, the prevailing sentiment was one of satisfaction at the success of the spectacle.|
04681|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0268.wav|||The remarks heard amongst the crowd were of coarse approval.|
04682|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0271.wav|||The reply evinced equal satisfaction, and the speaker, with a profane oath, declared that he would like to act as Jack Ketch to the whole lot.|
04683|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0272.wav|||To the disgrace of the better-educated and better-bred public, executions could still command the attendance of curious aristocrats from the West End.|
04684|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0273.wav|||At Müller's execution there was great competition for front seats,|
04685|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0274.wav|||and the windows of the opposite houses, which commanded a good view, as usual fetched high prices.|
04686|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0275.wav|||As much as twenty-five pounds was paid for a first-floor front on this occasion.|
04687|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0276.wav|||Never, indeed, had an execution been more generally patronized.|
04688|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0277.wav|||This is proved by contemporary accounts, especially one graphic and realistic article which appeared in the 'Times,'|
04689|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0278.wav|||and which contributed in no small degree to the introduction of private executions. A great crowd was expected, and a great crowd came.|
04690|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0279.wav|||They collected over night in the bright light of a November moon.|
04691|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0280.wav|||There were well-dressed and ill-dressed, old men and lads, women and girls.|
04692|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0281.wav|||Rain fell heavily at intervals, but did not thin the concourse.|
04693|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0282.wav|||nan|
04694|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0283.wav|||to do them mere justice, there was at least till then a half-drunken ribald gaiety among the crowd that made them all akin."|
04695|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0284.wav|||There were preachers among the crowd, but they could not get a patient hearing.|
04696|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0285.wav|||Then one struck up the hymn of the Promised Land, and the refrain was at once taken up with a mighty chorus --|
04697|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0286.wav|||Oh, my! Think I've got to die.|
04698|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0287.wav|||This was presently superseded by a fresh catch --|
04699|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0288.wav|||Müller, Müller, He's the man, till a diversion was created by the appearance of the gallows, which was received with continuous yells.|
04700|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0289.wav|||As day broke the character of the crowd was betrayed.|
04701|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0290.wav|||There were but few women, except of the most degraded sort; the men were mostly young men --|
04702|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0291.wav|||sharpers, thieves, gamblers, betting men, the outsiders of the boxing ring,|
04703|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0292.wav|||bricklayers' laborers, dock workmen, German artisans and sugar-bakers|
04704|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0293.wav|||with the rakings of cheap singing-halls and billiard-rooms, the fast young men of London.|
04705|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0294.wav|||But all, whether young or old, men or women, seemed to know nothing, feel nothing, to have no object but the gallows, and to laugh,|
04706|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0295.wav|||curse, or shout, as in this heaving and struggling forward they gained or lost in their strong efforts to get nearer where Müller was to die.|
04707|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0296.wav|||The actual execution made some impression.|
04708|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0297.wav|||The crowd was for a moment awed and stilled by the quiet rapid passage from life to death!|
04709|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0298.wav|||But before "the slight slow vibrations of the body had well ended,|
04710|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0299.wav|||robbery and violence, loud laughing, oaths, fighting, obscene conduct, and still more filthy language reigned round the gallows far and near.|
04711|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0300.wav|||Such too the scene remained with little change or respite till the old hangman (Calcraft) slunk again along the drop,|
04712|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0301.wav|||amid hisses and sneering inquiries of what he had had to drink that morning.|
04713|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0302.wav|||He, after failing once to cut the rope, made a second attempt more successfully, and the body of Müller disappeared from view.|
04714|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0303.wav|||It was preposterous to claim for such a scene as this that it conveyed any great moral lesson, or had any deterring influence.|
04715|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0304.wav|||Numbers of humane and thoughtful persons had long been convinced of this.|
04716|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0305.wav|||Already the urgent necessity for abolishing public executions had been brought before the House of Commons by Mr. Hibbert,|
04717|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0306.wav|||and the question, as part of the whole subject of capital punishment, had been referred to a royal commission in January eighteen sixty-four.|
04718|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0307.wav|||Full evidence was taken on all points, and on that regarding public executions there was a great preponderance of opinion towards their abolition,|
04719|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0308.wav|||yet the witnesses were not unanimous.|
04720|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0309.wav|||Some of the judges would have retained the public spectacle; the ordinary of Newgate was not certain that public executions were not the best.|
04721|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0310.wav|||Another distinguished witness feared|
04722|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0311.wav|||that any secrecy in the treatment of the condemned would invest them with a new and greater interest, which was much to be deprecated.|
04723|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0312.wav|||Foreign witnesses, too, were in favor of publicity.|
04724|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0313.wav|||On the other hand, Lords Cranworth and Wensleydale recommended private executions; so did Mr. Spencer Walpole, M.P.|
04725|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0314.wav|||Sir George Grey thought there was a growing feeling in favor of executions within the prison precincts.|
04726|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0315.wav|||Colonel (now Sir Edmund) Henderson was strongly in favor of them,|
04727|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0316.wav|||based on his experience of them in Western Australia. He not only thought them likely to be more deterrent,|
04728|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0317.wav|||but believed that a public ceremony destroyed the whole value of an execution.|
04729|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0318.wav|||Other officials, great lawyers, governors of prisons, and chaplains supported this view.|
04730|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0319.wav|||The only doubts expressed were as to the sufficiency of the safeguards, as to the certainty of death and its subsequent publication.|
04731|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0320.wav|||But these, it was thought, might be provided by the admission of the press and the holding of a coroner's inquest.|
04732|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0321.wav|||Duly impressed with the weight of evidence in favor of abolition,|
04733|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0322.wav|||the commission recommended that death sentences should be carried out within the jail, under such regulations as might be considered necessary|
04734|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0323.wav|||to prevent abuse, and satisfy the public that the law had been complied with.|
04735|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0324.wav|||But it is curious to note that there were several dissentients among the commissioners to this paragraph of the report.|
04736|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0325.wav|||The judge of the Admiralty Court, the Right Hon. Stephen Lushington, the Right Hon. James Moncrieff,|
04737|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0326.wav|||Lord Advocate, Mr. Charles Neate, Mr. William Ewart, and last, but not least, Mr. John Bright|
04738|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0327.wav|||declared that they were not prepared to agree to the resolution respecting private executions.|
04739|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0328.wav|||Nevertheless, in the very next session|
04740|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0329.wav|||a bill was introduced by Mr. Hibbert, M.P., and accepted by the Government, providing for the future carrying out of executions within prisons.|
04741|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0330.wav|||It was read for the first time in March eighteen sixty-six, but did not become law till eighteen sixty-eight.|
04742|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0331.wav|||The last public execution in front of Newgate was that of the Fenian Michael Barrett,|
04743|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0332.wav|||who was convicted of complicity in the Clerkenwell explosion, intended to effect the release of Burke and Casey|
04744|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0333.wav|||from Clerkenwell prison, by which many persons lost their lives.|
04745|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0334.wav|||Unusual precautions were taken upon this occasion, as some fresh outrage was apprehended.|
04746|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0335.wav|||There was no interference with the crowd, which collected as usual, although not to the customary extent.|
04747|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0336.wav|||But Newgate and its neighborhood was carefully held by the police, both city and metropolitan.|
04748|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0337.wav|||In the houses opposite the prison numbers of detectives mixed with the spectators;|
04749|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0338.wav|||inside the jail was Colonel Frazer, the chief commissioner of the city police, and at no great distance, although in the background,|
04750|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0339.wav|||troops were held in readiness to act if required. Everything passed off quite quietly, however,|
04751|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0340.wav|||and Calcraft, who had been threatened with summary retribution if he executed Barrett, carried out the sentence without mishap.|
04752|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0341.wav|||The sufferer was stolid and reticent to the last.|
04753|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0342.wav|||The first private execution under the new law took place within the precincts of Maidstone Jail.|
04754|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0343.wav|||The sufferer was a porter on the London, Chatham, and Dover railway, sentenced to death for shooting the station-master at Dover.|
04755|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0344.wav|||The ceremony, which was witnessed by only a few officials and representatives of the press, was performed with the utmost decency and decorum.|
04756|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0346.wav|||a fact duly advertised as completed by the hoisting of the black flag over the jail,|
04757|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0347.wav|||had undoubtedly a solemn, impressive effect upon those outside.|
04758|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0348.wav|||The same was realized in the first private execution within Newgate,|
04759|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0349.wav|||that of Alexander Mackay, who murdered his mistress at Norton Folgate by beating her with a rolling-pin and furnace-rake,|
04760|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0350.wav|||and who expiated his crime on the eighth September, eighteen sixty-eight.|
04761|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0351.wav|||A more marked change from the old scene can hardly be conceived. Instead of the roar of the brutalized crowd,|
04762|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0352.wav|||the officials spoke in whispers; there was but little moving to and fro.|
04763|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0353.wav|||Almost absolute silence prevailed until the great bell began to toll its deep note, and broke the stillness with its regular and monotonous clangour,|
04764|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0354.wav|||and the ordinary, in a voice trembling with emotion, read the burial service aloud.|
04765|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0355.wav|||Mackay's fortitude, which had been great,|
04766|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0356.wav|||broke down at the supreme moment before the horror of the stillness, the awful impressiveness of the scene in which he was the principal actor.|
04767|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0357.wav|||No time was lost in carrying out the dread ceremony; but it was not completed without some of the officials turning sick, and the moment it was over,|
04768|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0358.wav|||all who could were glad to escape from the last act of the ghastly drama at which they had assisted.|
04769|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0359.wav|||Private executions at their first introduction were not popular with the Newgate officials, and for intelligible reasons.|
04770|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0360.wav|||The change added greatly to the responsibilities of the governor and his subordinates. Hitherto the public had seemed to assist at the ceremony;|
04771|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0361.wav|||the moment too that the condemned man had passed through the debtors' door on to the scaffold the prison had done with him,|
04772|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0362.wav|||and the great outside world shared in the completion of the sacrifice.|
04773|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0363.wav|||This feeling was the stronger because|
04774|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0364.wav|||all the ghastly paraphernalia, the gallows itself and the process of erecting and removing it, rested with the city architect, and not with the prison officials.|
04775|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0365.wav|||Moreover, after the execution, under the old system, the latter had only to receive the body for burial after it had been cut down by the hangman,|
04776|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0366.wav|||and placed decently in a shell by the workmen who removed the gallows.|
04777|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0367.wav|||Under the new system the whole of the arrangements from first to last fell upon the officers.|
04778|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0368.wav|||It was they who formed the chief part of the small select group of spectators;|
04779|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0369.wav|||upon them devolved the painful duty of cutting down the body and preparing for the inquest.|
04780|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0370.wav|||All that the hangman, whoever he may be, does under the new regime is to unhook the halter and remove the pinioning straps.|
04781|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0371.wav|||The interment in a shell filled with quicklime in the passage-way leading to the Old Bailey is also a part of the duty of the prison officials.|
04782|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0373.wav|||and for the greater security of prisoners it is roofed in with iron bars which gives it, at least overhead, the aspect of a huge cage.|
04783|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0374.wav|||Underfoot and upon the walls roughly cut into the stones, are single initial letters, the brief epitaphs of those who lie below.|
04784|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0375.wav|||As this burial-ground leads to the adjacent Central Criminal Court, accused murderers, on going to and returning from trial,|
04785|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0376.wav|||literally walked over what, in case of conviction, would be their own graves.|
04786|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0377.wav|||The older officers, with several of whom I have conversed, have thus had unusual opportunities of watching the demeanor of murderers both before trial|
04787|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0378.wav|||and after sentence.|
04788|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0379.wav|||All as a rule, unless poignant remorse has brought a desire to court their richly-merited retribution, are buoyed up|
04789|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0380.wav|||with hope to the last. There is always the chance of a flaw in the indictment, of a missing witness, or extenuating circumstances.|
04790|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0381.wav|||Even when in the condemned cell, with a shameful death within measurable distance,|
04791|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0382.wav|||many cling still to life, expecting much from the intercession of friends or the humanitarianism of the age.|
04792|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0383.wav|||All almost without exception sleep soundly at night, except the first after sentence,|
04793|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0384.wav|||when the first shock of the verdict and the solemn notification of the impending blow keeps nearly all awake, or at least disturbs their night's rest.|
04794|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0385.wav|||But the uneasiness soon wears off. The second night sleep comes readily, and is sound;|
04795|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0386.wav|||many of the most abandoned murderers snore peacefully their eight hours, even on the night immediately preceding execution.|
04796|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0387.wav|||All too have a fairly good appetite, and eat with relish, up to the last moment.|
04797|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0388.wav|||A few go further, and are almost gluttonous.|
04798|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0389.wav|||Giovanni Lanni, the Italian boy who murdered a Frenchwoman in the Haymarket,|
04799|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0390.wav|||and was arrested on board ship just as he was about to leave the country, had a little spare cash, which he devoted entirely to the purchase of extra food.|
04800|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0391.wav|||He ate constantly and voraciously after sentence, as though eager to cram as many meals as possible into the few hours still left him to live.|

04802|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0393.wav|||called for a roast duck directly he entered the condemned cell.|
04803|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0394.wav|||The request was not granted, as the old custom of allowing capital convicts whatever they asked for in the way of food has not been the rule in Newgate.|
04804|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0395.wav|||The diet of the condemned is the ordinary diet of the prison,|
04805|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0396.wav|||but to which additions are sometimes made, chiefly of stimulants, if deemed necessary, by the medical officer of the jail.|
04806|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0397.wav|||The craving for tobacco which so dominates the habitual smoker often leads the convicted to plead hard for a last smoke.|
04807|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0398.wav|||As a special favor|
04808|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0399.wav|||Wainwright was allowed a cigar the night before execution, which he smoked in the prison yard, walking up and down with the governor, Mr. Sydney Smith.|
04809|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0400.wav|||Wainwright's demeanor was one of reckless effrontery steadily maintained to the last.|

04811|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0402.wav|||No woman could resist him, he calmly assured Mr. Smith that night as they walked together, and he recounted his villanies one by one.|
04812|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0403.wav|||His effrontery was only outdone by his cool contempt for the consolations of religion.|
04813|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0404.wav|||The man who had made a pious life a cloak for his misdeeds, the once exemplary young man and indefatigable Sunday School teacher,|
04814|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0405.wav|||went impenitent to the gallows. The only sign of feeling he showed was in asking to be allowed to choose the hymns on the Sunday|

04816|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0407.wav|||who generally attended the prison services.|
04817|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0408.wav|||During the singing of these hymns Wainwright fainted, but whether from real emotion or the desire to make a sensation was never exactly known.|

04845|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ016-0436.wav|||pointing to an aperture for ventilating the cell. On the morning of execution he asked how far it was to the gallows, and was told it was quite close.|

04856|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0002.wav|||As these records draw to a close, the crimes I chronicle become so much more recent in date that they will be fresh in the memory of most of my readers.|
04857|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0003.wav|||Nevertheless, in order to give completeness to the picture|
