04859|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0005.wav|||of some of the most heinous offenses of modern times.|
04860|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0006.wav|||The crime of poisoning has always been viewed with peculiar loathing and terror in this country.|
04861|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0007.wav|||It will be remembered that as far back as the reign of Henry the eighth a new and most cruel penalty was devised for the punishment of the Bishop of Rochester's cook,|
04862|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0008.wav|||who had poisoned his master and many of his dependents.|
04863|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0009.wav|||Sir Thomas Overbury was undoubtedly poisoned by Lord Rochester in the reign of James the first,|
04864|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0010.wav|||and it is hinted that James himself nearly fell a victim to a nefarious attempt of the Duke of Buckingham.|
04865|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0011.wav|||But secret poisoning on a wholesale scale such as was practiced in Italy and France was happily never popularized in England.|
04866|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0012.wav|||The well-known and lethal aqua Toffania,|
04867|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0013.wav|||so called after its inventress, a Roman woman named Toffana, and which was so widely adopted by ladies anxious to get rid of their husbands,|
04868|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0014.wav|||was never introduced into this country. Its admission was probably checked by the increased vigilance at the custom houses,|
04869|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0015.wav|||the necessity for which was urged by Mr. Addison, when Secretary of State, in seventeen seventeen.|
04870|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0016.wav|||The cases of poisoning in the British calendars are rare, nor indeed was the guilt of the accused always clearly established.|
04871|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0017.wav|||It is quite possible that Catherine Blandy, who poisoned her father at the instigation of her lover,|
04872|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0018.wav|||was ignorant of the destructive character of the powders, probably arsenic, which she administered.|
04873|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0019.wav|||Captain Donellan, who was convicted of poisoning his brother-in-law, Sir Theodosius Broughton, and executed for it,|
04874|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0020.wav|||would probably have had the benefit in these days of the doubts raised at his trial.|
04875|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0021.wav|||A third case, more especially interesting to us as having passed through Newgate,|
04876|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0022.wav|||was that of Eliza Fenning, who was convicted of an attempt to poison a whole family|
04877|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0023.wav|||by putting arsenic in the dumplings she had prepared for them. The charge rested entirely on circumstantial evidence,|
04878|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0024.wav|||and as Fenning, although convicted and executed, protested her innocence in the most solemn manner to the last,|
04879|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0025.wav|||the justice of the sentence was doubted at the time.|
04880|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0026.wav|||Yet it was clearly proved that the dumplings contained arsenic, that she, and she alone, had made the dough,|
04881|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0027.wav|||that arsenic was within her reach in the house,|
04882|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0028.wav|||that she had had a quarrel with her mistress, and that the latter with all others who tasted the dumplings were similarly attacked, although no one died.|
04883|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0029.wav|||The crime of poisoning is essentially one which will be most prevalent in a high state of civilization,|
04884|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0030.wav|||when the spread of scientific knowledge places nefarious means at the disposal of many,|
04885|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0031.wav|||instead of limiting them, as in the days of the Borgias and Brinvilliers, to the specially informed and unscrupulously powerful few.|
04886|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0032.wav|||The first intimation conveyed to society of the new terror which threatened it was in the arrest and arraignment of William Palmer,|
04887|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0033.wav|||a medical practitioner, charged with doing to death persons who relied upon his professional skill.|
04888|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0034.wav|||The case contained elements of much uncertainty, and yet it was so essential,|
04889|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0035.wav|||in the interests and for the due protection of the public, that the fullest and fairest inquiry should be made,|
04890|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0036.wav|||that the trial was transferred to the Central Criminal Court,|
04891|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0037.wav|||under the authority of an Act passed on purpose, known as the Trial of offenses Act, and sometimes as Lord Campbell's Act.|
04892|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0038.wav|||That the administration of justice should never be interfered with by local prejudice or local feeling|
04893|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0039.wav|||is obviously of paramount importance, and the powers granted by this Act have been frequently put in practice since.|
04894|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0040.wav|||The trial of Catherine Winsor, the baby farmer,|
04895|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0041.wav|||was thus brought to the Central Criminal Court from Exeter assizes, and that of the Stauntons from Maidstone.|
04896|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0042.wav|||Palmer's trial caused the most intense excitement.|
04897|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0043.wav|||The direful suspicions which surrounded the case filled the whole country with uneasiness and misgiving,|
04898|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0044.wav|||and the deepest anxiety was felt that the crime, if crime there had been, should be brought home to its perpetrator.|
04899|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0045.wav|||The Central Criminal Court was crowded to suffocation.|
04900|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0046.wav|||Great personages occupied seats upon the bench;|
04901|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0047.wav|||the rest of the available space was allotted by ticket, to secure which the greatest influence was necessary.|
04902|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0048.wav|||People came to stare at the supposed cold-blooded prisoner;|
04903|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0049.wav|||with morbid curiosity to scan his features and watch his demeanor through the shifting, nicely-balanced phases of his protracted trial.|
04904|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0050.wav|||Palmer, who was only thirty-one at the time of his trial, was in appearance short and stout, with a round head|
04905|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0051.wav|||covered rather scantily with light sandy hair.|
04906|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0052.wav|||His skin was extraordinarily fair, his cheeks fresh and ruddy; altogether his face, though commonplace, was not exactly ugly;|
04907|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0053.wav|||there was certainly nothing in it which indicated cruel cunning or deliberate truculence.|
04908|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0054.wav|||His features were not careworn, but rather set, and he looked older than his age.|
04909|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0055.wav|||Throughout his trial he preserved an impassive countenance, but he clearly took a deep interest in all that passed.|
04910|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0056.wav|||Although the strain lasted fourteen days, he showed no signs of exhaustion, either physical or mental.|
04911|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0057.wav|||On returning to jail each day he talked freely and without reserve to the warders in charge of him, chiefly on incidents in the day's proceedings.|
04912|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0058.wav|||He was confident to the very last that it would be impossible to find him guilty;|
04913|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0059.wav|||even after sentence, and until within a few hours of execution, he was buoyed up with the hope of reprieve.|
04914|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0060.wav|||The conviction that he would escape had taken so firm a hold of him,|
04915|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0061.wav|||that he steadily refused to confess his guilt, lest it should militate against his chances.|
04916|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0062.wav|||In the condemned cell he frequently repeated, quote, I go to my death a murdered man, end quote.|
04917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0063.wav|||He made no distinct admissions even on the scaffold; but when the chaplain at the last moment exhorted him to confess,|
04918|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0064.wav|||he made use of the remarkable words, quote, If it is necessary for my soul's sake to confess this murder,|
04919|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0065.wav|||I ought also to confess the others: I mean my wife and my brother's. End quote.|
04920|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0066.wav|||Yet he was silent when specifically pressed to confess that he had killed his wife and his brother.|
04921|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0067.wav|||Palmer was ably defended, but the weight of evidence was clearly with the prosecution, led by Sir Alexander Cockburn,|
04922|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0068.wav|||and public opinion at the termination of the trial coincided with the verdict of the jury.|
04923|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0069.wav|||Originally a doctor in practice at Rugeley, in Staffordshire, he had gradually withdrawn from medicine, and devoted himself to the turf;|
04924|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0070.wav|||but his sporting operations did not prosper, and he became a needy man, always driven to desperate straits for cash.|
04925|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0071.wav|||To meet his liabilities, he raised large sums on forged bills of acceptance drawn upon his mother, a woman of some means,|
04926|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0072.wav|||whose signature he counterfeited.|
04927|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0073.wav|||In eighteen fifty-four he owed a very large sum of money, but he was temporarily relieved by the death of his wife,|
04928|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0074.wav|||whose life he had insured for thirteen thousand pounds.|
04929|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0075.wav|||There is every reason to suppose that he poisoned his wife to obtain possession of this sum upon her death.|
04930|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0076.wav|||His brother was supposed to have been his next victim, upon whose life he had also effected an insurance for another thirteen thousand pounds.|
04931|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0077.wav|||The brother too died conveniently, but the life office took some exception to the manner of the death, and hesitated to disburse the funds claimed by Palmer.|
04932|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0078.wav|||Palmer tried to get a new insurance on the life of a hanger-on, one Bates, but no office would accept it, no doubt greatly to Bates's longevity.|
04933|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0079.wav|||Meanwhile the bill discounters who held the forged acceptances, with other promissory notes, began to clamor for payment, and talk of issuing writs.|
04934|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0080.wav|||Palmer, alive to the danger he ran of a prosecution for forgery, should the fraud he had committed be brought to light,|
04935|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0081.wav|||sought about for a fresh victim to supply him with funds.|
04936|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0082.wav|||He fixed upon a sporting friend, Mr. John Parsons Cook, who had been in luck at Shrewsbury races, both as a winner and a backer,|
04937|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0083.wav|||whom he persuaded to go and stay at Rugeley in an hotel just opposite his own house.|
04938|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0084.wav|||It was there that Cook was first taken ill with violent retchings and vomitings, all dating from visits of Palmer, who brought him medicines and food.|
04939|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0085.wav|||Palmer's plan was to administer poison in quantities insufficient to cause death, but enough to produce illness which would account for death.|
04940|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0086.wav|||For this purpose he gave, or there was the strongest presumption that he gave,|
04941|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0087.wav|||antimony, which caused Cook's constant sickness.|
04942|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0088.wav|||Quantities of antimony were found in the body after death.|
04943|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0089.wav|||While Cook lay ill, Palmer in his name pocketed the proceeds of the Shrewsbury settling,|
04944|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0090.wav|||and so got the money for which he was prepared to barter his soul.|
04945|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0091.wav|||The last act now approached, and in order to avoid the detection of this last fraud, Palmer laid his plans for disposing of Cook.|
04946|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0092.wav|||He decided to use strychnia, or the vegetable poison otherwise known as nux vomica;|
04947|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0093.wav|||and one of the many links in the long chain of evidence was an entry in a book of Palmer's to the effect that Quote.|
04948|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0094.wav|||strychnia kills by causing tetanic fixing of the respiratory muscles. End quote.|
04949|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0095.wav|||The purchase by Palmer of strychnia was proved.|
04950|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0096.wav|||The night he bought it, Cook, who had been taking certain pills under medical advice, not Palmer's, was seized with violent convulsions.|
04951|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0097.wav|||He had swallowed his pills as usual, at least Palmer had administered them|
04952|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0098.wav|||whether the ordinary or his own pills will never be known, except as may be inferred from the results, which indicate that he had taken the latter.|
04953|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0099.wav|||Cook recovered this time; it was probably Palmer's intention that he should recover, wishing to encourage the supposition that Cook was in a bad way.|
04954|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0100.wav|||Next night Cook had a second and a more violent attack.|
04955|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0101.wav|||That day Palmer had bought more strychnia, and had called in a fresh doctor.|
04956|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0102.wav|||The second attack was fatal, and ended in Cook's death from tetanus.|
04957|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0103.wav|||This tetanus, according to the prosecution, was produced by strychnia, and followed the administration of pills by Palmer|
04958|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0104.wav|||prescribed nominally by the fresh doctor, for which Palmer had substituted his own.|
04959|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0105.wav|||Cook's death was horrible|
04960|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0106.wav|||fearful paroxysms and cramps, ending in suffocation by the tetanic rigor which caught the muscles of the chest.|
04961|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0107.wav|||After Cook's death his stepfather, who was much attached to him, came to Rugeley.|
04962|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0108.wav|||He was struck with the appearance of the corpse, which was not emaciated, as after a long disease ending in death;|
04963|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0109.wav|||while the muscles of the fingers were tightly clenched, not open, as usual in a corpse.|
04964|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0110.wav|||He said nothing, but began to feel uneasy when he found that Cook's betting-book was missing, and that Palmer put it forward|
04965|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0111.wav|||that his friend had died greatly embarrassed, with bills to the amount of four thousand pounds out in his name.|
04966|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0112.wav|||Palmer too showed an indecent haste in preparing the body for interment, and in obtaining the usual certificate.|
04967|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0113.wav|||After this the step-father insisted upon a post-mortem, which was conducted somewhat carelessly.|
04968|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0114.wav|||The intestines were, however, preserved and sent for analysis,|
04969|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0115.wav|||but it was proved that Palmer tried hard to get possession of the jar containing them,|
04970|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0116.wav|||and even sought to upset the vehicle by which they were being conveyed a part of the way to London.|
04971|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0117.wav|||The examination of the stomach betrayed the presence of antimony in large quantities, but no strychnia,|
04972|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0118.wav|||and it was on the entire absence of the latter that the defense was principally based when Palmer was brought to trial.|
04973|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0119.wav|||All the circumstances were so suspicious that he could not escape the criminal charge.|
04974|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0120.wav|||He had already been arrested on a writ issued at the instance of the money-lenders, and an action had been commenced against Mrs. Palmer on her acceptances.|
04975|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0121.wav|||It came out at once that these had been forged, and the whole affair at once took the ugliest complexion.|
04976|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0122.wav|||A government prosecution was instituted, and Palmer was brought to Newgate for trial at the Central Criminal Court.|
04977|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0123.wav|||There was not much reserve about him when there.|
04978|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0124.wav|||He frequently declared before and during the trial that it would be impossible to find him guilty.|
04979|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0125.wav|||He never actually said that he was not guilty, but he was confident he would not be convicted.|
04980|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0126.wav|||He relied on the absence of the strychnia.|
04981|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0127.wav|||But the chain of circumstantial evidence was strong enough to satisfy the jury, who agreed to their verdict in an hour.|
04982|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0128.wav|||At the last moment Palmer tossed a bit of paper over to his counsel, on which he had written, quote, I think there will be a verdict of Not Guilty, end quote.|
04983|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0129.wav|||Even after the death sentence had been passed upon him he clung to the hope that the Government would grant him a reprieve.|
04984|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0130.wav|||To the last, therefore, he played the part of a man wrongfully convicted, and did not abandon hope|
04985|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0131.wav|||even when the high sheriff had told him there was no possibility of a reprieve, and within a few hours of execution.|
04986|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0132.wav|||He suffered at Stafford in front of the jail.|
04987|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0133.wav|||Palmer speedily found imitators.|
04988|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0134.wav|||Within a few weeks occurred the Leeds poisoning case, in which the murderer undoubtedly was inspired by the facts made public at Palmer's trial.|
04989|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0135.wav|||Dove, a fiendish brute, found from the evidence in that case that he could kill his wife, whom he hated,|
04990|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0136.wav|||with exquisite torture, and with a poison that would leave, as he thought, no trace.|
04991|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0137.wav|||In the latter hope he was happily disappointed. But as this case is beyond my subject, I merely mention it as one of the group already referred to.|
04992|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0138.wav|||Three years later came the case of Dr. Smethurst,|
04993|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0139.wav|||presenting still greater features of resemblance with Palmer's, for both were medical men, and both raised difficult questions of medical jurisprudence.|
04994|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0140.wav|||In both the jury had no doubt as to the guilt of the accused, only in Smethurst's case the then Home Secretary, Sir George Cornewall Lewis,|
04995|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0141.wav|||could not divest his mind of serious doubt, and of which the murderer got the benefit.|
04996|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0142.wav|||Smethurst's escape may have influenced the jury in the Poplar poisoning case,|
04997|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0143.wav|||which followed close on its heels, although in that the verdict of "Not Guilty" was excusable, as the evidence was entirely circumstantial.|
04998|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0144.wav|||There was no convincing proof that the accused had administered the poison, although beyond question that poison had occasioned the death.|
04999|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0145.wav|||Dr. Smethurst was long an inmate of Newgate, and was tried at the Central Criminal Court.|
05000|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0146.wav|||He had all the characteristics of the poisoner -- the calm deliberation,|
05001|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0147.wav|||the protracted dissimulation, as with unshrinking, relentless wickedness the deadly work is carried on to the end.|
05002|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0148.wav|||Smethurst's victim was a Miss Bankes, with whom he had contracted a bigamous marriage.|
05003|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0149.wav|||He had met her at a boarding-house, where he lived with his own wife, a person of "shady" antecedents,|
05004|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0150.wav|||and whom he left without scruple to join Miss Bankes.|
05005|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0151.wav|||The latter seems to have succumbed only too willingly to his fascinations, and to have as readily agreed to marry him,|
05006|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0152.wav|||in spite of the existence of the other Mrs. Smethurst.|
05007|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0153.wav|||Probably the doctor had told her the story he brought forward when tried for bigamy, namely,|
05008|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0154.wav|||that Mrs. Smethurst had no right to the name, but had a husband of her own, one Johnson, alive -- a story subsequently disproved.|
05009|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0155.wav|||Miss Bankes seems to have counted upon some species of whitewashing, no less than the repudiation of the other marriage,|
05010|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0156.wav|||and told her sister as much when they last met.|
05011|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0157.wav|||For some months Smethurst and Miss Bankes lived together as man and wife, first in London, and then at Richmond.|
05012|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0158.wav|||She had a little fortune of her own, some one thousand seven hundred pounds or one thousand eight hundred pounds,|
05013|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0159.wav|||and a life-interest in five thousand pounds, a fact on which Smethurst's counsel dwelt with much weight,|
05014|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0160.wav|||as indicating a motive for keeping her alive rather than killing her.|
05015|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0161.wav|||But probably the lump sum was the bait, or perhaps Smethurst wished to return to his temporarily deserted first wife.|
05016|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0162.wav|||Whatever the exact cause which impelled him to crime, it seems certain that he began to give her some poison,|
05017|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0163.wav|||either arsenic or antimony, or both, in small quantities,|
05018|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0164.wav|||with the idea of subjecting her to the irritant poison slowly but surely until the desired effect, death, was achieved.|
05019|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0165.wav|||As she became worse and worse, Smethurst called in the best medical advice in Richmond,|
05020|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0166.wav|||but was careful to prime them with his facts and lead them if possible to accept his diagnosis of the case.|
05021|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0167.wav|||Smethurst was found guilty by the jury, and sentenced to death.|
05022|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0168.wav|||But a long public discussion followed, and in consequence he was reprieved.|
05023|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0169.wav|||The Home Secretary, in a letter to the Lord Chief Baron, stated that, quote, although the facts are full of suspicion against Smethurst,|
05024|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0170.wav|||there is not absolute and complete evidence of his guilt. End quote.|
05025|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0171.wav|||Smethurst was therefore given a free pardon for the offense of murder,|
05026|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0172.wav|||but he was subsequently again tried for bigamy, and sentenced to twelve months' imprisonment.|
05027|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0173.wav|||Catherine Wilson was a female poisoner who did business wholesale.|
05028|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0174.wav|||She was tried in April eighteen sixty-two on suspicion of having attempted to poison a neighbor with oil of vitriol.|
05029|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0175.wav|||The circumstances were strange. Mrs. Wilson had gone to the chemist's for medicine,|
05030|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0176.wav|||and on her return had administered a dose of something which burnt the mouth badly, but did not prove fatal.|
05031|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0177.wav|||Wilson was acquitted on this charge, but other suspicious facts cropped up while she was in Newgate.|
05032|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0178.wav|||It appeared that several persons with whom she was intimate had succumbed suddenly.|
05033|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0179.wav|||In all cases the symptoms were much the same,|
05034|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0180.wav|||vomiting, violent retching, purging, such as are visible in cholera, and all dated from the time when she knew a young man named Dixon,|
05035|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0181.wav|||who had been in the habit of taking colchicum for rheumatism. Mrs. Wilson heard then casually from a medical man|
05036|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0182.wav|||that it was a very dangerous medicine, and she profited by what she had heard.|
05037|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0183.wav|||Soon afterwards Dixon died, showing all the symptoms already described.|
05038|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0184.wav|||Soon afterwards a friend, Mrs. Atkinson, came to London from Westmoreland, and stayed in Mrs. Wilson's house.|
05039|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0185.wav|||She was in good health on leaving home, and had with her a large sum of money.|
05040|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0186.wav|||While with Mrs. Wilson she became suddenly and alarmingly ill, and died in great agony.|
05041|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0187.wav|||Her husband, who came up to town, would not allow a post-mortem, and again Mrs. Wilson escaped.|
05042|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0188.wav|||Mrs. Atkinson's symptoms had been the same as Dixon's. Then Mrs. Wilson went to live with a man named Taylor,|
05043|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0189.wav|||who was presently attacked in the same way as the others, but, but, thanks to the prompt administration of remedies, he recovered.|
05044|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0190.wav|||After this came the charge of administering oil of vitriol, which failed, as has been described.|
05045|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0191.wav|||Last of all Mrs. Wilson poisoned her landlady, Mrs. Soames, under precisely the same conditions as the foregoing.|
05046|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0192.wav|||Here, however, the evidence was strong and sufficient.|
05047|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0193.wav|||It was proved that Mrs. Wilson had given Mrs. Soames something peculiar to drink,|
05048|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0194.wav|||that immediately afterwards Mrs. Soames was taken ill with vomiting and purging,|
05049|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0195.wav|||and that Mrs. Wilson administered the same medicine again and again.|
05050|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0196.wav|||The last time Mrs. Soames showed great reluctance to take it, but Wilson said it would certainly do her good.|
05051|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0197.wav|||This mysterious medicine Wilson kept carefully locked up, and allowed no one to see it,|
05052|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0198.wav|||but its nature was betrayed when this last victim also died.|
05053|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0199.wav|||The first post-mortem indicated death from natural causes,|
05054|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0200.wav|||but a more careful investigation attributed it beyond doubt to over-doses of colchicum.|
05055|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0201.wav|||Dr. Alfred Taylor, the great authority and writer on medical jurisprudence, corroborated this, and in his evidence on the trial|
05056|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0202.wav|||fairly electrified the court by declaring it his opinion that many deaths, supposed to be from cholera, were really due to poison.|
05057|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0203.wav|||This fact was referred to by the judge in his summing up,|
05058|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0204.wav|||who said that he feared it was only too true that secret poisoning was at that time very rife in the metropolis.|
05059|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0205.wav|||Wilson was duly sentenced to death, and suffered impenitent, hardened, and without any confession of her guilt.|
05060|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0206.wav|||Although murder by insidious methods had become more common, cases where violence of the most deadly and determined kind was offered|
05061|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0207.wav|||had not quite disappeared. I will mention two cases of this class, one accompanied with piracy on the high seas,|
05062|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0208.wav|||the other perpetrated in a railway-carriage, and showing the promptitude with which criminals accept and utilize altered conditions of life,|
05063|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0209.wav|||more particularly as regards locomotion.|
05064|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0210.wav|||The first case was that of the 'Flowery Land,'|
05065|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0211.wav|||which left London for Singapore on the twenty-eighth July, eighteen sixty-three, with a cargo of wine and other goods.|
05066|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0212.wav|||Her captain was John Smith;|
05067|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0213.wav|||the first and second mates, Karswell and Taffir; there were two other Englishmen on board, and the rest of the crew were a polyglot lot,|
05068|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0214.wav|||most of them, as was proved by their subsequent acts, blackguards of the deepest dye.|
05069|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0215.wav|||Six were Spaniards, or rather natives of Manilla, and men of color; one was a Greek, another a Turk;|
05070|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0216.wav|||there were also a Frenchman, a Norwegian (the carpenter), three Chinamen, a "Sclavonian," and a black on board.|
05071|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0217.wav|||Navigation and discipline could not be easy with such a nondescript crew.|
05072|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0218.wav|||The captain was kindly but somewhat intemperate, the first mate a man of some determination,|
05073|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0219.wav|||and punishment such as rope's-ending and tying to the bulwarks had to be applied to get the work properly done.|
05074|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0220.wav|||The six Spaniards, the Greek, and the Turk were in the same watch,|
05075|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0221.wav|||eight truculent and reckless scoundrels, who, brooding over their fancied wrongs, and burning for revenge,|
05076|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0222.wav|||hatched amongst them a plot to murder their officers and seize the ship.|
05077|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0223.wav|||The mutiny was organized with great secrecy, and broke out most unexpectedly in the middle of the night.|
05078|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0224.wav|||A simultaneous attack was made upon the captain and the first mate.|
05079|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0225.wav|||The latter had the watch on deck.|
05080|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0226.wav|||One half of the mutineers fell upon him unawares with handspikes and capstan-bars.|
05081|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0227.wav|||He was struck down, imploring mercy, but they beat him about the head and face|
05082|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0228.wav|||till every feature was obliterated, and then, still living, flung him into the sea.|
05083|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0229.wav|||Meanwhile the captain, roused from his berth,|
05084|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0230.wav|||came out of the cabin, was caught near the 'companion' by the rest of the mutineers, and promptly dispatched with daggers.|
05085|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0231.wav|||His body was found lying in a pool of blood in a night-dress, stabbed over and over again in the left side.|
05086|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0232.wav|||The captain's brother, a passenger on board the 'Flowery Land,' was also stabbed to death and his body thrown overboard.|
05087|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0233.wav|||The second mate, who had heard the hammering of the capstan-bars and the handspikes, with the first mate's and captain's agonized cries, had come out,|
05088|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0234.wav|||verified the murderers, and then shut himself up in his cabin.|
05089|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0235.wav|||He was soon summoned on deck, but as he would not move, the mutineers came down and stood in a circle round his berth.|
05090|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0236.wav|||Leon, or Lyons, who spoke English,|
05091|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0237.wav|||when asked said they would spare his life if he would navigate the ship for them to the River Plate or Buenos Aires.|
05092|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0238.wav|||Taffir, the second mate, agreed, but constantly went in fear of his life for the remainder of the voyage;|
05093|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0239.wav|||and although the mutineers spared him, they ill-treated the Chinamen, and cut one badly with knives.|
05094|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0240.wav|||Immediately after the murder cases of champagne, which formed part of the cargo, were brought on deck and broached;|
05095|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0241.wav|||the captain's cabin ransacked, his money and clothes divided amongst the mutineers, as well as much of the merchandise on board.|
05096|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0242.wav|||Leon wished to make every one on board share and share alike, so as to implicate the innocent with the guilty;|
05097|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0243.wav|||but Vartos, or Watto, the Turk, would not allow any but the eight mutineers to have anything.|
05098|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0244.wav|||The murders were perpetrated on the tenth September, and the ship continued her voyage for nearly three weeks, meeting and speaking one ship only.|
05099|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0245.wav|||On the second October they sighted land, ten miles distant;|
05100|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0246.wav|||the mutineers took command of the ship, put her about till night-fall, by which time they had scuttled her, got out the boats, and all left the ship.|
05101|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0247.wav|||The rest of the crew were also permitted to embark, except the Chinamen, one of whom was thrown into the water and drowned,|
05102|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0248.wav|||while the other two were left to go down in the ship, and were seen clinging to the tops until the waters closed over them.|
05103|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0249.wav|||The boats reached the shore on the fourth October. Leon had prepared a plausible tale to the effect that they belonged to an American ship|
05104|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0250.wav|||from Peru bound to Bordeaux, which had foundered at sea;|
05105|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0251.wav|||that they had been in the boats five days and nights, but that the captain and others had been lost.|
05106|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0252.wav|||The place at which they landed was not far from the entrance to the River Plate.|
05107|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0253.wav|||A farmer took them in for the night, and drove them next day to Rocha, a place north of Maldonado.|
05108|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0254.wav|||Taffir, the mate, finding there was a man who could speak English at another place twenty miles off,|
05109|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0255.wav|||repaired there secretly, and so gave information to the Brazilian authorities.|
05110|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0256.wav|||The mutineers were arrested, the case inquired into by a naval court-martial,|
05111|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0257.wav|||and the prisoners eventually surrendered to the British authorities, brought to England, and lodged in Newgate.|
05112|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0258.wav|||Their trial followed at the Central Criminal Court.|
05113|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0259.wav|||Eight were arraigned at the same time: six Spaniards, Leon, Blanco, Duranno, Santos, and Marsolino;|
05114|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0260.wav|||Vartos the Turk, and Carlos the Greek.|
05115|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0261.wav|||Seven were found guilty of murder on the high seas, and one, Carlos, acquitted.|
05116|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0262.wav|||Two of the seven, Santos and Marsolino, were reprieved, and their sentences commuted to penal servitude for life;|
05117|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0263.wav|||the remaining five were executed in one batch.|
05118|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0264.wav|||They were an abject, miserable crew, cowards at heart; but some, especially Lopez, continued bloodthirsty to the last.|
05119|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0265.wav|||Lopez took a violent dislike to the officer of the ward in charge of them, and often expressed a keen desire to do for him.|
05120|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0266.wav|||They none of them spoke much English except Leon, commonly called Lyons.|
05121|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0267.wav|||After condemnation, as the rules now kept capital convicts strictly apart, they could not be lodged in the two condemned cells,|
05122|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0268.wav|||and they were each kept in an ordinary separate cell of the newly-constructed block, with the "traps," or square openings in the cell door,|
05123|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0269.wav|||let down. A full view of them was thus at all times obtainable by the officers who, without intermission, day and night patrolled the ward.|
05124|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0270.wav|||On the morning of execution the noise of fixing the gallows in the street outside awoke one or two of them.|
05125|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0271.wav|||Lyons asked the time, and was told it was only five.|

05127|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0273.wav|||Lopez was more talkative.|
