05136|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ017-0284.wav|||was too much for his nerves, and he so nearly fainted that he had to be seated in a chair.|
05137|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0001.wav|||The Chronicles of Newgate, Volume two. By Arthur Griffiths. Section twenty-one: Newgate Notorieties, part two.|
05138|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0002.wav|||In July eighteen sixty-four occurred the murder of Mr. Briggs, a gentleman advanced in years and chief clerk in Robarts' bank.|
05139|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0003.wav|||As the circumstances under which it was perpetrated were somewhat novel,|
05140|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0004.wav|||and as some time elapsed before the discovery and apprehension of the supposed murderer,|
05141|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0005.wav|||the public mind was greatly agitated by the affair for several months. The story of the murder must be pretty familiar to most of my readers.|
05142|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0006.wav|||Mr. Briggs left the bank one afternoon as usual, dined with his daughter at Peckham,|
05143|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0007.wav|||then returned to the city to take the train from Fenchurch Street home, traveling by the North London Railway.|
05144|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0008.wav|||He lived at Hackney, but he never reached it alive.|
05145|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0009.wav|||When the train arrived at Hackney station, a passenger who was about to enter one of the carriages found the cushions soaked with blood.|
05146|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0010.wav|||Inside the carriage was a hat, a walking-stick, and a small black leather bag.|
05147|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0011.wav|||About the same time a body was discovered on the line near the railway-bridge by Victoria Park.|
05148|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0012.wav|||It was that of an aged man, whose head had been battered in by a life-preserver.|
05149|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0013.wav|||There was a deep wound just over the ear, the skull was fractured, and there were several other blows and wounds on the head.|
05150|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0014.wav|||Strange to say, the unfortunate man was not yet dead, and he actually survived more than four-and-twenty hours.|
05151|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0015.wav|||His identity was established by a bundle of letters in his pocket, which bore his full address:|
05152|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0016.wav|||T. Briggs, Esq., Robarts and Co., Lombard Street.|
05153|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0017.wav|||The friends of Mr. Briggs were communicated with, and it was ascertained that when he left home the morning of the murderous attack,|
05154|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0018.wav|||he wore gold-rimmed eye-glasses and a gold watch and chain.|
05155|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0019.wav|||The stick and bag were his, but not the hat.|
05156|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0020.wav|||A desperate and deadly struggle must have taken place in the carriage, and the stain of a bloody hand marked the door.|
05157|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0021.wav|||The facts of the murder and its object, robbery, were thus conclusively proved.|
05158|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0022.wav|||It was also easily established that the hat found in the carriage had been bought at Walker's, a hatter's in Crawford Street,|
05159|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0023.wav|||Marylebone; while within a few days Mr. Briggs' gold chain was traced to a jeweler's in Cheapside,|
05160|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0024.wav|||Mr. Death, who had given another in exchange for it to a man supposed to be a foreigner.|
05161|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0025.wav|||More precise clues to the murderer were not long wanting; indeed the readiness with which they were produced and followed up|
05162|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0026.wav|||showed how greatly the publicity and wide dissemination of the news regarding murder facilitate the detection of crime.|
05163|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0027.wav|||In little more than a week a cabman came forward and voluntarily made a statement which at once drew suspicion to a German, Franz Müller,|
05164|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0028.wav|||who had been a lodger of his. Müller had given the cabman's little daughter a jeweler's cardboard box bearing the name of Mr. Death.|
05165|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0029.wav|||A photograph of Müller shown the jeweler was identified as the likeness of the man who had exchanged Mr. Briggs' chain.|
05166|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0030.wav|||Last of all, the cabman swore that he had bought the very hat found in the carriage for Müller at the hatter's, Walker's of Crawford Street.|
05167|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0031.wav|||This fixed the crime pretty certainly upon Müller, who had already left the country, thus increasing suspicion under which he lay.|
05168|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0032.wav|||There was no mystery about his departure; he had gone to Canada, by the 'Victoria' sailing ship, starting from the London docks, and bound to New York.|
05169|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0033.wav|||Directly the foregoing facts were established, a couple of detective officers, armed with a warrant to arrest Müller,|
05170|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0034.wav|||and accompanied by Mr. Death the jeweler and the cabman, went down to Liverpool and took the first steamer across the Atlantic.|
05171|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0035.wav|||This was the 'City of Manchester,' which was expected to arrive some days before the 'Victoria,' and did so.|
05172|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0036.wav|||The officers went on board the 'Victoria' at once, Müller was identified by Mr. Death, and the arrest was made.|
05173|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0037.wav|||In searching the prisoner's box, Mr. Briggs' watch was found wrapped up in a piece of leather,|
05174|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0038.wav|||and Müller at the time of his capture was actually wearing Mr. Briggs' hat, cut down and somewhat altered.|
05175|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0039.wav|||The prisoner was forthwith extradited and sent back to England, which he reached with his escort on the seventeenth September the same year.|
05176|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0040.wav|||His trial followed at the next sessions of the Central Criminal Court, and ended in his conviction.|
05177|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0041.wav|||The case was one of circumstantial evidence, but, as Sir Robert Collyer the Solicitor-General pointed out,|
05178|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0042.wav|||it was the strongest circumstantial evidence which had ever been brought forward in a murder case.|
05179|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0043.wav|||It was really evidence of facts which could not be controverted or explained away.|
05180|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0044.wav|||There was the prisoner's poverty, his inability to account for himself on the night of the murder, and his possession of the property of the murdered man.|
05181|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0045.wav|||An alibi was set up for the defense, but not well substantiated, and the jury without hesitation returned a verdict of guilty.|
05182|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0046.wav|||Müller protested after sentence of death had been passed upon him that he had been convicted on a false statement of facts.|
05183|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0047.wav|||He adhered to this almost to the very last. His case had been warmly espoused by the Society for the Protection of Germans in this country,|
05184|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0048.wav|||and powerful influence was exerted both here and abroad to obtain a reprieve.|
05185|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0049.wav|||Müller knew that any confession would ruin his chances of escape.|
05186|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0050.wav|||His arguments were specious and evasive when pressed to confess. "Why should man confess to man?" he replied;|
05187|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0051.wav|||man cannot forgive man, only God can do so. Man is therefore only accountable to God.|
05188|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0052.wav|||But on the gallows, when the cap was over his eyes and the rope had been adjusted round his neck, and within a second of the moment when he would be launched into eternity,|
05189|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0053.wav|||he whispered in the ear of the German pastor who attended him on the scaffold,|
05190|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0054.wav|||While in the condemned cell he conversed freely with the warders in broken English or through an interpreter.|
05191|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0055.wav|||He is described as not a bad-looking man, with a square German type of face,|
05192|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0056.wav|||blue eyes which were generally half closed, and very fair hair.|
05193|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0057.wav|||He was short in stature, his legs were light for the upper part of his body, which was powerful, almost herculean.|
05194|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0058.wav|||It is generally supposed that he committed the murder under a sudden access of covetousness and greed.|
05195|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0059.wav|||He saw Mr. Briggs' watch-chain, and followed him instantly into the carriage, determined to have it at all costs.|
05196|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0060.wav|||His crime under this aspect of it was less premeditated, and less atrocious therefore, than that of Lefroy.|
05197|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0061.wav|||One other curious murder may be added to the two foregoing.|
05198|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0062.wav|||Christian Sattler was by birth a German.|
05199|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0063.wav|||He had led a wild life; had left his native land and enlisted first in the French army in Algeria,|
05200|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0064.wav|||afterwards in the British German Legion raised for the Crimean War.|
05201|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0065.wav|||At the disbandment of the force, as he was without resources, he turned his attention to hotel robberies, by which he lived for some years.|
05202|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0066.wav|||He at length stole a carpet-bag containing valuables, and fled to Hamburgh.|
05203|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0067.wav|||Thither, he was pursued by a detective officer,|
05204|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0068.wav|||Inspector Thain, who, being unable to obtain his extradition legally, had him inveigled on board an English steamer,|
05205|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0069.wav|||where the arrest was made.|
05206|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0070.wav|||Sattler was ironed for safe custody,|
05207|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0071.wav|||a proceeding which he vehemently resented, and begged that they might be removed, as the handcuffs hurt his wrists.|
05208|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0072.wav|||The inspector said that they could not be removed till he reached England.|
05209|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0073.wav|||This reply of his contained no promise of immediate release.|
05210|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0074.wav|||Sattler probably misunderstood, and he declared that the police officer had broken faith with him, having, moreover, stated that|
05211|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0075.wav|||while at sea the captain of the ship was responsible for the security of the prisoner.|
05212|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0076.wav|||As Sattler brooded over his wrongs, his rage got the upper hand, and he resolved to wreak it upon Thain.|
05213|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0077.wav|||Although manacled, he managed to get a pistol from his chest and load it.|
05214|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0078.wav|||The next time Thain entered his cabin he fired at him point-blank, and lodged three bullets in his breast.|
05215|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0079.wav|||The unfortunate man survived till he landed, but died in Guy's Hospital.|
05216|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0080.wav|||Sattler was tried for murder and convicted;|
05217|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0081.wav|||his defense being that he had intended to commit suicide, but that, on the appearance of this officer who had wronged him,|
05218|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0082.wav|||he had yielded to an irresistible impulse to kill him.|
05219|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0083.wav|||Sattler was a very excitable although not an ill-tempered man.|
05220|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0084.wav|||While in Newgate awaiting trial he frequently tried to justify his murder by declaring that the police officer had broken faith with him.|
05221|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0085.wav|||He would shoot any man or any policeman like a dog, or any number of them, who had treated him in that way.|
05222|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0086.wav|||His demeanor immediately preceding his execution I have referred to in the last chapter.|
05223|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0087.wav|||Several cases of gigantic fraud, rivaling any already recorded, were brought to light between eighteen fifty-six and eighteen seventy-three.|
05224|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0088.wav|||I propose next to describe the leading features of the most important of these.|
05225|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0089.wav|||Another case of long-continued successful forgery was brought to light two years after the convictions of Saward and his accomplices.|
05226|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0090.wav|||This conspiracy was cleverly planned, but had scarcely so many ramifications as that of Saward. Its originators were a couple of men,|
05227|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0091.wav|||Wagner and Bateman, who had already been convicted of systematic forgery, and sentenced to transportation, but they had been released on ticket-of-leave|
05228|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0092.wav|||in eighteen fifty-six.|
05229|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0093.wav|||As a blind for their new frauds, they set up as law-stationers in York Buildings, Adelphi, and at once commenced their nefarious traffic.|
05230|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0094.wav|||Forged cheques and bills were soon uttered in great numbers, as well as base coin.|
05231|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0095.wav|||The police suspecting the house in York Buildings, put a watch on the premises, which they kept up for more than a year,|
05232|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0096.wav|||and thus obtained personal knowledge of all who passed in and out, but without obtaining any direct evidence.|
05233|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0097.wav|||At length a man was caught in the act of passing a forged cheque at the Union Bank,|
05234|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0098.wav|||and recognized as one of the frequenters of the bogus law-stationers. His arrest led to that of others.|
05235|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0099.wav|||Among them was a man named Chandler, formerly a bill discounter by profession, who by degrees, to meet his extravagant expenditure,|
05236|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0100.wav|||took to appropriating the bills intrusted to him, and so lost his business, after which he became a clerk to Messrs. Wagner and Bateman.|
05237|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0101.wav|||Chandler while in Newgate turned informer, and betrayed the whole conspiracy.|
05238|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0102.wav|||Besides his employers, a jeweler named Humphreys was in the "swim," at whose shop in Red Lion Square was discovered a quantity of base gold|
05239|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0103.wav|||and silver coins, with all the latest appliances for coining, including those of electroplating;|
05240|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0104.wav|||also a furniture dealer and one or two more commonplace rogues. The arch villain was never taken into custody.|
05241|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0105.wav|||He, like Saward, was an artist in penmanship.|
05242|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0106.wav|||He was a German named Kerp,|
05243|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0107.wav|||eighty years of age, who had spent his whole life in imitating other people's signatures, and had acquired the most consummate skill in the practice.|
05244|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0108.wav|||His copies were generally pronounced indistinguishable from and as good as the originals.|
05245|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0109.wav|||The aged but wary Kerp, the moment the plot was discovered, vanished, and was never more heard of.|
05246|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0110.wav|||Much the same plan was adopted by these forgers as by Saward to get their cheques cashed.|
05247|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0111.wav|||They advertised for clerks, and employed the most likely of the applicants by sending them to the bank.|
05248|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0112.wav|||It was one of these, Glendinning, who had allowed himself to be utilized for some time in this way, whose capture led to the breaking up of the gang.|
05249|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0113.wav|||The principals in this conspiracy, Wagner and Bateman, were sentenced to penal servitude for life,|
05250|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0114.wav|||the others to twenty and ten years.|
05251|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0115.wav|||It was stated in evidence that the monies obtained by these forgeries amounted to eight thousand pounds or ten thousand pounds,|
05252|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0116.wav|||and that the forged cheques which had been presented, but refused, amounted to double the sum.|
05253|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0117.wav|||Wagner, after conviction, offered to reveal, for a reward of three thousand pounds|
05254|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0118.wav|||a system which had long been in practice of defrauding the Exchequer of vast sums by means of forged stamps.|
05255|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0119.wav|||His offer was not, however, accepted.|
05256|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0120.wav|||A more elaborate plot in many ways, more secretly, more patiently prepared than the preceding, or indeed than any in the calendar,|
05257|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0121.wav|||was the case of the forgeries upon the Bank of England discovered in eighteen sixty-three,|
05258|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0122.wav|||but not before the forged paper had been put in circulation for more than a couple of years. In eighteen sixty-one,|
05259|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0123.wav|||a man named Burnett came with his wife and took up his residence at Whitchurch, Hampshire, at no great distance from Laverstock,|
05260|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0124.wav|||where are Messrs. Portal's mills for the manufacture of bank-note paper.|
05261|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0125.wav|||Burnett had only just come out of jail after completing a sentence of penal servitude.|
05262|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0126.wav|||His object in visiting Whitchurch was to undermine the honesty of some workman in the mills;|
05263|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0127.wav|||and he eventually succeeded, his wife making the first overtures, in persuading a lad named Brown to steal some of the bank paper.|
05264|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0128.wav|||Brown took several sheets, and then was detected by Brewer, a fellow-workman of superior grade,|
05265|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0129.wav|||who threatened to betray the theft. But Brewer, either before or after this, succumbed to temptation,|
05266|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0130.wav|||and stole paper on a much larger scale than Brown.|
05267|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0131.wav|||All that was taken was handed over to Burnett, or a "woman in black" whom Brown met by appointment at Waterloo station.|
05268|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0132.wav|||To facilitate his operations, Brewer obtained a false master key from Burnett,|
05269|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0133.wav|||which gave him access to all parts of the mills, the packing-room included.|
05270|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0134.wav|||In this part of the mills a large quantity of bank-note paper was kept at the period of the robbery,|
05271|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0135.wav|||and in the states known as "water-leaf" and "sized," which are the penultimate processes of manufacture.|
05272|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0136.wav|||One more remains, that of "glazing," without which no paper is issued for engraving.|
05273|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0137.wav|||None of the stolen paper was glazed, and this was an important clue to the subsequent discovery of the crime.|
05274|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0138.wav|||Some time in eighteen sixty-two, a large deficiency in stock of bank paper unglazed was discovered at the mills.|
05275|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0139.wav|||Soon afterwards the inspectors of bank-notes at the Bank of England detected the presentation at the bank of spurious notes on genuine paper.|
05276|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0140.wav|||The two facts taken in conjunction|
05277|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0141.wav|||led to the employment of the police, and the offer of a reward of fifteen hundred pounds for the detection of the offenders.|
05278|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0142.wav|||By this time Brown alone had stolen three or four hundred sheets,|
05279|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0143.wav|||each containing two notes, many of the sheets suitable for engraving any kind of note from one thousand pounds downwards.|
05280|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0144.wav|||The amount of Brewer's abstractions (who was eventually acquitted) was never exactly estimated.|
05281|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0145.wav|||Suspicion appears to have rested on Brown, who had left Laverstock,|
05282|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0146.wav|||and he was soon approached by the police. Almost directly he was questioned he made a clean breast of the whole affair.|
05283|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0147.wav|||The next step was to take the principals, and under such circumstances as would insure their conviction.|
05284|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0148.wav|||A watch was set on Burnett, who was followed to the shop of one Buncher, a butcher in Strutton Ground.|
05285|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0149.wav|||Buncher was then tracked to North Kent Terrace, New Cross, where a Mr. and Mrs. Campbell resided,|
05286|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0150.wav|||with whom he did business in exchanging the false notes.|
05287|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0151.wav|||The police officers now taxed Mrs. Campbell with complicity, and frightened her into collusion.|
05288|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0152.wav|||With her assistance on a certain day a couple of bricks were taken out of the wall dividing her front and back parlors;|
05289|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0153.wav|||the officers ensconced themselves in the latter, and waited for Buncher's expected visit.|
05290|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0154.wav|||He came to complete a sale of forged notes, and he wanted a couple of hundred pounds for what he had.|
05291|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0155.wav|||Mrs. Campbell offered him less, and there was an altercation, in the course of which Buncher became very violent, and at length,|
05292|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0156.wav|||after using much intemperate language, he left the place in a huff.|
05293|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0157.wav|||In the course of his remarks, however, he said,|
05294|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0158.wav|||I am the man that has got all the bank paper; I have thirty thousand pounds now, and the Bank of England cannot stop it.|
05295|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0159.wav|||This was all the police wanted to know.|
05296|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0160.wav|||They next watched Buncher, and found that he paid frequent visits to Birmingham.|
05297|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0161.wav|||They also discovered that through the intermediacy of one Robert Cummings, well known as a reputed coiner,|
05298|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0162.wav|||he had been introduced to a man named Griffiths, an engraver and copper-plate printer.|
05299|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0163.wav|||Griffiths was an unusually clever and skilful workman,|
05300|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0164.wav|||who had devoted all his talent and all his energies for some seventeen years to the fabrication of false bank-notes.|
05301|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0165.wav|||On a certain day, the twenty-seventh October, eighteen sixty-two, the two were arrested simultaneously;|
05302|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0166.wav|||Buncher in London, and Griffiths in Birmingham.|
05303|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0167.wav|||Nothing was found in Buncher's premises in Strutton Ground, which were thoroughly searched,|
05304|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0168.wav|||but proofs of Griffiths' guilt were at once apparent on entering his work-room.|
05305|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0169.wav|||In one corner was a printing-press actually in use, and on it were twenty-one forged Bank of England notes, without date or signature.|
05306|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0170.wav|||On the bed were twenty forged ten-pound notes complete and ready for use, and twenty-five five-pound notes.|
05307|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0171.wav|||Mother plates for engraving the body of the notes lay about, and other plates for various processes.|
05308|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0172.wav|||More than this, Griffiths took the police to a field where, in a bank, a number of other plates were secreted.|
05309|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0173.wav|||Griffiths afterwards admitted that he had been employed in defrauding the bank since eighteen forty-six,|
05310|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0174.wav|||and the prominent part he played secured for him on conviction the heaviest sentence of the law.|
05311|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0175.wav|||This was penal servitude for life, Buncher's sentence being twenty-five, and Burnett's twenty years.|
05312|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0176.wav|||Cummings, who had introduced Buncher to Griffiths, was also tried for being in possession of stolen bank paper for improper purposes.|
05313|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0177.wav|||But as there was no independent corroboration of the informer's evidence, according to the custom of the British law,|
05314|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0178.wav|||the case was considered not proved, and he was acquitted.|
05315|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0179.wav|||On his return to Newgate to be finally discharged, Cummings jumped up the stairs and fairly danced for joy.|
05316|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0180.wav|||But he was not long at large; he was too active an evil-doer|
05317|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0181.wav|||and was perpetually in trouble. Commencing life as a resurrection man, when that trade failed through the change in the law,|
05318|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0182.wav|||and no more bodies were to be bought|
05319|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0183.wav|||he devoted his energies to coining and forgery, and in the latter line was a friend and associate of Saward's.|
05320|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0184.wav|||One narrow escape he had, however, before he abandoned his old business.|
05321|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0185.wav|||A Bow Street officer saw him leaving London in the evening by Camberwell Green, accompanied by two other men.|
05322|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0186.wav|||It was well known that they were resurrectionists, and a strict watch was kept at all the turnpike gates on the southern roads leading into London.|
05323|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0187.wav|||An officer was placed for this purpose at New Cross, Camberwell, and Kennington gates.|
05324|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0188.wav|||Presently "Old Bob" drove up to Camberwell Gate in the same cart in which he had been seen to start.|
05325|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0189.wav|||The officers rushed out to detain him. "What have you got here? We must search the cart," they cry.|
05326|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0190.wav|||By all means, replies Bob, and a close investigation follows, without any detection of the corpse concealed.|
05327|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0191.wav|||Bob was therefore allowed to pass on.|
05328|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0192.wav|||But they had the body, all the same; it had been dressed up in decent clothes and made to stand upright in the cart.|
05329|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0193.wav|||With the police officers it had passed muster as a living member of the party.|
05330|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0194.wav|||Cummings was repeatedly "run in" for the offense of coining and uttering bad money, whether coin or notes.|
05331|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0195.wav|||His regular trade, followed before he took to the life of resurrectionist, was that of an engraver.|
05332|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0196.wav|||He was a notorious criminal,|
05333|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0197.wav|||an habitual offender in his own particular line, one who would stick at no trifles to evade detection or escape capture.|
05334|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0198.wav|||It is told of "Bob" Brennan, an official specially employed for years by the Mint|
05335|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0199.wav|||to watch and prosecute coiners, that he received information that coining was carried on by Cummings and others at a place in Westminster.|
05336|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0200.wav|||He went there with a posse of officers and forced his way upstairs to the first floor,|
05337|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0201.wav|||where the coiners, unexpectedly disturbed, fell an easy prey.|
05338|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0202.wav|||But the police nearly paid the penalty of capture with their lives.|
05339|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0203.wav|||Proceeding cautiously down the stairs, they found that the flooring at the bottom had been taken up.|
05340|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0204.wav|||Where it had lain was a yawning gulf or trap sufficient to do for the whole body of police engaged in the capture.|
05341|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0205.wav|||Cummings was caught shortly afterwards.|
05342|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0206.wav|||He was a tall, slender man, with a long face and iron-gray hair.|
05343|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0207.wav|||The community of coiners of which he was so notorious a member|
05344|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0208.wav|||were a low lot, the lowest among criminals except, perhaps, the 'smashers,' or those who passed the counterfeit money.|
05345|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0209.wav|||It was not easy to detect coiners, or bring home their guilt to them.|
05346|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0210.wav|||Those who manufactured and those who passed had no direct dealings with each other.|
05347|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0211.wav|||The false coin was bought by an agent from an agent, and dealings were carried on secretly at the "Clock House" in Seven Dials.|
05348|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0212.wav|||The annals of fraudulent crime probably contain nothing|
05349|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0213.wav|||which in dramatic interest can compare with the conviction of William Roupell for forgery.|
05350|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0214.wav|||As the case must still be well remembered by the present generation, it will be necessary to give here only the briefest summary.|
05351|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0215.wav|||William Roupell was the eldest but illegitimate son of a wealthy man who subsequently married Roupell's mother, and had further legitimate issue.|
05352|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0216.wav|||William was brought up as an attorney, and became in due course his father's man of business.|
05353|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0217.wav|||As such he had pretty general control over his father's estates and affairs.|
05354|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0218.wav|||In eighteen fifty-five|
05355|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0219.wav|||he instructed certain solicitors to prepare a deed of gift as from his father, conveying to him estates near Kingston.|
05356|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0220.wav|||The old gentleman's signature to this deed of gift was a forgery,|
05357|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0221.wav|||but upon this forged and false conveyance William Roupell, who had already embarked upon a career of wild extravagance,|
05358|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0222.wav|||obtained a mortgage of seven thousand pounds.|
05359|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0223.wav|||In eighteen fifty-six the father died.|
05360|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0224.wav|||It had been supposed up to this date that he had willed his property, amounting in all to upwards of two hundred thousand pounds,|
05361|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0225.wav|||but after the funeral William Roupell produced another and a later will,|
05362|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0226.wav|||leaving everything to the widow, and constituting William sole executor.|
05363|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0227.wav|||This will was a deliberate forgery.|
05364|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0228.wav|||Five or six years later, William Roupell minutely described how he had effected the fraud.|
05365|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0229.wav|||The day his father died he got the keys of his private bureau, opened it, and took out the authentic will.|
05366|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0230.wav|||After reading it, and finding this unfavorable to himself, he resolved to carry out his deliberate plan,|
05367|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0231.wav|||namely, to suppress it and substitute another.|
05368|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0232.wav|||He himself prepared it on a blank form which he had brought with him on purpose.|
05369|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0233.wav|||To this fraudulent instrument he appended forged signatures, and in due course obtained probate.|
05370|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0234.wav|||As he possessed nearly unbounded influence over his mother, her accession to the property meant that William could dispose of it as he pleased.|
05371|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0235.wav|||He embarked forthwith in a career of the wildest extravagance, and ere long he had parted in his mother's name with most of the landed estates.|
05372|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0236.wav|||One large item of his expenditure was a contested election at Lambeth, which he gained at a cost of ten thousand pounds.|
05373|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0237.wav|||No fortune could stand the inroads he made into his mother's money,|
05374|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0238.wav|||and in eighteen sixty-two he was obliged to fly the country, hopelessly and irretrievably ruined.|
05375|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0239.wav|||His disappearance gave color and substance to evil reports already in circulation that the will and conveyance above referred to|
05376|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0240.wav|||were fictitious documents. His next brother, who should have inherited under the authentic will,|
05377|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0241.wav|||forthwith brought an ejectment on the possessor of lands purchased on the authority of the forged conveyance and will.|
05378|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0242.wav|||The case was tried at Guildford Assizes, and caused intense excitement,|
05379|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0243.wav|||the hardship to the holders of these lands being plain, should the allegations of invalidity be made good.|
05380|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0244.wav|||The effect of establishing the forgeries would be to restore to the Roupell family lands for which a price had already been paid|
05381|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0245.wav|||in all good faith to another, but a criminal member of the family.|
05382|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0246.wav|||At first the case was contested hotly, but, to the profound astonishment of every one inside and outside the court,|
05383|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0247.wav|||William Roupell himself was brought as a principal witness to clench the case by a confession altogether against himself.|
05384|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0248.wav|||He told his story with perfect coolness and self-possession, but in a grave and serious tone.|
05385|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0249.wav|||Every word he uttered was said with consideration, and sometimes with a long pause,|
05386|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0250.wav|||but at the same time with an air of the most entire truthfulness and candor.|
05387|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0251.wav|||He confessed himself a perjurer in having sworn to the false will, and a wholesale forger, having manufactured no less than ten false signatures|
05388|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0252.wav|||to deeds involving on the whole some three hundred fifty thousand pounds.|
05389|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0253.wav|||For these crimes William Roupell was tried at the Central Criminal Court on the twenty-fourth September, eighteen sixty-two.|
05390|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0254.wav|||He declined to plead, but a plea of "Not Guilty" was recorded.|
05391|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0255.wav|||The case was easily and rapidly disposed of.|
05392|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0256.wav|||Roupell made a long statement more in exculpation than in his defense.|
05393|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0257.wav|||He complained that he had at first been the dupe of others, and admitted that he had too readily fallen astray.|
05394|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0258.wav|||But while repudiating the charges made against him of systematic extravagance and immorality,|
05395|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0259.wav|||he confessed that his whole life had been a gigantic mistake, and he was ready to make what atonement he could.|
05396|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0260.wav|||Mr. Justice Byles, in passing sentence, commented severely upon the commission of such crimes by a man in Roupell's position in life,|
05397|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0261.wav|||and passed the heaviest sentence of the law, transportation for life.|
05398|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0262.wav|||Roupell received the announcement with a cheerful countenance,|
05399|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0263.wav|||and left the dock with evident satisfaction and relief at the termination of a most painful ordeal.|
05400|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0264.wav|||Roupell was quiet and submissive while in Newgate, unassuming in manner, and ready to make the best of his position.|
05401|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0265.wav|||He carried this character with him into penal servitude, and after enduring the full severity of his punishment for several years,|
05402|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0266.wav|||was at length advanced to the comparative ease of a post much coveted by convicts, that of hospital nurse.|
05403|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0267.wav|||His uniform good conduct gained him release from Portland on ticket-of-leave in eighteen eighty-two, just twenty years after his conviction.|
05404|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0268.wav|||A daring and cleverly-planned robbery of diamonds was that of the Tarpeys, man and wife,|
05405|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0269.wav|||from an assistant of Loudon and Ryder's, the jewelers in Bond Street. The trick was an old one.|
05406|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0270.wav|||The assistant called with the jewels on approbation at a house specially hired for the purpose in the West End,|
05407|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0271.wav|||and was rendered insensible by chloroform, after which he was bound and the precious stones stolen.|
05408|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0272.wav|||Mrs. Tarpey was almost immediately captured and put on her trial, but she was acquitted on the plea that she had acted under the coercion of her husband.|
05409|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0273.wav|||Tarpey was caught through his wife,|
05410|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0274.wav|||who was followed, disguised, and with her hair dyed black, to a house in the Marylebone Road, where she met her husband.|
05411|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0275.wav|||On Tarpey's defense it was stated that the idea of the theft had been suggested to him by a novel, at a time he had lost largely on the turf.|
05412|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0276.wav|||The first plot was against Mr. Harry Emmanuel, but he escaped, and the attempt was made upon Loudon and Ryder.|
05413|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0277.wav|||The last great case of fraud upon the Bank of England will fitly close this branch of the criminal records of Newgate.|
05414|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0278.wav|||This was the well and astutely devised plot of the brothers Bidwell,|
05415|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0279.wav|||assisted by Macdonell and Noyes, all of them citizens of the United States, by which the bank lost upwards of one hundred thousand pounds.|
05416|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0280.wav|||The commercial experience of these clever rogues was cosmopolitan.|
05417|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0281.wav|||Their operations were no less worldwide.|
05418|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0282.wav|||In eighteen seventy-one they crossed the Atlantic,|
05419|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0283.wav|||and by means of forged letters of credit and introduction from London, obtained large sums from continental banks, in Berlin,|
05420|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0284.wav|||Dresden, Bordeaux, Marseilles, and Lyons.|
05421|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0285.wav|||With this as capital they came back to England via Buenos Aires,|
05422|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0286.wav|||and Austin Bidwell opened a bona fide credit in the Burlington or West End branch of the Bank of England,|
05423|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0287.wav|||to which he was introduced by a well-known tailor in Saville Row.|
05424|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0288.wav|||After this the other conspirators traveled to obtain genuine bills and master the system of the leading houses at home and abroad.|
05425|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0289.wav|||When all was ready, Bidwell first "refreshed his credit" at the Bank of England, as well as disarmed suspicion,|
05426|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0290.wav|||by paying in a genuine bill of Messrs. Rothschilds' for forty-five hundred pounds, which was duly discounted.|
05427|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0291.wav|||Then he explained to the bank manager|
05428|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0292.wav|||that his transactions at Birmingham would shortly be very large, owing to the development of his business there in the alleged manufacture of Pullman cars.|
05429|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0293.wav|||The ground thus cleared, the forgers poured in from Birmingham numbers of forged acceptances,|
05430|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0294.wav|||all of which were discounted to the value of one hundred two thousand, two hundred seventeen pounds.|
05431|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0295.wav|||The fraud was rendered possible by the absence of a check usual in the United States.|
05432|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0296.wav|||There such bills would be sent to the drawer to be initialed, and the forgery would have been at once detected.|
05433|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0297.wav|||It was the discovery of this flaw in the banking system which had encouraged the Americans to attempt this crime.|
05434|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0298.wav|||Time was clearly an important factor in the fraud, hence the bills were sent forward in quick succession.|
05435|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0299.wav|||Long before they came to maturity the forgers hoped to be well beyond arrest. They had, moreover, sought to destroy all clue.|
05436|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0300.wav|||The sums obtained by Bidwell in the name of "Warren" at the Bank of England|
05437|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0301.wav|||were lodged at once by drafts to "Horton," another alias, in the Continental Bank.|
05438|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0302.wav|||For these cash was obtained in notes; the notes were exchanged by one of the conspirators for gold at the Bank of England, and again the same day|
05439|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0303.wav|||a second conspirator exchanged the gold for notes. But just as all promised well, the frauds were detected through the carelessness of the forgers.|
05440|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0304.wav|||They had omitted to insert the dates in certain bills.|
05441|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0305.wav|||The bills were sent as a matter of form to the drawer to have the date added, and the forgery was at once detected.|
05442|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0306.wav|||Noyes was seized without difficulty, as it was a part of the scheme that he should act as the dupe, and remain on the spot in London till all the money was obtained.|
05443|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0307.wav|||Through Noyes the rest of the conspirators were eventually apprehended. Very little if any of the ill-gotten proceeds, however, was ever recovered.|
05444|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0308.wav|||Large sums, as they were realized, were transmitted to the United States, and invested in various American securities,|
05445|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0309.wav|||where probably the money still remains.|
05446|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0310.wav|||The prisoners, who were committed to Newgate for trial,|
05447|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0311.wav|||had undoubtedly the command of large funds while there, and would have readily disbursed it to effect their enlargement.|
05448|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0312.wav|||A plot was soon discovered,|
05449|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0313.wav|||deep laid, and with many ramifications, by which some of the Newgate warders were to be bribed to allow the prisoners to escape from their cells at night.|
05450|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0314.wav|||Certain friends of the prisoners were watched, and found to be in communication with these warders,|
05451|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0315.wav|||to whom it was said one hundred pounds apiece had been given down as the price of their infidelity.|
05452|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0316.wav|||Further sums were to have been paid after the escape;|
05453|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0317.wav|||and one warder admitted that he was to have one thousand pounds more paid to him, and to be provided with a passage to Australia.|
05454|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0318.wav|||The vigilance of the Newgate officials, assisted by the city police, completely frustrated this plot.|
05455|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0319.wav|||A second was nevertheless set on foot,|
05456|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0320.wav|||in which the plan of action was changed, and the freedom of the prisoners was to be obtained by means of a rescue from the dock during the trial.|
05457|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0321.wav|||An increase of policemen on duty sufficed to prevent any attempt of this kind.|

05461|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0325.wav|||But extra precautions and close supervision have so far proved effectual, and the prisoners are still in custody after a lapse of ten years.|
05462|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0326.wav|||I propose to end at this point the detailed account of the more prominent criminal cases which lodged their perpetrators in Newgate.|
05463|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0327.wav|||The most recent affairs are still too fresh in the public mind to need more than a passing reference.|

05468|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0332.wav|||Greed in the latter case was a secondary motive;|

05470|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0334.wav|||Webster, it may be mentioned here, was one of the worst prisoners ever remembered in Newgate|
05471|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0335.wav|||most violent in temper, and addicted to the most frightful language.|
05472|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0336.wav|||Webster's devices for disposing of the body of her victim will call to mind those of Theodore Gardelle,|
05473|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0337.wav|||of Good, and Greenacre, and Catherine Hayes.|
05474|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0338.wav|||Greed in another form led the Stauntons to make away with Mrs. Patrick Staunton, murdering her with devilish cruelty by slow degrees.|
05475|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0339.wav|||The judge, Sir Henry Hawkins, in passing sentence|
05476|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0340.wav|||characterized this as a crime more black and hideous than any in the criminal annals of the country.|
05477|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0341.wav|||But it was scarcely worse than that of Mrs. Brownrigg, or that of the Meteyards, both of whom did their helpless apprentices to death.|
05478|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0342.wav|||It was to effect the rupture of an irksome tie that led Henry Wainwright to murder Harriet Lane deliberately and in cold blood.|
05479|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0343.wav|||In this case the tie was unsanctified, but it was not more inconvenient than that which urged Greenacre to a similar crime.|

05496|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0360.wav|||then to divert suspicion from herself by throwing it on a confectioner, whose sweetmeats she bought,|
05497|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0361.wav|||tampered with, and returned to the shop.|

05501|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0365.wav|||Kate Webster followed the same course; but these pleas of pregnancy are not common now-a-days.|

05506|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0370.wav|||unhappily show that society is more than ever at the mercy of the insidious and unscrupulous administration of poisonous drugs.|
05507|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0371.wav|||A case reproducing many of the features of the 'Flowery Land' occurred twelve years later, when the crew of the 'Lennie'|
05508|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0372.wav|||mutinied, murdered the captain and mates, sparing the steward only on condition that he would navigate the ship to the Mediterranean.|

05512|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0376.wav|||who was the ringleader, and who had long been an habitual criminal, a reputed murderer, and certainly an inmate more than once of a French bagne.|
05513|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0377.wav|||Conviction was obtained through the evidence of the steward and two of the least culpable of the crew.|

05515|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0379.wav|||Resolute, determined-looking men, their courage broke down in confinement.|
05516|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0380.wav|||They paid close attention to the counsels of the archimandrite, and died quite penitent. A story is told of one of them, "Big Harry,"|
05517|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0381.wav|||the wildest and most cut-throat looking of the lot, which proves that he could be grateful for kindness, and was not all bad.|
05518|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0382.wav|||He had steadfastly refused to eat meat on some religions scruples, and for the same reason would not touch soup.|
05519|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0383.wav|||He was glad, therefore, to get an extra allowance of bread,|
05520|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0384.wav|||and to show his gratitude to the warder who procured this privilege for him, he made him a present.|
05521|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0385.wav|||It was his own handiwork -- a bird pecking at a flower;|
05522|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0386.wav|||the whole manufactured while in the condemned cell of the crumb of bread made into paste.|
05523|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0387.wav|||The flower had berries also of bread fixed on stems made from the fiber drawn from the stuffing of his mattress,|

05525|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0389.wav|||Of the lesser criminals, forgers, thieves, swindlers, Newgate continued to receive its full share up to the last.|
05526|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0390.wav|||But there were few cases so remarkable as the great ones already recorded.|

05528|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0392.wav|||to have obtained as much as forty thousand pounds by false and fraudulent pretenses.|
