05532|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0396.wav|||The greatest causes célèbre, however, of recent times were the turf frauds by which the Comtesse de Goncourt was swindled|
05533|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0397.wav|||out of large sums in sham sporting speculations. The conviction of the principals in this nefarious transaction,|
05534|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ018-0398.wav|||Benson, the two Kurrs, Bale, and Murray, led to strange revelations of dishonest practices amongst the detective police,|
05535|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0001.wav|||The Chronicles of Newgate, Volume two. By Arthur Griffiths. Section twenty-two. Newgate Reformed.|
05536|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0002.wav|||The time at length approached when a radical and complete change was to come over the old city jail.|
05537|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0003.wav|||It was impossible for Newgate to escape for ever the influences pressing so strongly towards prison reform.|
05538|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0004.wav|||Elsewhere the spirit had been more or less active, although not uniformly or always to the same extent.|
05539|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0005.wav|||There had been a pause in legislation, except of a permissive kind. The second and third Victoria, cap. fifty-six|
05540|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0006.wav|||laid it down that individuals might be confined separately and apart in single cells.|
05541|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0007.wav|||By other acts local authorities were empowered to construct new jails or hire accommodation in the district;|
05542|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0008.wav|||but no steps had been taken in Parliament to enforce a better system of discipline,|
05543|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0009.wav|||or to insist upon the construction of prisons on the most approved plan.|
05544|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0010.wav|||As regards the first, however, Sir James Graham, when Home Secretary in eighteen forty-three,|
05545|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0011.wav|||had appointed a committee of prison inspectors, presided over by the Under Secretary of State, to draw up rules and dietaries,|
05546|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0012.wav|||which were then recommended to and generally adopted by the visiting justices all over the kingdom.|
05547|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0013.wav|||As regards the second, the Government had set a good example, and in deciding upon the erection of Pentonville prison|
05548|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0014.wav|||had embarked on a considerable expenditure in order to provide a model prison for general imitation.|
05549|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0015.wav|||The first stone of Pentonville prison was laid on the tenth April, eighteen forty, by the Marquis of Normanby,|
05550|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0016.wav|||then Home Secretary, and the prison, which contained five hundred and twenty cells, was occupied on the twenty-first December, eighteen forty-two.|
05551|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0017.wav|||This building was a costly affair. The site was uneven, and had to be leveled;|
05552|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0018.wav|||moreover, the gross expenditure was increased "partly from its being considered necessary, as it was a national prison,|
05553|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0019.wav|||to make a great archway, and to make the character of it more imposing than if it had been situated in the country, and had been an ordinary prison.|
05554|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0020.wav|||Up to the twenty-first December, eighteen forty-two,|
05555|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0021.wav|||with the additions made to that date, the total expenditure amounted to nearly ninety thousand pounds, or about one hundred eighty pounds per cell.|
05556|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0022.wav|||On the other hand, it must be admitted|
05557|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0023.wav|||that this was an experimental construction, and that too strict a limitation of outlay would have militated seriously against the usefulness of the building.|
05558|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0024.wav|||Nor must it be overlooked that this, the first model prison, although obtained at a considerable cost, became actually what its name implied.|
05559|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0025.wav|||Pentonville has really been the model on which all subsequent prison construction has been based. All prisons at home and abroad are but variations,|
05560|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0026.wav|||of course with the added improvements following longer experience, of the pattern originated by the architectural genius of Sir Joshua Jebb.|
05561|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0027.wav|||The internal arrangements of the new model were carefully supervised by a body of distinguished men, among which were many peers, Lord John Russell,|
05562|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0028.wav|||Mr. Shaw-Lefevre, the Speaker of the House of Commons, Sir Benjamin Brodie,|
05563|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0029.wav|||Major Jebb, R.E., and the two prison inspectors, Messrs. Crawford and Russell, with whose names the reader is already familiar.|
05564|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0030.wav|||Major, afterwards Sir Joshua Jebb,|
05565|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0031.wav|||was the moving spirit among these commissioners, and he is now generally recognized as the originator of modern prison architecture.|
05566|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0032.wav|||The movement thus laudably initiated by the Government soon spread to the provinces.|
05567|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0033.wav|||Some jurisdictions, greatly to their credit, strove at once to follow the lead of the central authority.|
05568|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0034.wav|||Within half-a-dozen years no less than fifty-four new prisons were built on the Pentonville plan, others were in progress,|
05569|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0035.wav|||and the total number of separate cells provided amounted to eleven thousand odd.|
05570|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0036.wav|||This list included Wakefield, Leeds, Kirkdale, Manchester, Birmingham, and Dublin.|
05571|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0037.wav|||Liverpool was building a new prison with a thousand cells, the county of Surrey one with seven hundred.|
05572|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0038.wav|||The cost in each varied considerably, the general average being from one hundred twenty pounds to one hundred thirty pounds per cell.|
05573|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0039.wav|||At Pentonville the rate was higher, but there the expense had been increased by the site,|
05574|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0040.wav|||the difficulty of access, and the admitted necessity of giving architectural importance to this the national model prison.|
05575|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0041.wav|||Other jurisdictions were less prompt to recognize their responsibilities, the city of London among the number, as I shall presently show at length.|
05576|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0042.wav|||These were either satisfied with a makeshift, and modified existing buildings, without close regard to their suitability, or for a long time did nothing at all.|
05577|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0043.wav|||Among the latter were notably the counties of Cheshire, Lincolnshire, Norfolk, Suffolk, Nottinghamshire, the East and North Ridings of Yorkshire.|
05578|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0044.wav|||The south and west of England were also very laggard, and many years were still to elapse before the prisons in these parts were properly reconstituted.|
05579|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0045.wav|||Not less remarkable than this diverse interpretation of a manifest duty|
05580|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0046.wav|||was the variety of views as regards the discipline to be introduced in these new prisons. The time was one|
05581|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0047.wav|||when thoughtful people who concerned themselves closely with social questions were greatly exercised as to the best system of treating the inmates of a jail.|
05582|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0048.wav|||A new and still imperfectly understood science had arisen,|
05583|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0049.wav|||the principles of which were debated by disputants of widely opposite opinions with an earnestness that sometimes bordered upon acrimony.|
05584|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0050.wav|||One school were strongly in favor of the continuous separation of prisoners,|
05585|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0051.wav|||the other supported the theory of labor in association, but under a stringent rule of silence, with isolation only at night.|
05586|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0052.wav|||Both systems came to us from the United States. The difference was really more in degree than in principle,|
05587|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0053.wav|||and our modern practice has prudently tried to steer between the two extremes, accepting as the best system a judicious combination of both.|
05588|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0054.wav|||But about eighteen fifty the two sides were distinctly hostile, and the controversy ran high.|
05589|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0055.wav|||High authorities were in favor of continuous separation.|
05590|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0056.wav|||Colonel Jebb preferred it; Messrs. Crawford and Whitworth Russell were convinced that the complete isolation of criminals from one another|
05591|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0057.wav|||was the true basis of a sound system of prison discipline.|
05592|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0058.wav|||Prison chaplains of experience and high repute, such as Messrs. Field, Clay, Kingsmill, Burt, and Osborne, also advocated it.|
05593|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0059.wav|||It was claimed for it that it was more deterrent;|
05594|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0060.wav|||that in districts where it was the rule, evil-doers especially dreaded coming under its irksome conditions.|
05595|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0061.wav|||Another argument was, that it afforded more hope of the reformation of criminals.|
05596|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0062.wav|||The system of associated labor in silence had also its warm supporters,|
05597|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0063.wav|||who maintained that under this system prisoners were more industrious and more healthy|
05598|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0064.wav|||that their condition was more natural, and approximated more nearly to that of daily life.|
05599|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0065.wav|||Better industrial results were obtained from it, and instruction in trades was easier, and prisoners were more likely to leave jail|
05600|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0066.wav|||with the means of earning an honest livelihood if so disposed.|
05601|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0067.wav|||The opposing champions were not slow to find faults and flaws in the system they condemned.|
05602|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0068.wav|||Separation was injurious to health, mental or physical, said one side; men broke down when subjected to it for more than a certain period,|
05603|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0069.wav|||and it was unsafe to fix this limit above twelve months, although some rash advocates were in favor of eighteen months, some indeed of two years.|
05604|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0070.wav|||The other side retorted that the system of associated labor was most costly, so many officers being required to maintain the discipline of silence;|
05605|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0071.wav|||moreover, it was nearly impossible to prevent communication and mutual contamination.|
05606|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0072.wav|||It is scarcely necessary to follow the controversy further. I have only introduced the subject as showing how little as yet the State|
05607|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0073.wav|||was impressed with the necessity for authoritative interference.|
05608|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0074.wav|||The legislature was content to let local jurisdictions experimentalize for themselves; with the strange, anomalous result,|
05609|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0075.wav|||that a thief or other criminal might be quite differently treated according as he was incarcerated on one side or another of a border line.|
05610|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0076.wav|||This variety was often extended to all branches of prison economy.|
05611|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0077.wav|||There was an absolute want of uniformity in dietaries; in some prisons it was too liberal, in others too low.|
05612|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0078.wav|||The amount of exercise varied from one or two hours daily to half the working day.|
05613|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0079.wav|||The cells inhabited by prisoners were of very varying dimensions;|
05614|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0080.wav|||some were not sufficiently ventilated, others were warmed artificially, and were unwholesomely close.|
05615|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0081.wav|||The use of gas or some other means of lighting might be adopted, but more often was dispensed with.|
05616|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0082.wav|||In a great number of prisons no provision was made for the education of prisoners, in some others there was a sufficient staff of schoolmasters and instructors.|
05617|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0083.wav|||The discipline also varied greatly, from the severely penal to the culpably lax.|
05618|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0084.wav|||The greatest pains might be taken to secure isolation,|
05619|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0085.wav|||the prisoners might be supervised and watched at every step, and made liable to punishment for a trifling breach of an irksome code of regulations,|
05620|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0086.wav|||or they might herd together or communicate freely as in the old worst days. They might see each other when they liked, and converse sotto voce,|
05621|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0087.wav|||or make signs; or the chances of recognizing or being recognized were reduced to a minimum by the use of a mask.|
05622|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0088.wav|||There was no general rule of employment. Hard labor was often not insisted upon in separate confinement;|
05623|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0089.wav|||sometimes it embraced the tread-wheel or the newly-invented instruments known as cranks, which ground air.|
05624|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0090.wav|||The alternative between labor or idleness, or the selection of the form of labor,|
05625|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0091.wav|||were mere matters of chance, and decided according to the views of the local magistracy.|
05626|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0092.wav|||They were approved of and employed at some prisons, at others objected to because they were unproductive,|
05627|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0093.wav|||and because the machine was often so imperfect that the amount of effort could not be exactly regulated.|
05628|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0094.wav|||Opinions differed greatly with regard to the tread-wheel; some authorities advocated it as a very severe and irksome punishment,|
05629|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0095.wav|||which was yet under full control, and might be made to work corn-mills or prove otherwise productive;|
05630|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0096.wav|||other authorities as strongly condemned it as brutalizing, unequal in its operation, and altogether a "deplorable invention."|
05631|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0097.wav|||This want of uniformity in prison discipline became ere long an acknowledged evil pressing for some remedy,|
05632|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0098.wav|||and the question was once more taken up in the House of Commons. In eighteen forty-nine Mr. Charles Pearson, M.P.,|
05633|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0099.wav|||moved for a committee to report upon the best means of securing some uniform system which should be "punitive, reformatory, and self-supporting;"|
05634|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0100.wav|||but the session was far advanced, and the matter was relegated to the following year.|
05635|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0101.wav|||In eighteen fifty Sir George Grey brought forward a new motion to the same effect,|
05636|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0102.wav|||which was promptly carried, with the additional instruction to the committee to suggest any improvements.|
05637|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0103.wav|||The latter had reference more especially to a proposal emanating from Mr. Charles Pearson himself.|
05638|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0104.wav|||That gentleman had come to the conclusion that the ordinary and hackneyed methods of treatment were practically inefficacious,|
05639|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0105.wav|||and that a new system of prison discipline should be introduced.|
05640|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0106.wav|||His plan was to devote the whole labor of prisoners sentenced to any term between three months and four years to agriculture.|
05641|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0107.wav|||District prisons were to be established for this purpose, each of which would be in the heart of a farm of a thousand acres.|
05642|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0108.wav|||The prisoners were to cultivate the land and raise sufficient produce for their own support.|
05643|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0109.wav|||Mr. Pearson backed up his recommendations by many sound arguments.|
05644|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0110.wav|||Field labor, he urged, and with reason, was a very suitable employment;|
05645|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0111.wav|||healthful, easily learnt, and well adapted to the circumstances of unskilled laborers.|
05646|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0112.wav|||Such excellent returns might be counted upon, that a margin of profit would be left after the cost of the prisons had been defrayed.|
05647|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0113.wav|||The scheme was no doubt fascinating, and in many respects feasible;|
05648|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0114.wav|||but Mr. Pearson overlooked some points in which a more practical mind would have foreseen difficulty, and perhaps forecasted failure.|
05649|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0115.wav|||In his proposal he dwelt much upon the humanizing effects of healthful open-air toil,|
05650|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0116.wav|||anticipating the best results from a system which made earnings, and indeed release, dependent upon the amount of work done.|
05651|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0117.wav|||That industry might thus be stimulated and encouraged was probable enough,|
05652|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0118.wav|||and later experience has fully proved the advantage of a judicious system of gratuities for labor;|
05653|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0119.wav|||but Mr. Pearson hardly considered the converse sufficiently, and|
05654|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0120.wav|||omitted the fact that he might have to deal with that persistent idleness which is not an unknown characteristic of the criminal class.|
05655|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0121.wav|||The hope of reward might do much, but no system of penal discipline is complete unless it can also count upon the fear of punishment.|
05656|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0122.wav|||Mr. Pearson seems to have taken for granted that all prisoners would behave well in his district prisons.|
05657|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0123.wav|||On that account he made no provision to insure safe custody,|
05658|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0124.wav|||thinking perhaps that prisoners so well disposed would cheerfully remain in jail of their own accord.|
05659|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0125.wav|||But an open farm of a thousand acres would have offered abundant chances of escape, which some at least would have attempted, probably with success.|
05660|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0126.wav|||The creation of an expensive staff for supervision,|
05661|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0127.wav|||or the still more costly process of walling in the whole farm, would have greatly added to the charges of these establishments.|
05662|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0128.wav|||I have lingered too long perhaps over Mr. Pearson's proposal, but some reference was indispensable to a scheme|
05663|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0129.wav|||which marked the growth of public interest in prison affairs, and which was the germ of the new system|
05664|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0130.wav|||since admirably developed in the convict prisons of this country.|
05665|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0131.wav|||Mr. Pearson and the committee of eighteen fifty have the more claim on our consideration, because,|
05666|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0132.wav|||in the inquiry which followed, attention was again attracted to Newgate.|
05667|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0133.wav|||The condition of that prison in eighteen fifty may be gathered from the pages of the report. Not much had been done to remedy the old defects;|
05668|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0134.wav|||radical improvement was generally considered impossible. The great evil, however, had been sensibly diminished.|
05669|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0135.wav|||There was no longer, or at worst but rarely, and for short periods, the same overcrowding.|
05670|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0136.wav|||This was obviated by the frequent sessions of the Central Criminal Court, and the utilization of the two subsidiary prisons in Giltspur Street and Southwark.|
05671|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0137.wav|||The prison population of Newgate was still subject to great fluctuations, but it seldom rose above two hundred and fifty or three hundred|
05672|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0138.wav|||at the most crowded periods, or just before the sessional jail delivery; and at its lowest it fell sometimes to fifty or sixty.|
05673|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0139.wav|||These numbers would have still further decreased, and the jail would have been almost empty, but for the misdemeanants who were still sent to Newgate|
05674|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0140.wav|||at times on long terms of imprisonment, and for the transports, whom the Home Office were often, as of old, slow to remove.|
05675|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0141.wav|||The old wards, day rooms and sleeping rooms combined, of which the reader has already heard so much,|
05676|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0142.wav|||now seldom contained more than ten or a dozen each. Some sort of decorum was maintained among the occupants in the day-time.|
05677|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0143.wav|||Drinking and gaming,|
05678|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0144.wav|||the indiscriminate visitation of friends, and the almost unlimited admission of extra food, these more glaring defects had disappeared.|
05679|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0145.wav|||But reformation was only skin deep. Below the surface many of the old evils still rankled.|
05680|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0146.wav|||There was as yet no control over the prisoners after locking-up time;|
05681|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0147.wav|||this occurred in summer at eight, but in the winter months it took place at dusk, and was often as early as four or five.|
05682|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0148.wav|||The prisoners were still left to themselves till next morning's unlocking,|
05683|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0149.wav|||and they spent some fourteen or fifteen hours in total darkness, and almost without check or control.|
05684|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0150.wav|||Captain Williams, who was the inspector of prisons for the home district in succession to Messrs. Crawford and Russell,|
05685|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0151.wav|||stated in evidence that he was visiting Newgate one night, when he heard a great disturbance in one of the day and sleeping rooms,|
05686|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0152.wav|||and on entering it found the prisoners engaged in kicking bundles of wood from one end of the ward to the other.|
05687|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0153.wav|||Some attempt at supervision was exercised by the night watchman stationed on the leads, who might hear what went on inside.|
05688|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0154.wav|||If any disturbance reached his ears, he reported the case to the governor, who next morning visited the ward in fault, and asked for the culprit.|
05689|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0155.wav|||The enforcement of discipline depended upon the want of honor among thieves.|
05690|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0156.wav|||Unless the guilty prisoner was given up, the whole ward was punished, either by the exclusion of visitors or the deprivation of fire,|
05691|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0157.wav|||sharp tests which generally broke down the fidelity of the inmates of the ward to one another.|
05692|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0158.wav|||Later on a more efficacious but still imperfect method of supervision was introduced. Iron cages, which are still to be seen in Newgate,|
05693|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0159.wav|||were constructed on the landings, ensconced in which warders spent the night, on duty, and alert to watch the sleepers below,|
05694|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0160.wav|||and check by remonstrance or threat of punishment all who broke the peace of the prison.|
05695|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0161.wav|||These disciplinary improvements were, however, only slowly and gradually introduced.|
05696|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0162.wav|||Other changes affecting the condition and proper treatment of prisoners were not made until the inspector had urged and recommended them.|
05697|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0163.wav|||Thus the wards, which, as I have said, were left in complete darkness, were now to be lighted with gas; and after this most salutary addition,|
05698|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0164.wav|||the personal superintendence of night officers, as already described, became possible.|
05699|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0165.wav|||The rule became general as regards the prison dress; hitherto clothing had been issued only to such as were destitute or in rags, and all classes of prisoners,|
05700|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0166.wav|||those for trial, and those sentenced for short terms or long|
05701|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0167.wav|||wore no distinguishing costume, although its use was admitted, not only for cleanliness, but as a badge of condition, and a security against escape.|
05702|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0168.wav|||Renewed recommendations to provide employment resulted in the provision of a certain amount of oakum for picking,|
05703|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0169.wav|||and one or two men were allowed to mend clothes and make shoes. The rules made by the Secretary of State were hung up in conspicuous parts of the prison;|
05704|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0170.wav|||more officers were appointed, as the time of so many of those already on the staff was monopolized by attendance at the Central Criminal Court.|
05705|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0171.wav|||Another custom which had led to disorder was abolished;|
05706|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0172.wav|||prisoners who had been acquitted were not permitted to return to the prison to show their joy and receive the congratulations of their unfortunate fellows.|
05707|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0173.wav|||The Corporation seems to have introduced these salutary changes without hesitation.|
05708|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0174.wav|||It was less prompt apparently in dealing with structural alterations and improvements.|
05709|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0175.wav|||Well-founded complaints had been made of the want of heating appliances in the jail.|
05710|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0176.wav|||The wards had open fires, but the separate cells were not warmed at all.|
05711|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0177.wav|||A scheme for heating the whole prison with hot-water pipes, after the system now generally adopted elsewhere, was considered,|
05712|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0178.wav|||and abandoned because of the expense. As to the entire reconstruction of Newgate, nothing had been done as yet.|
05713|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0179.wav|||This, with a scheme for limiting the jail to untried prisoners, had been urgently recommended by Lord John Russell in eighteen thirty.|
05714|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0180.wav|||His letter to the Corporation, under date fourth June,|
05715|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0181.wav|||is an interesting document, and shows that even at that date the Government contemplated the erection of a model prison.|
05716|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0182.wav|||Lord John Russell, commenting upon the offer of the Corporation to improve Newgate,|
05717|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0183.wav|||provided it was henceforth used only for untried prisoners, suggested that Newgate should be entirely reconstructed, and the new building adopted as a model.|
05718|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0184.wav|||The Corporation had agreed to spend twenty thousand pounds on alterations, but sixty thousand pounds would suffice to reconstruct.|
05719|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0185.wav|||Lord John, with great fairness, admitted that the whole of this burthen could not be imposed upon the city|
05720|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0186.wav|||seeing that since the establishment of the Central Criminal Court, Newgate received prisoners for trial from several counties,|
05721|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0187.wav|||and he was therefore prepared to submit to Parliament a proposal that half the cost of reconstruction should be borne by public funds.|
05722|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0188.wav|||He forwarded plans prepared by the inspectors of prisons, not for blind adoption, but as a guide.|
05723|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0189.wav|||This plan was on the principle of cellular separation, a system, according to Lord John Russell, desirable in all prisons,|
05724|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0190.wav|||but in a metropolitan prison absolutely essential. The Corporation in reply demurred rather to accepting strict separation as a rule,|
05725|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0191.wav|||feeling that it approached too nearly to solitary confinement.|
05726|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0192.wav|||The court was, however, prepared to consider Lord John Russell's proposal with regard to the cost of rebuilding;|
05727|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0193.wav|||but as the plan was "confessedly experimental, for the benefit of the country generally, the amount for which the city should be responsible should be distinctly limited|
05728|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0194.wav|||not to exceed a certain sum to be agreed upon.|
05729|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0195.wav|||A proviso was also made that the magistrates should continue to exercise full control over the new jail,|
05730|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0196.wav|||free from any other interference than that of the inspectors on the part of Government.|
05731|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0197.wav|||No doubt wiser counsels prevailed with Lord John Russell,|
05732|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0198.wav|||and on a more mature consideration he realized that the limited area of the existing Newgate site,|
05733|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0199.wav|||and the costliness of enlarging it, forbade all idea of entirely reconstructing the jail so as to constitute it a model prison.|
05734|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0200.wav|||It would be far better to begin at the beginning,|
05735|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0201.wav|||to select a sufficiently spacious piece of ground, and erect a prison which from foundations to roofs should be in conformity with the newest ideas.|
05736|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0202.wav|||The preference given to the Pentonville system destroyed all hopes of a complete reformation of Newgate.|
05737|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0203.wav|||But the condition of the great city jail was evidently considered a reproach by the city authorities, and a year after the opening of the new "model" at Pentonville,|
05738|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0204.wav|||a serious effort was made to reconstruct Newgate.|
05739|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0205.wav|||In eighteen forty-five the Jail Committee brought forward a definite proposal to purchase ground in the immediate vicinity for the erection of a new jail.|
05740|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0206.wav|||This jail was nominally to replace the Giltspur Street Compter,|
05741|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0207.wav|||The site of which was to be sold to Christ's Hospital, but the intention was of course to embody and absorb old Newgate in the new construction.|
05742|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0208.wav|||The proposal made was to purchase some fifty thousand square feet between Newgate, Warwick Lane, and the Sessions House,|
05743|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0209.wav|||the situation having been proved by long experience to be salubrious.|
05744|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0210.wav|||But when this suggestion was brought before the court of aldermen, various amendments were proposed.|
05745|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0211.wav|||It was urged that the area selected for purchase must be excessively costly to acquire, and still quite inadequate for the city needs.|
05746|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0212.wav|||The Home Secretary had laid it down that at least five acres would be indispensable, and such an area it was impossible to obtain within the limits of the city.|
05747|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0213.wav|||Now for the first time the Tuffnell estate in Holloway was mentioned.|
05748|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0214.wav|||The Corporation owned lands there covering from nineteen to twenty acres.|
05749|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0215.wav|||Why not move the city prison bodily into this more rural spot, with its purer air and greater breathing space?|
05750|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0216.wav|||Eventually Holloway was decided upon as a site for the new city prison.|
05751|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0217.wav|||The necessary preliminaries took some time, but the contracts for the new building were completed in eighteen forty-nine, when the works were commenced.|
05752|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0218.wav|||The prison was to contain four hundred and four prisoners, and the estimated expenditure was seventy-nine thousand pounds.|
05753|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0219.wav|||It was to accommodate only the convicted prisoners sentenced to terms short of penal servitude, and after its completion|
05754|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0220.wav|||the uses of Newgate were narrowed almost entirely to those of a prison of detention.|
05755|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0221.wav|||It was intended as far as possible that, except awaiting trial, no prisoner should find himself relegated to Newgate.|
05756|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0222.wav|||This principle became more and more generally the rule, although it has never been punctiliously observed. Now and again|
05757|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0223.wav|||misdemeanants have found their way into Newgate, and within the last few years one offender against the privileges of the House of Commons.|
05758|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0224.wav|||With the reduction of numbers to be accommodated, there was ample space in Newgate for its reconstruction on the most approved modern lines.|
05759|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0225.wav|||In eighteen fifty-seven|
05760|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0226.wav|||the erection of a wing or large block of cells was commenced within the original walls of the prison, and upon the north or male side.|
05761|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0227.wav|||This block contained one hundred and thirty cells, embracing every modern improvement;|
05762|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0228.wav|||it also contained eleven reception cells, six punishment cells, and a couple of cells for condemned criminals.|
05763|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0229.wav|||This block was completed in eighteen fifty-nine, after which the hitherto unavoidable and long-continued promiscuous association of prisoners|
05764|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0230.wav|||In eighteen sixty-one a similar work was undertaken to provide separate cellular accommodation for the female inmates of Newgate,|
05765|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0231.wav|||and by the following year forty-seven new cells had been built on the most approved plan.|
05766|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0232.wav|||During this reconstruction the female prisoners were lodged in Holloway,|
05767|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0233.wav|||and when it was completed, both sides of the prison were brought into harmony with modern ideas.|
05768|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0234.wav|||The old buildings were entirely disused, and the whole of the inmates of Newgate were kept constantly in separate confinement.|
05769|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0235.wav|||With the last re-edification of Newgate, a work executed some seven centuries after the first stone of the old jail was laid,|
05770|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0236.wav|||the architectural records of the prison end. Nothing much was done at Newgate in the way of building, outside or in, after eighteen sixty-two.|
05771|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0237.wav|||The Act for private executions led to the erection of the gallows shed in the exercising yard, and at the flank of the passage from the condemned cells.|
05772|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0238.wav|||The first "glass house," or room in which prisoners could talk in private with their attorneys, but yet be seen by the warder on the watch, had been constructed|
05773|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0239.wav|||and others were subsequently added.|
05774|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0240.wav|||But no structural alterations were made from the date first quoted until the time of closing the prison in eighteen eighty-one.|
05775|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0241.wav|||But in the interval very comprehensive and, I think it must be admitted, salutary changes were successively introduced into the management of prisons.|
05776|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0242.wav|||Newgate naturally shared in any advantages due to these reforms. I propose, therefore, to refer to them in the concluding pages of this work,|
05777|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0243.wav|||and thus bring the history of prison discipline down to our own times.|
05778|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0244.wav|||The last inquiry into the condition and management of our jails and houses of correction was that made by the Lords' Committee in eighteen sixty-three.|
05779|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0245.wav|||The inquiry was most searching and complete, and the committee spoke plainly in its report.|
05780|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0246.wav|||It animadverted strongly on "the many and wide differences as regards construction, labor, diet, and general discipline"|
05781|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0247.wav|||which existed in the various prisons,|
05782|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0248.wav|||leading to an inequality, uncertainty, and inefficiency of punishment productive of the most prejudicial results.|
05783|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0249.wav|||The varieties in construction were still very marked.|
05784|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0250.wav|||In many prisons the prisoners were still associated, and, from the want of a sufficient number of cells, the principle of separation was still greatly neglected.|
05785|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0251.wav|||Yet this principle, as the committee pointed out, "must now be accepted as the foundation of prison discipline,"|
05786|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0252.wav|||while its rigid maintenance was in its opinion vital to the efficiency of the jails.|
05787|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0253.wav|||Even where cells had been built|
05788|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0254.wav|||they were frequently below the standard size, and were therefore not certified for occupation as was required by law.|
05789|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0255.wav|||Great numbers were not lighted at night, and were without means by which their inmates could communicate, in case of urgent necessity, with their keepers.|
05790|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0256.wav|||Still greater were the differences with regard to employment. The various authorities held widely different opinions as to what constituted hard labor.|
05791|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0257.wav|||Here the tread-wheel was in use, there cellular cranks, or hard-labor machines.|
05792|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0258.wav|||Both, however, varied greatly in mechanism and in the amount of energy they called forth,|
05793|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0259.wav|||while the former was intended for the congregate labor of a number, and the latter, as its name implies, imposed continuous solitary toil.|
05794|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0260.wav|||At other prisons "shot-drill," the lifting and carrying of heavy round shot, was the favorite method of inflicting penal labor.|
05795|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0261.wav|||With these differences were others as opposed concerning industrial occupation.|
05796|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0262.wav|||The jail authorities often gave the highest, possibly undue, importance to the value of remunerative employment,|
05797|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0263.wav|||and sought to make profitable returns from prisoners' labor the test of prison efficiency. In this view the committee could not coincide,|
05798|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0264.wav|||and it was decidedly of opinion that in all short sentences the hard labor of the tread-wheel, crank, and so forth should be the invariable rule.|
05799|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0265.wav|||In dietaries, again, the same wide diversity of practice obtained.|
05800|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0266.wav|||The efforts made by Sir James Graham years before to introduce uniformity in this particular had failed of effect.|
05801|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0267.wav|||The Secretary of State's suggested scale of diet had seldom been closely followed.|
05802|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0268.wav|||In some places the dietary was too full, in others too meager. Its constituents were not of the most suitable character.|
05803|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0269.wav|||More animal food was given than was necessary.|
05804|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0270.wav|||Vegetables, especially the potato, that most valuable anti-scorbutic, was too often omitted.|
05805|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0271.wav|||In a word, the value of diet as a part of penal discipline was still insufficiently recognized.|
05806|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0272.wav|||The prisons were still far from inflicting the three punishments, hard labor, hard fare, and a hard bed|
05807|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0273.wav|||which Sir Joshua Jebb told the committee he considered the proper elements of penal discipline.|
05808|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0274.wav|||It is interesting to note here|
05809|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0275.wav|||that the committee of eighteen sixty-three fully endorsed Sir Joshua's recommendations as regards a "hard bed," and recommended that|
05810|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0276.wav|||during short sentences, or the earlier stages of a long confinement,|
05811|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0277.wav|||the prisoners should be made to dispense with the use of a mattress, and should sleep on planks.|
05812|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0278.wav|||This suggestion was adopted in the Act of eighteen sixty-five, which followed the committee's report, and of which more directly.|
05813|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0279.wav|||Clause ninety-two, Schedule one of that act authorized the use of plank beds, which were adopted in many prisons.|
05814|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0280.wav|||They are now the universal rule,|
05815|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0281.wav|||introduced, as was erroneously supposed, by the prison commissioners appointed under the Prison Act of eighteen seventy-seven.|
05816|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0282.wav|||Their origin it will be seen dates back much further than that.|
05817|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0283.wav|||Beds might well be made hard and their use strictly limited.|
05818|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0284.wav|||According to this committee of eighteen sixty-three, beds in the smaller and most carelessly conducted prisons formed a large element in the life of a prisoner.|
05819|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0285.wav|||In one jail fifteen hours were spent in bed out of the twenty-four. This was in keeping with other grave defects and omissions.|
05820|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0286.wav|||The minor borough prisons were the worst blot on the still dark and imperfect system.|
05821|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0287.wav|||They were very numerous, very imperfect in construction and management, and they were very little required.|
05822|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0288.wav|||In them, according to the committee, the old objectionable practices were still in full force.|
05823|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0289.wav|||There was unrestrained association of untried and convicted, juvenile with adult prisoners, vagrants, misdemeanants, felons.|
05824|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0290.wav|||There were dormitories without light, control, or regulation at night,|
05825|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0291.wav|||which warders, dreading assault, were afraid to enter after dark, even to check rioting and disturbance.|
05826|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0292.wav|||Prisoners still slept two in a bed.|
05827|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0293.wav|||In one prison the bedsteads had been removed lest the prisoners should break them up and convert them into weapons of offense.|
05828|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0294.wav|||The prison buildings were in many places out of repair; other houses often overlooked them.|
05829|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0295.wav|||A single officer was the only custodian and disciplinary authority in the jail.|
05830|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0296.wav|||Complete idleness was tolerated; there was neither penal labor nor light employment.|
05831|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0297.wav|||The prisoners inter-communicated freely, and exercised the most injurious, corrupting influences upon one another.|
05832|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0298.wav|||The total want of administration was very marked,|
05833|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0299.wav|||but in one prison it was such that the prisoners' food was supplied daily from the neighboring inn, and the innkeeper's bill constituted the only accounts kept.|
05834|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0300.wav|||The committee might well suggest the abolition of these jails, or their amalgamation with the larger county establishments in their immediate neighborhood.|
05835|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0301.wav|||Some idea of the comparative uselessness of these small borough prisons was conveyed by some figures quoted by the committee.|
05836|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0302.wav|||In eighteen sixty-two there were in all one hundred and ninety-three jails in England and Wales;|
05837|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0303.wav|||of these, sixty-three gave admittance during the entire year to less than twenty-five prisoners;|
05838|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0304.wav|||twenty-two others received between eleven and twenty-five;|
05839|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0305.wav|||fourteen received less than eleven and more than six;|
05840|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0306.wav|||while twenty-seven received less than six prisoners, and were in some instances absolutely tenantless.|
05841|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0307.wav|||The result of the recommendation of the committee of eighteen sixty-two was the Prison Act of eighteen sixty-five,|
05842|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0308.wav|||the penultimate of such enactments, many of the provisions of which still remain in force.|
05843|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0309.wav|||The main object of this act was to compass that uniformity in discipline and treatment generally|
05844|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0310.wav|||which had long been admitted as indispensable, and had never as yet been properly obtained.|
05845|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0311.wav|||The legislature was beginning to overcome its disinclination to interfere actively or authoritatively|
05846|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0312.wav|||with the local jurisdictions, although still very leniently disposed.|
05847|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0313.wav|||However, it now laid down in plain language and with precise details the requirements of a good jail system.|
05848|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0314.wav|||The separation of prisoners in cells duly certified by the inspectors was insisted upon,|
05849|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0315.wav|||also their constant employment in labor appropriate to their condition.|
05850|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0316.wav|||Hard labor of the first and second class was carefully defined.|
05851|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0317.wav|||The former, which consisted principally of the tread-wheel, cranks, capstans, shot-drill,|
05852|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0318.wav|||was to be the rule for all convicted prisoners throughout the early stages of their detention;|
05853|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0319.wav|||while the latter, which included various forms of industrial employment,|
05854|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0320.wav|||was the boon to which willing industry extending over a long period established a certain claim.|
05855|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0321.wav|||The infliction of punishment more or less uniform was thus aimed at.|
05856|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0322.wav|||On the other hand, new and careful regulations were framed to secure the moral and material well-being of the inmates of the jails.|
05857|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0323.wav|||The law made it imperative that every prison should have a prison chapel, and that daily and Sunday services should be held.|
05858|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0324.wav|||The chaplain's duties were enlarged, and the principle of toleration accepted to the extent of securing to all prisoners|
05859|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0325.wav|||the ministrations of ministers of their own form of belief.|
05860|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0326.wav|||Steps were taken to provide the illiterate with secular instruction.|
05861|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0327.wav|||No less close was the care as regards preservation of health.|
05862|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0328.wav|||Stringent rules were prescribed for the prison surgeons;|
05863|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0329.wav|||every prison was ordered to keep up an infirmary, and the medical supervision was to be strict and continuous.|
05864|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0330.wav|||Dietaries were drawn up for adoption on the recommendation of a committee of experts.|
05865|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0331.wav|||Baths were provided, ablutions ordered, and all appliances to insure personal cleanliness.|
05866|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0332.wav|||The administration of good government was to be watched over by the local magistracy, certain of whom, styled visiting justices,|
05867|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0333.wav|||were elected to inspect the prisons frequently, to examine the prisoners, hear complaints, and check abuses.|
05868|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0334.wav|||Under them the governor or jailer was held strictly responsible.|
05869|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0335.wav|||The books and journals he was to keep were minutely specified, and his constant presence in or near the jail was insisted upon.|
05870|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0336.wav|||His disciplinary powers were defined by the act, and his duties,|
05871|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0337.wav|||both in controlling his subordinates and in protecting the prisoners from petty tyranny and oppression, every one of whom he was to see once every twenty-four hours.|
05872|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0338.wav|||But discipline was to be maintained if necessary by punishment,|
05873|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0339.wav|||while decency and good order were to be insured by the strict prohibition of gambling and drunkenness.|
05874|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0340.wav|||The latter was rendered nearly impossible by the penalties imposed on persons bringing spirituous liquors into the jail.|
05875|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0341.wav|||The old custom, so fruitful of the worst evils, of keeping a tap inside the prison was made illegal.|
05876|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0342.wav|||So was the employment of prisoners in any position of trust or authority;|
05877|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0343.wav|||they were not to be turnkeys or assistant turnkeys, neither wardsman nor yardsman, overseer,|
05878|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0344.wav|||monitor, or schoolmaster, nor to be engaged in the service of any officer of the prison.|
05879|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0345.wav|||The Act of eighteen sixty-five also encouraged and empowered the local authorities to "alter, enlarge, or rebuild" their prisons.|
05880|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0346.wav|||They might raise funds for this purpose, provided a certificate for the necessity for the new works was given, either by the recorder|
05881|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0347.wav|||chairman of quarter sessions, or even by a couple of justices.|
05882|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0348.wav|||Every facility was promised. The sanction of the Secretary of State would not be withheld if plans and estimates were duly submitted,|
05883|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0349.wav|||and they met with the approval of his professional adviser, the surveyor-general of prisons.|
05884|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0350.wav|||The funds necessary would be advanced by the Public Works Loan Commissioners, and the interest might be charged against the county or borough rates.|
05885|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0351.wav|||Nor were these the only inducements offered. Where local authorities were indisposed to set their prisons in order,|
05886|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0352.wav|||or hesitated to embark upon any considerable expenditure to alter or rebuild,|
05887|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0353.wav|||they were at liberty to hire suitable cell accommodation from any neighbors who might have it to spare; the only proviso,|
05888|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0354.wav|||That no such contract was valid between one jurisdiction and another unless the Secretary of State was satisfied that the prison it was intended to use|
05889|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0355.wav|||came up in all respects to modern requirements.|
05890|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0356.wav|||But the act was not limited to permissive legislation. Its provisions and enactments were backed up by certain penalties.|
05891|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0357.wav|||The Secretary of State was empowered to deal rather summarily with "inadequate" prisons, in other words,|
05892|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0358.wav|||with those in which there was no separation, no proper enforcement of hard labor, no chapel, infirmary, and so forth.|
05893|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0359.wav|||He could in the first place withhold the government grant in aid of prison funds by refusing the certificate to the Treasury upon which the allowance was paid.|
05894|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0360.wav|||This he might do on the representation of the inspector of prisons,|
05895|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0361.wav|||who was bound to report any deficiencies and abuses he might find at his periodical visits. The Secretary of State might go further.|
05896|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0362.wav|||Where the local authority had neglected to comply with the provisions of the eighteen sixty-five Act for four consecutive years,|
05897|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0363.wav|||he could close the "inadequate" prison, by declaring it unfit for the reception of prisoners.|
05898|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0364.wav|||His order would at the same time specify some neighboring and more satisfactory prison which the local authority would be compelled to utilize instead,|
05899|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0365.wav|||and with the concurrence of the other authority, and on payment. A few provisos governed these rather extensive powers.|
05900|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0366.wav|||It was necessary, for instance, to give due notice when the government grant was to be withdrawn,|
05901|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0367.wav|||and with the warning a copy of the particular defects and allegations was to be sent to the local authority.|
05902|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0368.wav|||The latter too was to be laid before the House of Commons.|
05903|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0369.wav|||In the same way, six months' notice was required in cases where the closing of a prison was contemplated;|
05904|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0370.wav|||but if these conditions were observed, the Secretary of State could deal sharply enough with the defaulting jurisdictions.|
05905|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0371.wav|||Yet the law was seldom if ever enforced.|
05906|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0372.wav|||It was practically inoperative as regards the penalties for neglect. It was no doubt as irksome and inconvenient to the Secretary of State|
05907|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0373.wav|||to avail himself of his powers, as it was difficult to bring home the derelictions of duties and evasion of the acts. Too much was left to the inspectors.|
05908|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0374.wav|||It was nearly impossible for them to exercise a very close supervision over the whole of the prisons of the country.|
05909|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0375.wav|||There were only two of them, and they could not visit each prison more than once in each year, sometimes not oftener than once in eighteen months.|
05910|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0376.wav|||The task imposed upon them, tending as it did to the imposition of a fine upon the local authorities, was not a pleasant one,|
05911|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0377.wav|||and it is not strange if they did not very frequently hand up the offenders to the reproof and correction of the Secretary of State.|
05912|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0378.wav|||As the almost inevitable consequence, while the more glaring defects in prison management disappeared,|
05913|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0379.wav|||matters went on after the eighteen sixty-five Act much the same as they had done before. Districts differed greatly in the attention they paid to prison affairs.|
05914|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0380.wav|||In one part the most praiseworthy activity prevailed,|
05915|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0381.wav|||in another there was half-heartedness, even apathy and an almost complete contempt for the provisions of the act.|
05916|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0382.wav|||As the years passed, great want of uniformity continued to prevail throughout the prisons of the United Kingdom.|
05917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0383.wav|||The whole question assumed sufficient importance to become a part of the Government program when Lord Beaconsfield took office in eighteen seventy-four.|
05918|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0384.wav|||The Home Secretary in that administration,|
05919|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0385.wav|||Mr. (now Sir Richard) Cross, having applied himself vigorously to the task of reorganizing the whole system, became convinced|
05920|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0386.wav|||that no complete reform could be accomplished so long as the prisons were left under the jurisdiction of the local authorities.|
05921|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0387.wav|||The Prisons Bill of eighteen seventy-six contemplated the transfer of the prisons to Government.|
05922|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0388.wav|||This bill, reintroduced in eighteen seventy-seven, became law that year, after which the whole of the prisons, including Newgate,|
05923|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0389.wav|||passed under the more direct control of the State.|
05924|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0390.wav|||Since then a strong central authority has labored steadfastly to compass concentration,|
05925|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0391.wav|||to close useless prisons, and to insure that uniformity of system which all thoughtful persons had long admitted to be of paramount importance|
05926|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0392.wav|||in the administration of prisons.|
05927|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0393.wav|||Three years after the advent of the prison commissioners, it was decided that Newgate was an excessively costly and redundant establishment.|
05928|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0394.wav|||It was only filled at the periods when the sessions of the Central Criminal Court were in progress;|
05929|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0395.wav|||at others an expensive staff was maintained with little or nothing to do.|
05930|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0396.wav|||At a short distance stood another prison of detention, that of Clerkenwell,|
05931|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0397.wav|||with spare accommodation sufficient to receive all prisoners who were then committed to Newgate. These arguments were unanswerable.|
05932|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0398.wav|||Accordingly, it was ordered by Sir William Harcourt, the present Secretary of State, that Newgate should cease to be used as a regular prison,|
05933|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ019-0399.wav|||and it is now, except during sessions or when the gallows is in requisition, practically and for ever closed.|
05934|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0001.wav|||Marion Harland's Cookery for Beginners. Bread Sponge and Breakfast Breads.|
05935|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0002.wav|||Bread raised with what is known to bakers as a “sponge,” requires more time and a trifle more work than the simpler form for which I have just already given directions.|
05936|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0003.wav|||But it keeps fresh longer, is softer and more nutritious, and a second-rate brand of flour thus treated produces a better loaf|
05937|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0004.wav|||than when mixed up with yeast and water only.|
05938|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0005.wav|||Sponge-making is, therefore, an important if not an essential accomplishment in a cook, be she novice or veteran.|
05939|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0006.wav|||Three potatoes of fair size, peeled and boiled mealy.|
05940|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0007.wav|||Five tablespoonfuls of yeast. One tablespoonful of white sugar.|
05941|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0008.wav|||One tablespoonful of butter.|
05942|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0009.wav|||Three cups of lukewarm water in which the potatoes were boiled, strained through a coarse cloth.|
05943|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0010.wav|||One heaping cup of sifted flour.|
05944|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0011.wav|||Put the potatoes into a large bowl or tray and mash them to powder with a potato beetle, or a wooden spoon.|
05945|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0012.wav|||While still hot, mix in the sugar and butter, beating all to a lumpless cream.|
05946|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0013.wav|||Add a few spoonfuls at a time, the potato-water alternately with the flour by the handful,|
05947|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0014.wav|||beating the batter smooth as you go on until all of the liquid and flour has gone in.|
05948|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0015.wav|||Beat hard one minute before pouring in the yeast.|
05949|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0016.wav|||it is well to stir into the yeast a bit of soda no larger than a grain of corn already wet up in a teaspoonful of boiling water.|
05950|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0017.wav|||Now whip up the batter with a wooden spoon for another minute, and the sponge is made.|
05951|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0018.wav|||Throw a cloth over the bowl and set by for five or six hours to rise.|
05952|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0019.wav|||If you intend to bake in the forenoon, make the sponge at bedtime. If in the afternoon, early in the morning.|
05953|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0020.wav|||When the sponge is light sift a quart and a cup of flour into a bowl or tray with two teaspoonfuls of salt.|
05954|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0021.wav|||Into a hollow, like a crater in the middle of the flour, empty your sponge-bowl, and work the flour down into it.|
05955|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0022.wav|||Wash out the bowl with a little lukewarm water and add this to the dough. If it should prove too soft, work in, cautiously, a little more flour.|
05956|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0023.wav|||If too stiff, warm water, a spoonful at a time until you can handle the paste easily. The danger is in getting it too stiff. Now.|
05957|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0024.wav|||knead and set for risings first and second, as you have already been instructed. This sponge will be found especially useful in making Graham Bread.|
05958|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0025.wav|||One quart of Graham flour, one cup of white flour.|
05959|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0026.wav|||One half cup of Indian meal. One half cup of molasses. Two teaspoonfuls of salt. Soda, the size of a pea.|
05960|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0027.wav|||Half the quantity of sponge given in preceding receipt.|
05961|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0028.wav|||Warm water for rinsing bowl -- about half a cup.|
05962|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0029.wav|||Put the brown or Graham flour unsifted into the bread-bowl.|
05963|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0030.wav|||Sift into it white flour, meal and salt, and stir up well while dry.|
05964|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0031.wav|||Into the “crater” dug out in the middle, pour the sponge, warm water, the molasses, and soda dissolved in hot water.|
05965|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0032.wav|||Knead as you would white bread, and set aside for the rising.|
05966|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0033.wav|||It will not swell so fast as the white, so give yourself more time for making it.|
05967|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0034.wav|||When light, knead well and long;|
05968|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0035.wav|||make into two loaves, then put into well-greased pans and leave for an hour, or until it becomes more than twice the original size of the dough.|
05969|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0036.wav|||Take care that it does not burn in baking. The molasses renders it liable to scorching.|
05970|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0037.wav|||The oven must be steady, but not so hot as for white bread, nor will the Graham bread be done quite so soon as that made of bolted flour.|
05971|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0038.wav|||Turn the pans once while baking, moving them as gently as possible.|
05972|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0039.wav|||If rudely shaken or jarred, there will be heavy streaks in loaves.|
05973|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0040.wav|||Graham bread is wholesome and sweet, and ought to be eaten frequently in every family, particularly by young people whose bones and teeth are in forming.|
05974|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0041.wav|||The phosphates which the process of “bolting” removes to a large extent from white flour, go directly to the manufacture of bone,|
05975|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0042.wav|||and these also tend to nourish and strengthen the brain.|
05976|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0043.wav|||After mixing your bread in the morning either with sponge or with yeast, divide the kneaded dough into two portions.|
05977|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0044.wav|||Mould one into a round ball, and set aside for a loaf as already directed.|
05978|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0045.wav|||Make a hole in the middle of the other batch and pour into it a tablespoonful of butter, just melted, but not hot.|
05979|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0046.wav|||Close the dough over it, dust your hands and kneading-board with flour and work in the shortening until the dough is elastic and ceases to be sticky.|
05980|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0047.wav|||Put it into a floured bowl, cover with a cloth and set away out of draught and undue heat, for three hours.|
05981|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0048.wav|||Knead it again, then, and wait upon its rising for another three hours. The dough should be as soft as can be handled.|
05982|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0049.wav|||When it is light for the second time flour your board, rubbing in the flour and blowing lightly away what does not adhere to the surface.|
05983|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0050.wav|||Toss the lump dough upon it and knead thoroughly for five minutes.|
05984|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0051.wav|||Flour a rolling-pin and roll the dough into a sheet not more than half an inch thick.|
05985|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0052.wav|||Cut this into round cakes with a biscuit-cutter or a sharp-edged tumbler and fold, not quite in the middle,|
05986|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0053.wav|||in the form of turnovers, pinching the corners of the fold pretty hard to hinder the flap of dough from flying up as the rising proceeds.|
05987|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0054.wav|||Rub the bottom and sides of a baking-pan with sweet lard or butter. Do this with a bit of clean soft rag or tissue-paper,|
05988|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0055.wav|||visiting every corner of the pan, but not leaving thick layers and streaks of grease after it.|
05989|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0056.wav|||Arrange the rolls in regular rows in the pan about a quarter of an inch apart.|
05990|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0057.wav|||Cover with a cloth and set nearer the fire than you dared trust the dough, and let them rise for an hour.|
05991|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0058.wav|||Peep under the cloth two or three times to see whether they rise evenly, and turn the pan around once that all may be equally exposed to the heat.|
05992|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0059.wav|||When the time is up and the rolls are puffy and promising, set them in a pretty quick oven and bake half an hour,|
05993|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0060.wav|||turning the pan once in this time, and covering with clean -- never printed -- paper, should they brown too fast.|
05994|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0061.wav|||Break the rolls apart from one another and eat warm. They are also good cold, and if the directions be followed implicitly, very good always.|

06012|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0079.wav|||drill several finger-holes in it and fill them with the melted butter, the dissolved soda and the beaten yolk of egg.|

06015|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0082.wav|||Roll out into a sheet half an inch thick with a floured rolling-pin; cut into round cakes, set these closely together in a well-greased pan;|
