06041|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ020-0108.wav|||Other things besides rising dough get on quite as well without your standing by to watch them.|
06042|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0001.wav|||The Fireside Chats of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, by Franklin D Roosevelt, Section six.|
06043|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0002.wav|||September thirty, nineteen thirty-four.|
06044|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0003.wav|||Three months have passed since I talked with you shortly after the adjournment of the Congress.|
06045|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0004.wav|||Tonight I continue that report, though, because of the shortness of time, I must defer a number of subjects to a later date.|
06046|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0005.wav|||Recently the most notable public questions that have concerned us all|
06047|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0006.wav|||have had to do with industry and labor and with respect to these, certain developments have taken place which I consider of importance.|
06048|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0007.wav|||I am happy to report that after years of uncertainty, culminating in the collapse of the spring of nineteen thirty-three,|
06049|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0008.wav|||we are bringing order out of the old chaos|
06050|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0009.wav|||with a greater certainty of the employment of labor at a reasonable wage and of more business at a fair profit.|
06051|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0010.wav|||These governmental and industrial developments hold promise of new achievements for the nation.|
06052|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0011.wav|||Men may differ as to the particular form of governmental activity|
06053|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0012.wav|||with respect to industry and business, but nearly all are agreed that private enterprise in times such as these|
06054|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0014.wav|||but also our processes of civilization.|
06055|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0015.wav|||The underlying necessity for such activity|
06056|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0016.wav|||is indeed as strong now as it was years ago when Elihu Root said the following very significant words:|
06057|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0017.wav|||Instead of the give and take of free individual contract,|
06058|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0018.wav|||the tremendous power of organization has combined great aggregations of capital in enormous industrial establishments|
06059|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0019.wav|||working through vast agencies of commerce and employing great masses of men in movements of production|
06060|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0020.wav|||and transportation and trade, so great in the mass that each individual concerned in them is quite helpless by himself.|
06061|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0021.wav|||The relations between the employer and the employed, between the owners of aggregated capital and the units of organized labor,|
06062|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0022.wav|||between the small producer, the small trader, the consumer,|
06063|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0023.wav|||and the great transporting and manufacturing and distributing agencies,|
06064|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0024.wav|||all present new questions for the solution of which the old reliance upon the free action of individual wills appears quite inadequate.|
06065|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0025.wav|||And in many directions, the intervention of that organized control which we call government|
06066|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0026.wav|||seems necessary to produce the same result of justice and right conduct|
06067|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0027.wav|||which obtained through the attrition of individuals before the new conditions arose.|
06068|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0028.wav|||It was in this spirit thus described by Secretary Root|
06069|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0029.wav|||that we approached our task of reviving private enterprise in March, nineteen thirty-three.|
06070|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0030.wav|||Our first problem was, of course, the banking situation because, as you know, the banks had collapsed.|
06071|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0031.wav|||Some banks could not be saved but the great majority of them, either through their own resources or with government aid,|
06072|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0032.wav|||have been restored to complete public confidence.|
06073|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0033.wav|||This has given safety to millions of depositors in these banks.|
06074|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0034.wav|||Closely following this great constructive effort we have, through various federal agencies,|
06075|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0035.wav|||saved debtors and creditors alike in many other fields of enterprise, such as loans on farm mortgages and home mortgages;|
06076|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0036.wav|||loans to the railroads and insurance companies and, finally, help for home owners and industry itself.|
06077|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0037.wav|||In all of these efforts the government has come to the assistance of business|
06078|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0038.wav|||and with the full expectation that the money used to assist these enterprises will eventually be repaid.|
06079|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0039.wav|||I believe it will be.|
06080|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0040.wav|||The second step we have taken in the restoration of normal business enterprise|
06081|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0041.wav|||has been to clean up thoroughly unwholesome conditions in the field of investment.|
06082|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0042.wav|||In this we have had assistance from many bankers and businessmen,|
06083|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0043.wav|||most of whom recognize the past evils in the banking system, in the sale of securities, in the deliberate encouragement of stock gambling,|
06084|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0044.wav|||in the sale of unsound mortgages and in many other ways in which the public lost billions of dollars.|
06085|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0045.wav|||They saw that without changes in the policies and methods of investment|
06086|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0046.wav|||there could be no recovery of public confidence in the security of savings.|
06087|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0047.wav|||The country now enjoys the safety of bank savings under the new banking laws,|
06088|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0048.wav|||the careful checking of new securities under the Securities Act|
06089|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0049.wav|||and the curtailment of rank stock speculation through the Securities Exchange Act.|
06090|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0050.wav|||I sincerely hope that as a result|
06091|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0051.wav|||people will be discouraged in unhappy efforts to get rich quick by speculating in securities.|
06092|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0052.wav|||The average person almost always loses.|

06094|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0054.wav|||that the way to wealth is through work.|
06095|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0055.wav|||In meeting the problems of industrial recovery the chief agency of the government has been the National Recovery Administration.|
06096|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0056.wav|||Under its guidance, trades and industries covering over ninety percent of all industrial employees|

06100|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0060.wav|||Minimum wages have been established and other wages adjusted toward a rising standard of living.|
06101|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0061.wav|||The emergency purpose of the N.R.A. was to put men to work and since its creation more than four million persons have been reemployed,|
06102|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0062.wav|||in great part through the cooperation of American business brought about under the codes.|
06103|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0063.wav|||Benefits of the Industrial Recovery Program have come,|
06104|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0064.wav|||not only to labor in the form of new jobs, in relief from overwork and in relief from underpay,|
06105|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0065.wav|||but also to the owners and managers of industry because,|
06106|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0066.wav|||together with a great increase in the payrolls, there has come a substantial rise in the total of industrial profits|
06107|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0067.wav|||a rise from a deficit figure in the first quarter of nineteen thirty-three|
06108|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0068.wav|||to a level of sustained profits within one year from the inauguration of N.R.A.|
06109|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0069.wav|||Now it should not be expected that even employed labor and capital would be completely satisfied with present conditions.|
06110|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0070.wav|||Employed workers have not by any means all enjoyed a return to the earnings of prosperous times,|
06111|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0071.wav|||although millions of hitherto underprivileged workers are today far better paid than ever before.|
06112|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0072.wav|||Also, billions of dollars of invested capital have today a greater security of present and future earning power than before.|

06115|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0075.wav|||But it is an undeniable fact that the restoration of other billions of sound investments to a reasonable earning power|
06116|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0076.wav|||could not be brought about in one year.|
06117|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0077.wav|||There is no magic formula,|

06122|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0082.wav|||lines which as I have so often made clear, are in complete accord with the underlying principles of orderly popular government|
06123|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0083.wav|||which Americans have demanded since the white man first came to these shores.|
06124|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0084.wav|||We count, in the future as in the past, on the driving power of individual initiative|

06127|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0087.wav|||We have the right to expect that this driving power will be given patriotically and whole-heartedly to our nation.|
06128|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0088.wav|||We have passed through the formative period of code making in the National Recovery Administration|

06130|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0090.wav|||suited to the needs of the next phase, which is, in turn, a period of preparation for legislation which will determine its permanent form.|
06131|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0091.wav|||In this recent reorganization we have recognized three distinct functions:|
06132|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0092.wav|||first, the legislative or policy making function;|

06134|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0094.wav|||consumer complaints and the settlement of disputes between employers and employees and between one employer and another.|
06135|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0095.wav|||We are now prepared to move into this second phase, on the basis of our experience in the first phase|

06139|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0099.wav|||in order that the functions of N.R.A. which have proved their worth may be made a part of the permanent machinery of government.|

06141|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0101.wav|||gave businessmen the opportunity they had sought for years to improve business conditions through what has been called self-government in industry.|

06153|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0113.wav|||or whether their effect may have been to prevent that volume of production which would make possible lower prices and increased employment.|

06155|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0115.wav|||we have reached into the heart of the problem which is to provide such annual earnings for the lowest paid worker as will meet his minimum needs.|

06163|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0123.wav|||When the businessmen of the country were demanding the right to organize themselves adequately to promote their legitimate interests;|
06164|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0124.wav|||when the farmers were demanding legislation which would give them opportunities and incentives to organize themselves for a common advance,|

06174|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0134.wav|||It is time that we made a clean-cut effort to bring about that united action of management and labor,|

06184|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0144.wav|||in order to seek their cooperation in establishing what I may describe as a specific trial period of industrial peace.|

06186|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0146.wav|||I shall seek assurances of the making and maintenance of agreements, which can be mutually relied upon,|
06187|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0147.wav|||under which wages, hours and working conditions|
06188|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0148.wav|||may be determined and any later adjustments shall be made either by agreement or, in case of disagreement,|

06190|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0150.wav|||I shall not ask either employers or employees permanently to lay aside the weapons common to industrial war.|
06191|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0151.wav|||But I shall ask both groups to give a fair trial to peaceful methods of adjusting their conflicts of opinion and interest,|

06239|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0199.wav|||In our efforts for recovery|

06244|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0204.wav|||of regulating only to meet concrete needs -- a practice of courageous recognition of change.|

06246|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0206.wav|||whatever they need to have done but cannot do at all or cannot do so well for themselves in their separate and individual capacities."|
06247|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ021-0207.wav|||I am not for a return to that definition of liberty under which for many years a free people were being gradually regimented|

06293|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0043.wav|||I shall not confuse my discussion by a multitude of figures. So many figures are quoted to prove so many things.|

06296|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0046.wav|||It is true that while business and industry are definitely better our relief rolls are still too large.|

06300|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0050.wav|||and every day that passes offers more chances to work for those who want to work.|
06301|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0051.wav|||In spite of the fact that unemployment remains a serious problem|

06304|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0054.wav|||The first is to make provisions intended to relieve, to minimize, and to prevent future unemployment;|
06305|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0055.wav|||the second is to establish the practical means to help those who are unemployed in this present emergency.|
06306|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0056.wav|||Our social security legislation is an attempt to answer the first of these questions; our Works Relief program, the second.|

06308|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0058.wav|||While our present and projected expenditures for work relief are wholly within the reasonable limits of our national credit resources,|
06309|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0059.wav|||it is obvious that we cannot continue to create governmental deficits for that purpose year after year.|

06328|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0078.wav|||one. The projects should be useful.|

06330|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0080.wav|||Projects will be sought which promise ultimate return to the federal treasury of a considerable proportion of the costs.|
06331|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0081.wav|||Funds allotted for each project should be actually and promptly spent and not held over until later years.|
06332|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0082.wav|||In all cases projects must be of a character to give employment to those on the relief rolls.|

06398|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0148.wav|||to enforce minimum wages, to prevent excessive hours,|
06399|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0149.wav|||to safeguard, define and enforce collective bargaining, and, while retaining fair competition,|
06400|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0150.wav|||to eliminate so far as humanly possible, the kinds of unfair practices by selfish minorities which unfortunately|
06401|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0151.wav|||did more than anything else to bring about the recent collapse of industries.|
06402|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0152.wav|||There is likewise pending before the Congress|
06403|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0153.wav|||legislation to provide for the elimination of unnecessary holding companies in the public utility field.|
06404|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0154.wav|||I consider this legislation a positive recovery measure.|
06405|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0155.wav|||Power production in this country is virtually back to the nineteen twenty-nine peak.|
06406|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0156.wav|||The operating companies in the gas and electric utility field are by and large in good condition, but|
06407|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0157.wav|||under holding company domination the utility industry has long been hopelessly at war within itself and with public sentiment.|
06408|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0158.wav|||By far the greater part of the general decline in utility securities had occurred before I was inaugurated.|
06409|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0159.wav|||The absentee management of unnecessary holding company control|
06410|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0160.wav|||has lost touch with, and has lost the sympathy of, the communities it pretends to serve.|
06411|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0161.wav|||Even more significantly it has given the country as a whole an uneasy apprehension of overconcentrated economic power.|
06412|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0162.wav|||A business that loses the confidence of its customers and the goodwill of the public cannot long continue to be a good risk for the investor.|
06413|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0163.wav|||This legislation will serve the investor by ending the conditions which have caused that lack of confidence and goodwill.|
06414|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0164.wav|||It will put the public utility operating industry on a sound basis for the future,|
06415|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0165.wav|||both in its public relations and in its internal relations.|
06416|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0166.wav|||This legislation will not only in the long run result in providing lower electric and gas rates to the consumer,|
06417|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0167.wav|||but it will protect the actual value and earning power of properties now owned by thousands of investors|
06418|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0168.wav|||who have little protection under the old laws against what used to be called frenzied finance.|
06419|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0169.wav|||It will not destroy values.|
06420|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0170.wav|||Not only business recovery, but the general economic recovery of the nation will be greatly stimulated by the enactment of legislation|
06421|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0171.wav|||designed to improve the status of our transportation agencies.|
06422|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0172.wav|||There is need for legislation providing for the regulation of interstate transportation by buses and trucks,|
06423|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0173.wav|||for the regulation of transportation by water, for the strengthening of our Merchant Marine and Air Transport,|
06424|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0174.wav|||for the strengthening of the Interstate Commerce Commission to enable it to carry out a rounded conception of the national transportation system|
06425|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0175.wav|||in which the benefits of private ownership are retained while the public stake in these important services is protected by the public's government.|
06426|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0176.wav|||Finally, the reestablishment of public confidence in the banks of the nation|
06427|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0177.wav|||is one of the most hopeful results of our efforts as a Nation to reestablish public confidence in private banking.|
06428|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0178.wav|||We all know that private banking actually exists by virtue of the permission of and regulation by the people as a whole,|
06429|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0179.wav|||speaking through their government.|
06430|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0180.wav|||Wise public policy, however, requires not only that banking be safe|
06431|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0181.wav|||but that its resources be most fully utilized in the economic life of the country|
06432|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0182.wav|||To this end it was decided more than twenty years ago|
06433|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0183.wav|||that the government should assume the responsibility of providing a means by which the credit of the nation might be controlled,|
06434|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0184.wav|||not by a few private banking institutions, but by a body with public prestige and authority.|
06435|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0185.wav|||The answer to this demand was the Federal Reserve System.|
06436|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0186.wav|||Twenty years of experience with this system have justified the efforts made to create it,|
06437|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0187.wav|||but these twenty years have shown by experience definite possibilities for improvement.|
06438|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0188.wav|||Certain proposals made to amend the Federal Reserve Act deserve prompt and favorable action by the Congress.|
06439|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0189.wav|||They are a minimum of wise readjustments of our Federal Reserve System in the light of past experience and present needs.|
06440|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0190.wav|||These measures I have mentioned are, in large part, the program which under my constitutional duty I have recommended to the Congress.|
06441|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0191.wav|||They are essential factors in a rounded program for national recovery.|
06442|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0192.wav|||They contemplate the enrichment of our national life|
06443|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0193.wav|||by a sound and rational ordering of its various elements and wise provisions for the protection of the weak against the strong.|
06444|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0194.wav|||Never since my inauguration in March, nineteen thirty-three, have I felt so unmistakably the atmosphere of recovery.|
06445|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0195.wav|||But it is more than the recovery of the material basis of our individual lives.|
06446|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0196.wav|||It is the recovery of confidence in our democratic processes and institutions.|
06447|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0197.wav|||We have survived all of the arduous burdens and the threatening dangers of a great economic calamity.|
06448|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0198.wav|||We have in the darkest moments of our national trials retained our faith in our own ability to master our destiny.|
06449|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0199.wav|||Fear is vanishing and confidence is growing on every side,|
06450|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0200.wav|||renewed faith in the vast possibilities of human beings to improve their material and spiritual status|
06451|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0201.wav|||through the instrumentality of the democratic form of government.|
06452|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0202.wav|||That faith is receiving its just reward.|
06453|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ022-0203.wav|||For that we can be thankful to the God who watches over America.|
06454|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0001.wav|||The Fireside Chats of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, by Franklin D Roosevelt, Section nine.|
06455|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0002.wav|||March nine, nineteen thirty-seven. Part one.|
06456|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0003.wav|||Last Thursday I described in detail certain economic problems which everyone admits now face the nation.|
06457|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0004.wav|||For the many messages which have come to me after that speech, and which it is physically impossible to answer individually,|
06458|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0005.wav|||I take this means of saying "thank you."|
06459|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0006.wav|||Tonight, sitting at my desk in the White House, I make my first radio report to the people in my second term of office.|
06460|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0007.wav|||I am reminded of that evening in March, four years ago, when I made my first radio report to you.|
06461|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0008.wav|||We were then in the midst of the great banking crisis.|
06462|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0009.wav|||Soon after, with the authority of the Congress,|
06463|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0010.wav|||we asked the nation to turn over all of its privately held gold, dollar for dollar, to the government of the United States.|
06464|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0011.wav|||Today's recovery proves how right that policy was.|
06465|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0012.wav|||But when, almost two years later, it came before the Supreme Court its constitutionality was upheld only by a five-to-four vote.|
06466|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0013.wav|||The change of one vote would have thrown all the affairs of this great Nation back into hopeless chaos.|
06467|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0014.wav|||In effect, four Justices ruled that the right under a private contract|
06468|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0015.wav|||to exact a pound of flesh was more sacred than the main objectives of the Constitution to establish an enduring Nation.|
06469|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0016.wav|||In nineteen thirty-three you and I knew that we must never let our economic system get completely out of joint again|
06470|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0017.wav|||that we could not afford to take the risk of another great depression.|
06471|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0018.wav|||We also became convinced that the only way to avoid a repetition of those dark days was to have a government with power to prevent|
06472|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0019.wav|||and to cure the abuses and the inequalities which had thrown that system out of joint.|
06473|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0020.wav|||We then began a program of remedying those abuses and inequalities -- to give balance and stability to our economic system|
06474|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0021.wav|||to make it bomb-proof against the causes of nineteen twenty-nine.|
06475|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0022.wav|||Today we are only part-way through that program|
06476|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0023.wav|||and recovery is speeding up to a point where the dangers of nineteen twenty-nine are again becoming possible,|
06477|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0024.wav|||not this week or month perhaps, but within a year or two.|
06478|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0025.wav|||National laws are needed to complete that program.|
06479|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0026.wav|||Individual or local or state effort alone cannot protect us in nineteen thirty-seven any better than ten years ago.|
06480|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0027.wav|||It will take time -- and plenty of time -- to work out our remedies administratively even after legislation is passed.|
06481|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0028.wav|||To complete our program of protection in time, therefore,|
06482|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0029.wav|||we cannot delay one moment in making certain that our national government has power to carry through.|
06483|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0030.wav|||Four years ago action did not come until the eleventh hour.|
06484|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0031.wav|||It was almost too late.|
06485|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0032.wav|||If we learned anything from the depression|
06486|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0033.wav|||we will not allow ourselves to run around in new circles of futile discussion and debate, always postponing the day of decision.|
06487|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0034.wav|||The American people have learned from the depression.|
06488|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0035.wav|||For in the last three national elections|
06489|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0036.wav|||an overwhelming majority of them voted a mandate that the Congress and the President begin the task of providing that protection|
06490|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0037.wav|||not after long years of debate, but now.|
06491|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0038.wav|||The courts, however, have cast doubts on the ability of the elected Congress to protect us against catastrophe|
06492|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0039.wav|||by meeting squarely our modern social and economic conditions.|
06493|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0040.wav|||We are at a crisis in our ability to proceed with that protection.|
06494|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0041.wav|||It is a quiet crisis. There are no lines of depositors outside closed banks.|
06495|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0042.wav|||But to the far-sighted it is far-reaching in its possibilities of injury to America.|
06496|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0043.wav|||I want to talk with you very simply about the need for present action in this crisis|
06497|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0044.wav|||the need to meet the unanswered challenge of one-third of a Nation ill-nourished, ill-clad, ill-housed.|
06498|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0045.wav|||Last Thursday I described the American form of government as a three horse team provided by the Constitution to the American people|
06499|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0046.wav|||so that their field might be plowed.|
06500|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0047.wav|||The three horses are, of course, the three branches of government -- the Congress, the Executive and the courts.|
06501|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0048.wav|||Two of the horses are pulling in unison today; the third is not.|
06502|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0049.wav|||Those who have intimated that the President of the United States is trying to drive that team|
06503|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0050.wav|||overlook the simple fact that the President, as Chief Executive, is himself one of the three horses.|
06504|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0051.wav|||It is the American people themselves who are in the driver's seat.|
06505|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0052.wav|||It is the American people themselves who want the furrow plowed.|
06506|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0053.wav|||It is the American people themselves who expect the third horse to pull in unison with the other two.|
06507|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0054.wav|||I hope that you have re-read the Constitution of the United States in these past few weeks.|
06508|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0055.wav|||Like the Bible, it ought to be read again and again.|
06509|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0056.wav|||It is an easy document to understand when you remember that it was called into being|
06510|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0057.wav|||because the Articles of Confederation under which the original thirteen States tried to operate after the Revolution|
06511|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0058.wav|||showed the need of a national government with power enough to handle national problems.|
06512|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0059.wav|||In its Preamble, the Constitution states that it was intended to form a more perfect Union and promote the general welfare;|
06513|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0060.wav|||and the powers given to the Congress to carry out those purposes can be best described by saying|
06514|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0061.wav|||that they were all the powers needed to meet each and every problem which then had a national character|
06515|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0062.wav|||and which could not be met by merely local action.|
06516|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0063.wav|||But the framers went further.|
06517|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0064.wav|||Having in mind that in succeeding generations many other problems then undreamed of would become national problems|
06518|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0065.wav|||they gave to the Congress the ample broad powers "to levy taxes|
06519|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0066.wav|||and provide for the common defense and general welfare of the United States.|
06520|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0067.wav|||That, my friends, is what I honestly believe|
06521|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0068.wav|||to have been the clear and underlying purpose of the patriots who wrote a federal constitution to create a national government|
06522|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0069.wav|||with national power, intended as they said, "to form a more perfect union|
06523|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0070.wav|||for ourselves and our posterity.|
06524|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0071.wav|||For nearly twenty years there was no conflict between the Congress and the Court.|
06525|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0072.wav|||Congress passed a statute which, in eighteen oh three, the Court said violated an express provision of the Constitution.|
06526|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0073.wav|||The Court claimed the power to declare it unconstitutional and did so declare it.|
06527|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0074.wav|||But a little later the Court itself admitted|
06528|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0075.wav|||that it was an extraordinary power to exercise and through Mr. Justice Washington laid down this limitation upon it:|
06529|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0076.wav|||It is but a decent respect due to the wisdom, the integrity and the patriotism of the legislative body,|
06530|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0077.wav|||by which any law is passed,|
06531|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0078.wav|||to presume in favor of its validity until its violation of the Constitution is proved beyond all reasonable doubt.|
06532|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0079.wav|||But since the rise of the modern movement for social and economic progress through legislation,|
06533|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0080.wav|||the Court has more and more often and more and more boldly|
06534|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0081.wav|||asserted a power to veto laws passed by the Congress and state legislatures in complete disregard of this original limitation.|
06535|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0082.wav|||In the last four years the sound rule of giving statutes the benefit of all reasonable doubt has been cast aside.|
06536|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0083.wav|||The Court has been acting not as a judicial body, but as a policy-making body.|
06537|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0084.wav|||When the Congress has sought to stabilize national agriculture, to improve the conditions of labor,|
06538|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0085.wav|||to safeguard business against unfair competition,|
06539|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0086.wav|||to protect our national resources, and in many other ways, to serve our clearly national needs,|
06540|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0087.wav|||the majority of the Court has been assuming the power to pass on the wisdom of these acts of the Congress|
06541|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0088.wav|||and to approve or disapprove the public policy written into these laws.|
06542|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0089.wav|||That is not only my accusation.|
06543|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0090.wav|||It is the accusation of most distinguished justices of the present Supreme Court.|
06544|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0091.wav|||I have not the time to quote to you all the language used by dissenting justices in many of these cases.|
06545|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0092.wav|||But in the case holding the Railroad Retirement Act unconstitutional, for instance,|
06546|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0093.wav|||Chief Justice Hughes said in a dissenting opinion that the majority opinion was "a departure from sound principles,"|
06547|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0094.wav|||and placed "an unwarranted limitation upon the commerce clause."|
06548|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0095.wav|||And three other justices agreed with him.|
06549|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0096.wav|||In the case of holding the A.A.A. unconstitutional,|
06550|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0097.wav|||Justice Stone said of the majority opinion that it was a "tortured construction of the Constitution."|
06551|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0098.wav|||And two other justices agreed with him.|
06552|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0099.wav|||In the case holding the New York Minimum Wage Law unconstitutional, Justice Stone said|
06553|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0100.wav|||that the majority were actually reading into the Constitution their own "personal economic predilections," and that|
06554|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0101.wav|||if the legislative power is not left free to choose the methods of solving the problems of poverty,|
06555|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0102.wav|||subsistence, and health of large numbers in the community, then|
06556|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0103.wav|||government is to be rendered impotent.|
06557|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0104.wav|||And two other justices agreed with him.|
06558|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0105.wav|||In the face of these dissenting opinions, there is no basis for the claim made by some members of the Court|
06559|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0106.wav|||that something in the Constitution has compelled them regretfully to thwart the will of the people.|
06560|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0107.wav|||In the face of such dissenting opinions, it is perfectly clear that, as Chief Justice Hughes has said,|
06561|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0108.wav|||We are under a Constitution, but the Constitution is what the judges say it is.|
06562|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0109.wav|||The Court in addition to the proper use of its judicial functions has improperly set itself up as a third house of the Congress|
06563|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0110.wav|||a super-legislature, as one of the justices has called it|
06564|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0111.wav|||reading into the Constitution words and implications which are not there, and which were never intended to be there.|
06565|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0112.wav|||We have, therefore,|
06566|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0113.wav|||reached the point as a nation where we must take action to save the Constitution from the Court and the Court from itself.|
06567|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0114.wav|||We must find a way to take an appeal from the Supreme Court to the Constitution itself.|
06568|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0115.wav|||We want a Supreme Court which will do justice under the Constitution -- not over it.|
06569|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0116.wav|||In our courts we want a government of laws and not of men.|
06570|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0117.wav|||I want -- as all Americans want -- an independent judiciary as proposed by the framers of the Constitution.|
06571|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0118.wav|||That means a Supreme Court that will enforce the Constitution as written|
06572|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0119.wav|||that will refuse to amend the Constitution by the arbitrary exercise of judicial power -- amended by judicial say-so.|
06573|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0120.wav|||It does not mean a judiciary so independent that it can deny the existence of facts which are universally recognized.|
06574|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0121.wav|||How then could we proceed to perform the mandate given us?|
06575|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0122.wav|||It was said in last year's Democratic platform,|
06576|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0123.wav|||If these problems cannot be effectively solved within the Constitution,|
06577|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0124.wav|||we shall seek such clarifying amendment as will assure the power to enact those laws,|
06578|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0125.wav|||adequately to regulate commerce, protect public health and safety, and safeguard economic security.|
06579|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0126.wav|||In other words, we said we would seek an amendment only if every other possible means by legislation were to fail.|
06580|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0127.wav|||When I commenced to review the situation with the problem squarely before me,|
06581|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0128.wav|||I came by a process of elimination to the conclusion that, short of amendments,|
06582|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0129.wav|||the only method which was clearly constitutional, and would at the same time carry out other much needed reforms,|
06583|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0130.wav|||was to infuse new blood into all our courts.|
06584|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0131.wav|||We must have men worthy and equipped to carry out impartial justice.|
06585|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0132.wav|||But, at the same time, we must have judges who will bring to the courts a present-day sense of the Constitution|
06586|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0133.wav|||judges who will retain in the courts the judicial functions of a court,|
06587|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0134.wav|||and reject the legislative powers which the courts have today assumed.|
06588|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0135.wav|||In forty-five out of the forty-eight states of the Union, judges are chosen not for life but for a period of years.|
06589|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0136.wav|||In many states judges must retire at the age of seventy.|
06590|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0137.wav|||Congress has provided financial security|
06591|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0138.wav|||by offering life pensions at full pay for federal judges on all courts who are willing to retire at seventy.|
06592|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0139.wav|||In the case of Supreme Court justices, that pension is twenty thousand dollars a year.|
06593|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0140.wav|||But all federal judges, once appointed,|
06594|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ023-0141.wav|||can, if they choose, hold office for life, no matter how old they may get to be.|
06595|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0001.wav|||The Fireside Chats of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, by Franklin D Roosevelt|
06596|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0002.wav|||Section ten. March nine, nineteen thirty-seven. Part two.|
06597|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0003.wav|||What is my proposal?|
06598|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0004.wav|||It is simply this: whenever a judge or justice of any federal court|
06599|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0005.wav|||has reached the age of seventy and does not avail himself of the opportunity to retire on a pension,|
06600|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0006.wav|||a new member shall be appointed by the President then in office,|
06601|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0007.wav|||with the approval, as required by the Constitution, of the Senate of the United States.|
06602|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0008.wav|||That plan has two chief purposes.|
06603|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0009.wav|||By bringing into the judicial system a steady and continuing stream of new and younger blood, I hope, first,|
06604|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0010.wav|||to make the administration of all federal justice speedier and, therefore, less costly;|
06605|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0011.wav|||secondly, to bring to the decision of social and economic problems younger men who have had personal experience and contact|
06606|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0012.wav|||with modern facts and circumstances under which average men have to live and work.|
06607|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0013.wav|||This plan will save our national Constitution from hardening of the judicial arteries.|
06608|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0014.wav|||The number of judges to be appointed would depend wholly on the decision of present judges now over seventy,|
06609|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0015.wav|||or those who would subsequently reach the age of seventy.|
06610|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0016.wav|||If, for instance, any one of the six justices of the Supreme Court now over the age of seventy should retire as provided under the plan,|
06611|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0017.wav|||no additional place would be created.|
06612|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0018.wav|||Consequently, although there never can be more than fifteen, there may be only fourteen, or thirteen, or twelve.|
06613|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0019.wav|||And there may be only nine.|
06614|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0020.wav|||There is nothing novel or radical about this idea.|
06615|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0021.wav|||It seeks to maintain the federal bench in full vigor.|
06616|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0022.wav|||It has been discussed and approved by many persons of high authority|
06617|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0023.wav|||ever since a similar proposal passed the House of Representatives in eighteen sixty-nine.|
06618|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0024.wav|||Why was the age fixed at seventy?|
06619|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0025.wav|||Because the laws of many states, the practice of the Civil Service, the regulations of the Army and Navy,|
06620|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0026.wav|||and the rules of many of our universities and of almost every great private business enterprise,|
06621|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0027.wav|||commonly fix the retirement age at seventy years or less.|
06622|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0028.wav|||The statute would apply to all the courts in the federal system.|
06623|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0029.wav|||There is general approval so far as the lower federal courts are concerned.|
06624|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0030.wav|||The plan has met opposition only so far as the Supreme Court of the United States itself is concerned.|
06625|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0031.wav|||If such a plan is good for the lower courts it certainly ought to be equally good for the highest court from which there is no appeal.|
06626|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0032.wav|||Those opposing this plan have sought to arouse prejudice and fear by crying that I am seeking to "pack" the Supreme Court|
06627|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0033.wav|||and that a baneful precedent will be established.|
06628|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0034.wav|||What do they mean by the words "packing the Court"?|
06629|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0035.wav|||Let me answer this question with a bluntness that will end all honest misunderstanding of my purposes.|
06630|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0036.wav|||If by that phrase "packing the Court" it is charged that I wish to place on the bench spineless puppets|
06631|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0037.wav|||who would disregard the law and would decide specific cases as I wished them to be decided, I make this answer:|
06632|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0038.wav|||that no President fit for his office would appoint,|
06633|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0039.wav|||and no Senate of honorable men fit for their office would confirm, that kind of appointees to the Supreme Court.|
06634|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0040.wav|||But if by that phrase the charge is made|
06635|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0041.wav|||that I would appoint and the Senate would confirm justices worthy to sit beside present members of the Court|

06638|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0044.wav|||that I will appoint justices who will act as justices and not as legislators|
06639|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0045.wav|||if the appointment of such justices can be called "packing the Courts,"|
06640|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0046.wav|||then I say that I and with me the vast majority of the American people favor doing just that thing -- now.|
06641|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0047.wav|||Is it a dangerous precedent for the Congress to change the number of the justices? The Congress has always had, and will have, that power.|

06651|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0057.wav|||Why then should we leave the fulfillment of this public policy to chance|
06652|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0058.wav|||or make independent on upon the desire or prejudice of any individual justice?|
06653|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0059.wav|||It is the clear intention of our public policy to provide for a constant flow of new and younger blood into the judiciary.|
06654|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0060.wav|||Normally every President appoints a large number of district and circuit court judges and a few members of the Supreme Court.|

06656|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0062.wav|||President Taft appointed five members and named a Chief Justice;|
06657|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0063.wav|||President Wilson, three; President Harding, four, including a Chief Justice; President Coolidge, one;|

06659|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0065.wav|||Such a succession of appointments should have provided a Court well-balanced as to age.|
06660|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0066.wav|||But chance and the disinclination of individuals to leave the Supreme bench|
06661|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0067.wav|||have now given us a Court in which five justices will be over seventy-five years of age before next June|

06663|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0069.wav|||Thus a sound public policy has been defeated.|
06664|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0070.wav|||I now propose that we establish by law an assurance against any such ill-balanced court in the future.|
06665|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0071.wav|||I propose that hereafter, when a judge reaches the age of seventy,|

06669|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0075.wav|||to be determined by chance or the personal indecision of individuals.|

06679|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0085.wav|||and to have it resume its high task of building anew on the Constitution "a system of living law."|

06681|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0087.wav|||I have thus explained to you the reasons that lie behind our efforts to secure results by legislation within the Constitution.|
06682|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0088.wav|||I hope that thereby the difficult process of constitutional amendment may be rendered unnecessary. But,|

06687|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0093.wav|||It would take months or years to get substantial agreement upon the type and language of the amendment.|
06688|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0094.wav|||It would take months and years thereafter to get a two-thirds majority in favor of that amendment in both Houses of the Congress.|
06689|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0095.wav|||Then would come the long course of ratification by three-fourths of all the states.|

06711|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0117.wav|||you will find that many of those who pretend to support you will sabotage any constructive amendment which is proposed.|
06712|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0118.wav|||Look at these strange bed-fellows of yours.|
06713|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0119.wav|||When before have you found them really at your side in your fights for progress?|
06714|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0120.wav|||And remember one thing more.|
06715|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0121.wav|||Even if an amendment were passed, and even if in the years to come it were to be ratified,|
06716|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0122.wav|||its meaning would depend upon the kind of justices who would be sitting on the Supreme Court bench.|
06717|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0123.wav|||An amendment, like the rest of the Constitution,|
06718|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0124.wav|||is what the justices say it is rather than what its framers or you might hope it is.|
06719|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0125.wav|||This proposal of mine will not infringe in the slightest upon the civil or religious liberties so dear to every American.|
06720|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0126.wav|||My record as Governor and President proves my devotion to those liberties.|
06721|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0127.wav|||You who know me can have no fear that I would tolerate the destruction by any branch of government of any part of our heritage of freedom.|
06722|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0128.wav|||The present attempt by those opposed to progress to play upon the fears of danger to personal liberty|
06723|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0129.wav|||brings again to mind that crude and cruel strategy tried by the same opposition|
06724|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0130.wav|||to frighten the workers of America in a pay-envelope propaganda against the Social Security Law.|
06725|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0131.wav|||The workers were not fooled by that propaganda then. The people of America will not be fooled by such propaganda now.|
06726|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0132.wav|||I am in favor of action through legislation:|
06727|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0133.wav|||First, because I believe that it can be passed at this session of the Congress.|
06728|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0134.wav|||Second, because it will provide a reinvigorated|
06729|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0135.wav|||liberal-minded judiciary necessary to furnish quicker and cheaper justice from bottom to top.|
06730|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0136.wav|||Third, because it will provide a series of federal courts willing to enforce the Constitution as written,|
06731|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0137.wav|||and unwilling to assert legislative powers by writing into it their own political and economic policies.|
06732|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0138.wav|||During the past half century the balance of power between the three great branches of the federal government,|
06733|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0139.wav|||has been tipped out of balance by the courts in direct contradiction of the high purposes of the framers of the Constitution.|
06734|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0140.wav|||It is my purpose to restore that balance.|
06735|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0141.wav|||You who know me will accept my solemn assurance that in a world in which democracy is under attack,|
06736|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0142.wav|||I seek to make American democracy succeed.|
06737|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ024-0143.wav|||You and I will do our part.|
06738|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0001.wav|||The Science: History of the Universe, Volume five.|
06739|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0002.wav|||Edited by Francis Rolt-Wheeler. Biology. Chapter seven. Organic Functions. Part One.|
06740|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0003.wav|||The facts dealing with the physiology of organisms, the activities associated with that which we call life|
06741|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0004.wav|||are often designated Organic Functions.|
06742|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0005.wav|||The terms animal physiology, plant physiology and human physiology are in common use and often suggest to the lay reader|
06743|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0006.wav|||that the functions or workings of the organs of plants, animals or man are quite distinct,|
06744|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0007.wav|||so much so as to require discussion in different treatises.|
06745|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0008.wav|||This is true only as a matter of detail,|
06746|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0009.wav|||for in the past fifty years it has been made evident that in general principles all living things are fundamentally similar.|
06747|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0010.wav|||One of the most important summaries of this similarity|
06748|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0011.wav|||is Huxley's famous essay, "The Border Territory Between the Animal and Vegetable Kingdoms," written in eighteen seventy-six,|
06749|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0012.wav|||extracts from which follow.|
06750|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0013.wav|||In the second edition of the "Regne Animal," published in eighteen twenty-eight,|
06751|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0014.wav|||Cuvier devotes a special section to the Division of Organized Beings into Animals and Vegetables,|
06752|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0015.wav|||in which the question is treated with that comprehensiveness of knowledge and clear critical judgment which characterize his writings|
06753|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0016.wav|||and justify biologists in regarding them as representative expressions of the most extensive, if not the profoundest, knowledge of his time.|
06754|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0017.wav|||He affirms that living beings have been subdivided from the earliest times into animated beings, which possess sense and motion,|
06755|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0018.wav|||and inanimated beings, which are devoid of these functions and simply vegetable.|
06756|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0019.wav|||Although the roots of plants direct themselves toward moisture and their leaves toward air and light,|
06757|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0020.wav|||although the parts of some plants exhibit oscillating movements without any perceptible cause and the leaves of others retract when touched,|
06758|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0021.wav|||yet none of these movements justify the ascription to plants of perception of will.|
06759|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0022.wav|||From the mobility of animals Cuvier, with his characteristic partiality for teleological reasoning,|
06760|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0023.wav|||reduces the necessity of the existence in them of an alimentary cavity, or reservoir of food,|
06761|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0024.wav|||whence their nutrition may be drawn by vessels, which are a sort of internal roots; and, in the presence of this alimentary cavity|
06762|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0025.wav|||he naturally sees the primary and the most important distinction between animals and plants,|
06763|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0026.wav|||Following out his teleological argument, Cuvier remarks that the organization of this cavity|
06764|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0027.wav|||and its appurtenances must needs vary according to the nature of the aliment and the operations which it has to undergo|
06765|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0028.wav|||before it can be converted into substances fitted for absorption,|
06766|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0029.wav|||while the atmosphere and the earth supply plants with juices ready prepared and which can be absorbed immediately.|
06767|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0030.wav|||As the animal body required to be independent of heat and of the atmosphere,|
06768|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0031.wav|||there were no means by which the motion of its fluids could be produced by internal causes.|
06769|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0032.wav|||Hence arose the second great distinctive character of animals, or the circulatory system, which is less important than the digestive,|
06770|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0033.wav|||since it was unnecessary, and therefore is absent, in the more simple animals.|
06771|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0034.wav|||Animals further needed muscles for locomotion and nerves for sensibility.|
06772|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0035.wav|||Hence, says Cuvier, it was necessary that the chemical composition of the animal body should be more complicated than that of the plant;|
06773|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0036.wav|||and it is so, inasmuch as an additional substance -- nitrogen -- enters into it as an essential element;|
06774|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0037.wav|||while in plants nitrogen is only accidentally joined with the three other fundamental constituents of organic beings|
06775|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0038.wav|||carbon, hydrogen and oxygen.|
06776|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0039.wav|||he afterward affirms that nitrogen is peculiar to animals, and herein he places the third distinction between the animal and the plant.|
06777|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0040.wav|||The soil and the atmosphere supply plants with water composed of hydrogen and oxygen|
06778|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0041.wav|||and carbonic acid containing carbon and oxygen.|
06779|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0042.wav|||They retain the hydrogen and the carbon, exhale the superfluous oxygen and absorb little or no nitrogen.|
06780|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0043.wav|||The essential character of vegetable life is the exhalation of oxygen, which is effected through the agency of light.|
06781|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0044.wav|||Animals, on the contrary, derive their nourishment either directly or indirectly from plants.|
06782|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0045.wav|||They get rid of the superfluous hydrogen and carbon and accumulate nitrogen.|
06783|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0046.wav|||The relations of plants and animals to the atmosphere are therefore inverse.|
06784|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0047.wav|||The plant withdraws water and carbonic acid from the atmosphere, the animal contributes both to it.|
06785|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0048.wav|||Respiration -- that is, the absorption of oxygen and the exhalation of carbonic acid|
06786|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0049.wav|||is the specially animal function of animals and constitutes their fourth distinctive character.|
06787|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0050.wav|||Thus wrote Cuvier in eighteen twenty-eight.|
06788|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0051.wav|||But in the fourth and fifth decades of this century|
06789|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0052.wav|||the greatest and most rapid revolution which biological science has ever undergone was effected by the application of the modern microscope|
06790|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0053.wav|||to the investigation of organic structure,|
06791|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0054.wav|||by the introduction of exact and easily manageable methods of conducting the chemical analysis of organic compounds and finally|
06792|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0055.wav|||by the employment of instruments of precision for the measurement of the physical forces which are at work in the living economy.|
06793|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0056.wav|||That the semi-fluid contents (which we now term protoplasm) of the cells of certain plants,|
06794|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0057.wav|||such as the Charae, are in constant and regular motion was made out by Bonaventura Corti a century ago;|
06795|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0058.wav|||but the fact, important as it was, fell into oblivion and had to be rediscovered by Treviranus in eighteen oh seven.|
06796|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0059.wav|||Robert Brown noted the more complex motions of the protoplasm in the cells of Tradescantia in eighteen thirty-one,|
06797|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0060.wav|||and now such movements of the living substance of plants are well known to be some of the most widely prevalent phenomena of vegetable life.|
06798|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0061.wav|||Agardh and other of the botanists of Cuvier's generation who occupied themselves with the lower plants had observed that,|
06799|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0062.wav|||under particular circumstances, the contents of the cells of certain water-weeds were set free and moved about with considerable velocity|
06800|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0063.wav|||and with all the appearances of spontaneity as locomotive bodies,|
06801|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0064.wav|||which, from their similarity to animals of simple organization, were called "zoospores."|
06802|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0065.wav|||Even as late as eighteen forty-five, however, a botanist of Schleiden's eminence dealt very skeptically with these statements,|
06803|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0066.wav|||and his skepticism was the more justified since Ehrenberg in his elaborate and comprehensive work on the infusoria,|
06804|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0067.wav|||had declared the greater number of what are now recognized as locomotive plants to be animals.|
06805|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0068.wav|||At the present day, writes Huxley,|
06806|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0069.wav|||innumerable plants and free plant cells are known to pass the whole or part of their lives in an actively locomotive condition,|
06807|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0070.wav|||in nowise distinguishable from that of one of the simpler animals, and|
06808|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0071.wav|||while in this condition their movements are, to all appearances, as spontaneous -- as much the product of volition -- as those of such animals.|
06809|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0072.wav|||Hence the teleological argument for Cuvier's first diagnostic character|
06810|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0073.wav|||the presence in animals of an alimentary cavity, or internal pocket, in which they can carry about their nutriment|
06811|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0074.wav|||has broken down, so far, at least, as his mode of stating it goes. And|
06812|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0075.wav|||with the advance of microscopic anatomy, the universality of the fact itself among animals has ceased to be predicable.|
06813|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0076.wav|||Many animals of even complex structure which live parasitically within others are wholly devoid of an alimentary cavity.|
06814|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0077.wav|||Their food is provided for them,|
06815|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0078.wav|||not only ready cooked but ready digested, and the alimentary canal, become superfluous, has disappeared, and, again,|
06816|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0079.wav|||the males of most Rotifers have no digestive apparatus.|
06817|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0080.wav|||Finally amid the lowest forms of animal life the speck of gelatinous protoplasm, which constitutes the whole body,|
06818|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0081.wav|||has no permanent digestive cavity or mouth, but takes in its food anywhere and digests, so to speak, all over its body.|
06819|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0082.wav|||But although Cuvier's leading diagnosis of the animal from the plant will not stand a strict test,|
06820|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0083.wav|||it remains one of the most constant of the distinctive characters of animals.|
06821|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0084.wav|||And if we substitute for the possession of an alimentary cavity the power of taking solid nutriment into the body and there digesting it,|
06822|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0085.wav|||the definition so changed will cover all animals, except certain parasites,|
06823|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0086.wav|||and the few and exceptional cases of non-parasitic animals which do not feed at all.|
06824|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0087.wav|||On the other hand, the definition thus amended will exclude all ordinary vegetable organisms.|
06825|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0088.wav|||Cuvier himself practically gives up his second distinctive mark when he admits that it is wanting in the simpler animals.|
06826|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0089.wav|||The third distinction is based on a completely erroneous conception of the chemical differences|
06827|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0090.wav|||and resemblances between the constituents of animal and vegetable organisms, for which Cuvier is not responsible,|
06828|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0091.wav|||as it was current among contemporary chemists.|
06829|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0092.wav|||It is now established that nitrogen is as essential a constituent of vegetable as of animal living matter|
06830|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0093.wav|||and that the latter is, chemically speaking, just as complicated as the former.|
06831|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0094.wav|||Starchy substances, cellulose and sugar,|
06832|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0095.wav|||once supposed to be exclusively confined to plants, are now known to be regular and normal products of animals.|
06833|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0096.wav|||Amylaceous and saccharine substances are largely manufactured, even by the highest animals.|
06834|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0097.wav|||Cellulose is widespread as a constituent of the skeletons of the lower animals|
06835|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0098.wav|||and it is probable that amyloid substances are universally present in the animal organism, though not in the precise form of starch.|
06836|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0099.wav|||Moreover, although it remains true that there is an inverse relation between the green plant in sunshine and the animal,|
06837|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0100.wav|||in so far as under these circumstances the green plant|
06838|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0101.wav|||decomposes carbonic acid and exhales oxygen while the animal absorbs oxygen and exhales carbonic acid,|
06839|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0102.wav|||yet the exact researches of the modern chemical investigators of the physiological processes of plants have clearly demonstrated the fallacy|
06840|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0103.wav|||of attempting to draw any general distinction between animals and vegetables on this ground. In fact, the difference vanishes with the sunshine,|
06841|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0104.wav|||even in the case of the green plant, which in the dark absorbs oxygen and gives out carbonic acid like any animal.|
06842|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0105.wav|||On the other hand, those plants, such as the fungi,|
06843|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0106.wav|||which contain no chlorophyll and are not green, are always, so far as respiration is concerned, in the exact position of animals.|
06844|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0107.wav|||They absorb oxygen and give out carbonic acid.|
06845|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0108.wav|||Thus, by the progress of knowledge, Cuvier's fourth distinction between the animal and the plant|
06846|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0109.wav|||has been as completely invalidated as the third and second, and even the first can be retained only in a modified form|
06847|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0110.wav|||and subject to exceptions.|
06848|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0111.wav|||But has the advance of biology simply tended to break down old distinctions without establishing new ones?|
06849|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0112.wav|||With a qualification, to be considered presently, the answer to this question is undoubtedly in the affirmative.|
06850|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0113.wav|||The famous researches of Schwann and Schleiden in eighteen thirty-seven and the following years|
06851|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0114.wav|||founded the modern science of histology or that branch of anatomy which deals with the ultimate visible structure of organisms as revealed by the microscope,|
06852|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0115.wav|||and from that day to this the rapid improvement of methods of investigation and the energy of a host of accurate observers|
06853|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0116.wav|||have given greater and greater breadth and firmness to Schwann's great generalization|
06854|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0117.wav|||that a fundamental unity of structure obtains in animals and plants,|
06855|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0118.wav|||and that, however diverse may be the fabrics or tissues of which their bodies are composed, all these varied structures result|
06856|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0119.wav|||from the metamorphosis of morphological units (termed cells in a more general sense than that in which the word "cells" was at first employed),|
06857|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0120.wav|||which are not only similar in animals and in plants respectively,|
06858|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0121.wav|||but present a close resemblance when those of animals and those of plants are compared together.|
06859|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0122.wav|||The contractility which is the fundamental condition of locomotion," continues Huxley,|
06860|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0123.wav|||has not only been discovered to exist far more widely among plants than was formerly imagined,|
06861|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0124.wav|||but in the plants the act of contraction has been found to be accompanied,|
06862|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0125.wav|||as Dr. Burdon Sanderson's interesting investigations have shown, by a disturbance of the electrical state of the contractile substance|
06863|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0126.wav|||comparable to that which was found by Du Bois Reymond to be a concomitant of the activity of ordinary muscle in animals. Again,|
06864|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0127.wav|||I know of no test by which the reaction of the leaves of the Sundew and of other plants to stimuli, so fully and carefully studied by Mr. Darwin,|
06865|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0128.wav|||can be distinguished from those acts of contraction following upon stimuli, which are called "reflex" in animals.|
06866|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0129.wav|||On each lobe of the bi-lobed leaf of Venus flytrap are three delicate filaments which stand out at right angles from the surface of the leaf.|
06867|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0130.wav|||Touch one of them with the end of a fine human hair|
06868|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0131.wav|||and the lobes of the leaf instantly close together in virtue of an act of contraction of part of their substance,|
06869|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0132.wav|||just as the body of a snail contracts into its shell when one of its "horns" is irritated.|
06870|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0133.wav|||The reflex action of the snail is the result of the presence of a nervous system in the animal.|
06871|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0134.wav|||A molecular change takes place in the nerve of the tentacle,|
06872|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0135.wav|||is propagated to the muscles by which the body is retracted, and causing them to contract, the act of retraction is brought about.|
06873|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0136.wav|||Of course the similarity of the acts does not necessarily involve the conclusion that the mechanism by which they are effected is the same|
06874|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0137.wav|||but it suggests a suspicion of their identity which needs careful testing.|
06875|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0138.wav|||The results of inquiries into the structure of the nervous system of animals|
06876|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0139.wav|||converge toward the conclusion that the nerve fibers, which have been regarded as ultimate elements of nervous tissue,|
06877|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0140.wav|||are not such, but are simply the visible aggregations of vastly more attenuated filaments,|
