06878|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0141.wav|||the diameter of which dwindles down to the limits of our present microscopic vision,|
06879|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0142.wav|||greatly as these have been extended by modern improvements of the microscope, and that a nerve is, in its essence,|
06880|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0143.wav|||nothing but a linear tract of specially modified protoplasm between two points of an organism|
06881|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0144.wav|||one of which is able to affect the other by means of the communication so established.|
06882|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0145.wav|||Hence it is conceivable that even the simplest living being may possess a nervous system.|
06883|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0146.wav|||And the question whether plants are provided with a nervous system or not thus acquires a new aspect and presents the histologist and physiologist|
06884|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0147.wav|||with a problem of extreme difficulty, which must be attacked from a new point of view and by the aid of methods which have yet to be invented.|
06885|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0148.wav|||Thus it must be admitted, he says again, "that plants may be contractile and locomotive;|
06886|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0149.wav|||that, while locomotive, their movements may have as much appearance of spontaneity as those of the lowest animals,|
06887|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0150.wav|||and that many exhibit actions comparable to those which are brought about by the agency of a nervous system in animals.|
06888|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0151.wav|||And it must be allowed to be possible that further research may reveal the existence of something comparable to a nervous system in plants.|
06889|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0152.wav|||So that I know not where we can hope to find any absolute distinction between animals and plants, unless we return to their mode of nutrition|
06890|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0153.wav|||and inquire whether certain differences of a more occult character than those imagined to exist by Cuvier,|
06891|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0154.wav|||and which certainly hold good for the vast majority of animals and plants, are of universal application.|
06892|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0155.wav|||A bean may be supplied with water in which salts of ammonia and certain other mineral salts are dissolved in due proportion,|
06893|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0156.wav|||with atmospheric air containing its ordinary minute dose of carbonic acid and with nothing else but sunlight and heat.|
06894|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0157.wav|||Under these circumstances, unnatural as they are, with proper management, the bean will thrust forth its radicle and its plumule;|
06895|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0158.wav|||the former will grow down into roots, the latter grow up into the stem and leaves of a vigorous bean-plant,|
06896|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0159.wav|||and this plant will, in due time, flower and produce its crop of beans just as if it were grown in the garden or in the field.|
06897|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0160.wav|||The weight of the nitrogenous protein compounds,|
06898|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0161.wav|||of the oily, starchy, saccharine and woody substances contained in the full-grown plant and its seeds|
06899|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0162.wav|||will be vastly greater than the weight of the same substances contained in the bean from which it sprang.|
06900|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0163.wav|||But nothing has been supplied to the bean save water, carbonic acid, ammonia, potash, lime,|
06901|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0164.wav|||iron and the like in combination with phosphoric, sulphuric and other acids.|
06902|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0165.wav|||Neither protein, nor fat, nor starch, nor sugar, nor any substance in the slightest degree resembling them has formed part of the food of the bean.|
06903|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0166.wav|||But the weights of the carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur and other elementary bodies contained in the bean-plant|
06904|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0167.wav|||and in the seeds which it produces are exactly equivalent to the weights of the same elements which have disappeared from the materials supplied to the bean during its growth.|
06905|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0168.wav|||Whence it follows that the bean has taken in only the raw materials of its fabric and has manufactured them into bean-stuffs.|
06906|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0169.wav|||The bean has been able to perform this great chemical feat by the help of its green coloring matter, or chlorophyll,|
06907|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0170.wav|||for it is only the green parts of the plant which, under the influence of sunlight, have the marvelous power of decomposing carbonic acid,|
06908|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0171.wav|||setting free the oxygen and laying hold of the carbon which it contains.|
06909|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0172.wav|||In fact, the bean obtains two of the absolutely indispensable elements of its substance from two distinct sources.|
06910|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0173.wav|||The watery solution, in which its roots are plunged, contains nitrogen but no carbon;|
06911|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0174.wav|||the air, to which the leaves are exposed, contains carbon,|
06912|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0175.wav|||but its nitrogen is in the state of a free gas, in which condition the bean can make no use of it,|
06913|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ025-0176.wav|||and the chlorophyll is the apparatus by which the carbon is extracted from the atmospheric carbonic acid, the leaves being the chief laboratories|
06914|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0001.wav|||The Science: History of the Universe, Volume five. Edited by Francis Rolt-Wheeler. Biology. Chapter eight.|
06915|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0002.wav|||Life Processes. Part One.|
06916|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0003.wav|||Nutrition thus, as has been pointed out, makes it possible to classify most organisms as animals or plants.|
06917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0004.wav|||Yet there are many unicellular forms in which both kinds of nutrition go on at the same time;|
06918|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0005.wav|||that is, the forms may possess a mouth for the ingestion of solid food and green coloring matter, chlorophyll,|
06919|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0006.wav|||for the manufacture of starchy food from gaseous matter.|
06920|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0007.wav|||Many of the lowest forms of life have long been puzzles|
06921|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0008.wav|||and the beginner in biological study is surprised to find them described in textbooks of both botany and zoology.|
06922|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0009.wav|||The fact is that they are on the border line, are neither plants nor animals but simply organisms.|
06923|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0010.wav|||Since they cannot be classified, it is necessary that they be listed both under botany and zoology, in order to make sure that they will not be omitted entirely.|
06924|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0011.wav|||Because of these uncertain forms of life,|
06925|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0012.wav|||Haeckel proposed once to include all one-celled animals and plants in a third kingdom to be called Protista (meaning the first of all life).|
06926|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0013.wav|||Parker's definition of animals and plants,|
06927|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0014.wav|||based on the foregoing considerations, is convenient for distinguishing between animals and plants in all cases except the doubtful unicellar forms.|
06928|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0015.wav|||He says: Animals are organisms of fixed and definite form, in which the cell-body is not covered with a cellulose wall.|
06929|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0016.wav|||They ingest solid proteinaceous food,|
06930|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0017.wav|||their nutritive processes result in oxidation, they have a definite organ of excretion and are capable of automatic movement|
06931|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0018.wav|||Plants are organisms of constantly varying form in which the cell body is surrounded by a cellulose wall;|
06932|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0019.wav|||they cannot ingest solid food, but are nourished by a watery solution of nutrient materials.|
06933|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0020.wav|||If chlorophyll is present, the carbon dioxide of the air serves as a source of carbon,|
06934|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0021.wav|||nitrogen is obtained from simple salts and the nutritive processes result in deoxidation;|
06935|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0022.wav|||if chlorophyll is absent, carbon is obtained from sugar or some similar compound,|
06936|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0023.wav|||nitrogen either from simple salts or from proteids, and the process of nutrition is one of oxidation.|
06937|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0024.wav|||There is no special excretory organ, and, except in the case of certain reproductive bodies, there is usually no locomotion.|
06938|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0025.wav|||The important point to recognize is that these boundaries are artificial and that there are no scientific frontiers in Nature.|
06939|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0026.wav|||As in the liquefaction of gases, there is a "critical point" at which the substance under experiment is neither gaseous nor liquid.|
06940|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0027.wav|||as in a mountainous country, it is impossible to say where mountain ends and valley begins; as in the development of an animal,|
06941|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0028.wav|||it is futile to argue about the exact period when, for instance, the egg becomes a tadpole or the tadpole a frog,|
06942|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0029.wav|||so in the case under discussion.|
06943|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0030.wav|||The distinction between the higher plants and animals is perfectly sharp and obvious,|
06944|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0031.wav|||but when the two groups are traced downward they are found gradually to merge,|
06945|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0032.wav|||as it were, into an assemblage of organisms which partake of the characters of both kingdoms and cannot without a certain violence|
06946|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0033.wav|||be either included in or excluded from either.|
06947|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0034.wav|||When any given "protist" has to be classified the case must be decided on its individual merits;|
06948|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0035.wav|||the organism must be compared in detail with all those which resemble it closely in structure, physiology and life history,|
06949|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0036.wav|||and then a balance must be struck and the doubtful form placed in the kingdom with which it has, on the whole, most points in common.|
06950|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0037.wav|||It will no doubt occur to the reader that, on the theory of evolution,|
06951|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0038.wav|||the fact of the animal and vegetable kingdoms being related to one another like two trees united at the roots may be accounted for by the hypothesis that|
06952|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0039.wav|||the earliest organisms were protists and that from them animals and plants were evolved along divergent lines of descent.|
06953|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0040.wav|||And in this connection the fact that some bacteria -- the simplest organisms known and devoid of chlorophyll|
06954|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0041.wav|||may flourish in solutions wholly devoid of organic matter is very significant.|
06955|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0042.wav|||The lower plants and animals referred to above are so far from everyday observation|
06956|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0043.wav|||and hence so unfamiliar that to most people the comparison made will mean little in terms of ordinary green flowering plants and common vertebrate animals.|
06957|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0044.wav|||In order to emphasize the fundamental similarity of organic function in higher and lower animals and plants, let us compare any higher plant|
06958|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0045.wav|||e.g., a bean plant with a higher animal, e.g., frog or even man.|
06959|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0046.wav|||In each the life is the sum total of a series of definite processes -- nutrition or food supply,|
06960|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0047.wav|||circulation, metabolism, excretion, oxygenation (part of respiration),|
06961|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0048.wav|||movement, irritability (nervous activity) and reproduction.|
06962|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0049.wav|||In turn these will be compared for the animal and the plant,|
06963|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0050.wav|||following in part the comparisons of certain animals and plants by Sedgwick and Wilson and others.|
06964|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0051.wav|||These comparisons will, however, be translated into terms applicable to any species of higher plants or animals.|
06965|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0052.wav|||In the nutrition of the animal the most essential and characteristic part of the food supply is derived from vegetable|
06966|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0053.wav|||or animal matter in the form of various organic compounds, of which the most important are proteids (protoplasm, albumen, etc.),|
06967|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0054.wav|||carbohydrates (starch, cellulose) and fats.|
06968|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0055.wav|||These materials are used by the animal in the manufacture of new protoplasm to take the place of that which has been used up.|
06969|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0056.wav|||It is, however, impossible for the animal to build these materials directly into the substance of its own body.|
06970|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0057.wav|||They must first undergo certain preparatory chemical changes known collectively as digestion|
06971|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0058.wav|||and only after the completion of this process can all the food be absorbed into the circulation.|
06972|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0059.wav|||For this purpose the food is taken not into the body proper, but into a kind of tubular chemical laboratory; called the alimentary canal,|
06973|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0060.wav|||through which it slowly passes, being subjected meanwhile to the action of certain chemical substances or reagents, known as digestive ferments.|
06974|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0061.wav|||These substances, which are dissolved in a watery liquid to form the digestive fluid, are secreted by the walls of the alimentary tube.|
06975|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0062.wav|||Through their action the solid portions are liquefied and the food is rendered capable of absorption into the body proper.|
06976|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0063.wav|||The food supply of the higher plant, like that of the animal, is the source of the required matter and energy,|
06977|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0064.wav|||but unlike that of the animal, it is not chiefly an income of foods, but only of the raw materials of food.|
06978|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0065.wav|||Matter enters the plant in the liquid or gaseous form by diffusion,|
06979|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0066.wav|||both from the soil through the roots (liquids) and from the atmosphere through the leaves (gases).|
06980|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0067.wav|||We have here the direct absorption into the body proper of food-stuffs precisely as the animal takes in water and oxygen.|
06981|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0068.wav|||Energy enters the plant, to a small extent,|
06982|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0069.wav|||as the potential energy of foodstuffs, but comes in principally as the kinetic energy of sunlight absorbed in the leaves.|
06983|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0070.wav|||Of the substances the solids (salts, etc.) must be dissolved in water before they can be taken in.|
06984|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0071.wav|||Water and dissolved salts continually pass by diffusion from the soil into the roots, where together they constitute the sap.|
06985|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0072.wav|||The sap travels throughout the whole plant, the main though not the only cause of movement|
06986|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0073.wav|||being the constant transpiration (evaporation) of watery vapor from the leaves, especially through the stomata.|
06987|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0074.wav|||The gaseous matters (carbon dioxide, oxygen, nitrogen) enter the plant mainly by diffusion from the atmosphere,|
06988|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0075.wav|||are dissolved by the sap in the leaves and elsewhere and thus may pass to every portion of the plant.|
06989|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0076.wav|||The green plant owes its power of absorbing the energy of sunlight|
06990|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0077.wav|||to the chlorophyll bodies or chromatophores, for plants which, like fungi, etc., are devoid of chlorophyll, are unable thus to acquire energy.|
06991|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0078.wav|||Entering the chlorophyll bodies, the kinetic energy of sunlight is applied to the decomposition of carbon dioxide and water.|
06992|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0079.wav|||After passing through manifold but imperfectly known processes, the elements of these substances finally reappear as starch,|
06993|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0080.wav|||often in the form of granules embedded in the chlorophyll bodies and free oxygen, most of which is returned to the atmosphere.|
06994|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0081.wav|||Thus the leaf of a green plant in the light is continually absorbing carbon dioxide and giving forth free oxygen.|
06995|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0082.wav|||Carbon dioxide and water contain no potential energy, since the affinities of their constituent elements are completely satisfied.|
06996|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0083.wav|||Starch, however, contains potential energy, since the molecule is relatively unstable|
06997|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0084.wav|||i.e., capable of decomposition into simpler, stabler molecules in which stronger affinities are satisfied.|
06998|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0085.wav|||And this is due to the fact that in the manufacture of starch in the chlorophyll bodies|
06999|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0086.wav|||the kinetic energy of sunlight was expended in lifting the atoms into position of vantage, thus endowing them with energy of position.|
07000|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0087.wav|||In this way some of the radiant and kinetic energy of the sun comes to be stored up as potential energy in the starch.|
07001|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0088.wav|||In short, the green plant is able by cooperation with sunlight to use simple raw materials (carbon dioxide, water, oxygen, etc.)|
07002|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0089.wav|||poor in energy or devoid of it, and out of them to manufacture food -- i.e. complex compounds rich in available potential energy.|
07003|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0090.wav|||This power is possessed by green plants alone; all other organisms being dependent for energy upon the potential energy of ready-made food.|
07004|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0091.wav|||This must, in the first instance, be provided for them by green plants, and hence without chlorophyll-bearing plants,|
07005|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0092.wav|||animals (and colorless plants as well) apparently could not long exist.|
07006|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0093.wav|||The plant absorbs also a small amount of kinetic energy, independently of the sunlight, in the form of heat.|
07007|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0094.wav|||This, however, is probably not a source of vital energy, but only contributes to the maintenance of the body temperature.|
07008|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0095.wav|||Food (starch) thus produced in the green leaves of higher plants and the inorganic foods|
07009|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0096.wav|||water, nitrites or nitrates and various mineral substances in solution in water|
07010|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0097.wav|||furnish the materials and energy required for the life and growth of the plant.|
07011|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0098.wav|||The circulatory system distributes these foods. In animals foods prepared for absorption in the stomach and intestine (by digestion)|
07012|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0099.wav|||are absorbed by the circulating liquids (blood and lymph) and transported to all cells of the animal body.|
07013|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0100.wav|||In the plant the inorganic matter in water from the soil are absorbed by the roots and carried up definite tubes in the woody part of the stem.|
07014|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0101.wav|||The causes of this ascent are not clear,|
07015|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0102.wav|||but root pressure due to osmosis, capillary action and evaporation from the leaves are factors.|
07016|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0103.wav|||Just as the solid food of animals must be digested in preparation for absorption,|
07017|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0104.wav|||so starch manufactured in the leaves must be digested (dissolved) before it can be transported.|
07018|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0105.wav|||This is done by diastase, an enzyme of plant cells.|
07019|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0106.wav|||The change is from starch to a sugar capable of diffusion.|
07020|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0107.wav|||Dissolved in water, the sugar is transported down delicate tubes, chiefly in the growing bark region of the stem.|
07021|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0108.wav|||It is clear that there are upward and downward currents of water containing food (comparable to blood of an animal),|
07022|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0109.wav|||but no system of complete circulation as in the blood vessels of a higher animal.|
07023|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0110.wav|||However, the result in distributed food is the same in the plant and in the animal.|
07024|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0111.wav|||In the cells the foods undergo metabolic changes.|
07025|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0112.wav|||In an animal the foods in the circulating liquids, blood and lymph, are selected and absorbed by the cells.|
07026|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0113.wav|||Only proteid foods form new protoplasm|
07027|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0114.wav|||and even of proteids only a limited amount, seventy-five to one hundred grams a day for a man, is built into new protoplasm.|
07028|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0115.wav|||The excess undergoes oxidation and forms nitrogen excretions.|
07029|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0116.wav|||The foods containing only the elements carbon, hydrogen and oxygen (fats and carbohydrates)|
07030|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0117.wav|||are directly oxidized to excretions and, lacking nitrogen, cannot serve for making new animal protoplasm.|
07031|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0118.wav|||Fat and carbohydrate foods, then, never become living matter.|
07032|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0119.wav|||They may be stored, especially as fat, until needed for oxidation to supply energy.|
07033|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0120.wav|||The building up of the protoplasm from proteids is anabolism, constructive metabolism.|
07034|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0121.wav|||The destruction of protoplasm, excess proteids or the fat and carbohydrate foods is catabolism, destructive metabolism.|
07035|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0122.wav|||Catabolism is probably due to enzyme action, but the final result is chiefly carbon dioxide and water,|
07036|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0123.wav|||which could be derived by the ordinary chemical evolution of protoplasm, proteid, sugar, starch or fats.|
07037|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0124.wav|||In the plant, starch, as has been seen, is first formed in the chlorophyll-bodies.|
07038|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0125.wav|||But the formation of starch, all important as it is, is after all only the manufacture of food|
07039|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0126.wav|||as a preliminary to the real processes of nutrition.|
07040|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0127.wav|||These processes must take place everywhere in ordinary protoplasm,|
07041|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0128.wav|||for it is here that oxidation occurs and the need for a renewal of matter and energy consequently arises.|
07042|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0129.wav|||Sooner or later the starch grains are changed into a kind of sugar (glucose), which, unlike starch, dissolves in the sap|
07043|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0130.wav|||and may thus be easily transported to all parts of the plant.|
07044|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0131.wav|||Wherever there is need for new protoplasm, whether to repair previous waste or to supply materials for growth,|
07045|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0132.wav|||after absorption into the cells the elements of the starch (or glucose) are, by the living protoplasm, in some unknown way|
07046|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0133.wav|||combined with nitrogen and sulphur (probably also with salts, water, etc.) to form proteid matter.|
07047|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0134.wav|||The particles of this newly formed compound are incorporated into the protoplasm.|
07048|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0135.wav|||If a larger quantity of starch is formed in the chlorophyll bodies than is immediately needed by the protoplasm for purposes of repair or growth,|
07049|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0136.wav|||it may be reconverted into starch after journeying as glucose through the plant|
07050|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0137.wav|||and be laid down as "reserve starch" in the cells of root or stem or elsewhere.|
07051|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0138.wav|||Apparently when this reserve supply is finally needed at any point in the plant, it is again changed to glucose and transported thither.|
07052|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0139.wav|||It is probable that new leaves and new tissues generally are always formed in part from this reserve starch.|
07053|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0140.wav|||In the plant as in the animal metabolism must consist of anabolic and catabolic processes.|
07054|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0141.wav|||The construction in the cells of new proteid from the absorbed carbohydrate and the materials from the soil is true anabolism.|
07055|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0142.wav|||It is also clear that catabolism or oxidation for the liberation of energy occurs as in animals, but this process is slower.|
07056|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0143.wav|||Probably foods containing carbon, hydrogen and oxygen are the sources of energy in the higher plants as in animals.|
07057|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0144.wav|||In both plants and animals simple waste substances result from the catabolic processes in the cells.|
07058|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0145.wav|||In the animal carbon dioxide, water and nitrogen compounds are the chief excretions.|
07059|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0146.wav|||They are absorbed by the circulating liquids and carried to the eliminating organs, lungs and kidneys chiefly, for elimination.|
07060|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0147.wav|||In the higher plants the excretions are carbon dioxide, which escapes through the epidermis of root, stem and leaf and through the stomata;|
07061|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0148.wav|||water which is lost by evaporation, especially from the leaf surface through the stomata;|
07062|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0149.wav|||excretions which are lost by osmosis through the roots and the accumulated but useless mineral substances which are eliminated by leaf fall.|
07063|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0150.wav|||In both animals and plants oxygen is essential to the catabolic part of metabolism.|
07064|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0151.wav|||Hence oxygen must be supplied to the cells.|
07065|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0152.wav|||Oxygenation is the term used to denote the oxygen-supplying part of respiration;|
07066|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0153.wav|||the other part of respiration, elimination of carbon dioxide, has been treated under excretions.|
07067|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0154.wav|||In the animal oxygen is absorbed by the blood, in excess by the hemoglobin of the red cells of the blood|
07068|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0155.wav|||and later is absorbed from the blood and lymph by all the living cells.|
07069|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0156.wav|||In the plant also oxygen is absorbed through the epidermis and stomata from the air.|
07070|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0157.wav|||This process is, however, obscured during the day because of the oxygen freed in the manufacture of starch which goes on at that time.|
07071|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0158.wav|||Probably this freed oxygen is used for the purpose of oxygenation, but more is freed in the photosynthetic process than is needed for oxygenation|
07072|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0159.wav|||and hence the excess oxygen is eliminated while starch manufacture is in process.|
07073|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0160.wav|||In comparing a higher animal and a green plant confusion must be avoided regarding the part played by oxygen and carbon dioxide in true respiration|
07074|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0161.wav|||with the part played by the same substances in starch formation (photosynthesis).|
07075|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0162.wav|||In non-green plants like the Indian pipe and mushrooms the breathing of oxygen and the excretion of carbon dioxide are as in the animal.|
07076|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0163.wav|||This is true also of green plants in darkness and even in the light of all parts of green plants except the chlorophyll-bodies.|
07077|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0164.wav|||These constitute a sort of extra mechanism, enabling green plants to make their own carbohydrate food.|
07078|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0165.wav|||Imagine a higher animal with an attachment for turning the carbon dioxide and water excreted|
07079|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ026-0166.wav|||back to starch usable as food and the comparison of the green plant and the animal would be complete.|
07080|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0001.wav|||The Science: History of the Universe, Volume five. Edited by Francis Rolt-Wheeler.|
07081|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0002.wav|||Biology. Chapter ten. Morphology and Embryology, Part One.|
07082|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0003.wav|||The facts of biology which admit of adequate explanation only in connection with the theory of descent|
07083|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0004.wav|||are grouped by Romanes and other writers on organic evolution under the heads of morphology, embryology, classification,|
07084|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0005.wav|||paleontology, distribution and domestication.|
07085|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0006.wav|||In all these lines the facts are drawn together by a strong thread of unity.|
07086|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0007.wav|||There are numberless similarities and correlations and surprising uniformities.|
07087|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0008.wav|||The great variety of life as exhibited in the countless species of plants and animals has been referred to, and yet, great as this variety is,|
07088|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0009.wav|||there are, after all, only a few types of structure among all animals and plants, some three or four or eight or ten general modes of development,|
07089|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0010.wav|||and all the rest are modifications from these few types.|
07090|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0011.wav|||It is, moreover, true that all living forms are but series of modifications and extensions of one single plan of structure.|
07091|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0012.wav|||All have the same ultimate substance|
07092|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0013.wav|||the mysterious semi-fluid network of protoplasm, which is, so far as is known, the physical basis of all life;|
07093|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0014.wav|||and the equally mysterious nuclear substance or chromatin|
07094|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0015.wav|||which in some fashion presides over all the movements of the protoplasm and is the physical basis of the phenomena of heredity.|
07095|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0016.wav|||The same laws of heredity, variability and of response to outside stimulus hold in all parts of the organic world.|
07096|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0017.wav|||All organisms have the same need of reproduction.|
07097|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0018.wav|||All are forced to make concession after concession to their surroundings, and in these concessions all progress in life consists.|
07098|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0019.wav|||And at last each organism or each alliance of organisms must come to the greatest concession of all, which is called death.|
07099|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0020.wav|||The unity in life, then, is not less a fact than is life's great diversity.|
07100|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0021.wav|||Whatever emphasis is laid upon the diversity of life, the essential unity of all organisms must not be forgotten.|
07101|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0022.wav|||An examination of the facts in each of the lines of evidence makes it clear|
07102|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0023.wav|||that the only reasonable explanation for the existence of a fundamental unity in organic life|
07103|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0024.wav|||is the theory of descent -- i.e., that similarities are due to blood relationship and that differences come from adaptive modifications.|
07104|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0025.wav|||The facts adduced from morphology, being the result of researches into the structure of adult animals and plants,|
07105|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0026.wav|||lead to a preview of certain principles of adaptation, necessary for their interpretation.|
07106|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0027.wav|||First, it must be noted that some structures are not non-adaptive, that is, do not change to fit changed habits or conditions of life.|
07107|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0028.wav|||Such structures or organs are most often found internally.|
07108|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0029.wav|||For illustration: a change in the locomotive habit of a bird from that of flying to that of an ostrich|
07109|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0030.wav|||is associated with an adaptive modification of locomotor structures, legs and wings,|
07110|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0031.wav|||but not in any striking way is there change in the internal organs.|
07111|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0032.wav|||Internal organs may persist unchanged and hence they offer good guides to classification.|
07112|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0033.wav|||On the other hand, external structures are likely to undergo adaptation when habits or conditions of life change.|
07113|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0034.wav|||Hence, as Jordan has said, "the inside of an animal tells the real history of its ancestry; the outside tells us only where its ancestors have been."|
07114|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0035.wav|||In the second place, it must be noted that adaptations to similar conditions may result in superficial resemblances.|
07115|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0036.wav|||For example, there is a superficial resemblance between the wing of an insect and the wing of a bird|
07116|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0037.wav|||both adaptations to an aerial environment;|
07117|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0038.wav|||between the heart of an insect and the heart of a vertebrate animal|
07118|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0039.wav|||both adaptations for pumping blood;|
07119|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0040.wav|||between the fin of a fish and the paddle of a whale|
07120|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0041.wav|||both adaptive swimming organs, yet the resemblance in these cases does not go deeper than the surface -- it is one of function only.|
07121|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0042.wav|||All such cases of resemblance in function but not in detailed plan of structure are called "analogies,"|
07122|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0043.wav|||and mean nothing more than similarity of environment.|
07123|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0044.wav|||Turning to more fundamental resemblances, such as the wing of a bat and the wing of a bird,|
07124|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0045.wav|||careful study shows detailed internal as well as external similarities of structure. Such cases are "homologies".|
07125|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0046.wav|||On the one hand, then, are found structures which are perfectly analogous and yet in no way homologous:|
07126|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0047.wav|||totally different structures are modified to perform the same functions.|
07127|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0048.wav|||On the other hand are found structures which are perfectly homologous and yet in no way analogous:|
07128|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0049.wav|||the structural elements remain, but are profoundly modified to perform totally different functions.|
07129|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0050.wav|||Homology thus means identity of structure which is the result of identity of parentage. It is the stamp of heredity.|
07130|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0051.wav|||It means blood relationship.|
07131|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0052.wav|||These principles of homology are essential to a correct interpretation of the facts of morphology.|
07132|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0053.wav|||The most striking fact of similar structure among plants and among animals is the existence of a common general plan in any group.|
07133|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0054.wav|||Since backboned animals are best known to most readers, they may be taken as an illustration.|
07134|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0055.wav|||All vertebrate animals, and none other, says Le Conte, "have an internal jointed skeleton worked by muscles on the outside.|
07135|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0056.wav|||The relation of skeleton and muscle in arthropods is exactly the reverse.|
07136|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0057.wav|||In all vertebrates, and in none other, the axis of this skeleton is a jointed backbone (vertebral column)|
07137|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0058.wav|||enclosing and protecting the nervous centers (cerebrospinal axis).|
07138|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0059.wav|||These, therefore, may well be called backboned animals.|
07139|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0060.wav|||All vertebrates, and none other, have a number of their anterior vertebral joints enlarged and consolidated into a box to form the skull,|
07140|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0061.wav|||in order to enclose and protect a similar enlargement of the nervous center,|
07141|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0062.wav|||viz., the brain; and also usually, but not always, a number of posterior joints,|
07142|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0063.wav|||enlarged and consolidated to form the pelvis, to serve as a firm support to the hind-limbs.|
07143|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0064.wav|||All vertebrates, and none other, have two cavities,|
07144|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0065.wav|||enclosed and protected by the skeleton, viz., the neural cavity above, and the visceral or body cavity below, the vertebral column.|
07145|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0066.wav|||All vertebrates, with few exceptions, and no other animals, have two and only two pair of limbs.|
07146|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0067.wav|||The exceptions are of two kinds, viz.: (a) some lowest fishes, amphioxus and lampreys,|
07147|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0068.wav|||which probably represent the vertebrate condition before limbs were acquired;|
07148|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0069.wav|||and (b) degenerate forms like snakes and some lizards, which have lost their limbs by disuse.|
07149|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0070.wav|||So much concerns the general plan of skeletal structures and is strongly suggestive of -- in fact it is inexplicable without -- common origin.|
07150|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0071.wav|||But much more remains which is not only suggestive, but demonstrative of such origin.|
07151|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0072.wav|||By extensive comparison in the taxonomic and ontogenic series, the whole vertebrate structure in all its details in different animals|
07152|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0073.wav|||may be shown to be modifications one of another.|
07153|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0074.wav|||Sometimes a piece is enlarged, sometimes diminished, or even becomes obsolete; sometimes several pieces are consolidated into one;|
07154|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0075.wav|||but, in spite of all these obscurations, corresponding parts usually may be made out.|
07155|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0076.wav|||These remarkable similarities in the common general plan alone are convincing evidences of descent,|
07156|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0077.wav|||but attention may be called to a like similarity extending to the details of structure.|
07157|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0078.wav|||For example: the wings of a bat (a mammal), a bird and a fossil flying reptile all show the same bones adaptively modified;|
07158|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0079.wav|||a series of either fore or hind limbs of a mammal with one toe (horse),|
07159|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0080.wav|||two toes (sheep), four toes (hog) and five toes (dog)|
07160|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0081.wav|||exhibit a remarkable series of homologies pointing to a five-toed ancestor,|
07161|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0082.wav|||and any other series of organs of vertebrates would give the same evidence of fundamental resemblances (homologies).|
07162|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0083.wav|||For such a series of facts the reader must be referred to special books like Wiedersheim's "Comparative Anatomy of the Vertebrates,"|
07163|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0084.wav|||Romanes's "Darwin and After Darwin", and Le Conte's "Evolution."|
07164|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0085.wav|||The existence of great similarities in vertebrate structure is not always fully recognized.|
07165|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0086.wav|||To the superficial observer the bodies of animals of different classes seem to differ fundamentally in plan,|
07166|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0087.wav|||to be entirely different machines, made each for its own purposes, at once, out of hand.|
07167|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0088.wav|||Extensive comparison, on the contrary, shows them to be the same, although the essential identity is obscured by adaptive modifications.|
07168|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0089.wav|||The simplest, in fact the only scientific, explanation of the phenomena of vertebrate structure is the idea of a primal vertebrate,|
07169|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0090.wav|||modified more and more through successive generations by the necessities of different modes of life.|
07170|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0091.wav|||See, then, the difference between man's mode of working and Nature's.|
07171|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0092.wav|||A man having made a steam-engine, and desiring to use it for a different purpose from that for which it was first designed and used,|
07172|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0093.wav|||will nearly always be compelled to add new parts not contemplated in the original machine.|
07173|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0094.wav|||Nature rarely makes new parts -- never, if she can avoid it -- but, on the contrary, adapts an old part to the new function.|
07174|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0095.wav|||It is as if Nature were not free to use any and every device to accomplish her end, but were conditioned by her own plans of structure;|
07175|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0096.wav|||as, indeed, she must be according to the derivation theory.|
07176|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0097.wav|||Thus, in the fin of a fish, the fore-paw of a reptile or a mammal, the wing of a bird, and the arm and hand of a man|
07177|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0098.wav|||is found the same part, variously modified for many purposes.|
07178|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0099.wav|||Another striking class of the facts of morphology which admit of scientific explanation only along the line of homology|
07179|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0100.wav|||are the thousands of cases of rudimentary or vestigial structures to be found.|
07180|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0101.wav|||Throughout both the animal and vegetable kingdoms dwarfed and useless representatives of organs are constantly met with,|
07181|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0102.wav|||which in other and allied kinds of animals and plants are of large size and functional utility.|
07182|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0103.wav|||Thus, for instance, the unborn whale has rudimentary teeth,|
07183|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0104.wav|||which are never destined to cut the gums; and throughout its life this animal retains, in a similarly rudimentary condition,|
07184|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0105.wav|||a number of organs which never could have been of use to any kind of creature save a terrestrial quadruped.|
07185|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0106.wav|||Other well-known examples among vertebrates are: Vestiges of hind limbs in certain snakes, reduced wings in the Apteryx and ostriches,|
07186|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0107.wav|||rudiments of eyes in cave fishes, hind limbs beneath the skin of whales, the vermiform appendix in man,|
07187|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0108.wav|||as well as useless muscles to move the ears and the skin, and also a very much reduced hairy covering over the surface of the body.|
07188|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0109.wav|||Wiedersheim has recorded more than one hundred and eighty such structural reminiscences in man.|
07189|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0110.wav|||Now, rudimentary organs of this kind are of such frequent occurrence, that almost every species of organism presents one or more of them|
07190|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0111.wav|||usually, indeed, a considerable number.|
07191|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0112.wav|||How, then, are they to be accounted for?|
07192|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0113.wav|||Of course the theory of descent with adaptive modification has a simple answer to supply|
07193|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0114.wav|||Namely that when from changed conditions of life, an organ which was previously useful becomes useless,|
07194|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0115.wav|||it will be suffered to dwindle away in successive generations, under the influence of certain natural causes.|
07195|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0116.wav|||On the other hand, the theory of special creation can only maintain that these rudiments are formed for the sake of adhering to an ideal type.|
07196|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0117.wav|||Now, here again the former theory appears to be triumphant over the latter, says Romanes,|
07197|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0118.wav|||nan|
07198|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0119.wav|||surely if such a method were adopted in so many cases, we should expect that in consistency it would be adopted in all cases.|
07199|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0120.wav|||This reasonable expectation, however, is far from being realized.|
07200|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0121.wav|||In numberless cases, such as that of the fore-limbs of serpents, no vestige of a rudiment is present.|
07201|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0122.wav|||But the vacillating policy in the matter of rudiments does not end here; for it is shown in a still more aggravated form|
07202|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0123.wav|||where within the limits of the same natural group of organisms a rudiment is sometimes present and sometimes absent.|
07203|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0124.wav|||For instance, although in nearly all the numerous species of snakes there are no vestiges of limbs,|
07204|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0125.wav|||in the Python we find very tiny rudiments of the hindlimbs. Now,|
07205|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0126.wav|||is it a worthy conception of Deity that,|
07206|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0127.wav|||while neglecting to maintain his unity of ideal in the case of nearly all the numerous species of snakes, he should have added a tiny rudiment in the case of the Python|
07207|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0128.wav|||and even in that case should have maintained his ideal very inefficiently, inasmuch as only two limbs, instead of four, are represented?|
07208|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0129.wav|||Convincing as are the evidences of descent recorded in the structure of plants and animals,|
07209|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0130.wav|||these evidences have been in the past thirty years somewhat overshadowed by the far more surprising evidences|
07210|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0131.wav|||of descent discovered in the development of plant and animal embryos.|
07211|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0132.wav|||A dozen volumes would be necessary|
07212|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0133.wav|||to present the mass of embryological evidence, but a few salient facts will illustrate the kind of evidence to be deduced from embryology.|
07213|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0134.wav|||Most remarkable of all the principles which have been discovered by embryologists is the "Recapitulation Doctrine"|
07214|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0135.wav|||which, briefly stated, is that individual development (ontogeny) recapitulates ancestral history (phylogeny).|
07215|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0136.wav|||Illustrations quoted from the works of Romanes and Le Conte will make this principle clear.|
07216|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0137.wav|||It is an observable fact, says Romanes,|
07217|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0138.wav|||that there is often a close correspondence between developmental changes as revealed by any chronological series of fossils which may happen to have been preserved,|
07218|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0139.wav|||and developmental changes which may be observed during the life history of now existing individuals belonging to the same group of animals.|
07219|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0141.wav|||is closely reproduced in the life-history of existing deer. Or, in other words,|
07220|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0142.wav|||the antlers of an existing deer furnish in their development a kind of "resume," or recapitulation, of the successive phases|
07221|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0143.wav|||whereby the primitive horn was gradually superseded by horns presenting a greater and greater number of prongs in successive species of extinct deer.|
07222|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0144.wav|||Now, it must be obvious|
07223|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0145.wav|||that such a recapitulation in the life history of an existing animal of developmental changes successively distinctive of sundry allied,|
07224|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0146.wav|||though now extinct species, speaks strongly in favor of evolution.|
07225|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0147.wav|||For as it is of the essence of this theory that new forms arise from older forms by way of hereditary descent,|
07226|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0148.wav|||we should antecedently expect, if the theory is true,|
07227|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0149.wav|||that the phases of development presented by the individual organism would follow, in their main outlines, those phases of development|
07228|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0150.wav|||through which their long line of ancestors had passed.|
07229|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0151.wav|||The only alternative view is that as species of deer,|
07230|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0152.wav|||for instance, were separately created, additional prongs were successively added to their antlers; and yet that,|
07231|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0153.wav|||in order to be so added to successive species, every individual deer belonging to later species was required to repeat in his own lifetime|
07232|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0154.wav|||the process of successive additions which had previously taken place in a remote series of extinct species.|
07233|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0155.wav|||Now I do not deny that this view is a possible view; but I do deny that it is a probable one.|
07234|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0156.wav|||According to the evolutionary interpretation of such facts, we can see a very good reason why the life-history of the individual|
07235|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0157.wav|||is thus a condensed resume of the life history of its ancestral species.|
07236|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0158.wav|||But according to the opposite view no reason can be assigned why such should be the case.|
07237|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0159.wav|||It is well known, likewise comments Le Conte,|
07238|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0160.wav|||that the embryo or larva of a frog or toad, when first hatched, is a legless, tail-swimming, water-breathing, gill-breathing animal.|
07239|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0161.wav|||It is essentially a fish, and would be so classed if it remained in this condition.|
07240|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0162.wav|||The fish retains permanently this form, but the frog passes on.|
07241|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0163.wav|||Next, it forms first one pair and then another pair of legs; and meanwhile it begins to breathe also by lungs.|
07242|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0164.wav|||At this stage it breathes equally by lungs and by gills -- i.e., both air and water.|
07243|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0165.wav|||Now, the lower forms of amphibians, such as siredon, menobranchus, siren, etc.,|
07244|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0166.wav|||retain permanently this form, and are therefore called "perennibranchs," but the frog still passes on.|
07245|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0167.wav|||Then the gills gradually dry up, as the lungs develop, and they now breathe wholly by lungs, but still retain the tail.|
07246|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0168.wav|||Now this is the permanent, mature condition of many amphibians,|
07247|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0169.wav|||such as the triton, the salamander, etc., which are therefore called "caducibranchs," but the frog still passes on.|
07248|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0170.wav|||Finally, it loses the tail, or rather its tail is absorbed and its material used in further development, and it becomes a perfect frog,|
07249|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0171.wav|||the highest order (anoura) of this class. Thus, then, in ontogeny the fish goes no further than the fish stages.|
07250|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0172.wav|||The perennibranch passes through the fish stage to the perennibranch amphibian.|
07251|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0173.wav|||The caducibranch takes first the fish form, then the perennibranch form, and finally the caducibranch form, but goes no further.|
07252|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0174.wav|||Last, the anoura takes first the fish-form, then that of the perennibranch, then that of the caducibranch, and finally becomes anoura.|
07253|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0175.wav|||Now, this is undoubtedly the order of succession of forms in geological times -- i.e., in the phylogenic series.|
07254|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0176.wav|||Fishes first appeared in the Devonian and Upper Silurian in very reptilian or rather amphibian forms.|
07255|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0177.wav|||Then in the Carboniferous, fishes still continuing, there appeared the lowest -- i.e., most fish-like forms of amphibians.|
07256|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0178.wav|||These were undoubtedly perennibranchs. In the Permian and Triassic higher forms appeared, which were certainly caducibranch.|
07257|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0179.wav|||Finally, only in the Tertiary, so far as we yet know, do the highest form (anoura) appear.|
07258|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ027-0180.wav|||The general similarity of the three series is complete.|
07259|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0001.wav|||The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. By Edgar J. Banks. Chapter two. The Walls of Babylon.|
07260|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0002.wav|||In the old city of Damascus you climb to the hump of a tall fleet dromedary.|
07261|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0003.wav|||With guides and guards about you, you ride through the covered bazaars crowded with dark-faced Arabs in strange costumes,|
07262|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0004.wav|||and along the narrow winding lane which was once called the "Street Called Straight."|
07263|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0005.wav|||Leaving the city by the eastern gate, and passing a small village or two,|
07264|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0006.wav|||you ascend the hill to the plateau, and before you, as far as the eye can reach, stretches the great Arabian Desert.|
07265|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0007.wav|||With mingling fear and wonder at the mystery always lying beyond the desert horizon,|
07266|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0008.wav|||you tap gently with your heel upon the shoulder of the dromedary to urge her on.|
07267|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0009.wav|||At first, paying little heed to you, she hesitates and glances anxiously about the desert as if in search of an enemy.|
07268|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0010.wav|||Now and then she reaches down to graze the thorny argool along the way.|
07269|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0011.wav|||As the taps upon her shoulder are repeated, she stretches out her long neck, and with long strides makes for the eastern horizon;|
07270|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0012.wav|||she realizes that she is bound on the long journey across the desert. Hour after hour she bears you over the hard monotonous plain.|
07271|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0013.wav|||The Damascus mosques and their minarets sink beneath the western sky.|
07272|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0014.wav|||The desert about you shows no signs of life;|
07273|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0015.wav|||only a tall column of whirling sand, rearing its head until it is lost in the blue above, moves majestically along.|
07274|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0016.wav|||In the distance your eyes detect a beautiful lake with shores fringed with trees,|
07275|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0017.wav|||but soon the phantom lake vanishes, while others, still farther beyond, appear and vanish in rapid succession.|
07276|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0018.wav|||Like a great ball of fire the sun sinks in the west.|
07277|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0019.wav|||The stars come out one by one and shine brighter than elsewhere as if to light you on your way.|
07278|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0020.wav|||Late at night the weary dromedary kneels, and on the ground, close beside her, you lie down to sleep.|
07279|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0021.wav|||Again, long before the stars have been scattered by the morning sun, you are on your way.|
07280|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0022.wav|||Day after day you travel on, scorched by the heat of noon-day, shivering in the chill winds of the night.|
07281|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0023.wav|||Two weeks pass, and at last you stand on the eastern edge of the plateau|
07282|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0024.wav|||gazing down upon the great Euphrates winding along the valley beneath.|
07283|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0025.wav|||You have crossed the Arabian Desert, the first stage of the long journey to the walls of Babylon.|
07284|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0026.wav|||Here in the valley the water is sweet and the food abundant.|
07285|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0027.wav|||For ten days you follow down the river, through little villages and black tent encampments, among scenes of strange Arab life which never lose their charm.|
07286|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0028.wav|||Everywhere the valley is dotted with the mounds of buried cities carefully guarding the secrets of the centuries of long ago.|
07287|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0029.wav|||At last you see before you a mound rising like a mountain from the level plain.|
07288|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0030.wav|||Your journey is at an end. Before you is Babylon, the "Gate of God," as the old name means.|
07289|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0031.wav|||About you is all that remains of the second of the Seven Wonders of the World.|
07290|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0032.wav|||Babylon, even in the days of Nebuchadnezzar, was an old, old city.|
07291|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0033.wav|||There is a Hebrew tradition that it was the oldest of all cities, but now we know that great empires flourished and passed away before Babylon was built.|
07292|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0034.wav|||Old King Sargon I., who may have lived as early as three thousand eight hundred B.C.,|
07293|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0035.wav|||seems to have been the first to mention Babylon, and one of his inscriptions seems to say that he built the city and gave it its name.|
07294|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0036.wav|||But in those very early days Babylon was little more than a shrine, surrounded with mud huts and date palms.|
07295|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0037.wav|||It was about twenty-two fifty B.C., when the great Hammurabi made it his capital, that it became the chief city of Babylonia.|
07296|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0038.wav|||Its history for the next fifteen hundred years or more is obscure.|
07297|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0039.wav|||We know the names of its kings, and the records speak of long wars with the Assyrians.|
07298|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0040.wav|||In the year six eighty-nine B.C., Sinacherib, King of Nineveh, captured Babylon,|
07299|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0041.wav|||tore down its palaces and temples and walls, and scraped even the foundations of the city into the river.|
07300|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0042.wav|||The place where the old city had stood for three thousand years again became a desert.|
07301|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0043.wav|||Esarhaddon, the son of Sinacherib, was the next King of Nineveh.|
07302|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0044.wav|||He rebuilt Babylon that in accordance with the ancient custom he might be crowned in the sacred city.|
07303|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0045.wav|||When Esarhaddon died, one of his sons, Samas-sum-yukin, was made King of Babylon.|
07304|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0046.wav|||Another son, Assurbanipal, or the great Sardanapalus of the Greeks, became the King of Nineveh.|
07305|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0047.wav|||War broke out between the two brothers, and again Babylon was captured.|
07306|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0048.wav|||In six twenty-six Assurbanipal died,|

07312|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0054.wav|||He continued the building operations of his father, until Babylon became the greatest city of its age,|
07313|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0055.wav|||and surrounded it with walls the like of which no other city has ever seen.|
07314|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0056.wav|||Nebuchadnezzar, or Nebuchadrezzar, as his name should be spelled, was the greatest character in Babylonian history,|
07315|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0057.wav|||but about his name so many legends have grown that it is sometimes difficult to learn the facts of his life.|

07318|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0060.wav|||In six oh five,|

07321|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0063.wav|||Then Syria and Palestine were added to his future empire.|

07323|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0065.wav|||Eleven years later, in five eighty-six, he destroyed the sacred Hebrew city,|

07326|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0068.wav|||They tell how he forced the exiles to carry heavy bags of sand across the desert to increase their burdens;|

07331|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0073.wav|||The walls of the palaces of many of the Assyrian kings were lined with great stone slabs engraved with reliefs and sometimes with the portrait of a king.|
07332|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0074.wav|||But in Babylonia stone was difficult to obtain, and sculptures were very rare.|
07333|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0075.wav|||Therefore it was useless to hope that Nebuchadnezzar's portrait would be found on his palace walls.|
07334|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0076.wav|||However, several decades ago, an Oriental appeared at the Berlin Museum,|

07336|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0078.wav|||About the head was an inscription in Greek characters saying that the face was that of Nebuchadnezzar.|
07337|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0079.wav|||The museum authorities believed that the cameo was one of the many spurious objects which the Eastern forgers were constantly sending to Europe,|
07338|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0080.wav|||yet they took an impression of it, and returned it to its owner.|

07340|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0082.wav|||it was recognized that the cameo was genuine, and that it bore the likeness of the great King.|
07341|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0083.wav|||Unfortunately, the little stone seal, perhaps the only one to preserve for us his features, appears to have been lost for ever.|

07373|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0115.wav|||I laid its foundation deep to the water level;|

07384|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0126.wav|||Berossus, a priest of the temple of Bel at Babylon, writing about two fifty B.C.,|

07397|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0140.wav|||The city stands on a broad plain, and is an exact square, a hundred and twenty furlongs in length each way,|
07398|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0141.wav|||so that the entire circuit is four hundred and eighty furlongs.|
07399|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0142.wav|||While such is its size, in magnificence there is no other city that approaches to it.|
07400|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0143.wav|||It is surrounded, in the first place, by a broad and deep moat, full of water, behind which rises a wall|
07401|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0144.wav|||fifty royal cubits in width, and two hundred in height.|
07402|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0145.wav|||And here I may not omit to tell the use to which the mould dug out of the great moat was turned, nor the manner wherein the wall was wrought.|
07403|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0146.wav|||As fast as they dug the moat, the soil which they got from the cutting was made into bricks,|
07404|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0147.wav|||and when a sufficient number were completed they baked the bricks in kilns.|
07405|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0148.wav|||Then they set to building, and began by bricking the borders of the moat, after which they proceeded to construct the wall itself,|
07406|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0149.wav|||using throughout for their cement hot bitumen, and interposing a layer of wattled reeds at every thirtieth course of the bricks.|
07407|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0150.wav|||On the top, along the edges of the wall, they constructed buildings of a single chamber facing one another,|
07408|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0151.wav|||leaving between them room for a four-horse chariot to turn.|
07409|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0152.wav|||In the circuit of the wall are a hundred gates, all of brass, with brazen lintels and sideposts.|
07410|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0153.wav|||The bitumen used in the work was brought to Babylon from Is, a small stream which flows into the Euphrates|
07411|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0154.wav|||at the point where the city of the same name stands, eight days' journey from Babylon.|

07426|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0169.wav|||a square enclosure two furlongs each way, with gates of solid brass; which was also remaining in my time.|

07431|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0174.wav|||Other ancient descriptions of the walls have been left us by Ctesias of the fifth century B.C., and by Strabo of the beginning of the Christian era,|

07435|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ028-0178.wav|||the walls of Babylon were so long and wide and high that all who saw them were amazed.|
