08583|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0106.wav|||end quote. Hidell was a fictitious president of an organization of which Oswald was the only member.|
08584|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0107.wav|||When seeking employment in New Orleans,|
08585|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0108.wav|||Oswald listed a "Sgt. Robert Hidell" as a reference on one job application and "George Hidell" as a reference on another.|
08586|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0109.wav|||Both names were found to be fictitious.|
08587|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0110.wav|||Moreover, the use of "Alek" as a first name for Hidell is a further link to Oswald because "Alek" was Oswald's nickname in Russia.|
08588|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0111.wav|||Letters received by Marina Oswald from her husband signed "Alek" were given to the Commission.|
08589|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0112.wav|||Oswald's Palmprint on Rifle Barrel|
08590|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0113.wav|||Based on the above evidence, the Commission concluded that Oswald purchased the rifle found on the sixth floor of the Depository Building.|
08591|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0114.wav|||Additional evidence of ownership was provided in the form of palmprint identification which indicated that Oswald had possession of the rifle he had purchased.|
08592|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0115.wav|||A few minutes after the rifle was discovered on the sixth floor of the Depository Building|
08593|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0116.wav|||it was examined by Lt. J. C. Day of the identification bureau of the Dallas police.|
08594|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0117.wav|||He lifted the rifle by the wooden stock after his examination convinced him that the wood was too rough to take fingerprints.|
08595|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0118.wav|||Capt. J. W. Fritz then ejected a cartridge by operating the bolt,|
08596|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0119.wav|||but only after Day viewed the knob on the bolt through a magnifying glass and found no prints.|
08597|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0120.wav|||Day continued to examine the rifle with the magnifying glass, looking for possible fingerprints.|
08598|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0121.wav|||He applied fingerprint powder to the side of the metal housing near the trigger, and noticed traces of two prints.|
08599|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0122.wav|||At eleven:forty-five p.m. on November twenty-two,|
08600|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0123.wav|||the rifle was released to the FBI and forwarded to Washington where it was examined on the morning of November twenty-three|
08601|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0124.wav|||by Sebastian F. Latona, supervisor of the Latent Fingerprint Section of the FBI's Identification Division.|
08602|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0125.wav|||In his testimony before the Commission, Latona stated that when he received the rifle, the area where prints were visible was protected by cellophane.|
08603|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0126.wav|||He examined these prints, as well as photographs of them which the Dallas police had made, and concluded that:|
08604|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0127.wav|||the formations, the ridge formations and characteristics, were insufficient for purposes of either effecting identification|
08605|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0128.wav|||or a determination that the print was not identical with the prints of people.|
08606|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0129.wav|||Accordingly, my opinion simply was that the latent prints which were there were of no value, end quote.|
08607|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0130.wav|||Latona then processed the complete weapon but developed no identifiable prints.|
08608|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0131.wav|||He stated that the poor quality of the wood and the metal would cause the rifle to absorb moisture from the skin, thereby making a clear print unlikely.|
08609|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0132.wav|||On November twenty-two, however, before surrendering possession of the rifle to the FBI Laboratory,|
08610|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0133.wav|||Lieutenant Day of the Dallas Police Department had "lifted" a palmprint from the underside of the gun barrel|
08611|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0134.wav|||quote, near the firing end of the barrel about three inches under the woodstock when I took the woodstock loose, end quote,|
08612|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0135.wav|||Lifting a print involves the use of adhesive material to remove the fingerprint powder which adheres to the original print.|
08613|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0136.wav|||In this way the powdered impression is actually removed from the object.|
08614|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0137.wav|||The lifting had been so complete in this case that there was no trace of the print on the rifle itself when it was examined by Latona.|
08615|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0138.wav|||Nor was there any indication that the lift had been performed.|
08616|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0139.wav|||Day, on the other hand, believed that sufficient traces of the print had been left on the rifle barrel,|
08617|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0140.wav|||because he did not release the lifted print until November twenty-six, when he received instructions to send "everything that we had" to the FBI.|
08618|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0141.wav|||The print arrived in the FBI Laboratory in Washington on November twenty-nine, mounted on a card on which Lieutenant Day had written the words|
08619|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0142.wav|||quote, off underside gun barrel near end of grip C two seven six six, end quote,|
08620|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0143.wav|||The print's positive identity as having been lifted from the rifle|
08621|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0144.wav|||was confirmed by FBI Laboratory tests which established that the adhesive material bearing the print|
08622|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0145.wav|||also bore impressions of the same irregularities that appeared on the barrel of the rifle.|
08623|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0146.wav|||Latona testified that this palmprint was the right palmprint of Lee Harvey Oswald.|
08624|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0147.wav|||At the request of the Commission, Arthur Mandella,|
08625|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0148.wav|||fingerprint expert with the New York City Police Department, conducted an independent examination and also determined that this was the right palmprint of Oswald.|
08626|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0149.wav|||Latona's findings were also confirmed by Ronald G. Wittmus, another FBI fingerprint expert.|
08627|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0150.wav|||In the opinion of these experts, it was not possible to estimate the time which elapsed between the placing of the print on the rifle and the date of the lift.|
08628|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0151.wav|||Experts testifying before the Commission agreed that palmprints are as unique as fingerprints for purposes of establishing identification.|
08629|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0152.wav|||Oswald's palmprint on the underside of the barrel demonstrates that he handled the rifle when it was disassembled.|
08630|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0153.wav|||A palmprint could not be placed on this portion of the rifle, when assembled, because the wooden foregrip covers the barrel at this point.|
08631|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0154.wav|||The print is additional proof that the rifle was in Oswald's possession.|
08632|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0155.wav|||Fibers on Rifle|
08633|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0156.wav|||In a crevice between the butt plate of the rifle and the wooden stock|
08634|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0157.wav|||was a tuft of several cotton fibers of dark blue, gray-black, and orange-yellow shades.|
08635|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0158.wav|||On November twenty-three, nineteen sixty-three,|
08636|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0159.wav|||these fibers were examined by Paul M. Stombaugh, a special agent assigned to the Hair and Fiber Unit of the FBI Laboratory.|
08637|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0160.wav|||He compared them with the fibers found in the shirt which Oswald was wearing when arrested in the Texas Theatre.|
08638|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0161.wav|||This shirt was also composed of dark blue, gray- black and orange-yellow cotton fibers.|
08639|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0162.wav|||Stombaugh testified that the colors, shades, and twist of the fibers found in the tuft on the rifle matched those in Oswald's shirt.|
08640|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0163.wav|||Stombaugh explained in his testimony that in fiber analysis, as distinct from fingerprint or firearms identification,|
08641|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0164.wav|||it is not possible to state with scientific certainty that a particular small group of fibers come from a certain piece of clothing|
08642|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0165.wav|||to the exclusion of all others because there are not enough microscopic characteristics present in fibers.|
08643|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0166.wav|||Judgments as to probability will depend on the number and types of matches.|
08644|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0167.wav|||He concluded, quote, There is no doubt in my mind that these fibers could have come from this shirt.|
08645|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0168.wav|||There is no way, however, to eliminate the possibility of the fibers having come from another identical shirt, end quote,|
08646|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0169.wav|||Having considered the probabilities as explained in Stombaugh's testimony,|
08647|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0170.wav|||the Commission has concluded that the fibers in the tuft on the rifle most probably came from the shirt worn by Oswald when he was arrested,|
08648|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0171.wav|||and that this was the same shirt which Oswald wore on the morning of the assassination.|
08649|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0172.wav|||Marina Oswald testified that she thought her husband wore this shirt to work on that day.|
08650|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0173.wav|||The testimony of those who saw him after the assassination was inconclusive about the color of Oswald's shirt,|
08651|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0174.wav|||but Mary Bledsoe, a former landlady of Oswald, saw him on a bus approximately ten minutes after the assassination|
08652|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0175.wav|||and identified the shirt as being the one worn by Oswald primarily because of a distinctive hole in the shirt's right elbow.|
08653|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0176.wav|||Moreover, the bus transfer which he obtained as he left the bus was still in the pocket when he was arrested.|
08654|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0177.wav|||Although Oswald returned to his roominghouse after the assassination and when questioned by the police, claimed to have changed his shirt,|
08655|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0178.wav|||the evidence indicates that he continued wearing the same shirt which he was wearing all morning and which he was still wearing when arrested.|
08656|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0179.wav|||In light of these findings the Commission evaluated the additional testimony of Stombaugh|
08657|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0180.wav|||that the fibers were caught in the crevice of the rifle's butt plate, quote, in the recent past, end quote,|
08658|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0181.wav|||Although Stombaugh was unable to estimate the period of time the fibers were on the rifle he said that the fibers, quote,|
08659|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0182.wav|||were clean, they had good color to them, there was no grease on them and they were not fragmented. They looked as if they had just been picked up, end quote.|
08660|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0183.wav|||The relative freshness of the fibers is strong evidence that they were caught on the rifle on the morning of the assassination or during the preceding evening.|
08661|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0184.wav|||For ten days prior to the eve of the assassination Oswald had not been present at Ruth Paine's house in Irving, Texas, where the rifle was kept.|
08662|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0185.wav|||Moreover, the Commission found no reliable evidence that Oswald used the rifle at any time between September twenty-three,|
08663|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0186.wav|||when it was transported from New Orleans, and November twenty-two, the day of the assassination.|
08664|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0187.wav|||The fact that on the morning of the assassination Oswald was wearing the shirt from which these relatively fresh fibers most probably originated,|
08665|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0188.wav|||provides some evidence that they were placed on the rifle that day|
08666|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0189.wav|||since there was limited, if any, opportunity for Oswald to handle the weapon during the two months prior to November twenty-two.|
08667|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0190.wav|||On the other hand Stombaugh pointed out that fibers might retain their freshness if the rifle had been|
08668|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0191.wav|||quote, put aside, end quote, after catching the fibers.|
08669|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0192.wav|||The rifle used in the assassination probably had been wrapped in a blanket for about eight weeks prior to November twenty-two.|
08670|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0193.wav|||Because the relative freshness of these fibers might be explained by the continuous storage of the rifle in the blanket,|
08671|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0194.wav|||the Commission was unable to reach any firm conclusion as to when the fibers were caught in the rifle.|
08672|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0195.wav|||The Commission was able to conclude, however, that the fibers most probably came from Oswald's shirt.|
08673|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0196.wav|||This adds to the conviction of the Commission that Oswald owned and handled the weapon used in the assassination.|
08674|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0197.wav|||Photograph of Oswald With Rifle|
08675|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0198.wav|||During the period from March two, nineteen sixty-three, to April twenty-four, nineteen sixty-three,|
08676|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0199.wav|||the Oswalds lived on Neely Street in Dallas in a rented house which had a small back yard.|
08677|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0200.wav|||One Sunday, while his wife was hanging diapers, Oswald asked her to take a picture of him holding a rifle, a pistol|
08678|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0201.wav|||and issues of two newspapers later identified as the Worker and the Militant.|
08679|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0202.wav|||Two pictures were taken. The Commission has concluded that the rifle shown in these pictures is the same rifle which was found on the sixth floor of the Depository Building|
08680|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0203.wav|||on November twenty-two, nineteen sixty-three. One of these pictures, Exhibit Number one thirty-three A, shows most of the rifle's configuration.|
08681|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0204.wav|||Special Agent Lyndal L. Shaneyfelt, a photography expert with the FBI,|
08682|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0205.wav|||photographed the rifle used in the assassination, attempting to duplicate the position of the rifle and the lighting in Exhibit Number one thirty-three A.|
08683|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0206.wav|||After comparing the rifle in the simulated photograph with the rifle in Exhibit Number one thirty-three A, Shaneyfelt testified, quote,|
08684|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0207.wav|||I found it to be the same general configuration. All appearances were the same, end quote,|
08685|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0208.wav|||He found, quote, one notch in the stock at this point that appears very faintly in the photograph, end quote.|
08686|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0209.wav|||He stated, however, that while he, quote, found no differences, end quote, between the rifles in the two photographs, he could not make a, quote, positive identification|
08687|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0210.wav|||to the exclusion of all other rifles of the same general configuration, end quote.|
08688|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0211.wav|||The authenticity of these pictures has been established by expert testimony which links the second picture,|
08689|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0212.wav|||Commission Exhibit Number one thirty-three B, to Oswald's Imperial Reflex camera, with which Marina Oswald testified she took the pictures.|
08690|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0213.wav|||The negative of that picture, Commission Exhibit Number one thirty-three B, was found among Oswald's possessions.|
08691|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0214.wav|||Using a recognized technique of determining whether a picture was taken with a particular camera,|
08692|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0215.wav|||Shaneyfelt compared this negative with a negative which he made by taking a new picture with Oswald's camera.|
08693|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0216.wav|||He concluded that the negative of Exhibit Number one thirty-three B was exposed in Oswald's Imperial Reflex camera to the exclusion of all other cameras.|
08694|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0217.wav|||He could not test Exhibit Number one thirty-three A in the same way because the negative was never recovered.|
08695|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0218.wav|||Both pictures, however, have identical backgrounds and lighting and, judging from the shadows, were taken at the same angle.|
08696|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0219.wav|||They are photographs of the same scene.|
08697|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0220.wav|||Since Exhibit Number one thirty-three B was taken with Oswald's camera,|
08698|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0221.wav|||it is reasonably certain that Exhibit Number one thirty-three A was taken by the same camera at the same time, as Marina Oswald testified.|
08699|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0222.wav|||Moreover, Shaneyfelt testified that in his opinion the photographs were not composites of two different photographs|
08700|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0223.wav|||and that Oswald's face had not been superimposed on another body.|
08701|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0224.wav|||One of the photographs taken by Marina Oswald was widely published in newspapers and magazines,|
08702|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0225.wav|||and in many instances the details of these pictures differed from the original, and even from each other, particularly as to the configuration of the rifle.|
08703|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0226.wav|||The Commission sought to determine whether these photographs were touched prior to publication.|
08704|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0227.wav|||Shaneyfelt testified that the published photographs appeared to be based on a copy of the original which the publications had each retouched differently.|
08705|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0228.wav|||Several of the publications furnished the Commission with the prints they had used, or described by correspondence the retouching they had done.|
08706|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0229.wav|||This information enabled the Commission to conclude|
08707|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0230.wav|||that the published pictures were the same as the original except for retouching done by these publications, apparently for the purpose of clarifying the lines of the rifle|
08708|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0231.wav|||and other details in the picture.|
08709|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0232.wav|||The dates surrounding the taking of this picture and the purchase of the rifle|
08710|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0233.wav|||reinforce the belief that the rifle in the photograph is the rifle which Oswald bought from Klein's.|
08711|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0234.wav|||The rifle was shipped from Klein's in Chicago on March twenty, nineteen sixty-three, at a time when the Oswalds were living on Neely Street.|
08712|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0235.wav|||From an examination of one of the photographs, the Commission determined the dates of the issues of the Militant and the Worker which Oswald was holding in his hand.|
08713|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0236.wav|||By checking the actual mailing dates of these issues and the time it usually takes to effect delivery to Dallas,|
08714|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0237.wav|||it was established that the photographs must have been taken sometime after March twenty-seven.|
08715|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0238.wav|||Marina Oswald testified that the photographs were taken on a Sunday about two weeks before the attempted shooting of Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker|
08716|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0239.wav|||on April ten, nineteen sixty-three.|
08717|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0240.wav|||By Sunday, March thirty-one, nineteen sixty-three,|
08718|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0241.wav|||ten days prior to the Walker attempt, Oswald had undoubtedly received the rifle shipped from Chicago on March twenty,|
08719|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0242.wav|||the revolver shipped from Los Angeles on the same date, and the two newspapers which he was holding in the picture.|

08722|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0245.wav|||Moreover, it was the only rifle owned by her husband following his return from the Soviet Union in June nineteen sixty-two.|
08723|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0246.wav|||It had been purchased in March nineteen sixty-three, and taken to New Orleans where Marina Oswald saw it in their rented apartment|
08724|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ032-0247.wav|||during the summer of nineteen sixty-three.|

08889|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0137.wav|||It was not a standard type bag which could be obtained in a store and it was presumably made for a particular purpose.|
08890|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0138.wav|||It was the appropriate size to contain, in disassembled form,|
08891|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0139.wav|||Oswald's Mannlicher-Carcano rifle, serial Number C two seven six six, which was also found on the sixth floor.|

08898|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0146.wav|||Scientific Evidence Linking Rifle and Oswald to Paper Bag|
08899|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0147.wav|||Oswald's fingerprint and palmprint found on bag.|
08900|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0148.wav|||Using a standard chemical method involving silver nitrates|
08901|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0149.wav|||the FBI Laboratory developed a latent palmprint and latent fingerprint on the bag.|
08902|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0150.wav|||Sebastian F. Latona, supervisor of the FBI's Latent Fingerprint Section,|

08904|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0152.wav|||The portion of the palm which was identified was the heel of the right palm, i.e., the area near the wrist, on the little finger side.|
08905|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0153.wav|||These prints were examined independently by Ronald G. Wittmus of the FBI,|
08906|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0154.wav|||and by Arthur Mandella, a fingerprint expert with the New York City Police Department.|
08907|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0155.wav|||Both concluded that the prints were the right palm and left index finger of Lee Oswald. No other identifiable prints were found on the bag.|

08912|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0160.wav|||Materials used to make bag.|
08913|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0161.wav|||On the day of the assassination, the Dallas police obtained a sample of wrapping paper and tape|
08914|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0162.wav|||from the shipping room of the Depository and forwarded it to the FBI Laboratory in Washington.|
08915|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0163.wav|||James C. Cadigan, a questioned-documents expert with the Bureau, compared the samples with the paper and tape in the actual bag.|
08916|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0164.wav|||He testified, quote,|
08917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0165.wav|||In all of the observations and physical tests that I made I found the bag and the paper sample were the same, end quote.|
08918|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0166.wav|||Among other tests, the paper and tape were submitted to fiber analysis and spectrographic examination.|
08919|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0167.wav|||In addition the tape was compared to determine whether the sample tape and the tape on the bag had been taken from the tape dispensing machine at the Depository.|
08920|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0168.wav|||When asked to explain the similarity of characteristics, Cadigan stated, quote, well briefly|
08921|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0169.wav|||it would be the thickness of both the paper and the tape, the color under various lighting conditions of both the paper and the tape,|
08922|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0170.wav|||the width of the tape, the knurled markings on the surface of the fiber, the texture of the fiber, the letting pattern|
08923|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0171.wav|||I found that the paper sack found on the sixth floor and the sample|
08924|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0172.wav|||had the same observable characteristics both under the microscope and all the visual tests that I could conduct.|
08925|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0173.wav|||The papers I also found were similar in fiber composition, therefore, in addition to the visual characteristics,|
08926|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0174.wav|||microscopic and UV (ultra violet) characteristics, end quote.|
08927|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0175.wav|||Mr. Cadigan concluded that the paper and tape from the bag were identical in all respects to the sample paper and tape|
08928|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0176.wav|||taken from the Texas School Book Depository shipping room on November twenty-two, nineteen sixty-three.|
08929|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0177.wav|||On December one, nineteen sixty-three, a replica bag was made from materials found on that date in the shipping room.|
08930|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0178.wav|||This was done as an investigatory aid|
08931|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0179.wav|||since the original bag had been discolored during various laboratory examinations and could not be used for valid identification by witnesses.|
08932|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0180.wav|||Cadigan found that the paper used to make this replica sack had different characteristics from the paper in the original bag.|
08933|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0181.wav|||The science of paper analysis enabled him to distinguish between different rolls of paper even though they were produced by the same manufacturer.|
08934|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0182.wav|||Since the Depository normally used approximately one roll of paper every three working days,|
08935|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0183.wav|||it was not surprising that the replica sack made on December one, nineteen sixty-three,|

08950|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0198.wav|||Despite these matches, however, Stombaugh was unable to render on opinion that the fibers which he found in the bag had probably come from the blanket,|
08951|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0199.wav|||because other types of fibers present in the blanket were not found in the bag.|
08952|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0200.wav|||He concluded, quote,|
08953|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0201.wav|||All I would say here is that it is possible that these fibers could have come from this blanket.|
08954|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0202.wav|||because this blanket is composed of brown and green woolen fibers, brown and green delustered viscose fibers, and brown and green cotton fibers.|

08956|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ033-0204.wav|||So if I found all of these then I would have been able to say these fibers probably had come from this blanket. But since I found so few,|

08971|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0005.wav|||He worked principally on the first and sixth floors of the building, gathering books listed on orders and delivering them to the shipping room on the first floor.|

08986|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0020.wav|||The cartons were forwarded to the FBI in Washington.|
08987|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0021.wav|||Sebastian F. Latona, supervisor of the Latent Fingerprint Section,|
08988|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0022.wav|||testified that twenty identifiable fingerprints and eight palmprints were developed on these cartons.|
08989|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0023.wav|||The carton on the windowsill and the large carton below the window contained no prints which could be identified as being those of Lee Harvey Oswald.|

08991|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0025.wav|||as being the left palmprint and right index fingerprint of Lee Harvey Oswald.|
08992|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0026.wav|||The Commission has considered the possibility that the cartons might have been moved in connection with the work that was being performed on the sixth floor on November twenty-two.|

08999|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0033.wav|||During the afternoon of November twenty-two,|
09000|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0034.wav|||Lieutenant Day of the Dallas police dusted this carton with powder and developed a palmprint on the top edge of the carton on the side nearest the window.|
09001|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0035.wav|||The position of this palmprint on the carton was parallel with the long axis of the box, and at right angles with the short axis;|
09002|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0036.wav|||the bottom of the palm rested on the box.|

09004|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0038.wav|||This print which had been cut out of the box was also forwarded to the FBI and Latona identified it as Oswald's right palmprint.|
09005|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0039.wav|||In Latona's opinion, quote,|
09006|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0040.wav|||not too long, end quote, a time had elapsed between the time that the print was placed on the carton and the time that it had been developed by the Dallas police.|
09007|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0041.wav|||Although Bureau experiments had shown that twenty-four hours was a likely maximum time, Latona stated|
09008|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0042.wav|||that he could only testify with certainty that the print was less than three days old.|
09009|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0043.wav|||The print, therefore, could have been placed on the carton at any time within this period.|
09010|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0044.wav|||The freshness of this print could be estimated only because the Dallas police developed it through the use of powder.|
09011|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0045.wav|||Since cartons absorb perspiration, powder can successfully develop a print on such material only within a limited time.|
09012|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0046.wav|||When the FBI in Washington received the cartons, the remaining prints, including Oswald's on the Rolling Readers carton,|
09013|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0047.wav|||were developed by chemical processes.|
09014|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0048.wav|||The freshness of prints developed in this manner cannot be estimated,|
09015|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0049.wav|||so no conclusions can be drawn as to whether these remaining prints preceded or followed the print developed in Dallas by powder.|
09016|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0050.wav|||Most of the prints were found to have been placed on the cartons by an FBI clerk|
09017|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0051.wav|||and a Dallas police officer after the cartons had been processed with powder by the Dallas Police.|
09018|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0052.wav|||In his independent investigation, Arthur Mandella of the New York City Police Department|
09019|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0053.wav|||reached the same conclusion as Latona that the prints found on the cartons were those of Lee Harvey Oswald.|
09020|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0054.wav|||In addition, Mandella was of the opinion that the print taken from the carton on the floor|
09021|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0055.wav|||was probably made within a day or a day and a half of the examination on November twenty-two.|
09022|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0056.wav|||Another expert with the FBI, Ronald G. Wittmus, conducted a separate examination and also agreed with Latona that the prints were Oswald's.|
09023|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0057.wav|||In evaluating the significance of these fingerprint and palmprint identifications,|
09024|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0058.wav|||the Commission considered the possibility that Oswald handled these cartons as part of his normal duties.|
09025|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0059.wav|||Since other identifiable prints were developed on the cartons, the Commission requested that they be compared with the prints of the twelve warehouse employees|
09026|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0060.wav|||who, like Oswald, might have handled the cartons. They were also compared with the prints of those law enforcement officials who might have handled the cartons.|
09027|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0061.wav|||The results of this investigation are fully discussed in chapter six, page two forty-nine.|
09028|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0062.wav|||Although a person could handle a carton and not leave identifiable prints,|
09029|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0063.wav|||none of these employees except Oswald left identifiable prints on the cartons.|
09030|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0064.wav|||This finding, in addition to the freshness of one of the prints and the presence of Oswald's prints on two of the four cartons and the paper bag|
09031|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0065.wav|||led the Commission to attach some probative value to the fingerprint and palmprint identifications in reaching the conclusion|
09032|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0066.wav|||that Oswald was at the window from which the shots were fired, although the prints do not establish the exact time he was there.|

09034|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0068.wav|||Additional testimony linking Oswald with the point from which the shots were fired|
09035|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0069.wav|||was provided by the testimony of Charles Givens, who was the last known employee to see Oswald inside the building prior to the assassination.|
09036|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0070.wav|||During the morning of November twenty-two, Givens was working with the floor-laying crew in the southwest section of the sixth floor.|
09037|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0071.wav|||At about eleven:forty-five a.m. the floor-laying crew used both elevators to come down from the sixth floor.|

09041|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0075.wav|||He saw Oswald, a clipboard in hand, walking from the southeast corner of the sixth floor toward the elevator.|

09056|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0090.wav|||Eyewitness Identification of Assassin|
09057|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0091.wav|||Howard L. Brennan was an eyewitness to the shooting. As indicated previously the Commission considered his testimony as probative|
09058|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0092.wav|||in reaching the conclusion that the shots came from the sixth floor, southeast corner window of the Depository Building.|
09059|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0093.wav|||Brennan also testified that Lee Harvey Oswald,|
09060|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0094.wav|||whom he viewed in a police lineup on the night of the assassination, was the man he saw fire the shots from the sixth-floor window of the Depository Building.|
09061|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0095.wav|||When the shots were fired, Brennan was in an excellent position to observe anyone in the window. He was sitting on a concrete wall|
09062|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0096.wav|||on the southwest corner of Elm and Houston Streets, looking north at the Depository Building which was directly in front of him.|
09063|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0097.wav|||The window was approximately one hundred twenty feet away.|
09064|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0098.wav|||In the six to eight minute period before the motorcade arrived, Brennan saw a man leave and return to the window, quote, a couple of times, end quote,|

09066|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0100.wav|||this man I saw previously was aiming for his last shot. As it appeared to me he was standing up and resting against the left window sill, end quote.|
09067|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0101.wav|||Brennan saw the man fire the last shot and disappear from the window.|

09069|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0103.wav|||This description most probably led to the radio alert sent to police cars at approximately twelve:forty-five p.m., which described the suspect as white,|
09070|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0104.wav|||slender, weighing about one sixty-five pounds, about five foot ten inches tall, and in his early thirties.|

09089|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0123.wav|||Although Brennan testified that the man in the window was standing when he fired the shots, most probably he was either sitting or kneeling.|
09090|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0124.wav|||The half-open window, the arrangement of the boxes, and the angle of the shots virtually preclude a standing position.|
09091|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0125.wav|||It is understandable, however, for Brennan to have believed that the man with the rifle was standing. A photograph of the building taken seconds after the assassination|

09093|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0127.wav|||Brennan testified that they were standing, which is their apparent position in the photograph.|

09160|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0195.wav|||based on other evidence, to have fired the shots from the window.|

09162|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0197.wav|||who was one of the first witnesses to alert the police to the Depository as the source of the shots, as has been discussed in chapter three.|
09163|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0198.wav|||Euins, who was on the southwest corner of Elm and Houston Streets testified that he could not describe the man he saw in the window.|

09165|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0200.wav|||Shortly after the assassination, Euins signed an affidavit describing the man as "white,"|

09168|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0203.wav|||Euins stated that he could not ascertain the man's race and that the statement in the affidavit was intended to refer only to the white spot on the man's head|

09172|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ034-0207.wav|||Accordingly, Euins' testimony is considered probative as to the source of the shots but is inconclusive as to the identity of the man in the window.|

09196|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0012.wav|||At about this time he heard the first shot.|

09217|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0033.wav|||The stairway is located in the northwest corner of the Depository Building.|
09218|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0034.wav|||The stairs from one floor to the next are "L-shaped," with both legs of the "L" approximately the same length.|
09219|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0035.wav|||Because the stairway itself is enclosed, neither Baker nor Truly could see anything on the second-floor hallway until they reached the landing at the top of the stairs.|
09220|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0036.wav|||On the second-floor landing there is a small open area with a door at the east end.|
09221|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0037.wav|||This door leads into a small vestibule, and another door leads from the vestibule into the second-floor lunchroom.|
09222|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0038.wav|||The lunchroom door is usually open, but the first door is kept shut by a closing mechanism on the door.|
09223|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0039.wav|||This vestibule door is solid except for a small glass window in the upper part of the door.|
09224|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0040.wav|||As Baker reached the second floor, he was about twenty feet from the vestibule door. He intended to continue around to his left toward the stairway going up|

09253|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0069.wav|||Baker placed himself on a motorcycle about two hundred feet from the corner of Elm and Houston Streets where he said he heard the shots.|

09255|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0071.wav|||At a given signal, they reenacted the event. Baker's movements were timed with a stopwatch.|
09256|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0072.wav|||On the first test, the elapsed time between the simulated first shot and Baker's arrival on the second-floor stair landing|
09257|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0073.wav|||was one minute and thirty seconds.|
09258|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0074.wav|||The second test run required one minute and fifteen seconds.|
09259|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0075.wav|||A test was also conducted to determine the time required to walk from the southeast corner of the sixth floor to the second-floor lunchroom by stairway.|
09260|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0076.wav|||Special Agent John Howlett of the Secret Service carried a rifle from the southeast corner of the sixth floor along the east aisle to the northeast corner.|
09261|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0077.wav|||He placed the rifle on the floor near the site where Oswald's rifle was actually found after the shooting.|

09263|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0079.wav|||The first test, run at normal walking pace, required one minute, eighteen seconds;|
09264|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0080.wav|||the second test, at a "fast walk" took one minute, fourteen seconds.|
09265|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0081.wav|||The second test followed immediately after the first.|
09266|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0082.wav|||The only interval was the time necessary to ride in the elevator from the second to the sixth floor and walk back to the southeast corner.|
09267|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0083.wav|||Howlett was not short winded at the end of either test run.|
09268|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0084.wav|||The minimum time required by Baker to park his motorcycle and reach the second-floor lunchroom was within three seconds of the time needed to walk|
09269|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0085.wav|||from the southeast corner of the sixth floor down the stairway to the lunchroom.|
09270|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0086.wav|||The time actually required for Baker and Truly to reach the second floor on November twenty-two was probably longer than in the test runs. For example,|
09271|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0087.wav|||Baker required fifteen seconds after the simulated shot to ride his motorcycle one hundred eighty to two hundred feet,|
09272|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0088.wav|||park it, and run forty-five feet to the building.|

09274|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0090.wav|||possible delayed reaction to the shot, jostling with the crowd of people on the steps and scanning the area along Elm Street and the parkway.|

09278|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0094.wav|||the Commission concluded that Oswald could have fired the shots and still have been present in the second-floor lunchroom when seen by Baker and Truly.|
09279|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0095.wav|||That Oswald descended by stairway from the sixth floor to the second-floor lunchroom|
09280|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0096.wav|||is consistent with the movements of the two elevators, which would have provided the other possible means of descent.|
09281|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0097.wav|||When Truly, accompanied by Baker, ran to the rear of the first floor,|
09282|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0098.wav|||he was certain that both elevators, which occupy the same shaft, were on the fifth floor.|
09283|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0099.wav|||Baker, not realizing that there were two elevators, thought that only one elevator was in the shaft and that it was two or three floors above the second floor.|
09284|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0100.wav|||In the few seconds which elapsed while Baker and Truly ran from the first to the second floor,|
09285|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0101.wav|||neither of these slow elevators could have descended from the fifth to the second floor. Furthermore, no elevator was at the second floor when they arrived there.|
09286|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0102.wav|||Truly and Baker continued up the stairs after the encounter with Oswald in the lunchroom.|
09287|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0103.wav|||There was no elevator on the third or fourth floor.|

09289|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0105.wav|||They took the east elevator to the seventh floor and ran up a stairway to the roof where they searched for several minutes.|
09290|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0106.wav|||Jack Dougherty, an employee working on the fifth floor,|
09291|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0107.wav|||testified that he took the west elevator to the first floor after hearing a noise which sounded like a backfire.|
09292|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0108.wav|||Eddie Piper, the janitor, told Dougherty that the President had been shot,|
09293|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0109.wav|||but in his testimony Piper did not mention either seeing or talking with Dougherty during these moments of excitement.|
09294|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0110.wav|||Both Dougherty and Piper were confused witnesses. They had no exact memory of the events of that afternoon.|
09295|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ035-0111.wav|||Truly was probably correct in stating that the west elevator was on the fifth floor when he looked up the elevator shaft from the first floor.|

09410|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0016.wav|||Lee Harvey Oswald left the building approximately three minutes after the assassination.|
09411|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0017.wav|||He probably walked east on Elm Street for seven blocks to the corner of Elm and Murphy|
09412|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0018.wav|||where he boarded a bus which was heading back in the direction of the Depository Building, on its way to the Oak Cliff section of Dallas.|
09413|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0019.wav|||When Oswald was apprehended, a bus transfer marked for the Lakewood-Marsalis route was found in his shirt pocket.|
09414|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0020.wav|||The transfer was dated "Friday November twenty-two, 'sixty-three" and was punched in two places by the bus driver.|
09415|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0021.wav|||On the basis of this punchmark, which was distinctive to each Dallas driver,|
09416|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0022.wav|||the transfer was conclusively identified as having been issued by Cecil J. McWatters, a busdriver for the Dallas Transit Co.|
09417|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0023.wav|||On the basis of the date and time on the transfer, McWatters was able to testify that the transfer had been issued by him|
09418|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0024.wav|||on a trip which passed a check point at St. Paul and Elm Streets at twelve:thirty-six p.m., November twenty-two, nineteen sixty-three.|
09419|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0025.wav|||McWatters was sure that he left the checkpoint on time|
09420|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0026.wav|||and he estimated that it took him three to four minutes to drive three blocks west from the checkpoint to Field Street,|
09421|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0027.wav|||which he reached at about twelve:forty p.m.|
09422|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0028.wav|||McWatters' recollection is that he issued this transfer to a man who entered his bus just beyond Field Street,|
09423|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0029.wav|||where a man beat on the front door of the bus, boarded it and paid his fare.|
09424|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0030.wav|||About two blocks later, a woman asked to get off to make a one o'clock train at Union Station|

09580|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0186.wav|||Oswald had entered the house in his shirt sleeves, but when he left, he was zipping up a jacket.|
09581|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0187.wav|||Mrs. Roberts saw him a few seconds later standing near the bus stop in front of the house on the east side of Beckley.|

09585|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0191.wav|||he would have reached tenth and Patton shortly after one:fifteen p.m.|

09587|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0193.wav|||Description of Shooting|
09588|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0194.wav|||Patrolman J. D. Tippit joined the Dallas Police Department in July nineteen fifty-two.|
09589|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0195.wav|||He was described by Chief Curry as having the reputation of being "a very fine, dedicated officer."|
09590|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0196.wav|||Tippit patroled district Number seventy-eight in the Oak Cliff area of Dallas during daylight hours.|
09591|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0197.wav|||He drove a police car painted distinctive colors with Number ten prominently displayed on each side.|
09592|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0198.wav|||Tippit rode alone, as only one man was normally assigned to a patrol car in residential areas during daylight shifts.|
09593|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0199.wav|||At about twelve:forty-four p.m. on November twenty-two,|
09594|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0200.wav|||the radio dispatcher on channel one ordered all downtown patrol squads to report to Elm and Houston, code three (emergency).|
09595|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0201.wav|||At twelve:forty-five p.m. the dispatcher ordered Number seventy-eight (Tippit) to, quote, move into central Oak Cliff area, end quote.|
09596|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0202.wav|||At twelve:fifty-four p.m., Tippit reported that he was in the central Oak Cliff area at Lancaster and Eighth.|
09597|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0203.wav|||The dispatcher ordered Tippit to be, quote, at large for any emergency that comes in, end quote.|
09598|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0204.wav|||According to Chief Curry, Tippit was free to patrol the central Oak Cliff area.|
09599|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0205.wav|||Tippit must have heard the description of the suspect wanted for the President's shooting; it was broadcast over channel one at twelve:forty-five p.m.,|
09600|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0206.wav|||again at twelve:forty-eight p.m., and again at twelve:fifty-five p.m.|
09601|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0207.wav|||The suspect was described as a, quote,|
09602|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0208.wav|||white male, approximately thirty, slender build, height five foot ten inches, weight one hundred sixty-five pounds, end quote.|
09603|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0209.wav|||A similar description was given on channel two at twelve:forty-five p.m.|
09604|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0210.wav|||At approximately one:fifteen p.m., Tippit, who was cruising east on tenth Street,|
09605|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0211.wav|||passed the intersection of tenth and Patton, about eight blocks from where he had reported at twelve:fifty-four p.m.|
09606|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0212.wav|||About one hundred feet past the intersection Tippit stopped a man walking east along the south side of Patton.|
09607|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0213.wav|||The man's general description was similar to the one broadcast over the police radio.|
09608|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0214.wav|||Tippit stopped the man and called him to his car.|
09609|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0215.wav|||He approached the car and apparently exchanged words with Tippit through the right front or vent window.|
09610|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0216.wav|||Tippit got out and started to walk around the front of the car|
09611|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0217.wav|||As Tippit reached the left front wheel the man pulled out a revolver and fired several shots.|
09612|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ036-0218.wav|||Four bullets hit Tippit and killed him instantly.|
09613|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0001.wav|||Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.|
09614|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0002.wav|||Chapter four. The Assassin: Part six.|
09615|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0003.wav|||Eyewitnesses|
09616|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0004.wav|||At least twelve persons saw the man with the revolver in the vicinity of the Tippit crime scene at or immediately after the shooting.|
09617|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0005.wav|||By the evening of November twenty-two, five of them had identified Lee Harvey Oswald in police lineups as the man they saw.|
09618|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0006.wav|||A sixth did so the next day.|
09619|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0007.wav|||Three others subsequently identified Oswald from a photograph.|
09620|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0008.wav|||Two witnesses testified that Oswald resembled the man they had seen.|
09621|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0009.wav|||One witness felt he was too distant from the gunman to make a positive identification.|
09622|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0010.wav|||A taxi driver, William Scoggins,|
09623|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0011.wav|||was eating lunch in his cab which was parked on Patton facing the southeast corner of tenth Street and Patton Avenue a few feet to the north.|
09624|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0012.wav|||A police car moving east on tenth at about ten or twelve miles an hour passed in front of his cab.|
09625|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0013.wav|||About one hundred feet from the corner the police car pulled up alongside a man on the sidewalk. This man, dressed in a light-colored jacket, approached the car.|
09626|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0014.wav|||Scoggins lost sight of him behind some shrubbery on the southeast corner lot,|
09627|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0015.wav|||but he saw the policeman leave the car, heard three or four shots, and then saw the policeman fall.|
09628|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0016.wav|||Scoggins hurriedly left his seat and hid behind the cab as the man came back toward the corner with gun in hand.|
09629|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0017.wav|||The man cut across the yard through some bushes, passed within twelve feet of Scoggins, and ran south on Patton.|
09630|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0018.wav|||Scoggins saw him and heard him mutter either "Poor damn cop" or "Poor dumb cop."|
09631|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0019.wav|||The next day Scoggins viewed a lineup of four persons and identified Oswald as the man whom he had seen the day before at tenth and Patton.|
09632|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0020.wav|||In his testimony before the Commission,|
09633|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0021.wav|||Scoggins stated that he thought he had seen a picture of Oswald in the newspapers prior to the lineup identification on Saturday.|
09634|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0022.wav|||He had not seen Oswald on television and had not been shown any photographs of Oswald by the police.|
09635|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0023.wav|||Another witness, Domingo Benavides, was driving a pickup truck west on tenth Street.|
09636|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0024.wav|||As he crossed the intersection a block east of tenth and Patton, he saw a policeman standing by the left door of the police car parked along the south side of tenth.|
09637|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0025.wav|||Benavides saw a man standing at the right side of the parked police car. He then heard three shots and saw the policeman fall to the ground.|
09638|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0026.wav|||By this time the pickup truck was across the street and about twenty-five feet from the police car.|
09639|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0027.wav|||Benavides stopped and waited in the truck until the gunman ran to the corner.|
09640|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0028.wav|||He saw him empty the gun and throw the shells into some bushes on the southeast corner lot.|
09641|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0029.wav|||It was Benavides, using Tippit's car radio, who first reported the killing of Patrolman Tippit at about one:sixteen p.m.:|
09642|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0030.wav|||quote, We've had a shooting out here, end quote,|
09643|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0031.wav|||He found two empty shells in the bushes and gave them to Patrolman J. M. Poe who arrived on the scene shortly after the shooting.|
09644|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0032.wav|||Benavides never saw Oswald after the arrest.|
09645|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0033.wav|||When questioned by police officers on the evening of November twenty-two, Benavides told them that he did not think that he could identify the man who fired the shots.|
09646|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0034.wav|||As a result, they did not take him to the police station.|
09647|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0035.wav|||He testified that the picture of Oswald which he saw later on television bore a resemblance to the man who shot Officer Tippit.|
09648|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0036.wav|||Just prior to the shooting, Mrs. Helen Markham, a waitress in downtown Dallas, was about to cross tenth Street at Patton.|
09649|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0037.wav|||As she waited on the northwest corner of the intersection for traffic to pass, she noticed a young man as he was, quote, almost ready to get up on the curb, end quote.|
09650|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0038.wav|||at the southeast corner of the intersection, approximately fifty feet away.|
09651|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0039.wav|||The man continued along tenth Street. Mrs. Markham saw a police car slowly approach the man from the rear and stop alongside of him.|
09652|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0040.wav|||She saw the man come to the right window of the police car. As he talked, he leaned on the ledge of the right window with his arms.|
09653|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0041.wav|||The man appeared to step back as the policeman, quote, calmly opened the car door, end quote, and very slowly got out and walked toward the front of the car.|
09654|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0042.wav|||The man pulled a gun. Mrs. Markham heard three shots and saw the policeman fall to the ground near the left front wheel.|
09655|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0043.wav|||She raised her hands to her eyes as the man started to walk back toward Patton.|
09656|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0044.wav|||She peered through her fingers, lowered her hands, and saw the man doing something with his gun. Quote,|
09657|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0045.wav|||He was just fooling with it. I didn't know what he was doing. I was afraid he was fixing to kill me. End quote.|
09658|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0046.wav|||The man, quote, in kind of a little trot, end quote, headed down Patton toward Jefferson Boulevard, a block away.|
09659|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0047.wav|||Mrs. Markham then ran to Officer Tippit's side and saw him lying in a pool of blood.|
09660|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0048.wav|||Helen Markham was screaming as she leaned over the body.|
09661|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0049.wav|||A few minutes later she described the gunman to a policeman.|
09662|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0050.wav|||Her description and that of other eyewitnesses led to the police broadcast at one:twenty-two p.m.|
09663|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0051.wav|||describing the slayer as, quote, about thirty, five foot eight inches, black hair, slender, end quote.|
09664|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0052.wav|||At about four:thirty p.m., Mrs. Markham,|
09665|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0053.wav|||who had been greatly upset by her experience, was able to view a lineup of four men handcuffed together at the police station.|
09666|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0054.wav|||She identified Lee Harvey Oswald as the man who shot the policeman.|
09667|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0055.wav|||Detective L. C. Graves, who had been with Mrs. Markham before the lineup|
09668|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0056.wav|||testified that she was, quote, quite hysterical, end quote, and was, quote, crying and upset, end quote.|
09669|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0057.wav|||He said that Mrs. Markham started crying when Oswald walked into the lineup room.|
09670|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0058.wav|||In testimony before the Commission, Mrs. Markham confirmed her positive identification of Lee Harvey Oswald|
09671|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0059.wav|||as the man she saw kill Officer Tippit. In evaluating Mrs. Markham's identification of Oswald, the Commission considered certain allegations|
09672|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0060.wav|||That Mrs. Markham described the man who killed Patrolman Tippit as, quote, short, a little on the heavy side, end quote.|
09673|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0061.wav|||and having, quote, somewhat bushy, end quote, hair.|
09674|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0062.wav|||The Commission reviewed the transcript of a phone conversation in which Mrs. Markham is alleged to have provided such a description.|
09675|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0063.wav|||A review of the complete transcript has satisfied the Commission|
09676|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0064.wav|||that Mrs. Markham strongly reaffirmed her positive identification of Oswald and denied having described the killer|
09677|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0065.wav|||as short, stocky and having bushy hair. She stated that the man weighed about one hundred fifty pounds.|
09678|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0066.wav|||Although she used the words, quote, a little bit bushy, end quote, to describe the gunman's hair,|
09679|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0067.wav|||the transcript establishes that she was referring to the uncombed state of his hair, a description fully supported by a photograph of Oswald|
09680|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0068.wav|||taken at the time of his arrest.|
09681|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0069.wav|||Although in the phone conversation she described the man as, quote, short, end quote, on November twenty-second,|
09682|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0070.wav|||within minutes of the shooting and before the lineup, Mrs. Markham described the man to the police as five foot eight inches tall.|
09683|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0071.wav|||During her testimony Mrs. Markham initially denied that she ever had the above phone conversation.|
09684|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0072.wav|||She has subsequently admitted the existence of the conversation and offered an explanation for her denial.|
09685|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0073.wav|||Addressing itself solely to the probative value of Mrs. Markham's contemporaneous description of the gunman|
09686|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0074.wav|||and her positive identification of Oswald at a police lineup, the Commission considers her testimony reliable.|
09687|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0075.wav|||However, even in the absence of Mrs. Markham's testimony, there is ample evidence to identify Oswald as the killer of Tippit.|
09688|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0076.wav|||Two young women,|
09689|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0077.wav|||Barbara Jeanette Davis and Virginia Davis, were in an apartment of a multiple-unit house on the southeast corner of tenth and Patton|
09690|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0078.wav|||when they heard the sound of gunfire and the screams of Helen Markham.|
09691|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0079.wav|||They ran to the door in time to see a man with a revolver cut across their lawn and disappear around a corner of the house onto Patton.|
09692|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0080.wav|||Barbara Jeanette Davis assumed that he was emptying his gun as, quote, he had it open and was shaking it, end quote. She immediately called the police.|
09693|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0081.wav|||Later in the day each woman found an empty shell on the ground near the house. These two shells were delivered to the police.|
09694|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0082.wav|||On the evening of November twenty-two,|
09695|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0083.wav|||Barbara Jeanette and Virginia Davis viewed a group of four men in a lineup and each one picked Oswald as the man who crossed their lawn while emptying his pistol.|
09696|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0084.wav|||Barbara Jeanette Davis testified that no one had shown her a picture of Oswald before the identification and that she had not seen him on television.|
09697|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0085.wav|||She was not sure whether she had seen his picture in a newspaper on the afternoon or evening of November twenty-two prior to the lineup.|
09698|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0086.wav|||Her reaction when she saw Oswald in the lineup was that, quote,|
09699|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0087.wav|||I was pretty sure it was the same man I saw. When they made him turn sideways, I was positive that was the one I seen, end quote.|
09700|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0088.wav|||Similarly, Virginia Davis had not been shown pictures of anyone prior to the lineup and had not seen either television or the newspapers during the afternoon.|
09701|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0089.wav|||She identified Oswald, who was the Number two man in the lineup, as the man she saw running with the gun:|
09702|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0090.wav|||she testified, quote, I would say that was him for sure, end quote.|
09703|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0091.wav|||Barbara Jeanette Davis and Virginia Davis were sitting alongside each other when they made their positive identifications of Oswald.|
09704|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0092.wav|||Each woman whispered Oswald's number to the detective. Each testified that she was the first to make the identification.|
09705|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0093.wav|||William Arthur Smith was about a block east of tenth and Patton when he heard shots.|
09706|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0094.wav|||He looked west on tenth and saw a man running to the west and a policeman falling to the ground.|
09707|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0095.wav|||Smith failed to make himself known to the police on November twenty-two.|
09708|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0096.wav|||Several days later he reported what he had seen and was questioned by FBI agents.|
09709|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0097.wav|||Smith subsequently told a Commission staff member|
09710|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0098.wav|||that he saw Oswald on television the night of the murder and thought that Oswald was the man he had seen running away from the shooting.|
09711|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0099.wav|||On television Oswald's hair looked blond, whereas Smith remembered that the man who ran away had hair that was brown or brownish black.|
09712|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0100.wav|||Later, the FBI showed Smith a picture of Oswald. In the picture the hair was brown.|
09713|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0101.wav|||According to his testimony, Smith told the FBI, quote, It looked more like him than it did on television, end quote,|
09714|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0102.wav|||He stated further that from, quote, What I saw of him, end quote, the man looked like the man in the picture.|
09715|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0103.wav|||Two other important eyewitnesses to Oswald's flight were Ted Callaway,|
09716|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0104.wav|||manager of a used-car lot on the northeast corner of Patton Avenue and Jefferson Boulevard, and Sam Guinyard, a porter at the lot.|
09717|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0105.wav|||They heard the sound of shots to the north of their lot. Callaway heard five shots, and Guinyard three.|
09718|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0106.wav|||Both ran to the sidewalk on the east side of Patton at a point about a half a block south of tenth.|
09719|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0107.wav|||They saw a man coming south on Patton with a revolver held high in his right hand. According to Callaway, the man crossed to the west side of Patton.|

09757|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0145.wav|||Four cartridge cases were found in the shrubbery on the corner of tenth and Patton by three of the eyewitnesses -- Domingo Benavides,|
09758|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0146.wav|||Barbara Jeanette Davis, and Virginia Davis.|
09759|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0147.wav|||It was the unanimous and unequivocal testimony of expert witnesses before the Commission that these used cartridge cases were fired from the revolver|
09760|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0148.wav|||in Oswald's possession to the exclusion of all other weapons.|
09761|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0149.wav|||Cortlandt Cunningham, of the Firearms Identification Unit of the FBI Laboratory, testified|
09762|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0150.wav|||that he compared the four empty cartridge cases found near the scene of the shooting with a test cartridge fired from the weapon in Oswald's possession when he was arrested.|
09763|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0151.wav|||Cunningham declared that this weapon fired the four cartridges to the exclusion of all other weapons.|
09764|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0152.wav|||Identification was effected through breech face marks and firing pin marks.|

09769|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0157.wav|||taken from Oswald.|
09770|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0158.wav|||He concluded that all of these cartridges were fired from the same weapon.|

09772|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0160.wav|||He explained that the bullets were slightly smaller than the barrel of the pistol which had fired them. This caused the bullets to have an erratic passage through the barrel|
09773|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0161.wav|||and impressed upon the lead of the bullets inconsistent individual characteristics which made identification impossible.|
09774|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0162.wav|||Consecutive bullets fired from the revolver by the FBI experts could not be identified as having been fired from that revolver.|

09777|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0165.wav|||with five lands and grooves and a right twist which were the rifling characteristics of the revolver taken from Oswald.|

09794|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0182.wav|||Ownership of Revolver|
09795|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0183.wav|||By checking certain importers and dealers after the assassination of President Kennedy and slaying of Officer Tippit,|
09796|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0184.wav|||agents of the FBI determined that George Rose and Co. of Los Angeles was a major distributor of this type of revolver.|
09797|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0185.wav|||Records of Seaport Traders, Incorporated, a mail-order division of George Rose and Co.,|
09798|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0186.wav|||disclosed that on January three, nineteen sixty-three,|
09799|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0187.wav|||the company received from Empire Wholesale Sporting Goods, Ltd., Montreal, a shipment of ninety-nine guns in one case.|
09800|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0188.wav|||Among these guns was a thirty-eight Special caliber Smith and Wesson revolver, serial Number V five one zero two one zero,|
09801|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0189.wav|||the only revolver made by Smith and Wesson with this serial number. When first manufactured, it had a five-inch barrel.|
09802|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0190.wav|||George Rose and Co. had the barrel shortened by a gunsmith to two and one quarter inches.|
09803|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0191.wav|||Sometime after January twenty-seven, nineteen sixty-three,|
09804|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0192.wav|||Seaport Traders, Incorporated, received through the mail a mail-order coupon for one, quote, point three-eight|
09805|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0193.wav|||S T. W. two inch BBL, unquote, cost twenty-nine dollars, ninety-five cents.|
09806|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0194.wav|||Ten dollars in cash was enclosed.|

09808|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0196.wav|||A. J. Hidell, aged twenty-eight, end quote. The date of the order was January twenty-seven. No year shown.|

09861|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0249.wav|||Mrs. Earlene Roberts, the housekeeper at Oswald's roominghouse and the last person known to have seen him before he reached tenth Street and Patton Avenue,|

09863|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0251.wav|||It seemed to her that the jacket Oswald wore was darker than Commission Exhibit Number one sixty-two.|
09864|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0252.wav|||Ted Callaway, who saw the gunman moments after the shooting, testified that Commission Exhibit Number one sixty-two|
09865|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0253.wav|||looked like the jacket he was wearing but, quote, I thought it had a little more tan to it, end quote.|

09867|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0255.wav|||testified that Commission Exhibit Number one sixty-two was the jacket worn by the man they saw on November twenty-two.|
09868|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0256.wav|||Mrs. Markham and Barbara Davis thought that the jacket worn by the slayer of Tippit was darker than the jacket found by Westbrook.|
09869|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0257.wav|||Scoggins thought it was lighter.|
09870|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0258.wav|||There is no doubt, however, that Oswald was seen leaving his roominghouse at about one p.m. wearing a zipper jacket,|
09871|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0259.wav|||that the man who killed Tippit was wearing a light-colored jacket,|
09872|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0260.wav|||that he was seen running along Jefferson Boulevard, that a jacket was found under a car in a lot adjoining Jefferson Boulevard|
09873|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0261.wav|||that the jacket belonged to Lee Harvey Oswald, and that when he was arrested at approximately one:fifty p.m., he was in shirt sleeves.|

09875|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0263.wav|||The foregoing evidence establishes that (one) two eyewitnesses who heard the shots and saw the shooting of Dallas Police Patrolman J. D. Tippit|
09876|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0264.wav|||and seven eyewitnesses who saw the flight of the gunman with revolver in hand|
09877|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0265.wav|||positively identified Lee Harvey Oswald as the man they saw fire the shots or flee from the scene,|

09879|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0267.wav|||to the exclusion of all other weapons,|
09880|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ037-0268.wav|||(three) the revolver in Oswald's possession at the time of his arrest was purchased by and belonged to Oswald, and (four)|
