09884|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0003.wav|||Oswald's Arrest|
09885|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0004.wav|||The Texas Theatre is on the north side of Jefferson Boulevard, approximately eight blocks from the scene of the Tippit shooting and six blocks|
09886|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0005.wav|||from where several witnesses last saw Oswald running west on Jefferson Boulevard. Shortly after the Tippit murder,|
09887|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0006.wav|||police sirens sounded along Jefferson Boulevard.|
09888|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0007.wav|||One of the persons who heard the sirens was Johnny Calvin Brewer, manager of Hardy's Shoestore, a few doors east of the Texas Theatre.|
09889|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0008.wav|||Brewer knew from radio broadcasts that the President had been shot and that a patrolman had also been shot in Oak Cliff.|
09890|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0009.wav|||When he heard police sirens, he, quote, looked up and saw the man enter the lobby, end quote.|
09891|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0010.wav|||a recessed area extending about fifteen feet between the sidewalk and the front door of his store.|
09892|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0011.wav|||A police car made a U-turn, and as the sirens grew fainter,|
09893|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0012.wav|||the man in the lobby, quote, looked over his shoulder and turned around and walked up West Jefferson towards the theatre, end quote.|
09894|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0013.wav|||The man wore a T-shirt beneath his outer shirt and he had no jacket.|
09895|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0014.wav|||Brewer said, quote, He just looked funny to me. His hair was sort of messed up and looked like he had been running, and he looked scared, and he looked funny, end quote.|
09896|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0015.wav|||Mrs. Julia Postal, selling tickets at the box office of the Texas Theatre,|
09897|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0016.wav|||heard police sirens and then saw a man as he, quote, ducked into, end quote, the outer lobby space of the theatre near the ticket office.|
09898|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0017.wav|||Attracted by the sound of the sirens, Mrs. Postal stepped out of the box office and walked to the curb.|
09899|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0018.wav|||Shortly thereafter, Johnny Brewer, who had come from the nearby shoestore, asked Mrs. Postal whether the fellow that had ducked in had bought a ticket.|
09900|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0019.wav|||She said, quote, No; by golly, he didn't, end quote, and turned around, but the man was nowhere in sight.|
09901|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0020.wav|||Brewer told Mrs. Postal that he had seen the man ducking into his place of business and that he had followed him to the theatre.|
09902|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0021.wav|||She sent Brewer into the theatre to find the man and check the exits, told him about the assassination, and said, quote,|
09903|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0022.wav|||I don't know if this is the man they want. But he is running from them for some reason, end quote, She then called the police.|
09904|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0023.wav|||At one:forty-five p.m., the police radio stated, quote, Have information a suspect just went in the Texas Theatre on West Jefferson, end quote.|
09905|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0024.wav|||Patrol cars bearing at least fifteen officers converged on the Texas Theatre.|
09906|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0025.wav|||Patrolman M. N. McDonald, with Patrolmen R. Hawkins, T. A. Hutson, and C. T. Walker, entered the theatre from the rear.|
09907|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0026.wav|||Other policemen entered the front door and searched the balcony.|
09908|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0027.wav|||Detective Paul L. Bentley rushed to the balcony and told the projectionist to turn up the house lights.|
09909|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0028.wav|||Brewer met McDonald and the other policemen at the alley exit door,|
09910|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0029.wav|||stepped out onto the stage with them and pointed out the man who had come into the theatre without paying.|
09911|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0030.wav|||The man was Oswald. He was sitting alone in the rear of the main floor of the theatre near the right center aisle.|
09912|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0031.wav|||About six or seven people were seated on the theatre's main floor and an equal number in the balcony.|
09913|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0032.wav|||McDonald first searched two men in the center of the main floor, about ten rows from the front.|
09914|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0033.wav|||He walked out of the row up the right center aisle.|
09915|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0034.wav|||When he reached the row where the suspect was sitting, McDonald stopped abruptly and told the man to get on his feet.|
09916|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0035.wav|||Oswald rose from his seat, bringing up both hands.|
09917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0036.wav|||As McDonald started to search Oswald's waist for a gun, he heard him say, quote, Well, it's all over now, end quote.|
09918|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0037.wav|||Oswald then struck McDonald between the eyes with his left fist; with his right hand he drew a gun from his waist.|
09919|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0038.wav|||McDonald struck back with his right hand and grabbed the gun with his left hand. They both fell into the seats.|
09920|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0039.wav|||Three other officers, moving toward the scuffle, grabbed Oswald from the front, rear and side.|
09921|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0040.wav|||As McDonald fell into the seat with his left hand on the gun, he felt something graze across his hand and heard what sounded like the snap of the hammer.|
09922|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0041.wav|||McDonald felt the pistol scratch his cheek as he wrenched it away from Oswald.|
09923|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0042.wav|||Detective Bob K. Carroll, who was standing beside McDonald, seized the gun from him.|
09924|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0043.wav|||The other officers who helped subdue Oswald corroborated McDonald in his testimony|
09925|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0044.wav|||except that they did not hear Oswald say, quote, It's all over now, end quote.|
09926|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0045.wav|||Deputy Sheriff Eddy R. Walthers recalled such a remark but he did not reach the scene of the struggle|
09927|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0046.wav|||until Oswald had been knocked to the floor by McDonald and the others.|
09928|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0047.wav|||Some of the officers saw Oswald strike McDonald with his fist. Most of them heard a click which they assumed to be a click of the hammer of the revolver.|
09929|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0048.wav|||Testimony of a firearms expert before the Commission established that the hammer of the revolver never touched the shell in the chamber.|
09930|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0049.wav|||Although the witnesses did not hear the sound of a misfire,|
09931|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0050.wav|||they might have heard a snapping noise resulting from the police officer grabbing the cylinder of the revolver and pulling it away from Oswald while he was attempting to pull the trigger.|
09932|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0051.wav|||Two patrons of the theatre and John Brewer|

09936|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0055.wav|||No other theatre patron or officer has testified that Oswald was hit by a gun.|

09958|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0077.wav|||Statements of Oswald during Detention.|
09959|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0078.wav|||Oswald was questioned intermittently for approximately twelve hours between two:thirty p.m., on November twenty-two, and eleven a.m.,|
09960|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0079.wav|||on November twenty-four.|
09961|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0080.wav|||Throughout this interrogation he denied that he had anything to do either with the assassination of President Kennedy or the murder of Patrolman Tippit.|
09962|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0081.wav|||Captain Fritz of the homicide and robbery bureau did most of the questioning, but he kept no notes and there were no stenographic or tape recordings.|
09963|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0082.wav|||Representatives of other law enforcement agencies were also present, including the FBI and the U.S. Secret Service.|
09964|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0083.wav|||They occasionally participated in the questioning.|
09965|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0084.wav|||The reports prepared by those present at these interviews are set forth in appendix eleven.|
09966|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0085.wav|||A full discussion of Oswald's detention and interrogation is presented in chapter five of this report.|
09967|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0086.wav|||During the evening of November twenty-two, the Dallas Police Department performed paraffin tests on Oswald's hands and right cheek|
09968|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0087.wav|||in an apparent effort to determine, by means of a scientific test, whether Oswald had recently fired a weapon.|
09969|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0088.wav|||The results were positive for the hands and negative for the right cheek.|
09970|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0089.wav|||Expert testimony before the Commission|
09971|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0090.wav|||was to the effect that the paraffin test was unreliable in determining whether or not a person has fired a rifle or revolver.|
09972|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0091.wav|||The Commission has, therefore, placed no reliance on the paraffin tests administered by the Dallas police.|
09973|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0092.wav|||Oswald provided little information during his questioning.|
09974|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0093.wav|||Frequently, however, he was confronted with evidence which he could not explain, and he resorted to statements which are known to be lies.|
09975|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0094.wav|||While Oswald's untrue statements during interrogation were not considered items of positive proof|
09976|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0095.wav|||by the Commission, they had probative value in deciding the weight to be given to his denials that he assassinated President Kennedy|
09977|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0096.wav|||and killed Patrolman Tippit. Since independent evidence revealed that Oswald repeatedly and blatantly lied to the police,|
09978|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0097.wav|||the Commission gave little weight to his denials of guilt.|
09979|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0098.wav|||Denial of Rifle Ownership|
09980|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0099.wav|||From the outset, Oswald denied owning a rifle.|
09981|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0100.wav|||On November twenty-three, Fritz confronted Oswald with the evidence that he had purchased a rifle under the fictitious name of "Hidell."|
09982|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0101.wav|||Oswald said that this was not true. Oswald denied that he had a rifle wrapped up in a blanket in the Paine garage.|
09983|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0102.wav|||Oswald also denied owning a rifle and said that since leaving the Marine Corps he had fired only a small bore twenty-two rifle.|
09984|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0103.wav|||On the afternoon of November twenty-three, Officers H. M. Moore,|
09985|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0104.wav|||R. S. Stovall, and G. F. Rose obtained a search warrant and examined Oswald's effects in the Paine garage.|
09986|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0105.wav|||They discovered two photographs, each showing Oswald with a rifle and a pistol.|
09987|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0106.wav|||These photographs were shown to Oswald on the evening of November twenty-three and again on the morning of the twenty-fourth.|
09988|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0107.wav|||According to Fritz, Oswald sneered, saying that they were fake photographs, that he had been photographed a number of times the day before by the police,|
09989|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0108.wav|||that they had superimposed upon the photographs a rifle and a revolver. He told Fritz a number of times that the smaller photograph|
09990|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0109.wav|||was either made from the larger, or the larger photograph was made from the smaller and that at the proper time he would show that the pictures were fakes.|
09991|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0110.wav|||Fritz told him that the two small photographs were found in the Paine garage.|
09992|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0111.wav|||At that point, Oswald refused to answer any further questions.|
09993|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0112.wav|||As previously indicated, Marina Oswald testified that she took the two pictures with her husband's Imperial Reflex camera|
09994|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0113.wav|||when they lived on Neely Street.|
09995|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0114.wav|||Her testimony was fully supported by a photography expert who testified that in his opinion the pictures were not composites.|
09996|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0115.wav|||At the first interrogation, Oswald claimed that his only crime was carrying a gun and resisting arrest.|
09997|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0116.wav|||When Captain Fritz asked him why he carried the revolver, he answered, quote, Well, you know about a pistol. I just carried it, end quote.|
09998|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0117.wav|||He falsely alleged that he bought the revolver in Fort Worth, when in fact he purchased it from a mail-order house in Los Angeles.|
09999|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0118.wav|||The Aliases "Hidell" and "O. H. Lee"|
10000|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0119.wav|||The arresting officers found a forged selective service card with a picture of Oswald and the name "Alek J. Hidell"|
10001|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0120.wav|||in Oswald's billfold. On November twenty-two and twenty-three, Oswald refused to tell Fritz why this card was in his possession,|
10002|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0121.wav|||or to answer any questions concerning the card.|

10045|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0164.wav|||The Attempt on the Life of Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker|
10046|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0165.wav|||At approximately nine p.m., on April ten, nineteen sixty-three, in Dallas, Texas, Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker,|
10047|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0166.wav|||an active and controversial figure on the American political scene since his resignation from the U.S. Army in nineteen sixty-one|
10048|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0167.wav|||narrowly escaped death when a rifle bullet fired from outside his home passed near his head as he was seated at his desk.|
10049|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0168.wav|||There were no eyewitnesses, although a fourteen-year-old boy in a neighboring house claimed that immediately after the shooting|
10050|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0169.wav|||he saw two men, in separate cars, drive out of a church parking lot adjacent to Walker's home. A friend of Walker's testified that|
10051|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0170.wav|||two nights before the shooting he saw, quote, two men around the house peeking in windows, end quote.|
10052|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0171.wav|||General Walker gave this information to the police before the shooting, but it did not help solve the crime.|
10053|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0172.wav|||Although the bullet was recovered from Walker's house, in the absence of a weapon it was of little investigatory value.|
10054|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0173.wav|||General Walker hired two investigators to determine whether a former employee might have been involved in the shooting.|
10055|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0174.wav|||Their results were negative.|
10056|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0175.wav|||Until December three, nineteen sixty-three, the Walker shooting remained unsolved.|
10057|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0176.wav|||The Commission evaluated the following evidence in considering whether Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shot which almost killed General Walker:|
10058|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0177.wav|||A note which Oswald left for his wife on the evening of the shooting,|
10059|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0178.wav|||(two) photographs found among Oswald's possessions after the assassination of President Kennedy,|
10060|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0179.wav|||(three) firearm identification of the bullet found in Walker's home, and (four)|
10061|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0180.wav|||admissions and other statements made to Marina Oswald by Oswald concerning the shooting. Note left by Oswald.|
10062|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0181.wav|||On December two, nineteen sixty-three, Mrs. Ruth Paine turned over to the police some of the Oswalds' belongings,|
10063|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0182.wav|||including a Russian volume entitled, quote, Book of Useful Advice, end quote. In this book was an undated note written in Russian.|
10064|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0183.wav|||In translation, the note read as follows: one.|
10065|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0184.wav|||This is the key to the mailbox which is located in the main post office in the city on Ervay Street.|
10066|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0185.wav|||This is the same street where the drugstore, in which you always waited is located.|
10067|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0186.wav|||You will find the mailbox in the post office which is located four blocks from the drugstore on that street.|
10068|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0187.wav|||I paid for the box last month so don't worry about it.|
10069|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0188.wav|||two. Send the information as to what has happened to me to the Embassy.|
10070|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0189.wav|||and include newspaper clippings (should there be anything about me in the newspapers). I believe that the Embassy will come quickly to your assistance on learning everything.|
10071|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0190.wav|||three. I paid the house rent on the second so don't worry about it. four. Recently I also paid for water and gas.|
10072|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0191.wav|||five. The money from work will possibly be coming. The money will be sent to our post office box. Go to the bank and cash the check.|
10073|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0192.wav|||six. You can either throw out or give my clothing, etc. away. Do not keep these.|
10074|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0193.wav|||However, I prefer that you hold on to my personal papers (military, civil, etc.).|
10075|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0194.wav|||seven. Certain of my documents are in the small blue valise.|
10076|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0197.wav|||ten. I left you as much money as I could,|
10077|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0198.wav|||sixty dollars on the second of the month. You and the baby can live for another two months using ten dollars per week.|
10078|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0199.wav|||eleven. If I am alive and taken prisoner,|
10079|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0200.wav|||the city jail is located at the end of the bridge through which we always passed on going to the city (right in the beginning of the city after crossing the bridge).|
10080|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0201.wav|||James C. Cadigan, FBI handwriting expert, testified that this note was written by Lee Harvey Oswald.|
10081|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0202.wav|||Prior to the Walker shooting on April ten, Oswald had been attending typing classes on Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday evenings.|
10082|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0203.wav|||He had quit these classes at least a week before the shooting, which occurred on a Wednesday night.|

10086|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0207.wav|||When he came back I asked him what had happened. He was very pale.|

10091|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0212.wav|||which appeared to be the work of a man expecting to be killed, or imprisoned, or to disappear.|
10092|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0213.wav|||The last paragraph directed her to the jail|

10094|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0215.wav|||It is clear that the note was written while the Oswalds were living in Dallas before they moved to New Orleans in the spring of nineteen sixty-three.|
10095|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0216.wav|||The references to house rent and payments for water and gas|
10096|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0217.wav|||indicated that the note was written when they were living in a rented apartment; therefore it could not have been written while Marina Oswald was living with the Paines.|

10134|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0255.wav|||Firearms identification.|
10135|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0256.wav|||In the room beyond the one in which General Walker was sitting on the night of the shooting the Dallas police recovered a badly mutilated bullet|
10136|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0257.wav|||which had come to rest on a stack of paper.|

10138|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0259.wav|||The oral report was negative because of the battered condition of the bullet.|

10140|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0261.wav|||the Dallas Police Department forwarded it on December two, nineteen sixty-three.|
10141|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0262.wav|||Robert A. Frazier, an FBI ballistics identification expert, testified that he was, quote, unable to reach a conclusion, end quote,|
10142|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0263.wav|||as to whether or not the bullet recovered from Walker's house had been fired from the rifle found on the sixth floor of the Texas School Book Depository Building.|
10143|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0264.wav|||He concluded that, quote, the general rifling characteristics of the rifle are of the same type as those found on the bullet|
10144|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0265.wav|||and, further, on this basis the bullet could have been fired from the rifle on the basis of its land and groove impressions, end quote.|
10145|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0266.wav|||Frazier testified further that the FBI avoids the category of "probable" identification.|

10147|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ038-0268.wav|||the FBI refuses to draw any conclusion as to probability.|

10241|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0056.wav|||the Commission considered whether Oswald, using his own rifle,|
10242|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0057.wav|||possessed the capability to hit his target with two out of three shots under the conditions described in chapter three.|
10243|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0058.wav|||The Commission evaluated (one) the nature of the shots, (two) Oswald's Marine training in marksmanship,|
10244|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0059.wav|||(three) his experience and practice after leaving the Marine Corps, and (four) the accuracy of the weapon and the quality of the ammunition.|
10245|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0060.wav|||The Nature of the Shots|
10246|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0061.wav|||For a rifleman situated on the sixth floor of the Texas School Book Depository Building|
10247|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0062.wav|||the shots were at a slow-moving target proceeding on a downgrade in virtually a straight line|
10248|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0063.wav|||with the alinement of the assassin's rifle, at a range of one hundred seventy-seven to two hundred sixty-six feet.|
10249|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0064.wav|||An aerial photograph of Dealey Plaza shows that Elm Street runs at an angle|
10250|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0065.wav|||so that the President would have been moving in an almost straight line away from the assassin's rifle.|
10251|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0066.wav|||In addition, the three degree downward slope of Elm Street was of assistance in eliminating at least some of the adjustment|
10252|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0067.wav|||which is ordinarily required when a marksman must raise his rifle as a target moves farther away.|

10254|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0069.wav|||Maj. Eugene D. Anderson, assistant head of the Marksmanship Branch of U.S. Marine Corps|

10258|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0073.wav|||when you shoot at one hundred seventy-five feet or two hundred sixty feet, which is less than a hundred yards, with a telescopic sight,|
10259|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0074.wav|||you should not have any difficulty in hitting your target. I mean it requires no training at all to shoot a weapon with a telescopic sight|
10260|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0075.wav|||once you know that you must put the crosshairs on the target and that is all that is necessary.|

10269|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0084.wav|||you identify it and the crosshairs are in close relationship to the point you want to shoot at,|
10270|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0085.wav|||it just takes a minor move in aiming to bring the crosshairs to bear, and then it is a quick squeeze.|

10283|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0098.wav|||Oswald's Marine Training|
10284|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0099.wav|||In accordance with standard Marine procedures, Oswald received extensive training in marksmanship.|
10285|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0100.wav|||During the first week of an intensive eight-week training period he received instruction in sighting, aiming, and manipulation of the trigger.|
10286|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0101.wav|||He went through a series of exercises called dry firing where he assumed all positions which would later be used in the qualification course.|

10290|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0105.wav|||Following that training, Oswald was tested in December of nineteen fifty-six, and obtained a score of two hundred twelve,|
10291|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0106.wav|||which was two points above the minimum for qualifications as a "sharpshooter" in a scale of marksman, sharpshooter, expert.|
10292|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0107.wav|||In May of nineteen fifty-nine, on another range, Oswald scored one hundred ninety-one, which was one point over the minimum for ranking as a "marksman."|
10293|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0108.wav|||The Marine Corps records maintained on Oswald further show that he had fired and was familiar with the Browning Automatic rifle,|
10294|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0109.wav|||forty-five caliber pistol, and twelve-gauge riot gun.|
10295|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0110.wav|||Based on the general Marine Corps ratings, Lt. Col. A. G. Folsom, Jr.|
10296|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0111.wav|||head, Records Branch, Personnel Department, Headquarters U.S. Marine Corps,|
10297|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0112.wav|||evaluated the sharpshooter qualification as a, quote, fairly good shot, end quote, and a low marksman rating|
10298|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0113.wav|||as a, quote, rather poor shot, end quote.|
10299|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0114.wav|||When asked to explain the different scores achieved by Oswald on the two occasions when he fired for record,|
10300|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0115.wav|||Major Anderson said, quote, when he fired that two twelve|
10301|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0116.wav|||he had just completed a very intensive preliminary training period.|
10302|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0117.wav|||He had the services of an experienced highly trained coach.|
10303|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0118.wav|||He had high motivation. He had presumably a good to excellent rifle and good ammunition.|
10304|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0119.wav|||We have nothing here to show under what conditions the B course was fired. It might well have been a bad day for firing the rifle|
10305|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0120.wav|||windy, rainy, dark. There is little probability that he had good, expert coach,|
10306|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0121.wav|||and he probably didn't have as high a motivation because he was no longer in recruit training and under the care of the drill instructor.|
10307|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0122.wav|||There is some possibility that the rifle he was firing might not have been as good a rifle as the rifle that he was firing in his A course firing,|
10308|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0123.wav|||because he may well have carried this rifle for quite some time, and it got banged around in normal usage.|
10309|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0124.wav|||End quote. Major Anderson concluded, quote, I would say that as compared to other Marines receiving the same type of training,|
10310|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0125.wav|||that Oswald was a good shot, somewhat better than or equal to -- better than the average let us say.|
10311|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0126.wav|||As compared to a civilian who had not received this intensive training, he would be considered as a good to excellent shot. End quote.|
10312|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0127.wav|||When Sergeant Zahm was asked whether Oswald's Marine Corps training would have made it easier to operate a rifle with a four-power scope, he replied, quote,|
10313|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0128.wav|||Based on that training, his basic knowledge in sight manipulation and trigger squeeze and what not, I would say that he would be capable of sighting that rifle in well,|
10314|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0129.wav|||firing it, with ten rounds.|
10315|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0130.wav|||After reviewing Oswald's marksmanship scores,|

10317|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0132.wav|||and as compared to the average male of his age throughout the civilian, throughout the United States, that he is an excellent shot, end quote.|
10318|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0133.wav|||Oswald's Rifle Practice Outside the Marines|
10319|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0134.wav|||During one of his leaves from the Marines, Oswald hunted with his brother Robert,|
10320|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0135.wav|||using a twenty-two caliber bolt-action rifle belonging either to Robert or Robert's in-laws.|
10321|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0136.wav|||After he left the Marines and before departing for Russia, Oswald, his brother, and a third companion went hunting for squirrels and rabbits.|
10322|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0137.wav|||On that occasion Oswald again used a bolt-action twenty-two caliber rifle; and according to Robert,|
10323|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0138.wav|||Lee Oswald exhibited an average amount of proficiency with that weapon.|
10324|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0139.wav|||Oswald obtained a hunting license, joined a hunting club and went hunting about six times, as discussed more fully in chapter six.|
10325|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0140.wav|||Soon after Oswald returned from the Soviet Union|
10326|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0141.wav|||he again went hunting with his brother, Robert, and used a borrowed twenty-two caliber bolt-action rifle.|
10327|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0142.wav|||After Oswald purchased the Mannlicher-Carcano rifle, he told his wife that he practiced with it.|
10328|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0143.wav|||Marina Oswald testified that on one occasion she saw him take the rifle, concealed in a raincoat, from the house on Neely Street.|
10329|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0144.wav|||Oswald told her he was going to practice with it.|
10330|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0145.wav|||According to George De Mohrenschildt, Oswald said that he went target shooting with that rifle.|
10331|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0146.wav|||Marina Oswald testified that in New Orleans in May of nineteen sixty-three, she observed Oswald sitting with the rifle on their screened porch at night,|
10332|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0147.wav|||sighting with the telescopic lens and operating the bolt.|
10333|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0148.wav|||Examination of the cartridge cases found on the sixth floor of the Depository Building|
10334|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0149.wav|||established that they had been previously loaded and ejected from the assassination rifle,|
10335|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0150.wav|||which would indicate that Oswald practiced operating the bolt.|
10336|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0151.wav|||Accuracy of Weapon|
10337|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0152.wav|||It will be recalled from the discussion in chapter three|
10338|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0153.wav|||that the assassin in all probability hit two out of the three shots during the maximum time span of|
10339|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0154.wav|||four point eight to five point six seconds if the second shot missed,|
10340|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0155.wav|||or, if either the first or third shots missed, the assassin fired the three shots during a minimum time span of seven point one|
10341|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0156.wav|||to seven point nine seconds.|
10342|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0157.wav|||A series of tests were performed to determine whether the weapon and ammunition used in the assassination|
10343|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0158.wav|||were capable of firing the shots which were fired by the assassin on November twenty-two, nineteen sixty-three.|
10344|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0159.wav|||The ammunition used by the assassin was manufactured by Western Cartridge Co. of East Alton, Illinois.|
10345|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0160.wav|||In tests with the Mannlicher-Carano C twenty-seven sixty-six rifle, over one hundred rounds of this ammunition were fired by the FBI|
10346|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0161.wav|||and the Infantry Weapons Evaluation Branch of the U.S. Army. There were no misfires.|
10347|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0162.wav|||In an effort to test the rifle under conditions which simulated those which prevailed during the assassination,|
10348|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0163.wav|||the Infantry Weapons Evaluation Branch of the Ballistics Research Laboratory had expert riflemen fire the assassination weapon|
10349|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0164.wav|||from a tower at three silhouette targets at distances of one hundred seventy-five, two hundred forty, and two hundred sixty-five feet.|
10350|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0165.wav|||The target at two hundred sixty-five feet was placed to the right of the two hundred forty-foot target|
10351|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0166.wav|||which was in turn placed to the right of the closest silhouette.|
10352|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0167.wav|||Using the assassination rifle mounted with the telescopic sight, three marksmen, rated as master by the National Rifle Association,|
10353|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0168.wav|||each fired two series of three shots.|
10354|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0169.wav|||In the first series the firers required time spans of four point six, six point seven five,|
10355|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0170.wav|||and eight point two five seconds respectively.|
10356|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0171.wav|||On the second series they required five point one five, six point four five, and seven seconds.|
10357|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0172.wav|||None of the marksmen had any practice with the assassination weapon except for exercising the bolt for two or three minutes on a dry run.|
10358|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0173.wav|||They had not even pulled the trigger because of concern about breaking the firing pin.|
10359|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0174.wav|||The marksmen took as much time as they wanted for the first target and all hit the target.|
10360|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0175.wav|||For the first four attempts, the firers missed the second shot by several inches.|
10361|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0176.wav|||The angle from the first to the second shot|
10362|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0177.wav|||was greater than from the second to the third shot and required a movement in the basic firing position of the marksmen.|
10363|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0178.wav|||This angle was used in the test because the majority of the eyewitnesses to the assassination|
10364|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0179.wav|||stated that there was a shorter interval between shots two and three than between shots one and two.|
10365|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0180.wav|||As has been shown in chapter three, if the three shots were fired within a period of from four point eight to five point six seconds,|
10366|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0181.wav|||the shots would have been evenly spaced and the assassin would not have incurred so sharp an angular movement.|
10367|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0182.wav|||Five of the six shots hit the third target where the angle of movement of the weapon was small.|
10368|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0183.wav|||On the basis of these results, Simmons testified that in his opinion the probability of hitting the targets at the relatively short range at which they were hit|
10369|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0184.wav|||Considering the various probabilities which may have prevailed during the actual assassination,|
10370|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0185.wav|||the highest level of firing performance which would have been required of the assassin and the C two seven six six rifle|
10371|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0186.wav|||would have been to fire three times and hit the target twice within a span of four point eight to five point six seconds.|
10372|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0187.wav|||In fact, one of the firers in the rapid fire test in firing his two series of three shots,|
10373|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0188.wav|||hit the target twice within a span of four point six and five point one five seconds.|
10374|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0189.wav|||The others would have been able to reduce their times if they had been given the opportunity to become familiar with the movement of the bolt and the trigger pull.|
10375|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0190.wav|||Simmons testified that familiarity with the bolt could be achieved in dry practice and, as has been indicated above,|
10376|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0191.wav|||Oswald engaged in such practice. If the assassin missed either the first or third shot,|
10377|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0192.wav|||he had a total of between four point eight and five point six seconds between the two shots which hit|
10378|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0193.wav|||and a total minimum time period of from seven point one to seven point nine seconds for all three shots.|
10379|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0194.wav|||All three of the firers in these tests|
10380|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0195.wav|||were able to fire the rounds within the time period which would have been available to the assassin under those conditions.|
10381|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0196.wav|||Three FBI firearms experts tested the rifle in order to determine the speed with which it could be fired.|
10382|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0197.wav|||The purpose of this experiment was not to test the rifle under conditions which prevailed at the time of the assassination|
10383|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0198.wav|||but to determine the maximum speed at which it could be fired.|
10384|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0199.wav|||The three FBI experts each fired three shots from the weapon at fifteen yards in six, seven, and nine seconds,|
10385|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0200.wav|||and one of these agents, Robert A. Frazier,|
10386|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0201.wav|||fired two series of three shots at twenty-five yards in four point six and four point eight seconds.|
10387|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0202.wav|||At fifteen yards each man's shots landed within the size of a dime.|
10388|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0203.wav|||The shots fired by Frazier at the range of twenty-five yards landed within an area of two inches and five inches respectively.|
10389|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0204.wav|||Frazier later fired four groups of three shots at a distance of one hundred yards in five point nine, six point two,|
10390|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0205.wav|||five point six, and six point five seconds.|
10391|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0206.wav|||Each series of three shots landed within areas ranging in diameter from three to five inches.|
10392|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0207.wav|||Although all of the shots were a few inches high and to the right of the target,|
10393|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0208.wav|||this was because of a defect in the scope which was recognized by the FBI agents and which they could have compensated for if they were aiming to hit a bull's-eye.|
10394|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0209.wav|||They were instead firing to determine how rapidly the weapon could be fired and the area within which three shots could be placed.|
10395|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0210.wav|||Frazier testified that while he could not tell when the defect occurred, but that a person familiar with the weapon could compensate for it.|
10396|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0211.wav|||Moreover, the defect was one which would have assisted the assassin aiming at a target which was moving away.|
10397|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0212.wav|||Frazier said, quote, The fact that the crosshairs are set high would actually compensate for any lead which had to be taken|
10398|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0213.wav|||So that if you aimed with this weapon as it actually was received at the laboratory, it would not be necessary to take any lead whatsoever|
10399|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0214.wav|||in order to hit the intended object. The scope would accomplish the lead for you, end quote,|
10400|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0215.wav|||Frazier added that the scope would cause a slight miss to the right.|
10401|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0216.wav|||It should be noted, however, that the President's car was curving slightly to the right when the third shot was fired.|
10402|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0217.wav|||Based on these tests the experts agreed that the assassination rifle was an accurate weapon.|
10403|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0218.wav|||Simmons described it as, quote, quite accurate, end quote, in fact, as accurate as current military rifles.|
10404|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0219.wav|||Frazier testified that the rifle was accurate, that it had less recoil than the average military rifle|
10405|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0220.wav|||and that one would not have to be an expert marksman to have accomplished the assassination with the weapon which was used.|
10406|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0221.wav|||The various tests showed that the Mannlicher-Carcano was an accurate rifle and that the use of a four-power scope|
10407|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0222.wav|||was a substantial aid to rapid, accurate firing.|
10408|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0223.wav|||Oswald's Marine training in marksmanship, his other rifle experience and his established familiarity with this particular weapon|
10409|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0224.wav|||show that he possessed ample capability to commit the assassination.|
10410|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0225.wav|||Based on the known facts of the assassination,|
10411|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0226.wav|||the Marine marksmanship experts, Major Anderson and Sergeant Zahm, concurred in the opinion that Oswald had the capability to fire three shots,|
10412|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0227.wav|||with two hits, within four point eight and five point six seconds.|
10413|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0228.wav|||Concerning the shots which struck the President in the back of the neck,|
10414|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0229.wav|||Sergeant Zahm testified, quote,|
10415|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0230.wav|||With the equipment he [Oswald] had and with his ability I consider it a very easy shot, end quote.|
10416|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0231.wav|||Having fired this slot|
10417|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0232.wav|||the assassin was then required to hit the target one more time within a space of from four point eight to five point six seconds.|
10418|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0233.wav|||On the basis of Oswald's training and the accuracy of the weapon as established by the tests,|
10419|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0234.wav|||the Commission concluded that Oswald was capable of accomplishing this second hit even if there was an intervening shot which missed.|
10420|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0235.wav|||The probability of hitting the President a second time would have been markedly increased if, in fact, he had missed either the first or third shots|
10421|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0236.wav|||thereby leaving a time span of four point eight to five point six seconds between the two shots which struck their mark.|
10422|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0237.wav|||The Commission agrees with the testimony of Marine marksmanship expert Zahm|
10423|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0238.wav|||that it was an easy shot to hit some part of the President's body, and that the range where the rifleman would be expected to hit|
10424|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0239.wav|||would include the President's head.|
10425|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0240.wav|||On the basis of the evidence reviewed in this chapter, the Commission has found that Lee Harvey Oswald (one)|
10426|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0241.wav|||owned and possessed the rifle used to kill President Kennedy and wound Governor Connally,|
10427|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0242.wav|||(two) brought this rifle into the Depository Building on the morning of the assassination,|
10428|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0243.wav|||(three) was present, at the time of the assassination, at the window from which the shots were fired|
10429|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0244.wav|||killed Dallas Police Officer J. D. Tippit in an apparent attempt to escape,|
10430|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0245.wav|||(five) resisted arrest by drawing a fully loaded pistol and attempting to shoot another police officer,|
10431|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0246.wav|||(six) lied to the police after his arrest concerning important substantive matters,|
10432|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0247.wav|||(seven) attempted, in April nineteen sixty-three, to kill Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, and (eight)|
10433|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ039-0248.wav|||possessed the capability with a rifle which would have enabled him to commit the assassination.|
10434|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0001.wav|||Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.|
10435|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0002.wav|||Chapter seven. Lee Harvey Oswald: Background and Possible Motives, Part one.|
10436|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0003.wav|||The evidence reviewed above identifies Lee Harvey Oswald as the assassin of President Kennedy and indicates that he acted alone in that event.|
10437|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0004.wav|||There is no evidence that he had accomplices or that he was involved in any conspiracy directed to the assassination of the President.|
10438|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0005.wav|||There remains the question of what impelled Oswald to conceive and to carry out the assassination of the President of the United States.|
10439|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0006.wav|||The Commission has considered many possible motives for the assassination, including those which might flow from Oswald's commitment to Marxism or communism,|
10440|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0007.wav|||the existence of some personal grievance,|
10441|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0008.wav|||a desire to effect changes in the structure of society or simply to go down in history as a well publicized assassin.|
10442|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0009.wav|||None of these possibilities satisfactorily explains Oswald's act if it is judged by the standards of reasonable men.|
10443|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0010.wav|||The motives of any man, however, must be analyzed in terms of the character and state of mind of the particular individual involved.|
10444|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0011.wav|||For a motive that appears incomprehensible to other men may be the moving force of a man whose view of the world has been twisted,|
10445|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0012.wav|||possibly by factors of which those around him were only dimly aware.|
10446|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0013.wav|||Oswald's complete state of mind and character are now outside of the power of man to know.|
10447|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0014.wav|||He cannot, of course, be questioned or observed by those charged with the responsibility for this report or by experts on their behalf.|
10448|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0015.wav|||There is, however, a large amount of material available in his writings|
10449|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0016.wav|||and in the history of his life which does give some insight into his character and, possibly, into the motives for his act.|
10450|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0017.wav|||Since Oswald is dead,|
10451|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0018.wav|||the Commission is not able to reach any definite conclusions as to whether or not he was, quote, sane, unquote, under prevailing legal standards.|
10452|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0019.wav|||Under our system of justice no forum could properly make that determination unless Oswald were before it.|
10453|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0020.wav|||It certainly could not be made by this Commission which, as has been pointed out above,|
10454|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0021.wav|||ascertained the facts surrounding the assassination but did not draw conclusions concerning Oswald's legal guilt.|
10455|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0022.wav|||Indications of Oswald's motivation|
10456|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0023.wav|||may be obtained from a study of the events, relationships and influences which appear to have been significant in shaping his character and in guiding him.|
10457|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0024.wav|||Perhaps the most outstanding conclusion of such a study is that Oswald was profoundly alienated from the world in which he lived.|
10458|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0025.wav|||His life was characterized by isolation, frustration, and failure.|
10459|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0026.wav|||He had very few, if any, close relationships with other people and he appeared to have great difficulty in finding a meaningful place in the world.|
10460|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0027.wav|||He was never satisfied with anything.|
10461|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0028.wav|||When he was in the United States he resented the capitalist system which he thought was exploiting him and others like him.|
10462|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0029.wav|||He seemed to prefer the Soviet Union and he spoke highly of Cuba.|
10463|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0030.wav|||When he was in the Soviet Union, he apparently resented the Communist Party members,|
10464|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0031.wav|||who were accorded special privileges and who he thought were betraying communism, and he spoke well of the United States.|
10465|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0032.wav|||He accused his wife of preferring others to himself and told her to return to the Soviet Union without him but without a divorce.|
10466|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0033.wav|||At the same time he professed his love for her and said that he could not get along without her.|
10467|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0034.wav|||Marina Oswald thought that he would not be happy anywhere, quote, Only on the moon, perhaps, end quote.|
10468|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0035.wav|||While Oswald appeared to most of those who knew him as a meek and harmless person, he sometimes imagined himself as, quote, the Commander, end quote,|
10469|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0036.wav|||and, apparently seriously, as a political prophet -- a man who said that after twenty years he would be prime minister.|
10470|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0037.wav|||His wife testified that he compared himself with great readers of history.|
10471|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0038.wav|||Such ideas of grandeur were apparently accompanied by notions of oppression.|
10472|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0039.wav|||He had a great hostility toward his environment, whatever it happened to be,|
10473|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0040.wav|||which he expressed in striking and sometimes violent acts long before the assassination.|
10474|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0041.wav|||There was some quality about him that led him to act with an apparent disregard for possible consequences.|
10475|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0042.wav|||He defected to the Soviet Union, shot at General Walker, tried to go to Cuba and even contemplated hijacking an airplane to get there.|
10476|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0043.wav|||He assassinated the President, shot Officer Tippit, resisted arrest and tried to kill another policeman in the process.|
10477|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0044.wav|||Oswald apparently started reading about communism when he was about fifteen.|
10478|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0045.wav|||In the Marines, he evidenced a strong conviction as to the correctness of Marxist doctrine,|
10479|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0046.wav|||which one associate described as, quote, irrevocable, end quote, but also as, quote, theoretical, end quote,|
10480|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0047.wav|||That associate did not think that Oswald was a Communist.|
10481|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0048.wav|||Oswald did not always distinguish between Marxism and communism.|
10482|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0049.wav|||He stated several times that he was a Communist but apparently never joined any Communist Party.|
10483|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0050.wav|||His attachment to Marxist and Communist doctrine was probably, in some measure, an expression of his hostility to his environment.|
10484|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0051.wav|||While there is doubt about how fully Oswald understood the doctrine which he so often espoused, it seems clear|
10485|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0052.wav|||that his commitment to Marxism was an important factor influencing his conduct during his adult years.|
10486|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0053.wav|||It was an obvious element in his decision to go to Russia and later to Cuba and it probably influenced his decision to shoot at General Walker.|
10487|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0054.wav|||It was a factor which contributed to his character and thereby might have influenced his decision to assassinate President Kennedy.|
10488|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0055.wav|||The discussion below will describe the events known to the Commission which most clearly reveals the formation and nature of Oswald's character.|
10489|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0056.wav|||It will attempt to summarize the events of his early life, his experience in New York City and in the Marine Corps, and his interest in Marxism.|
10490|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0057.wav|||It will examine his defection to the Soviet Union in nineteen fifty-nine, his subsequent return to the United States and his life here|
10491|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0058.wav|||after June of nineteen sixty-two.|
10492|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0059.wav|||The review of the latter period will evaluate his personal and employment relations, his attempt to kill General Walker, his political activities,|
10493|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0060.wav|||and his unsuccessful attempt to go to Cuba in late September of nineteen sixty-three.|

10495|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0062.wav|||The Early Years|
10496|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0063.wav|||Significant in shaping the character of Lee Harvey Oswald was the death of his father, a collector of insurance premiums.|
10497|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0064.wav|||This occurred two months before Lee was born in New Orleans on October eighteen, nineteen thirty-nine.|
10498|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0065.wav|||That death strained the financial fortunes of the remainder of the Oswald family.|
10499|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0066.wav|||It had its effect on Lee's mother, Marguerite, his brother Robert, who had been born in nineteen thirty-four,|
10500|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0067.wav|||and his half-brother John Pic, who had been born in nineteen thirty-two during Marguerite's previous marriage.|
10501|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0068.wav|||It forced Marguerite Oswald to go to work to provide for her family.|
10502|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0069.wav|||Reminding her sons that they were orphans and that the family's financial condition was poor,|
10503|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0070.wav|||she placed John Pic and Robert Oswald in an orphans' home.|
10504|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0071.wav|||From the time Marguerite Oswald returned to work until December twenty-six, nineteen forty-two, when Lee too was sent to the orphans' home,|
10505|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0072.wav|||he was cared for principally by his mother's sister, by babysitters and by his mother, when she had time for him.|
10506|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0073.wav|||Marguerite Oswald withdrew Lee from the orphans' home and took him with her to Dallas when he was a little over four years old.|
10507|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0074.wav|||About six months later she also withdrew John Pic and Robert Oswald.|
10508|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0075.wav|||Apparently that action was taken in anticipation of her marriage to Edwin A. Ekdahl, which took place in May of nineteen forty-five.|
10509|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0076.wav|||In the fall of that year John Pic and Robert Oswald went to a military academy|
10510|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0077.wav|||where they stayed, except for vacations, until the spring of nineteen forty-eight.|
10511|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0078.wav|||Lee Oswald remained with his mother and Ekdahl, to whom he became quite attached.|
10512|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0079.wav|||John Pic testified that he thought Lee found in Ekdahl the father that he never had.|
10513|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0080.wav|||That situation, however, was short-lived,|
10514|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0081.wav|||for the relations between Marguerite Oswald and Ekdahl were stormy and they were finally divorced, after several separations and reunions,|
10515|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0082.wav|||in the summer of nineteen forty-eight.|
10516|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0083.wav|||After the divorce Mrs. Oswald complained considerably about how unfairly she was treated,|
10517|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0084.wav|||dwelling on the fact that she was a widow with three children.|
10518|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0085.wav|||John Pic, however, did not think her position was worse than that of many other people.|
10519|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0086.wav|||In the fall of nineteen forty-eight she told John Pic and Robert Oswald|
10520|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0087.wav|||that she could not afford to send them back to the military school and she asked Pic to quit school entirely to help support the family.|
10521|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0088.wav|||which he did for four months in the fall of nineteen forty-eight.|
10522|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0089.wav|||In order to supplement their income further she falsely swore that Pic was seventeen years old so that he could join the Marine Corps Reserves.|
10523|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0090.wav|||Pic did turn over part of his income to his mother,|
10524|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0091.wav|||but he returned to high school in January of nineteen forty-nine, where he stayed until three days before he was scheduled to graduate,|
10525|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0092.wav|||when he left school in order to get into the Coast Guard. Since his mother did not approve of his decision to continue school|
10526|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0093.wav|||he accepted the responsibility for that decision himself and signed his mother's name to all his own excuses and report cards.|
10527|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0094.wav|||Pic thought that his mother overstated her financial problems and was unduly concerned about money.|
10528|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0095.wav|||Referring to the period after the divorce from Ekdahl, which was apparently caused in part by Marguerite's desire to get more money from him,|
10529|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0096.wav|||Pic said, quote,|
10530|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0097.wav|||Lee was brought up in this atmosphere of constant money problems, and I am sure it had quite an effect on him, and also Robert, end quote.|
10531|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0098.wav|||Marguerite Oswald worked in miscellaneous jobs after her divorce from Ekdahl.|
10532|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0099.wav|||When she worked for a time as an insurance saleslady,|
10533|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0100.wav|||she would sometimes take Lee with her, apparently leaving him alone in the car while she transacted her business.|
10534|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0101.wav|||When she worked during the school year, Lee had to leave an empty house in the morning,|
10535|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0102.wav|||return to it for lunch and then again at night, his mother having trained him to do that rather than to play with other children.|
10536|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0103.wav|||An indication of the nature of Lee's character at this time was provided in the spring of nineteen fifty,|
10537|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0104.wav|||when he was sent to New Orleans to visit the family of his mother's sister, Mrs. Lillian Murret, for two or three weeks.|

10541|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0108.wav|||which became more significant as the children grew older.|

10549|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0116.wav|||who was becoming quite a disciplinary problem for his mother, having struck her on at least one occasion.|

10551|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0118.wav|||and threatened to use it on Mrs. Pic.|

10553|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0120.wav|||Lee refused to discuss the matter with Pic, whom he had previously idolized, and their relations were strained thereafter.|
10554|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0121.wav|||On September thirty, nineteen fifty-two, Lee enrolled in P.S. one seventeen|
10555|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0122.wav|||a junior high school in the Bronx, where the other children apparently teased him because of his, quote, western clothes and Texas accent.|
10556|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0123.wav|||He began to stay away from school, preferring to read magazines and watch television at home by himself.|
10557|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0124.wav|||This continued despite the efforts of the school authorities and, to a lesser extent, of his mother to have him return to school.|
10558|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0125.wav|||Truancy charges were brought against him alleging that he was, quote, beyond the control of his mother insofar as school attendance is concerned, end quote.|
10559|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0126.wav|||Oswald was remanded for psychiatric observation to Youth House, an institution in which children are kept for psychiatric observation|
10560|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0127.wav|||or for detention pending court appearance or commitment to a child-caring or custodial institution such as a training school.|
10561|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0128.wav|||He was in Youth House from April sixteen to May seven, nineteen fifty-three,|
10562|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0129.wav|||during which time he was examined by its Chief Psychiatrist, Dr. Renatus Hartogs,|
10563|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0130.wav|||and interviewed and observed by other members of the Youth House staff.|
10564|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0131.wav|||Marguerite Oswald visited her son at Youth House, where she recalled that she waited in line, quote,|
10565|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0132.wav|||with Puerto Ricans and Negroes and everything, end quote.|
10566|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0133.wav|||She said that her pocketbook was searched, quote, because the children in this home were such criminals, dope fiends, and had been in criminal offenses,|
10567|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0134.wav|||that anybody entering this home had to be searched in case the parents were bringing cigarettes or narcotics or anything, end quote.|
10568|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0135.wav|||She recalled that Lee cried and said, quote, Mother, I want to get out of here.|
10569|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0136.wav|||There are children in here who have killed people, and smoke. I want to get out, end quote,|
10570|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0137.wav|||Marguerite Oswald said that she had not realized until then in what kind of place her son had been confined.|
10571|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0138.wav|||On the other hand, Lee told his probation officer, John Carro, that, quote,|
10572|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0139.wav|||while he liked Youth House, he missed the freedom of doing what he wanted. He indicated that he did not miss his mother, end quote.|
10573|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0140.wav|||Mrs. Evelyn D Siegel, a social worker who interviewed both Lee and his mother while Lee was confined in Youth House,|
10574|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0141.wav|||reported that Lee, quote, confided that the worse thing about Youth House was the fact that he had to be with other boys all the time,|
10575|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0142.wav|||was disturbed about disrobing in front of them, taking showers with them etc., end quote.|
10576|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0143.wav|||Contrary to reports that appeared after the assassination, the psychiatric examination did not indicate that Lee Oswald was a potential assassin,|
10577|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0144.wav|||potentially dangerous, that, quote, his outlook on life had strongly paranoid overtones, end quote, or that he should be institutionalized.|
10578|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0145.wav|||Dr. Hartogs did find Oswald to be a tense, withdrawn, and evasive boy who intensely disliked talking about himself and his feelings.|
10579|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0146.wav|||He noted that Lee liked to give the impression that he did not care for other people but preferred to keep to himself,|
10580|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ040-0147.wav|||so that he was not bothered and did not have to make the effort of communicating.|

10745|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ041-0072.wav|||that he was a man of great ability and intelligence and that many of his superiors in the Marine Corps were not sufficiently competent to give him orders.|
10746|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ041-0073.wav|||While Oswald did not seem to object to authority in the abstract, he did think that he should be the one to exercise it.|
10747|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ041-0074.wav|||John E. Donovan, one of his former officers, testified that Oswald thought, quote,|
10748|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ041-0075.wav|||that authority, particularly the Marine Corps, ought to be able to recognize talent such as his own, without a given magic college degree,|
10749|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ041-0076.wav|||and put them in positions of prominence, end quote. Oswald manifested this feeling about authority by baiting his officers.|
10750|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ041-0077.wav|||He led them into discussions of foreign affairs about which they often knew less than he did, since he had apparently devoted considerable time to a study of such matters.|
10751|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ041-0078.wav|||When the officers were unable to discuss foreign affairs satisfactorily with him, Oswald regarded them as unfit to exercise command over him.|

10755|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ041-0082.wav|||in an attempt to attract attention to himself and to support his exaggerated idea of his own abilities.|

11829|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0029.wav|||It is unlikely that measures can be devised to eliminate entirely the multitude of diverse dangers that may arise,|

11837|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0037.wav|||The nature of the protective assignment.|
11838|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0038.wav|||The President is Head of State, Chief Executive, Commander in Chief, and leader of a political party.|
11839|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0039.wav|||As the ceremonial head of the Government the President must discharge a wide range of public duties, not only in Washington but throughout the land.|

11842|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0042.wav|||As Chief Executive, the President controls the exercise of the vast, almost incalculable powers of the executive branch of the Federal Government.|

11845|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0045.wav|||it is the President's right and duty to be the active leader of his party, as when he seeks to be reelected or to maintain his party in power.|

11917|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0117.wav|||is to collect, process, and evaluate information about persons or groups who may be a danger to the President.|

12014|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0214.wav|||members of his immediate family, the President-Elect, and the Vice-President is within the exclusive jurisdiction of the U.S. Secret Service.|
12015|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ046-0215.wav|||Any information indicating the possibility of an attempt against the person or safety of the President,|

12178|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ047-0124.wav|||and if we determined that the course of the investigation required us to clarify or face him down with this information, we would do it at the appropriate time.|

12264|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ047-0210.wav|||I think all of those, if we had them all together,|

12266|english|english|LJSpeech-1.1/wavs/LJ047-0212.wav|||would have seemed somewhat serious to us, even though I must admit, that none of these in themselves would be|
